text: PART 1 Quinn buried her head in her hands and looked at the clock that stood watch over the room. She’d heard complaints from classmates and online reviewers that time moved backwards in Professor McHugh’s classes, but she hadn’t known just how literal they were meant to be taken. Against the laws of physics and the rule of common sense, there were still twenty-five minutes left of class.  To her credit, Quinn had tried her hardest to listen all semester. She slipped in and out of her haze just enough to catch scattered phrases like "implicit differentiation", "parametric coordinate system", and "MacLaurin series", which so far had kept her from failing the course. Today, however, the tug of last night’s restlessness combined with the temperate beauty that was this Friday afternoon were too strong for Quinn. She knew allowing her mind to wander would only make the class go by more slowly, but she was beyond helping herself.  She looked at the students around her. From the back row, it was easy to see who was asleep, who was listening, and who was waging the war of attention in their mind.

It was a record-setting day for the zone-out crowd, thought Quinn. Most students fidgeted, or stared off into the distance, or drew absentmindedly in their notebooks. Professor McHugh, sixty-five or so, author of over one hundred papers, internationally renowned for his research, dutifully continued his droning to the mindless husks that were his students.  Quinn thought back to her elementary school days, when she and her old friends would pass notes around during particularly boring classes. Wouldn’t that be a great way to kill time now? She scanned the room, and wondered what she would write, if she could be that young again.  She studied the back of the other students’ heads. It amazed her how little she knew about the rest of them. Quinn made the decision three years ago to commute to college despite the fact that almost every one of her classmates was residential. She hadn’t wanted to be too far from her family– or, what was left of it– even if it meant she would forgo the college experience she had heard so much about from her insufferable high school guidance counselor.  She could put a few names to faces in that room, but not many. Soon enough, she wondered not about what she would write on the hypothetical note, but who she would pass it to.

Of course, there was always the boy with the ripped jeans to her left. Throughout the course of the semester she had caught him glancing in her direction a few times, but they hadn’t spoken. For a brief moment, she thought about how best to mess with his mind. What would he do if she slipped him the note and it was blank? What if it was a picture of McHugh? Or a fake address? Rolling her eyes at herself, she dismissed the idea and resumed her daydreaming.  Mercifully, time forged a deal with reality and agreed to move forward.  Quinn felt as though she’d just awoken from a long nap when she stood up to grab her bookbag. She would have loved to enjoy the autumn sun on the quad and read, or saunter through the campus garden and take the long way home, as she often did. But she could not afford to do any of that today. As Quinn followed the boy with the ripped jeans out of the math building, she felt the fresh air tease what the rest of the day would bring. Outwardly, her younger sister Maeve was modest, shy, even shyer than Quinn had been at her age. Somehow, their father had convinced Maeve to perform at her high school’s fall talent show, in spite of the fact that she was just a freshman. Quinn had always been impressed by Maeve’s natural propensity to be good at things– school, music, understanding people. Whenever her sister gathered the courage to show off, Quinn wanted to be there to see it. She crossed the parking lot and entered her car. Three warning lights on the dashboard greeted her. Every time she started her Impala, she swore she’d quit her job at the mini-golf course and find something else, anything else, that paid better. She wanted nothing more than to push the old piece of crap into a deep river. That, or to clean it out, and pay thousands of dollars for the repairs it so sorely needed.

The more she thought about it, the more the river option appealed to her.  The traffic was slow for a Friday afternoon. Quinn jammed a CD into her old car’s disc slot and rubbed her temples. The twenty-minute drive home became thirty by way of red lights and indecisive day-drivers. Her eyes began to glaze over, aggravation building under crusted daydream sowed by the somnambulant Professor McHugh.  But as Quinn at last turned onto the high school’s street, she saw a squirrel out of the corner of her eye, sitting exactly where her tires were about to make contact with the road.  Her heart leapt, and she swerved to the right. No telltale thump. While she had avoided disaster, she scolded herself. She would have been better off hoping the squirrel moved and avoiding the risk of flipping her car.

But before Quinn’s heart even had a chance to decelerate, she saw something else, this time out of her rearview mirror– an ambulance, sirens full boar, screaming down the main road. She pulled to the side and let it pass, her eyes trained on the blinking lights, red, white, yellow, as it sped ahead.  A thought raised the hairs on the back of her neck. God, please don’t go where it looks like you’re going. But it took the right turn she intended to take herself, skidded to a halt beside the main entrance, and coughed out a half dozen paramedics. Maeve’s high school was under siege by vest-wearing first responders with frazzled hair and wide eyes.  Quinn, stopped a few hundred feet from the scene, watched as drivers in front of her put on their hazard lights and hurried after the ambulance on foot. Some were younger than her, but many must have been at least her grandparents’ age. They all ran, to the best of their ability. The spectacle took the feeling from Quinn’s hands. She followed the others. The day was a handful of degrees too warm for running. A thin film of sweat formed just below her hair as she cut across pavement and pushed past others. The air itself, usually put in motion by the neverending flow of traffic, stagnant now, was reluctant to enter her lungs.

She had just reached the school’s large, grassy front lawn when swaths of teenagers began to flood out of the main entrance. Some were frantically in discussion with one another, some joked around, but most were quiet. Parents who had parked their cars on the shoulder of the road gathered in front of Quinn and muttered anxiously, scanning the tops of the adolescents’ heads. A few teachers led the students out, shouting instructions and taking counts.  Police sirens were not far behind. Three fortified cars pushed through the chaos and stopped next to the ambulance. Rows of officers, wearing helmets and bulletproof vests, strode into the school with weapons trained forward. Quinn, arching and angling her body to watch, found herself in battle against a wave of vertigo. The arrival of the police officers had caused a shift in the students’ demeanor. Many, beginning to sense the gravity of the situation, shouted and ran in every direction. Quinn searched for any hope that something harmless had happened. Maybe someone pulled a prank. Maybe a talent show warmup had gone wrong, and everyone was going to be fine. But there was a tangible gravity emanating from the school, a sickening pulse that needed to be escaped from. Everyone looked for someone else. Children called for parents, lovers called for boyfriends and girlfriends, believers cried for God.  Students continued to spill out of the building. Fillmore High wasn’t large– Quinn had graduated from there a few years ago with a class of around 150– but that day, thousands and millions ran across that grassy lot.

The early autumn sun bore down on Quinn. Around her, scores of loved ones reunited. Countless more waited for their chance to do so, stuck on the road behind cars that were no more than driverless shells. Fuck them, she needed to find Maeve. She pressed forward. She looked to the left. "Maeve?" A small child, in an embrace with his mother.  "Maeve?" An errant shoulder to the sternum. She coughed, and turned around.  To her right, two friends whispered in hushed tones. She nestled into a gap between two adults and attempted to address them.

"Do you guys know Maeve Harper?" she asked, her words a register above where they should have been.  They shook their heads. Their faces were blank. One of the boys, wearing a baggy t-shirt and standing five feet tall, spoke, his words aimed less at Quinn and more at the space around him. "Miss Lacey said someone got shot." Quinn’s heart dropped.

The crowd was growing thicker. Officers shouted for order, herded students off the grass and away from the school, but it seemed to make no difference. Any soul misfortunate enough to lose their balance among the shoving and the movement would not have lasted long.  "Maeve!"  She was yelling, jostling, eyes wide open, scanning the faces of the mourners. Why couldn’t she find her?  "Maeve!"

She had fought all the way through to the school’s entrance, and still she couldn’t find her sister.  She climbed up onto a balcony next to a middle-aged man who was shouting on his cell phone. It should be so easy to find her from here, she thought, scanning the tops of heads through brimming tears. And though she tried to push the idea out of her mind, she was right. No one in the history of Fillmore High had redder hair than the Harper sisters.  Quinn climbed down from the balcony. Behind her, the school was empty, save for the officers and paramedics. Should she try the ambulance? No, she thought. She has to be on the field, somewhere.  But just as Quinn prepared to wedge herself back into the crowd, she saw motion in her peripheral vision. A group of five or six students and a teacher exited the high school through a side entrance. Last in that group was Maeve.

Quinn sobbed and ran to her sister.  "I’m going to get you home, okay? We need to go home."  Quinn wrapped her arms around a ghost.  Maeve was stock still and completely mute. Quinn pulled out of the embrace and grabbed her hand. Maeve’s pupils were dilated, her face was pale. She dragged her feet as Quinn sped her around the congregation on the lawn to her hastily parked car.

As she sat in the driver’s seat, she felt her phone buzz in her pocket. She had already missed four calls from her mother, and this was attempt five. With shaking hands and heaving breaths, she answered.  "Mom?" "QUINN! Honey, where are you?" She was hysterical. Quinn was still dizzy. She spoke as slowly as she could.

"I’m here. I found Maeve. She’s in the car with me." Crying, laughter. Quinn cast a glance at her sister and felt sick.  "Can I talk to her?" Quinn pursed her lips and asked Maeve a question that did not need asking.
"She doesn’t want to talk right now." "Ok, ok. Just bring her home." "To Dad’s?" "Yes. We’ll meet you there. I love you."

It was evident that they would not move for some time. Cars, stacked in tight rows, some occupied and some empty, lined the road two, three across. Quinn, completely unsure of what Maeve had seen, decided it would be best to let her sister say something when she was ready. The result was nearly an hour of silence. Quinn watched as wave after wave of emergency response vehicles arrived on scene, mainly for the purpose of thinning the crowd from the lawn. Gradually, they found success, and all that remained were a mismatched group of adults and children, who walked around the lot aimlessly, and asked the officers questions, and refused to leave. Quinn stole glances at her sister. Her eyes didn’t change; her face didn’t change. The vehicle ahead of them snaked through an opening. It was their turn to go. There would be five more minutes of emptiness. When they arrived home, they had to park behind both her mother’s and her father’s cars in the driveway. Although her mother had promised they would both be there, it was still jarring for Quinn to see their vehicles together. Her parents had divorced five years ago, an acrid affair, one that had limited them to speaking once a month, if that frequently. For a brief moment, Quinn was twelve years old again, flatly refusing to step out of Jenny’s minivan the morning after a sleepover.  She snapped out of it quickly, though. She had to leave the car, the crowd, the scene behind. She threw her door open and led her sister across granite steps toward their father’s house.  Even before they entered, Quinn heard something remarkably familiar, in spite of the passing of time. Her mother and her father were in a shouting match.

Quinn, cursing her parents’ incessant fighting, rested her hand on the doorknob. She held her breath and waited a moment before entering her home. The shouting, indecipherable from outside, was a piercing wall of noise to the ears of the exasperated girls.  "Steven, she’s our little girl! How can you live with yourself?"  "Anna, we’ve talked about this!"  "Well, how could I have known about the school? When were you going to tell me?"

"Anna, please! You know what the stakes are." Quinn and Maeve stepped around the corner into the living room. Their mother, otherwise very mild, stood nose-to-nose with their father, who towered some eight inches over her. And although Mrs. Harper looked utterly disheveled– eyes red-rimmed, hair frazzled– she imposed herself upon her husband admirably.  Their father, slim, dark-haired, sharp, still in his button-down shirt and work pants, had lost his patience with her. The kids could not see his face, but it appeared as though their parents had been fighting for a while.  Their mother caught Maeve’s eye just as she was about to shout again. Instantly, she changed. She ran toward her youngest daughter and pulled her into a tight embrace.

"Oh, Maeve, honey…"  Anna could not suppress heavy, shaking sobs. Even now, her sister was under the spell of stoicism.  Steven turned to the three women and his gaze softened. Every time Quinn saw him, he looked older. As his wife and daughter hugged, he addressed Quinn, and spoke to her.  "Quinnie May," he said, suddenly smiling, and pulling her into an embrace of his own. "You’re a hero, you know. I love you, and I always will."

Still shaken, Quinn hugged him back. This type of sentimentality from her father was rare, even for a day such as this one. Initially ready to scold him for his yelling, her voice cracked. "I love you too, dad." Anna released her grip on Maeve and approached Quinn. Impossibly, Anna’s crying grew even more frantic as she hugged her oldest daughter. Quinn tried to console her, but found her eyes wandering to her father and her sister.  Steven had taken a knee in front of Maeve. He spoke to her quietly, but even if he hadn’t, she wouldn’t have been able to decipher his words over the wails of her mother. Maeve listened to him for a while, and nodded her head.

Anna released Quinn and began to breathe again. She studied her husband, and he studied her. Quinn thought it unmistakable that some psychic piece of information passed between the two at that moment. Steven put his arm on Maeve’s back and stood up. Wordlessly, emotionlessly, he led her out of the living room and across the hall, retracing her and Quinn’s steps, heading back outside. Quinn turned to her mother and spoke in a whisper. "Where are they going?"  Anna shook her head.

The front door slammed shut. Something was wrong. Where were they going, and now of all times? And so abruptly? And why couldn’t she know? Quinn drew the curtains and watched through the front window as her father led her sister into his car.   "Where are they going?" she repeated. Her mother had positioned herself behind Quinn, and stared outside as well. But again, she did not offer her daughter a single word in response.  The engine started outside. She was going to have to ask her father herself. Before she could even take a step in the direction of the front door, however, an ice cold hand latched on to her arm. Mouth open, heart pounding, she turned to her mother, who only shook her head.

Anna had learned to live with little– little means, little living space, little dignity– in the years following her divorce. What that had taught her was how to get by with little. Quinn was twenty-one, tallish, certainly less than a world-class athlete, but in decent shape, for her age. She should have been able to pull free of her mother’s grasp and run to her father’s car in plenty of time to ask him her question. But the lean years had given Anna a strength– a strength of body, a strength of reason, a strength of persuasiveness– that she employed every bit of to keep her daughter in check. Quinn looked into her mother’s eyes and began to doubt herself. She was probably not thinking clearly. Maybe Maeve had asked for a private ride with her dad, or maybe he was taking her to the police station, or to a counseling center. Quinn sat down on the couch and faced her mother, who was trying to be so strong for her.  The car backed out of the driveway. ./.

(Really Part One) Quinn ran her fingers over colored boxes and bags, scanning each row of the pantry with careful eyes. Nothing on the floor. Perhaps they were on the shelf, behind something. She stuck out her arm to reach behind a stack of cans. One wobbled, fell onto its side, and rolled, stopping precariously short of the rest of the stack. "Looking for something, honey?" asked her mother, from the living room.

Quinn froze.  "No. Yeah. I’ll find it." As gingerly as she could, she snaked her arm free from the maze of beans and corn and stacked boxes of rice. She then stood on her tiptoes to see what was hidden at the top layer.  A-ha. Behind a sack of potatoes, which had begun to sprout tiny, wriggling roots.

Quinn collected two bottles of water and shut the pantry door.  "I just bought water the other day. There are cold ones in the fridge," said her mother, as Quinn climbed the stairs. "These are fine," she responded, without breaking stride. Her room was straight across the hall. She stepped inside and tossed one of the bottles at her guest.

He caught it with one hand, unscrewed the cap, and emptied the entire thing without taking a single breath. "Jesus, Ty," said Quinn, twisting her own open. "What?" he said, wiping his mouth. "That was disgusting."

"I mean, I asked for water. I needed water." "You should have told me before you were dying of thirst." He shrugged, and looked back down at his notebook. "Did you get… negative e to the x squared for number seven?" he asked.

"Yeah. I was looking at that one. But I do not remember what I did to get that answer." "See, I… was having the same problem as you." They both poured over their notebooks for several silent minutes. Finally, Ty lit up. "You can’t tell me you don’t remember this," said Ty, in poor impression of the cackling voice of their wicked professor, Dr. Edgerrington. "The chain rule! This is basic Calculus, Quinn. I mean, how have you even gotten this far?"

Quinn sighed. "I don’t know, professor. Maybe if some of my fellow classmates would start staring at you and stop staring at other fellow classmates, those hypothetical classmates would be less distracted." Ty turned beet red, which only made Quinn smirk.  "Dude, I’m just messing with you. I suck at calculus. I didn’t even know what the integration symbol meant until winter break." "You don’t suck at calculus, Q. You just don’t pay attention. Which, um… I guess I can relate."

She took a sip of her water. It was dusty, like the rest of the pantry.  "We should figure this question out. The goal’s not going to achieve itself." The goal, an idea they had hatched at the start of the semester, was for them both to earn C’s in Calculus III. It had started as a joke, but morphed into a rallying cry whenever one of them began to feel lost or overwhelmed. They would whisper it to one another in class at intervals and text each other about it while they were doing their homework. It was dumb, but Quinn knew it helped. The two classmates sat on her bed and continued their work. While Quinn’s room was ordinarily very neat, they had strewn stapled review packets, torn loose leaf pages, and old, tattooed textbooks across the bedsheets and carpet. Although it was almost eight o’clock, the mid-March sun had not yet fully set, and golden light poured in from the window.

Quinn and Ty had been in the room for most of the afternoon. Though the goal kept them from ever deviating too far from their studying, they allowed themselves to wonder what life might be like after their graduation in a few months’ time. "I can’t stay here a minute longer. I’ll be off the stage and into my car. I don’t even know where the hell I’ll go," said Ty.  Quinn raised her eyebrows. "Yeah? I can get behind that. No destination, and what, thirty-two dollars in your pocket? Sounds good to me." "Come on. Tell me you don’t feel the same way."

Quinn sighed. "Sure, but I think your idea is pretty reckless. Maybe even self-destructive." "Optimistic," Ty said. "The word you were looking for was ‘optimistic’." Quinn chuckled. Then, Ty asked her the question she was hoping not to hear.  "Well, what are you doing after you get off that stage?"
Quinn paused. She opened her mouth to speak, but before she did, Ty cut her off.  "You don’t know either."  "I’ve been applying for stuff, it’s just… no one’s gotten back to me." "Like…where?"
She shrugged.  "Different places." "Different places?" She nodded.

"That’s a pretty reckless plan, if you ask me," he said. "I’d call it optimistic." replied Quinn, weakly. In reality, Quinn had been feeling less optimistic than ever about life after college. Before classes, she would overhear students talking about jobs they had lined up, or cities that they would move to, or even families that they planned to start. She couldn’t seem to bring herself to think that far ahead.  For now, though, the task at hand was tomorrow’s end-of-week quiz. The two classmates managed to familiarize themselves somewhat with the material, and by the time the last of the natural light had vanished, they decided that they would be able to at least understand their upcoming assessment.

"Alright, Ty," said Quinn, standing up, arching her back. "This has been fun. I can’t wait to see your smiling face tomorrow morning." Ty pulled out his phone, checked the time, and did the same. "Oh. Yeah! Tomorrow. I just can’t wait."  They picked through the mess they made to gather their notes, and walked down the stairs together. Quinn’s mother sat on the living room couch, just where she had been earlier in the evening, staring sleepily at the television.  "Have a good night, Mrs. Harper," Ty said quickly.

"Thanks, Tyler," she responded, keeping her eyes trained forward. "And good luck tomorrow. All that studying you guys have done; you should ace it." He laughed awkwardly.  Quinn stepped in. "See you tomorrow, Ty." He cast a final look at her and hurried through the front door. As soon as it closed, her mother spoke again.

"You know, he can always stay the night if he wants. You guys aren’t sixteen anymore." Quinn took a breath and walked back upstairs. Her mother turned her attention back to the television.  ./. Quinn had been struggling to find respite in sleep.

After the incident, the first few hours bled into the first few days in one unyielding storm of anxiety and uncertainty. She called and texted her sister with every free moment she had. Though her mother assured her that Maeve would be out of commission for some time, Quinn’s unanswered calls, placed first with hope and later by habit, piled up by the dozens.  Quinn found her trust in her parents fading quickly. In between calls, she hounded her mother for information. Every time, the answer was the same. "Quinnie, please, trust them. They’ll be back." Or, "They can handle themselves." Or, "You know your father wouldn’t do anything to hurt her." But Quinn thought her mother was trying just as hard to convince herself of her words as she was trying to convince her.  Quinn didn’t leave the house that weekend, and she didn’t go to school the next Monday. She spent those days harassing her mother for information, calling her father, calling Maeve, and watching the news for information.  The dead student was named Jason Bellemare. He was a senior who had run away from his home in Pennsylvania last year. He was shot with a silenced pistol in a closet near the music wing of the high school. Another loud noise alerted nearby teachers, the school began lockdown processes, and eventually every other student was reunited with their family.

There was one other body in that closet– that of the primary suspect. He was an older, unidentified man, with no known prior relationship to the deceased. Oddly enough, security cameras never showed him entering the school, no witnesses stepped forward, and no other suspects or enemies were identified. Seemingly the only person who authorities believed could have had any connection to the case was the school’s principal, Edna Mills. Though she’d stepped into the role just last year following the surprise resignation of the former principal, she had quickly become well-liked by students and faculty. The poor woman endured days of questioning, but swore up and down she thought her school was safe and that she had no knowledge of any potential killer. Though she was never charged with anything, she resigned less than a week after the shooting.  Quinn found the news coverage hard to stomach. Jason’s friends talked about how kind he was, and how much he had overcome. Apparently, his original living situation had been less than ideal, and he was fortunate to have an uncle in New Jersey who would take him in. His uncle. Oh, how he wept. He struggled to get through his interview. "You couldn’t have known what his life was like," he said. "And I was just thinking he’d left it all behind him." That night, Quinn had had enough. She looked at her mother and said, "If you don’t tell me where they are by tomorrow morning, I will call the police."

Her mother responded in a small, fearful voice. "Just do it now." The house was filled with officers, looking for anything left behind by Steven or Maeve. Their home, which had always felt small, was positively claustrophobic. The night sky seemed to weigh upon the rooms like the footsteps of the policemen on the creaky floorboards. Once the officers had spent some time looking around, they called Quinn upstairs into her own room for questioning. Already off-put by the presence of the two large, male officers in her room, she found it difficult to recount exactly what happened that day.  "I… saw her come out of the side entrance," she said.

One of the officers wrote something down on his pad. The other continued to talk to her. "And then?" "We drove home. We were stuck on the road for a while, but… she never said anything to me. She didn’t even cry." "Well, she was probably in shock, Miss Harper. What happened when you two got home?" The argument. She thought about how exhausted her mother looked. What had they said?

"We walked in, and our parents were… were talking. Then they hugged us, my dad told me he loved me, and he… and Maeve…" "They drove off?"  The ice cold hand. Quinn was going after them, but her mother stopped her.  "Yes, sir."

The other officer finished writing on his pad and looked up. The interrogating officer sighed and spoke.  "Well, I can’t say I have much reason to believe anything unlawful has happened, Miss Harper. We can send out an amber alert and look for plates, but your dad is your sister’s guardian. There’s only so much we can do. Have either of them ever mentioned the idea of anything like this? Anywhere they would go if they got the chance?" Quinn took a breath. "No, nothing like that." After a few more minutes of rather unhelpful questions, the officers sent Quinn back downstairs, and called her mother up. Quinn sat on the living room couch and waited. It hit her for the first time, for real. Her father had run off with Maeve and completely shut off contact with the rest of his family. She just hoped they were alright.

Her mother came down fifteen minutes later. The police left shortly after that, promising to call them immediately with anything that they found. Quinn did not say anything to her mother. Quinn did not sleep that night, either.  Days passed. Eventually, the story of the rogue father and the kidnapped daughter made its way to the local news. Quinn had to start going back to school, but she didn’t understand a word said in her classes. The eyes of her classmates poked, prodded, pushed. Did they know what had happened? Did they think it was all some hoax for popularity? Did they feel sorry for her?  The only reason she passed her classes that winter was because of a kind, if slightly creepy, classmate sitting next to her. Quinn would never forget the first thing she ever said to him, on the morning of the Calc II final. "If you let me copy your answers, I’ll talk to you for ten minutes after class." Ty jumped when he heard her speak. "Uh, okay. I just…don’t really know what I’m doing."

He was right about that, too. They earned matching 68’s on the final.    Quinn, walking back up the stairs, listened to Ty’s engine grow quieter as he made his way down the street. She stopped at the landing and thought about the last six months. She often did when she passed Maeve’s room. It was spotlessly clean, as it always was, and as inviting as if Maeve herself would be back tomorrow.

Sometimes Quinn would sit down in her room and reminisce silently for hours. Sometimes, she would lay on Maeve’s bed and cry, if she could manage it. Some nights, she tried to pretend the whole section of the house wasn’t there. But tonight, her eye was drawn to the acoustic guitar perched on the stand next to Maeve’s dresser.  It was a real beauty of an instrument. It was made of mahogany wood, much deeper than most other guitars she’d seen. The fact that its strings were getting old and its fretboard was dusty seemed only to add character to it.  Quinn grabbed it and sat down on her bed. She remembered how effortlessly her sister, who was primarily a cellist, navigated the fretboard. Before she left, she spent some time trying to teach Quinn how to play.  Quinn’s favorite was the A chord. That was easy to play, and it was the one she always remembered. She plucked the strings one by one, the stagnant harmony ringing in her ears.

She tried to maneuver her fingers into position for a F chord. Quinn had always laughed when she tried to play this one. Human fingers can’t possibly bend like that, she said. In mock frustration, she’d tell her sister that she was going to quit. Then, Maeve would grab her hands, reposition her fumbling fingers, and like magic, the chord would emerge.  For a moment, holding that instrument, Quinn felt close to Maeve. It was a feeling she struggled to grasp and one she was terrified of losing. Beneath this fleeting feeling, and with each passing day, and week, and month, she felt more and more resigned to the fact that she was never coming back.  Quinn returned the guitar to its stand and left the room. She climbed into her own bed and looked out of her window, into the night. She had to fall asleep soon, and wake up seemingly even sooner. Her quiz wouldn’t wait for her.  Nothing would.

./. "Come on, Q. The triple integrals were the easiest part!" said Tyler, pushing open the creaky front door of the academic building. "Yeah, yeah. I messed that up. But I actually think I got everything else." It was a beautiful spring day. Wispy clouds covered the sun, and a light breeze neutralized the temperature, unusually hot for March. Perhaps making the day even brighter was the fact that the quiz was over, and both Ty and Quinn had done surprisingly well.

"And who do you have to thank for that?" asked Ty, expectantly.  Quinn rolled her eyes at him. He had been so shy, so very recently. She could still see it sometimes. But when the two of them talked together, he was a completely different person. "Both of us. You know what, mostly me. We were at my house." "Using my notes! And expertise!"

Quinn shook her head. It hadn’t been this nice outside in months. The winters’ snow, which had turned dreary shades of gray and then black as it melted, had finally run off into sewers or evaporated into the sky. Orchids and peonies and daisies, threatening to bloom into their traditional spring colors, lined the narrow walkway on both sides. Quinn was no artist, but she found herself wishing she could keep this moment for herself in a sketchbook.  They walked for a time in silent reverence toward the softening of nature.  It was Ty who broke that silence.

"Hey, Quinn." They had just crossed the quad, and entered the half-full parking lot. Quinn could see her hideous Impala from where she stood. "Yeah?" "Do you have to go home right now? We could, uh, sit at one of those benches and study. I mean, that quiz went really well today, and–"

"Tyler. It’s Friday afternoon. Calculus doesn’t exist for three more days." "I don’t know. It’s nice out. We don’t have to study." Quinn took a slow breath. It was true that on a day like this, she would often sit outside on campus and enjoy a moment of solitude. But with Ty?  "Alright. I can’t stay too long, though."

They turned around and found an unoccupied bench near the library. As Quinn sat, she watched groups of students move from class to class. Some talked far too loud, some ran, and some seemed completely oblivious to the world around them, buried in their phones. But everyone had a destination. Every time Quinn sat and watched people go by, she could not escape the thought.  There was just so much motion in the world.  She was pulled out of her reverie by a shift in the weight of the old wooden bench. Ty had sat down, and she saw him in motion, too. His energy had changed on a dime.  His right foot bounced, and his eyes darted from student to student. Quinn went up and down with each motion of his leg. Suddenly she was on a violent, if undersized, see-saw, and it was not long before her hair fell in front of her face. When she brushed it back, he stopped and scratched a sudden itch on the back of his neck.
"Sorry," he mumbled. After a few seconds of suddenly uncomfortable silence, Ty spoke.  "Um… it is nice out today, isn’t it?" "Yeah…it is."

"You know…I really should thank you for having me over last night. I don’t think I would have gotten any work done otherwise." He was delaying the inevitable. She readied herself for it.  "Don’t mention it. Any excuse to put someone in between me and my mom? I’ll take it." He laughed, too quickly. He’d heard the joke, but he hadn’t listened to it.

"Anyway…whatever. I need to tell you something, if you’ll hear me out." Quinn jumped in. "I’ll listen, but I need to tell you something first." At this point, both students were sitting on that bench, on a beautiful Friday in spring, feeling absolutely sick to their stomachs. Quinn felt a buzz in her left side pocket, but ignored it and started to speak.  "You, Tyler Morrisey, are the only friend I have made in nearly four years at this hellscape. And what I am about to tell you stays between us, at least for now. Do you understand?"

He nodded. He focused every ounce of his attention on Quinn. That stupid buzzing continued in her pocket. She clicked her phone off to stop it and slowly went on.  "I wasn’t…really…raised…"  She stopped and shut her eyes. She had thought about this moment for some time now. In fact, she had been thinking about it long before her college days started. She’d never imagined it would be so hard. She felt like she was watching herself fumble with her words from above.  And that buzzing! It was back. Angrily, she apologized to Tyler, and pulled out the stupid phone.

As she pinched the buttons that would turn it off completely, she glanced at the screen. Below the two calls she’d just hung up on was a long text from the same number. Quinn got spam calls and texts all the time, but they never seemed to be this persistent– or this urgent. Quinn narrowed her eyes and read the contents of the text message.    Quinn,

You are needed at the following address: 827 FAIRVIEW RD, ALLENSBURG, CO 80121 There is a guest waiting for you. You need to be there by Monday. Do NOT alert any authorities. I ask that you don’t fly, either. If you want to see her again, you’ll need to leave tomorrow morning.

Quinn’s face, already pink from the conversation on the park bench, went red. Her heart thumped against her ribcage.  Tyler was quick to notice that something had happened.  "Hey, is everything alright, Q?"

Quinn stood up. The world spun around her. Who was this? Who could possibly be playing this sick joke on her? "I need to leave," she said distantly. Without another moment’s hesitation, she started to walk towards the car. She didn’t hear Ty call out to her as she made her way back across the quad and into the parking lot. In fact, the whole world faded into colors, devoid of meaning, devoid of permanence. All that there was, and all that there would be, was that text message. She opened her car door and sat down. Through unsteady breaths, she gripped the wheel as tightly as she could. She tried to close her eyes, but she couldn’t escape the visual of the words "guest waiting for you", in unsettlingly polite lettering. The words stared back at her just as intensely as she stared at them.

With trembling fingers and uncertain eyes, she called the number back. The phone rang for hours. Nothing. She cursed and tried again and waited and waited and waited. Still nothing.  Quinn nearly forgot to put the car in reverse as she backed out of her parking spot.  She cut the twenty-minute drive home to a harrowing twelve-minute rollercoaster ride. Horns honked, dirty looks were thrown, curbs were hit. And by the time she pulled into her driveway, Quinn had completely forgotten about them all.  Her initial instinct, upon seeing the message, was to see her mother. If the message was legitimate, and if anyone had a clue about its origins, it would have had to be her.

But as Quinn skidded to a stop on the shoulder of the road in front of her house, she saw no car in the driveway. Quinn had thought it might be beneficial for her mother to move out of the dingy apartment she’d lived in ever since the divorce. It had been a long, arduous process, with court dates and fancy clothes and relatives who couldn’t stand to look at one another. Although Quinn was sixteen then, and mired in the chaos and uncertainty of her own adolescent life, she could not resist exploring the dark energy that fueled the divorce proceedings. Many nights, she would stay awake well past midnight, listening to indecipherable arguing from other rooms, the words just outside the threshold of her hearing. She would wonder what life would be like with her dad, or what it would be like with her mom, or what it would be like to be separated from Maeve. She tried to gather as much information as she could, in court, at home, at night, to pick a side, to root for one outcome over the other. But she never could. The more she tried to understand, the more it seemed as though they split simply because that was who they had become. Inevitably, she wondered what ultimately caused the dam to burst. She hadn’t ever seen a physical alteration, though perhaps it was not outside the realm of possibility that something of the sort had happened. They did spar verbally often, but Quinn had thought that to be normal. What was it, then? Was it him? Was it her?  Was it me?

Ultimately, her mother seemed to take the entire process much harder than her father. The court ruled that most of their shared assets would belong to Steven, and Anna was so fed up with him and with the law that she moved in with her sister in New Hampshire. Before Anna left, both she and Steven had sat Quinn down and explained their version of events. Her mother, tearful and tired, promised her it wasn’t her fault, things had just spoiled between her and Dad, she’d still be around to give Quinn anything she needed, she just needed some space. Her father had said the same thing, hugged her, and returned to work before his lunch break was over.  Anna had found meager work as a substitute elementary school teacher and made almost no money. Quinn had made the trip north a handful of times since she received her drivers’ license, but there was almost no room to breathe. The apartment, the town, all of it– claustrophobic. But she never had seen her mother smile so wide as when she would open that door.  Every Sunday after the divorce, her mother would call, and Maeve, who was just nine at the time, would skip out of her seat and pick up the old-fashioned landline phone the family hung on to. The two of them would talk for fifteen, twenty, thirty minutes or more. Sometimes Maeve would be up long past her bedtime talking and laughing with her mother. Steven always allowed this. But he never talked to her himself, except to say goodbye.  Quinn had hoped in a distant silver-lining sense that returning back home and being free of Steven would help to restart her mother’s life, or at the very least to bridge the gap that had formed between her and her oldest daughter. But the years, and the disappearance of Maeve, had taken their toll. Anna leveraged her doctorate in biology to work nights as a custodian, which forced her to sleep during the days, and she rarely left the house for anything else. As she marked time, Quinn tried her best to live around her.

And of all days, she had to be out today.  Quinn dialed her number, an ordeal that was more than trivial as she fought for control of her fingers. The phone rang once, twice, three times.  "Hello there, this is Anna Harper. I’m sorry I’m unavailable to pick up the phone at the moment, but I’ll get back to you as soon as I can."  What?
Quinn called again. She waited, waited.  A break in the ringing.  "Hello there, this is Anna Harper."  Quinn hung up, slammed the phone onto the car floor, and screamed.

Where the hell is she? Quinn had to breathe. She threw open the door and stepped outside. Two squirrels chased one another across the stone walkway that connected the house’s front stoop to the driveway. Across the street, her neighbor pushed a lawn mower through his yard. Around and around they went. Quinn shook her head and grabbed her phone (sporting a fresh crack down the middle) and hurried inside her house. That day last fall was the fastest she had ever seen life move. She thought there was no possibility of a day, a moment, ever coming to be as dizzying as that one outside of the high school. She was wrong.  She considered her options while pacing across the living room. There weren’t many. She could wait at home, calling her mother, ignoring the message; this way, with any luck, she could find help, or if not, rob some sick prankster or malicious scam artist of some kind of satisfaction.

Alternatively, she could act.  That message. For all she knew, she may have been given false information. She pulled out her phone and searched for the address. Sure enough, Allensburg was a real town, and 827 Fairview Road was a real place. It was an old-looking building, standing maybe four stories tall, buried behind a chain link fence and what looked to be thick rows of forest. It was constructed with old, weathered bricks, and vines grew on all of its walls. Windows, some covered with plywood, and still others broken, looked out onto the lonely road that connected the building to the rest of the world.  Maeve shouldn’t be there. And, perhaps most importantly, who had sent her that message? She read through it again, hoping that some clue would jump out at her. But she had already memorized and turned over every word of the text. It was more or less as concise as it could be.

Quinn took a seat at the dining room table. She hovered her thumbs above the reply bar.  What else could she do?  She formulated a response by asking the two questions that were most pressingly on her mind. Typing them out made her dizzy.  "A guest"? Who is this?
She sent the text and felt a wave of nausea rise in her throat.  The response came almost immediately.

Head out tomorrow morning to the Quickie Motel in Springfield, Illinois, for proof of life. Text this number when you get there.   Just like that, she had a destination. It, too, was a real place; the drive there was around fourteen hours in length. She put her phone down and for the first time took note of the stillness of her surroundings. The plan was in motion, now, not her.

But how stupid it was! Quinn could count on one hand the number of times she had ever left her home state of New Jersey, and she had to prepare to go across the country by car over the span of three days on a rescue mission to save her sister. A rescue mission, by herself. She was sure she’d seen a movie– no, a television show– just like it. She laughed out loud, a nervous, chattering laugh that was foreign to her ears. How did that show end?  That’s right. I never finished it. Working further against her was that she still had no name. The rational conclusion she should have arrived at was that some sadistic student had come upon her number somehow, probably from college, and was getting a laugh out of messing with her. She was easy pickings, after all. Not very social, a public incident in the recent past. The message, combined with the hidden identity, and the request to keep the police uninvolved, reeked of dishonesty. But that phrase– if you want to see her again– there was no way she could not see it through.  So, against her better judgment, she raced up the stairs to grab her bag. As she threw a few days’ worth of clothes in it, she wondered what exactly she would need for this excursion, should it be legitimate. This mysterious text figure hadn’t ever mentioned a transfer of money. Was this person just going to meet with Quinn at the ivy-covered building and hand Maeve over? Would Quinn have to do something in exchange for her? And where was her father in all of this?

The more Quinn thought about what she may be getting into, the less it all made sense. So she decided to focus on her breathing, and what to bring. Would she need a weapon? There were no guns in the house. And for all she knew, someone was out there, following her every move. They managed to get her phone number. If she went to buy a weapon, would this person know about it? If she brought one on her ride, would that ruin something? Plans and fears flashed in her mind. She lept in logic, played with ideas that were just as plausible as they were fantastical.  She considered texting the number back, but decided against it. Yes, she needed to know what to bring, what to expect, what to do, but calling was against the rules. What if sending off-topic text messages was, too? Returning downstairs, she caught a gleam from the kitchen. Next to the stove, a magnetic block of wood displayed three knives, each larger than the last. Quinn looked over her shoulder, certain that someone was watching, but the house was as still as it ever had been.

Through measured breaths, she made her way to the block. She wrapped her fingers around the handle of the largest knife, and daydreamed. She stuck the knife into someone else, someone who wanted to kill her, someone who wanted to kill Maeve. It was heavy enough. It was certainly intimidating enough.  No, this wasn’t happening. Quinn pulled out her phone and dialed her mother’s number again. Nothing. She texted her. I need to talk to you ASAP. A minute, two, five. Nothing. The knife would make the journey with her.

Quinn made one more pass through the house to ensure she had packed everything she needed.  As she reached the upstairs landing, she stepped on a particularly creaky patch of floor, one that had been notorious for announcing its existence to the rest of the house for as long as Quinn could remember. It was directly in front of Maeve’s room. Maeve’s room, ajar, looking into her, pleading. Make me whole again. Quinn shut the door and went back downstairs. It was still only 3 o’clock. She threw her bag onto the coffee table, sat on her couch, and turned on the television. It was a Friends rerun. She had never found the episodes very funny, but she did enjoy them. The show brought her back to middle school, when her father used to sit her down at the table and help her with math homework, or essays, as the laugh track drifted into the dining room table. Her mother always had Friends on those nights.

Her father wasn’t home much back then, but when he was, he was always ready to help her. Homework, girl scout projects, even video games. Quinn remembered one night, when she was very little, being stuck on a level of an old racing game that she loved to play. Just as she was about to give up and go to bed, her father came home from work, and upon hearing what was happening, beat the level on the first try. Her ten-year-old self absolutely thought him a superhero that night.  Interspersed throughout those times, and even after the messy divorce, were dozens of small superhero moments. Throughout the past few months, Quinn had been asked about her father countless times, from other family members, acquaintances, and curious news-watching onlookers. She always struggled to feel she could describe him well. Steven, the truant, distant superhero.  She could only imagine where he was and what he was doing now.

As she watched, Quinn felt her eyes grow heavy. She unzipped her bag and put a sweatshirt on. The show numbed her mind, chilled her body, made her cognizant of all of the hours she’d spent awake in bed over the past days, weeks, months. One episode finished, another began, and then another.  She was not sure exactly when she nodded off. Sleep was so similar to waking.  ./. She lay there, frozen.

The stage lights grew hotter and hotter against her cheek.  She knew the words, but they wouldn’t come out. In her periphery, she saw him, standing there, waiting, expecting, wondering what was wrong. The audience’s silence was interrupted by scattered murmurs.  She tried to breathe. She couldn’t. She tried again. There was no air in that building. She panicked. She screamed. No one else moved. She was dying.

Everyone was watching her die. The pain was unbearable. She felt color drain from her face.  Bang, bang! Someone was pounding on the door stage left.  BANG! BANG! Would they not just let her die? Quinn awoke, gasping for air. Someone was banging on the front door, loud enough to hear over the falling rain.

Rain? Was it not just beautiful outside? She glanced at the digital clock underneath the television as she stood up. 8:45. She had been out longer than she intended.  She sauntered to the front door, nerves still muted by sleep, and looked out the peephole. It was Ty, soaking wet.  Quinn creaked open the door and spoke groggily.  "Hey, Ty. What’s up?"
He looked relieved. "Can I come in for a second? It sucks out here." "Yeah, sure." Quinn swung open the door and Ty stepped in. Shit. The bag.

It was still open. Ty looked at it, and at the object inside, which rested on top of a sea of clothes. His expression changed, and he spoke quietly.  "Is everything alright, Q?" She sighed. She still wasn’t thinking clearly enough to craft a lie, so she answered truthfully.

"No," she breathed. "Not right now." As if he had not heard her, he started into a clumsy speech. "Look, I’m sorry if what… I did earlier was upsetting. That wasn’t what I wanted. And I wouldn’t be bothering you, trust me, but you looked really messed-up, and you weren’t responding to anything I sent you. I know, I’m being nosy, and creepy, but I’ve never seen you like that, and I…I was just worried."  After saying this, he seemed to come back to reality.

"And if that big-ass knife is for me, then I guess I just made myself an easier target showing up here, right?" he added. Quinn found the joking smile on his lips to be so foreign that she smiled back herself.  What a dork.  "No, it’s not for you."

Without warning, she hugged him.  Taken by surprise, Ty eventually put his arms around her.  "Seriously, though, I am going to have to know what the knife is for." Quinn took a breath, and pulled back.

"It’s family shit. Nothing you have to worry about." Ty happened to know about Quinn’s family history, and could not help himself. "Did you find your dad? Are you gonna kill him?" "Tyler, stop." "Ah– sorry, Q," he responded, sheepishly. "I just… don’t want you to get hurt. Can you tell me what’s going on? Please. I won’t say a word to anybody. Hell, I don’t even know who I’d tell if I wanted to."

She thought this was probably true. Ty lived alone in an apartment, and he had lost contact with his parents years ago. She wasn’t sure how many friends he liked to gossip with, but he didn’t exactly exude social confidence in the classes they had together.  Still, she spoke carefully.  "You don’t know anything right now. That’s probably for the best. What you should do, is leave now, and I’ll be back at school later this week. No one will be hurt, with the knife, or with anything else; I swear it. Okay?" He looked back at her blankly. "You’re scaring me. What is happening?"

Quinn covered her face with her hands. "Just leave before I ask you to help me." Ty puffed his chest out. "A harrowing, life-or-death mission with a girl from my Calc class who I just met a few months ago? How could I walk away from that opportunity?" Quinn sat down on the couch, defeated. "Last chance." "No shot, Q."

Without another word, she pulled her phone out of her pocket and showed Ty the mysterious texts. He read through them slowly and carefully.  "This is insane," he concluded. "This can’t be real. It’s not... one of your high school friends pulling a dumb prank on you?" Quinn shrugged. "Maybe. But what if it’s not?" He sighed. "Either way, there’s no way in hell you’re going alone. Plus, your car is a piece of crap. We can take mine. And drive in shifts."
A pause.  "If anything happens, good, bad, or indifferent, I’ll have your back. Okay?" Quinn’s voice cracked. "Don’t you have anything better to do?"

Ty grinned. "Are you kidding me? Video games and my bong are very important, but they can wait this time. And if we miss a little bit of class, who cares? We just crushed our quizzes. We’ll be fine."  Quinn could hardly believe what she was hearing. She took an uneven sigh.  "Okay." Ty started toward the door. "I’ll be packed and in your driveway at 7:30 tomorrow morning. See you then."

Quinn didn’t stand up to walk him out. Her eyes followed his tall, athletic frame out of the door, watching the colors of his clothes move through space.  She peeked through the blinds to watch him pull away. Just one car, her own, remained in the driveway to absorb the sheets of rain that forced themselves upon her town.  Of course, her mother had not responded to her text, either. Though she felt unready to welcome sleep again, felt unready for anything, Quinn went upstairs, changed, opened her laptop, as though it was any other night. But there were strings, long, wispy, attached to her fingers. Every time she tried to pull them off, they would knot; every time she moved, she felt the weight of the object the strings were attached to. As the rest of the quiet evening dragged on, she longed to free herself.

Doing so would have been an inefficient use of her time. She needed rest, after all. Her marionette would be early tomorrow. ./. Quinn’s eyes shot open at the sound of her phone’s alarm. She bolted upright and fought for rapid, shallow breaths. Her clothes stuck to her body from sweat. It had been another long night.

She had learned the trick from her father years ago. She grabbed clothes from her drawer and headed straight for the shower. She undressed, waited for the water to warm up, and stepped in. She closed her eyes and put her head directly under the faucet.  She took a deep breath. The weight of her feet on the floor. The warm water, landing on the crown of her head, and running down her shoulder-length hair. Another breath. The hissing of the water as it exited the faucet and landed on the porcelain bathtub. The air, dense with steam, as it entered and exited her lungs, slower and slower.  "The idea," said her father, years ago, "is to immerse yourself in the present. Notice everything that is happening around you, acknowledge it, and make peace with it."  Quinn, just a freshman in high school at the time, listened to him skeptically.

"How will that make the nightmares go away?" "It might not, at first. But the idea is to check in with yourself every morning. To feel that feeling, of being awake, in a moment of time. And the more you do that, the more your brain might know when it’s not awake, and the less the nightmares may end up hurting you." Quinn still wasn’t buying it.  "It’s called meditation, Quinnie. A lot of people do it every day. I do it too. It’s always helped me. And I think it could help you."

Quinn had been standing in the shower for some time before she was ready to move on. The dream. She let as much in as she could, every detail that she could remember.  Digging. It was raining, and she was digging. There was so much wet earth. It burrowed underneath her nails and onto her face. She’d never dig deep enough. The dirt was as black as the night sky, as cold as the relentless rain. The hole grew and grew. She dug faster and faster.  At last, she found it; what she was digging for. She pulled the large object up through the exposed mud.  It was herself, decaying. Her own sunken eyes and graying flesh and tattered clothes were in her tired hands. She froze in terror.

The corpse woke up. It opened its eyes, now yellow, and flashed a twisted smile that revealed missing teeth. It slowly reached up with its disfigured arm and pulled the skin off of its face, revealing muscle tissue and exposed bone. It felt no pain.  She tried to throw it off, but it had grabbed onto her. She cried for help. The corpse’s cold hand only squeezed tighter. She tried to run up the muddy slope she had created. It was no use.  She turned her head to the top of the pit, which must have been twenty feet deep. Silently standing there was Ty. He watched Quinn struggle without emotion.  The corpse grabbed her head. Quinn’s neck snapped forward again, toward herself. Its face was skinless, and its hands were iron. It reached for her, pulled her closer. The discarded flesh hung from its neck. Quinn fought to break free but the corpse was far too strong. It brought its skinless lips to Quinn’s.

That was all she could remember. Fleeting mental images threatened to suffocate her. But she focused on the weight of her feet on the floor, and the water on her head, and the steam in the air.  As the minutes passed, the images of the corpse and of Ty came in and out of her mind. But slowly, she felt reality start to win out over her dream.  "You’re telling me I have to think about it again in the morning?" asked Quinn, incredulously. "I am, and I wish I didn’t have to. But you can’t get better if you don’t face what’s bothering you head-on. And I know," he continued, rubbing her head with his hand, "that for as bad as those nightmares are, you’re so much stronger. Okay?"
She nodded, without a word. "I love you, Quinnie May," said the superhero. "I love you too." ./.

Quinn fidgeted on the couch. Her eyes were dry and her muscles ached, but she had spent so much of her life in rough shape after a fruitless night of sleep that she hardly noticed anything out of the ordinary. In front of her was the bag she had packed yesterday, and a small collection of some snacks for the road. Each of the colorful plastic bags featured processed food that seemed equally inedible to her.  She had been on that couch for some time, turning around to check for Ty through the blinds every few minutes. Different scenarios ran through her mind. Would it all just be a big prank? Would they be trafficked to another country? Would they be robbed at gunpoint? The more she sat and thought, the more wild her ideas became.  Behind her dread, however, was the illuminating, poisonous hope that within seventy-two hours, she would be able to bring her sister home. She hadn’t heard anything about her father in the text message, but sometimes, she would let herself imagine that they were together in Colorado as a part of some big misunderstanding, and everything in her home could go back to the way it had been six months ago. That was, of course, until she remembered that her mother was still gone. Surely, she must be at one of her friend’s houses, or maybe she had some meeting. Maybe she even met someone new, thought Quinn, daring to smile. But she couldn’t linger on it. She had bigger things to worry about.  She heard a rumble from outside at 7:25. She jumped up, grabbed her bags, and opened the front door.

Ty had just stepped out of the car when she saw him. He looked tired. Maybe some of the machismo he had so effortlessly displayed yesterday had worn off.  "Ty, it’s alright, really, if you–" "Let’s go, Q," he said, shaking his head. She threw her bags in the back seat and slid into his car. Wordlessly, the two began their journey westward.

*        *        * Quinn pulled into the driveway. Even though it was almost 6:30, the late summer sun hung powerfully in the sky.  She parked, grabbed her backpack, and walked on aching feet across the uneven cobblestone steps that led toward her home’s front door.  The smell hit her as soon as she opened the door. Her father– unbelievably, home at this hour– was making some kind of sauce, and she was nothing if not hungry. Unfortunately for her, she wouldn’t be staying at home that night.

"You’re home early," she said to him, breezing upstairs. He yelled to her as she walked into her room. "Yes. I wanted to make sure you were all set for tonight. And I wanted to make something for when you come home, since I know it’ll be late." Quinn frowned as she threw her backpack into the closet. On an average weeknight, he wasn’t out of work until ten or eleven. The smell and the sound made the Harper household feel a lot busier than it otherwise should have been. "How was work, honey?" he asked from the kitchen.

"Fun, as always," she responded.  She had been standing at the booth of a mini-golf course for the past five hours. Almost no one ever came, and she hardly made any money, but she had the job since high school, and figured that holding on to it was better than being unemployed.  As Quinn came down the stairs, father and daughter locked eyes for a tense moment. She wasn’t sure exactly what he was trying to communicate to her. "Well, have fun tonight and be safe. And, Quinnie, were you planning on keeping that hat on?"

She stopped mid-stride and felt her head. She had been wearing her company-issued visor for so long that she forgot it was there. She threw it on the table. It was a really hideous shade of orange, just like the polo shirt that they made her wear.  "Uh, no, thanks, dad." She grabbed the envelope from the living room mantle and walked back out to the car. As she sat down behind the wheel, she read the small, precise letters imprinted on the back of the card. To Maeve– Love, Dad.

She threw it in the glove compartment and jammed her key into the ignition. When she turned it, the engine coughed and sputtered. Damn it! She turned it again. Begrudgingly, the car started. Maybe if she had worked at the steakhouse across the street from the mini golf course, she’d have been able to afford a slightly more reliable car.  She made her way to the high school.  *        *        * Ty had been driving on the highway for a half hour or so when he started stealing glances at Quinn.

Although she had been spending her ride looking out the window, and trying not to think too hard about anything, she could start to feel his eyes. Whenever she looked back over at him, he would glance back at the mostly open road ahead of him.  Eventually, she had enough. "Alright Ty, what is it?" He pretended to be surprised. "Oh, uh, nothing." "I can’t drive all day in complete silence. If you’ve got something to say to me, go ahead."

He looked relieved. "I was just wondering if you wanted to put on some music, or something." Quinn nodded. "Sure, go ahead." "Any preferences?" he asked. "You’re the passenger, you get the AUX." She shrugged, and plugged her phone into his charger. Soon, the rough guitar and gritty voice of Bob Dylan filled the car.
Ty chuckled. "Dylan? Really?" Quinn got defensive. "What’s wrong with that?" "Nothing, Q. It’s just– so perfect." "What do you mean?"

"Well," he stated, with a hint of haughtiness, "the fundamental theorem of Tyler clearly states that every person’s musical tastes are easily identifiable by Tyler himself, in accordance with their personality and interests. And you are the perfect example of that." She hated him. "How so?" "Well, he’s old school. A real outsider. A bit rough around the edges, but with a real passion for leaving something great behind." Quinn stared at him. She felt like she was sitting in a fortune teller’s tent.

"Let me guess," he continued. "You hate modern stuff. Won’t even give it a listen. You probably like Bob Marley, too. And the Wilson sisters. I think you’d like some of Miles Davis’ stuff, but you’ve never heard it before." He paused. "How did I do?" She could still see the Heart poster that she had up on her wall for years, until she decided to try to make her room look a bit more grown-up. And while Marley wasn’t exactly her favorite, she had a few of his songs saved on the playlist that currently was still only playing through the very first song she had chosen.  "Am I really that easy?" she asked, impressed.  "Yes," he responded, clearly satisfied with himself. "But everyone is, once you get to know them. At least, they are to me."

"Huh," she responded. "Listen," he said. "Once we go through your playlist, I have to show you something. Did you know Miles Davis– you know, the trumpet guy– did a hip hop album in the nineties? I know, you might be skeptical. But trust me on this one." Quinn ventured a sarcastic sigh. "At this point, how could I not trust you?" The two sped onwards.

*        *        * Quinn had been out front for a while before the students poured out of the Fillmore High’s side exit.  She couldn’t help but notice how much energy some of them had. They swung their violins, trapped in sturdy black cases, and laughed loudly amongst each other, despite the fact that they had just had a full school day and a nearly four-hour rehearsal afterwards. She admired their resolve.  After most of the students had filed out, she spotted Maeve, slowly lugging her cello outside. She was in rapt conversation with who Quinn could only assume was the orchestra’s conductor. Quinn suddenly felt a bit embarrassed to be picking her sister up in her barely functioning car.

Maeve spotted her sister and waved goodbye to the man. She opened the trunk and maneuvered her cello inside. It was a small miracle that the massive instrument even fit.  Maeve sat down in the passenger’s seat and strapped herself in.  "How’d we do today, kiddo?" asked Quinn.  "Alright," replied Maeve. "Mr. Lin and I were just going over some bowing techniques for next week."

"Bowing techniques. Sounds fascinating," said Quinn, her voice dripping with sarcasm. "It is! Well, to me. Maybe not…objectively." Quinn smiled as she turned onto the main road.  "So, first week of high school is done. How many of the students are complete animals?"

Maeve thought for a moment. "You know, judging by the cafeteria tables, the rampant unchecked bullying, and the three fights that have already broken out, I’d say a solid… 90%?" Quinn laughed ruefully. "Sounds just like when I was there." "Well, it could be worse. Alexa is in almost all of my classes, and I think she hates high school just as much as me. We’ll get through it, just like you and Jenny did." Quinn nodded. She really wasn’t sure how she would have gotten through high school without Jenny.

They reached a stoplight. Instead of turning left, which was the way to get home, Quinn drove straight ahead.  "Uhhh…Quinn?" said her sister, timidly.  "Wha– oh, damn it. Shit. I wasn’t even paying attention! Sorry." "It’s fine. Just turn left up on this next road. I think this back way is prettier anyway."

Quinn passed that left as well. She didn’t even slow down. "Quinn. This isn’t funny." She didn’t respond. Instead, she turned to look at Maeve. Her expression was completely blank. Finally, she spoke softly. "Where are we going?"

Ordinarily, this may have made Maeve even more frustrated than she already was. But there was really nothing except for confusion behind her sister’s eyes. Maeve turned white, and fought for words.  "Uh–" Quinn suddenly dropped the act and howled with laughter. Maeve, still confused, but thankful her sister hadn’t just lost her mind, started screaming at her. "Quinnie, I HATE you! What’s wrong with you! Where are we going?" "Just give me half an hour. Trust me."

Maeve put on her headphones and stared out the window.  *        *        * "I cannot go higher than six and a half. I can’t! It’s just too weird for me." "I know, I know. But– it’s good. You just have to listen to it a few times to really get it."

Quinn, now behind the wheel, sighed. She had been listening to John Zorn– according to Ty, the king of the avant-garde– for the past hour, and his music was nothing if not unconventional.  "Look, it was creative. The thing it was lacking was not creativity. I’d say it probably could have used…I don’t know… some kind of tether back to reality?" "That’s the point, Q! Get lost out there, on the sea of rhythm and dissonance! Let him tell a story in a new language! You’ll hear it, I know you will!" She couldn’t tell how much he was messing with her and how much he was serious. She hoped it was mostly the former.

"Listen, we’ve been playing your stuff for the past eight hours. Will you let me pick something for you?" Ty seemed skeptical. "Alright. Be warned, though, I am a stern judge of musical talent." Quinn nodded. "Alright. But give me one of your favorites first. I’ll work off of that. That’s how you picked mine." "Fair enough."

He searched his phone for a moment, and came to his decision. Suddenly, without warning, overdriven guitars, ripping cymbals, and the guttural screams of some death metal singer filled the car. Quinn jumped when the song started. She had to shout to Ty to be heard. "Are you kidding me?" Ty seemed completely unaffected by the offensive noise in the car. "This is awesome!" Quinn wondered how someone with such self-proclaimed musical appreciation could like something so sonically grating.

When the song was mercifully over, Ty spoke to Quinn. He was barely understandable over the lasting ringing that played from inside her skull.  "So. What did you think?" "You know what? It was technically impressive. I couldn’t scream like that for five and a half minutes, and the guitar solos were…very fast." He nodded. He was hanging on every word that came out of her mouth.

"But I mean, how are you going to sit there and listen to that kind of music all of the time? I mean, I’m surprised you can even hear at all." Ty laughed. "Yeah. Most people I show my real stuff to say that." Quinn thought for a moment. "Let me guess. You listen to music that’s unappealing at first listen but really is complex underneath because that’s how you see yourself. Or at least, that’s how you want to be seen." Ty opened his mouth to say something, but couldn’t. He was clearly unprepared for that.

"Hey, man, you did the same thing to me. It looks like the fundamental theorem of Tyler may need some rewording." "Yeah, yeah, Q," muttered Ty. "Listen. I have something that you might like. It’s a little bit different from your death metal, though."  *        *        *

The two sisters had been driving for about twenty minutes when Maeve started to catch on to what was happening. She took off her headphones. "Wait. We’re not…" Quinn knew that she knew. "Look in the glove compartment." Maeve opened it and grabbed the envelope. She looked at the words on the front, and tore it open.

"No. No way. This– this is sold out! I was checking all week! How did you– How did he–"  Maeve was quickly too overcome with excitement to continue her train of thought. Inside the envelope were two tickets to the Pinky Meteor concert happening in Newark. Maeve absolutely loved them, but unfortunately, so did seemingly everyone else in the greater New Jersey area.  "Well, don’t go too crazy," said Quinn. "We probably have the worst seats in the house." "I don’t care. Oh my God! I can’t even feel my face."

Quinn smiled. She had been hoping for this kind of reaction from her sister.  Maeve continued to run her mouth wildly as they approached the Prudential Hall for their concert. After they parked, they had to practically run into the building for the 7:30 start time.  The stage lights dimmed just as they took their seats. They were up on the fourth row, in the corner furthest from the stage. They really were probably the worst seats in the house. But Maeve could not have seemed to care less. Quinn had never seen her so enraptured by anything.  The music was wild, but bright. There were only three members of the group– a keyboardist, a drummer, and a singer, who rarely was on stage. They played at breakneck speeds, moving together in unisons that seemed at first illogical and then downright impossible. It wasn’t the type of music Quinn would seek out and listen to, but it didn’t matter. For two hours that night, she enjoyed the show.

*        *        * It had been dark for almost an hour. Quinn’s joints were positively aching from the ride, which had seemed to grow exponentially longer the closer they got to the motel. More than that, however, the feeling of dread that Quinn could not escape earlier in the day was back with a vengeance. What would be waiting for her here? Ty hadn’t said anything for a while, either. The moment seemed to be weighing down on them in equal measure.  Quinn turned onto an old, empty road. At long last, she could see the motel. She almost couldn’t believe it was real.

As they pulled into the dirt lot, Ty spoke. "I guess this Quickie Motel looks just as upscale as it sounds." It was a long building with two floors. Paint chipped off the doors, tall grass grew in the cracks of the sidewalk outside the rooms, and a number of windows were either boarded up or broken. (Quinn was beginning to notice a theme.) There were a few stores that sparsely populated the road the motel was on, but it seemed like a great place to hide from society. It was not the type of venue that Quinn had ever hoped to spend a night at.  She pulled out her phone, and opened the mysterious message she had received the previous day. The instructions were simple enough.  We’re here, she replied.

Ty and Quinn held their breath, waiting for a response. It came quickly.    Great. Ask for room 116, and request the deluxe package. Leave for the Residence Inn in Denver CO tomorrow morning, and text this number when you’ve arrived.

She looked at him. Wordlessly, the two exited the car and walked toward the reception area by the side of the motel.  It was a small, dingy room. The lights flickered on and off, and the couches looked damp and unpleasant. An old woman, who looked to be half asleep, manned the desk.

Quinn spoke first. "Uh, hello there. We were wondering if we could stay in room 116 tonight?" The woman didn’t seem to have heard her at first, but slowly looked up and then considered her request. "You can stay here, but we don’t do room requests." Ty jumped in quickly. "We were, actually, here for the deluxe package." The woman thought about that for another moment. Could she be moving any slower?

"Alright," she said. She reached into a drawer of her desk and grabbed a key, and handed it to Quinn. "Room 116’s all the way at the end of the building. Enjoy your night." Quinn and Ty headed out of the reception area and toward their own room. As they walked, they heard some adult sounds coming from at least three other rooms. They tried not to think about that.  Quinn opened the door. Room 116 was small, and just as uninviting as the rest of the motel. Ugly brown wallpaper peeled everywhere, the carpet was dug up in some places, and the bed was sloppily made. The door to the bathroom was open a few inches, and Quinn didn’t even want to think about what was waiting for her in there.  In front of the bed was an old television, mounted on a cart with wheels. Quinn hadn’t seen anything like that since she was in elementary school. It had a VHS tape slot, and hanging from it was a tape. Surely, this was the promised "proof of life".

Ty looked at Quinn. She stepped into the room and sat on the end of the bed. It was just as hard and uncomfortable as it looked. Ty sat beside her.  "Are you ready?" he asked, quietly.  She nodded.  Ty turned on the old television, pushed the tape into the slot, and pressed play.

The footage was rather grainy, and taken from a peculiar angle. It looked down on a dazzlingly white room, completely devoid of furniture. The floor, walls, and ceiling seemed all to be made up of the same type of tile, except for the furthest wall from the camera, which featured a wooden door, also painted white, and what Quinn could only assume to be a two-way mirror. A young girl sat against the opposite wall. She wore a gray hospital gown, and on her feet were two black ankle-length socks. She seemed to be staring at the door.  Was that Maeve? The girl certainly had her red hair. But it was impossible to see her face from where she was sitting, and even if it was, the footage may have been too grainy to see anything definitive regardless.  The girl didn’t move for some time. The only reason why Quinn knew the video wasn’t paused was the incessant crackling of the picture.

Then, a buzzer sounded. The audio, like the video, was distorted and muffled, but coherent enough for the two friends to understand what was happening. The door swung open. Out came a black dog. The door shut behind it as it inquisitively pawed its way into the room, nose down, smelling its new surroundings.  Suddenly, an amplified voice filled the room. "This is attempt number four, subject Emily, 2-10-23." Then, silence. The girl sat exactly where she was, just as before. The dog, maybe a border collie, kept exploring the room.

Quinn’s heart raced. What in the world was this about? What was going to happen?  The dog eventually noticed the girl’s presence, and started to jog over to greet her. After a few steps, however, it stopped in its tracks. It was tough to make out exactly what it was doing on the video, but it looked like it cocked its ears back and turned its head, as though trying to locate a sharp sound.  The girl brought her hands to her face. The dog started pedaling backwards, ears flat against its head, tail wagging ferociously. It bared its teeth and began to growl.  The dog quickly backed up all the way to the wall with the two-way mirror. It started to bark angrily. Its eyes were now trained directly forward, not on the girl, but on some spot directly in front of itself.
