Then, suddenly, the dog seemed to lose its invisible prey. Its head swung wildly around, attempting to find whatever it had just been looking at.  The girl removed her hands from her head, and stood up. At that moment, the door swung open once more, and a tall, thin man with pale skin and dark hair entered the room.  He was built much like Quinn’s father.  The man walked over to the girl and pulled her into an embrace. He knelt down, said something to her that was too quiet to be heard, and started to lead her toward the door. The dog, still looking wildly around the room, seemed not to notice the presence of either the man or the girl. As the two walked out, the amplified voice spoke again. "Attempt four is unsuccessful."

With that, the tape cut.  ./. Quinn and Ty sat there, in that small, dingy room, trying to make any sense of what they had just seen.  The silence persisted for a while, the tape frozen. The girl and the man, both turned away from the camera, were just about to leave the room, and the black dog seemed to have found itself in the mirror.

Quinn’s eyes scanned every inch of the screen. The video was just as unclear– and just as foreboding– as the text messages had been.  Ty spoke first. "So, uh... do you think that was her?" Quinn shook her head. "I don’t know. I can’t tell you that it wasn’t," "And that man– was he–"

Quinn looked at him. "I don’t know, Tyler. It looked a lot like him. But– a lot of people look like that–" "His face! When he comes out of the door. You can see his face. Hold on–" Ty rewound the tape to the moment the man stepped out of the door.          He pressed play. The man strode confidently toward the girl. He was dressed in a navy suit and brown dress shoes. That much was clear. But the entirety of his face was only a few pixels on the old television. It was impossible to make out any defining features, except…

"Well, he’s clean shaven," said Ty. "Did your dad… have a beard?" Quinn thought back. "Yeah, he did. But that was last fall; he usually shaves it when it starts to get warmer." Ty shrugged. "Your guess is as good as mine, then." Quinn sighed. "What do you think M– the girl– was trying to do?"

"I don’t know, Q. That dog looked pretty spooked. Maybe… it wasn’t about the girl. Maybe they were playing some kind of high-pitched sound? Or, maybe there was some chemical in the room?" Quinn did not like either of those suggestions. But she felt like at that moment, anything they might come up with would be complete guesswork. There was still one question on her mind, however.  "I don’t know. I just wonder– what if the attempt had succeeded? What would that have looked like?"  Ty shrugged. "I thought leaving today that this trip was easily the craziest shit I’ve ever done. Now I’m sure of it."

Quinn looked at him desperately. "How do you think I feel?"  He sighed sympathetically, and took a moment to speak. "It’s almost 11. We should probably get some sleep and think about it tomorrow. Long day for driving and brainstorming." Quinn’s chest tightened. Somehow, she hadn’t even thought of that– sleep. They were in a single room, with no couches.  "Uh, would you mind… asking the receptionist lady if she has a cot, or something? I–"

"Oh! Ah–yeah, of course. I’ll be right back." Ty darted out of the room.  Quinn took a breath. Somehow, after watching the tape, she felt exactly as she had last night– dreadful that she was getting herself into something that was well out of her depth and yet hopeful that her family was out there, somewhere, still able to be saved.  She played the tape back, and watched it all. The girl, the voice, the dog. It seemed ready to jump out of its own skin to attack the very air in front of it. And then, all of a sudden, it wasn’t. The tape couldn’t have been more than two minutes long. But it posed so many more questions than it answered.  Ty opened the door, empty-handed. "I tried to ask for something, but the receptionist lady just made fun of me."

Quinn scowled. "What?" "Yeah. I asked her if we could get a cot, or an extra mattress, or something, and she just laughed at me. She said…" he trailed off. "Well, I won’t…say what she said." Quinn stood up and walked past him out the door.  "Good luck," he called out, more sarcastic than earnest.

Quinn stormed over to the reception area, and threw open the door.  "Are you really telling me you don’t have anything extra to sleep on? Nothing?" she said, still walking up to the desk.  This sent the old woman into a riot. She had to wait several moments to respond through her laughter. "Wooo, this is trouble in paradise if I’ve ever seen it! I do not want to know what just went on in there." Quinn took an exasperated sigh. "Do you have an extra room? Or– anything? I can pay for it."

The old woman began to regain her composure. "Look, sweetie. This isn’t usually the place where two young kids check in and then need… separate sleeping arrangements. So we’re not exactly equipped for that scenario. And unfortunately–" she glanced at a pad of paper on her desk– "we are booked full tonight. So, I am sure that you two will be able to work it out. Alright?" Quinn was stunned. "You are so creepy." The old woman howled, with more gusto than ever. As Quinn turned to leave, she figured that working in a place like this motel must twist a person’s mind.  She made her way back to room 116, and tried to be rational. It wasn’t that bad; it was just one night. Her sister needed her. And if this was what she had to put up with, then so be it.

She opened the door, and saw Ty laying one of the bedsheets down on the narrow strip of floor beside the bed.  "Oh, Ty, you don’t– have to–" "No, it’s fine, Q. I can sleep anywhere. One of my finest talents. I’m assuming the Queen of England there at the reception desk gave you a hard time?" Quinn laughed. Suddenly, her voice cracked. "Yeah, she did."

She stepped over the bedsheet and into the small bathroom. She closed the door. At last, in this dingy motel, in Nowhere, Illinois, in the far and away most disgusting bathroom she had ever seen, she had a moment to herself.  Scenes from the video flashed in her head. The girl. Her hair was just like Maeve’s was last fall, only a bit longer. Even the way she walked reminded Quinn of her. If that tape was really some kind of surveillance footage, and if the mysterious messenger was an ally…what was her sister doing? And why did her father whisk her away from her life to do it? And why was she in trouble? Quinn realized at that moment just how overwhelming her emotions were. All of them. The barrier she had constructed, out of pure necessity, to keep them contained was under massive pressure. She just had to hold it together a little longer.  Eventually, she stepped out of the bathroom. Ty was next to wash up, and he clearly noticed the state of things in there. "Wow, Q, you really did a number on this bathroom!"

Damn it, Tyler. "That is the worst thing anyone has ever said to me." But, suddenly, she could not keep herself from smiling. When Ty was done, and in his makeshift bed, Quinn rolled over and put her hand on the light switch. "Are you ready?" "Mmhmm," he muttered. Amazingly, he was already half asleep, if not more.  Quinn turned off the light. Images from the night cycled through her mind at a frantic pace, but fatigue pounded even more violently at her head. It was not long before she, too, was asleep.

./. Quinn bounced her leg up and down. Her seat, a cheap, plastic chair which should have been too small and too green for use in any high school, gave a nearly  inaudible creak as she shifted her weight. Around her, scores of high schoolers, all in gowns or tuxedos, raced across the room, laughing, or warming up their voices. Someone savagely banged on the piano. It didn’t really matter to Quinn. She didn’t notice any of it. All she knew was that the grimy rags she wore seemed to be even more uncomfortable than usual.  She stared at her director, Mr. Abrams, chatting with the pit orchestra conductor near the room’s exit. Were they watching her? If they were, she was sure she wasn’t projecting any kind of confidence.

Quinn felt like standing up and moving around, but her legs were too heavy. In fact, she thought she might even pass out. Why did she go out for the play? It all seemed so shortsighted, now that the moment was actually here.  As her thoughts continued to swirl, the door she was staring at opened, and a friendly face appeared. Jenny, dressed in all black and holding her violin, immediately spotted Quinn and sat down in the vacant chair next to her. "Closing night," she said. Quinn nodded absently. "Yep."

Jenny turned her head at an angle. "Oh, come on. You can’t tell me you’re gonna be nervous now! What happened to yesterday? And the day before? I mean, you were crazy! Everybody loved you!" Quinn gave her a small smile. "Yeah?" "Of course, yeah! I had no idea you…even had that in you. The acting, the singing, all of it. It’s all there, you can do it one more time."  Quinn wasn’t perking up.

Jenny sighed. "It’s not those state adjudicators, right? Because they can go to hell. The awards are all rigged, anyway. Tony, one of the three people here? His son’s the lead in the play two towns over, and–" Quinn interrupted. "Yeah, I know. You’re right. But it’s not that, I just– my whole family is here tonight, and they haven’t ever seen me do…anything like this before. It’s not like I have any, problems, or anything… with them, it just…feels…"  She wasn’t sure how to finish that thought.  Jenny grabbed Quinn’s hands. She felt a warmth in Jenny’s fingers, less like sunshine, more like a bonfire. Their eyes locked together.

"Quinn. How long have we been rehearsing for this play? Three months? Four?" "Four and a half. And you don’t have to remind me." "Alright, four and a half months, at three days a week, plus every day for the past two weeks, gives…a long time. And what percentage of that was your family here for?" "Uhh…none."

"None! So here’s what you’re going to do tonight. You will get on that stage. You will act. You will sing. You will win the hearts of the audience. And you will do it the exact same way you’ve been doing it for the last four and a half months. For yourself. This whole play thing is something that you, Quinn Harper, are doing for you, and because of you. Anyone who so happens to see it will love it–your family, me, the judges, the president of the United States, if he’s here. But the work you put in wasn’t for them. It was for you. And it was damn good work. All you have to do tonight is reward yourself." Quinn nodded, her eyes suddenly misty. She wished she could listen to Jenny talk all night.  The moment abruptly ended when Mr. Abrams moved to the center of the room and bellowed, "Actors, in your seats!" Jenny stood up, hugged Quinn, and left the room. Why couldn’t she just follow her and play violin tonight?

As the last of the finely dressed high schoolers took their assigned seats, Mr. Abrams continued to shout. Quinn, sitting directly in front of him, bore the full brunt of his elevated voice.  "Alright everyone, listen up! As soon as I am done talking, I need everyone to be in their places in five. Understood?" In sync, the actors responded, "Thank you, places in five." The director continued, in a slightly more palatable tone. "This is my tenth show at Fillmore High. And this is the tenth closing morning that I have woken up with a terrible pit in my stomach, because I can’t imagine getting up tomorrow and not going to work on our show. And that is a testament to everyone sitting here, from our fantastic dancers in the back to our leads up front."

Although a few of the boys in the ensemble were busy wrestling on the top riser, the vast majority of students paid close attention to Mr. Abrams’ words. A wave of earnest applause filled the room. Though he was being a bit corny, Quinn knew the old drama director loved his job more than anything else.  "First, I want all of our seniors to stand up." Chairs shuffled across the room. Most of the students in Quinn’s row stood up. "I have done my best to get to know everyone standing this past year. I wish I had more time with every last one of you, but I know that no matter what happens and where you all go, great things lie ahead in the future." More applause, even more raucous than the first round.

"Now, I want you to keep standing if you’ve been in the theater program all four years." Around half of the seniors in the room sat down. No one in Quinn’s row moved a muscle.  "You guys–" Mr. Abrams tried vainly to suppress emotion. This was not unlike him, but even the rowdy boys at the back of the room paused their scuffling to listen. "Absolutely mean the world to our program and to me. You all remember Grease, your freshman year?" The standing seniors nodded and smiled. "We’ve come a long way since then. And the credit belongs to you. This green room, and that auditorium, will always be open to you." There was some sentimental silence.

Mr. Abrams took a composing breath. "Alright, alright. Enough with that. We still have one more show to do. New Jersey state adjudicators are in attendance tonight, but I don’t want anyone to overact. Yesterday was as close to a perfect run as I thought we’ve ever come. Let’s do it one more time. Alright?" Some more assorted howling and cheering. There was a rush of young actors standing to leave, and the band director poked his head in the room, presumably to say something to Mr. Abrams. With a single flourish of his intimidatingly large hand, however, he restored order in the room and spoke one more time.  "One last thing. My assistant directors and I took a risk this year– one that I wasn’t sure you all would be receptive to. We’ve never had an underclassman– let alone, a freshman– be our leading lady for any musical I’ve been a part of. But everyone in this room supported her, and brought it every day to help her, and I think you’d all agree–" he looked directly at Quinn– "that she was the right young woman for the job." The room went wild. Quinn’s face absolutely boiled. Some of the high school boys behind her slapped her on the back.

"Come on, Quinn, stand up!" said Mr. Abrams, the corners of his mouth pulling upwards, feeding on the energy of the room.  She obliged. Her head felt like it was filled with helium gas. The actors continued to shout and applaud as she turned around to look at them sheepishly. Then, she noticed Alex, who sat next to her, stand up as well. He played James, the male lead– a junior, he was tall and muscular, and looked and acted much like a Prince Charming even when he wasn’t wearing his medieval-style Sunday best.  He turned to her, and with an air of bravado, whispered to her amidst the chaos: "Practice, for later."

In an instant, he grabbed her waist with one hand, the back of her head with the other, and pressed his lips to hers. The noise in the room, already deafening, must have tripled. Quinn went from beet red to a ghostly white. Not a single thought or emotion won out in her head. Alex’s face took up the entirety of her vision. The moment only lasted a few seconds, but Quinn could have sworn that she stood in that spot kissing Alex for days.  The next scenes blurred together in her mind. Mr. Abrams tossing his hands in the air in surprise. Students running out of the room, to their places, some shouting at her, all talking about her. There must have been whispers behind her back. What were they saying? What was she going to do?

As she stood on stage, behind the rising curtain, she found it hard to breathe. Her body had taken her to her spot, sure. But that was just instinct. There was no room left for art. She was going to fold, right there, in front of everyone. Her lines, and her performance, had utterly vacated her mind. The music started. The music. Jenny was down in the pit somewhere, rooting for her. In a moment of desperate brilliance, Quinn slid her to the forefront of her consciousness. The trick was easy, as she’d had much practice with it over the past few months. Jenny was next to her, about to give her a note. She was backstage, adjusting the lighting, or grabbing costumes. She was in the audience, with one thousand clones of herself, waiting to clap and whistle and laugh along with every beat of the show.  Quinn pretended nothing had happened, for one pivotal moment, and found only Jenny, and what she had said back in the green room. Something amazing happened. She started to move. She performed.

She was a headstrong peasant’s wife who, after falling for a nobleman, vowed to leave her abusive husband and woo her real love interest. After stealing a gown to wear to a formal ball, she confesses her love to the nobleman, who loves her back, thinking her to be wealthy as well. When her husband finds out what she has done, he nearly kills her in a fit of drunken rage, but the nobleman kills him before he can deal her a final blow. As she lays there, dying in the nobleman’s arms, he uses the power of love to bring her back from the dead. Quinn knew that the play was derivative, oddly paced, and potentially problematic thematically. But Mr. Abrams’ wife had written it, Mr. Abrams loved it, and Quinn was determined to put on a show.  Tonight, she was Judy, wife of Nicholas, and secret admirer of James. She was Judy because it was too difficult to be Quinn. And she was a great Judy. The play went by quickly. She found herself laying there, in the last scene of the play, covered in fake blood, breathing her last breaths in James’s arms.

"James–there is still so much left to say–" "And you will get to say it all! Just hold on a moment longer, please–" "James– I– l–" A tear rolled down Judy’s cheek as her eyes turned to glass. James gave heavy, deep sobs.

"My dazzling light dulled far too soon! My star, my angel! Judy, I love thee!" Alex’s lips touched Quinn’s. Her eyes flew open and she sat up. She was alive again. She knew her next lines by heart. But there was no air in her lungs with which to say them.  In fact, there was no air in the whole auditorium. Every muscle in her body tensed. She was dying.

The eyes of every member of the audience bore into her. Everyone, every living soul in that building, was waiting for her to give them something. But she didn’t have it. In fact, it was she that needed their help.  She shook her head, and tried to call to her parents, to scream, to break free of Alex’s grasp, to do anything. But she was frozen. And everyone else, with eyes trained directly at her, was frozen in place as well.  She started to sweat. She had mere seconds left before she was going to black out. Noise rattled in her head. Who was making that noise? What was happening?  "Quinn! QUINN!"

Ty stood over her, his face wracked with fear.  ./. Quinn shot upright in her bed. Her clothes were damp from sweat, and her lungs burned as though she’d just run a marathon. She looked at Ty through bloodshot eyes. "Oh, shit," she said, breathing heavily. "How bad was I?"

Ty was frantic. "How bad were you? I mean, I’ve had nightmares, but nothing like that. You…you were mumbling at first, but then you were talking. It was nonsense words, I couldn’t make anything out, but you sounded so scared. And then, all of a sudden, you were fighting your sheets, and moaning, and I was pretty sure you were being visited by some supernatural…I don’t know. So I stood up, and then you stopped breathing! Coughing, choking–I didn’t know what to do! Then I started yelling, and I was about to fucking shake you awake, but… I didn’t have to." Quinn rested her head back on her pillow. It, too, was wet.  "So, pretty bad." "I’d say."

Quinn sighed. "I’ve always had crazy nightmares, ever since I was little. I’ve seen every sleep specialist in New Jersey for them, but nothing seems to help."  "So this just happens to you?" asked Ty, incredulously. "Well, they’ve always come and gone, but recently, they’ve been worse than ever, probably because of…" "...Everything?" Ty offered.

"Yeah. Everything."  The two shared a quiet moment in the dank motel room. The world weighed heavily on Quinn this morning. She had never felt so far from home; so disconnected from the life she led.  "It’s nothing, though. Look, I’m sorry. I should have warned you that I don’t sleep well. I guess I was just hoping that somehow–" "Q. I–We–have more important things to worry about." He looked at the cheap alarm clock on the nightstand. "It’s almost six. Do you want to leave a little early? Maybe we can bail before anyone comes to kill us for watching that tape last night."

Quinn didn’t find that to be a particularly funny joke, and judging by Ty’s delivery of the line, he didn’t, either. "Alright. I’m gonna need a minute to shower, though." ./. They were on the road before long. Ty volunteered to take the first driving shift again, even though Quinn could see in his eyes that the previous night– or maybe the rush of that morning– had taken its toll on him.

As they drove, Quinn stared out the window. Farms, gentle hills, and occasional tree cover comprised the landscape. The last of the morning’s dew reflected gently off of the crops and the grass.  Perhaps it was the emptiness of the Sunday morning highway, or the monotony of rural midwest America. Perhaps it was the guilt she felt for scaring Ty, or the plain fact that they were a day closer to whatever they may find in Colorado. But the silence in the car was deafening.  Quinn, who even still didn’t feel much like talking, turned to Ty. "Hey, would you mind if I turned on the radio?"

Ty jumped up at the sound of her voice, as though he had received a small shock. "Mmm? Oh, go ahead." She turned the dial around, and found her mother’s favorite station.  Her mother. Where was she? Quinn pulled out her phone, and looked at the texts she sent her over the past day. No response. The knot in her chest tightened.

So much had happened since Friday, and she knew so little. All she had were a few messages from an unknown number and a VHS tape, stashed in the trunk of their car. They drove on through the morning. Unfortunately, Anna’s favorite radio station only played from a selection of about eight songs, so when Sleazy Love Song by Insufferable Artist looped for a third time, Quinn had had enough.  When she reached for the dial, Ty jumped again, and jerked the car to the right. Fortunately, the other lane of the highway was still as empty as ever. "Jesus, Ty, are you alright?"

Ty rubbed his eyes. "Me? No, no, I’m fine. Uh, sorry about that." Quinn changed the station. Three very loud, vulgar men talked boisterously through waves of faint static. "...You know, Dukes, I would! I really would." "This guy! Can you believe it?"

"I can’t. Taz, are you cooking chicken over there? Cause that’s all I can smell." "No! Let me put this on record. Dukes is the worst golfer I have ever–" "But how the fuck are you gonna prove–?" "Will you let me finish? The worst golfer I have ever met. Swear to God. And I’d put a hundred on that every day of the week–"

"THEN WHY DON’T YOU?" "I’M TELLING YOU! I am in husband jail. Big boy timeout. The doghouse, whatever you want to call it." "What the fuck are you talking about?" "Let’s see…the wife wasn’t too happy about last week, Dusty…"

Uproarious laughter. They were completely insufferable. They aired their grievances about their wives, they talked over each other about a football player, and they bragged about the drunkest they had ever been in college. Finally, when they started debating which was the best part of the female anatomy, Quinn shut the radio off altogether.  "Men," she muttered, without even thinking.  Ty laughed. "Yeah," he said. "Most of us." Quinn looked at him, and spoke with more bite than she had possibly intended.

"Let me guess. Not you, though. Right?"         He smiled. "Me? No, I was raised proper. My parents always taught me…oh, wait. My parents didn’t teach me anything. They bailed as soon as they saw me." Ty, ever the king of wit around Quinn, delivered his last sentence deadpan. She gave a pitying smile. She wasn’t really sure how to react.

He saw that he made her uncomfortable and winced. "Ah- sorry. That was, like, twenty years ago. And they left me lots of college money. I’m over it." Quinn gave a small chuckle. She’d gotten to know Ty for a few months now, and understood that he rarely, if ever, talked about his family. She had no idea he had been on his own for that long.  He tried to change the subject through a semi-stifled yawn. "Hey, we’re almost halfway there. Did you want to take over soon?" "Sure. We can switch at the next exit."

With the radio off, the silence was even harsher than before.  Before long, they were back on the road again, Quinn now behind the wheel. Ty positioned his headrest as far back as it could go, and turned to his side.  "Hey Q?" he asked. "Mmm?" replied Quinn, who was looking over her shoulder to merge back onto the highway.

"I have to ask you one question before I fall asleep." "Go ahead." "What do you dream about? When you have your nightmares. I just want to avoid them, if possible." Quinn pursed her lips. Ty was back.

"Well, sometimes they’re pretty standard. Falling, being chased, getting my teeth punched out, that kind of thing. But there’s one recurring dream that I have–" "Recurring? That can, like– really happen?" "Yes, Ty. People have recurring dreams. But mine is more like a recurring… memory." Ty listened as raptly as anyone who so clearly looked to be about to fall asleep ever could.

She continued. "You went to Piscataway High, right? And it’s relatively close to Rutgers?" Ty nodded. "There’s probably a good chance your local news station picked it up, then. Not like anybody really watches that–" "My stepmom did!" interjected Ty. "She had that crap on every night, as long as I knew her. Channel 8, six to seven. I never really paid attention, though."

"Ah. Okay. Well, it was my freshman year at Fillmore. I was in our school’s musical. And I…passed out, right on the stage." Ty frowned. "You were in a musical? Like, singing?" She nodded. "Yep. They told me I was the first freshman to ever be a lead in a Fillmore musical. That might be why stupid Channel 8 wanted to cover the story so badly." Her voice had fallen to a mutter.

"Well, what– happened?" asked Ty, timidly. She sighed, and told the story, as she had so many times, to so many people and professionals alike.  "I don’t know for sure. It was the last scene of closing night, and I had felt completely fine before then. There must have been five minutes left of the play. But all of a sudden, right there, at the end, the walls started to close in. And I stopped breathing. It wasn’t like I forgot how, or anything, but it felt like there was just no air in the auditorium. And, so, instead of giving my last few lines, I was out. Completely. I don’t remember any of it, but apparently paramedics had to run onto the stage, and I ended up going to the hospital. They asked me some questions, they ran some tests, but they couldn’t figure out what was wrong with me. They told me it was probably stress-related, but…I don’t know." Ty was silent for a moment, thinking. Finally, he said, "Do you think it was because you were dreading the end? Of the musical, I mean. Some of the theater kids that I knew in high school didn’t show up to school the day after closing night because they were too emotional. Or, too hungover from the cast party. One of the two."

Quinn laughed. Somehow, he could always get her to laugh.  "I’m not sure. I don’t think it was necessarily…" Her gaze seemed to drift through the open highway in front of her. For a moment, she was completely lost in the memory of that night at Fillmore. But she quickly came out of it. "All I know is that night was definitely the end of my theater career."

A pause. "I’m sorry that you have to relive that so often, Q." "It could be worse. At least I don’t have to be back in ninth grade again every time the dream ends." Ty nodded, and rolled over. It looked like his fatigue would finally overcome him. Quinn started her new playlist of songs. It was not long before she heard Ty’s snores from the passenger seat.

*        *        * Quinn shuffled across the parking lot. Her knees ached, her ears rang, and her head buzzed. But she couldn’t stand to feel sorry for herself while she was looking at Maeve. "That was unbelievable! They were so tight live! I mean, even more so than on their albums. It was incredible!" Her face glowed bright orange under the streetlight.  "Yeah, that was pretty cool. I could barely tell what was going on half the time," admitted Quinn as she stepped into the car.

"Yeah, they’re pretty fluid with things like time signatures and scales. But they’re always together. It’s almost…conversational? I mean, they’re totally better live. It’s like you can hear them thinking while they’re playing. And then the improv section! Holy crap!" Quinn smiled. She loved when her sister lit up like this.  "Yeah, that was pretty wild." "And Dylan! Oh my God, he was so good!"
"Dylan? The singer? Maeve, he was probably on stage for twenty minutes." "Well…I still thought he was good." "Mmmm…you thought he was handsome." "Maybe," said Maeve, sheepishly. "He can be both."

They turned out of the parking lot. There was a long row of stationary cars waiting for the stoplight at the end of the road. Quinn turned to her sister. "So, Dylan. I mean, why him?" Maeve looked back. "What?" "Why Dylan? Why don’t you have a crush on, I don’t know, one of the two other much more talented members of the band?"

Maeve sighed. "You are so awkward, Quinn." She laughed. "Come on. We’re gonna be waiting at this light forever." Maeve gave another sigh, this one even more exasperated than the last.  "Alright. But what I’m telling you is a secret, and it will not leave this car. Alright?"

Quinn nodded. "Alright." "It’s, uh…the curly hair. I like guys with curly hair. That’s it." "Okay. So…that might explain the sudden interest in the Jonas Brothers? Even though you said two years ago that you hated their music?" "...Yes."
"Hmmm. Justin Timberlake?" "He’s alright." Quinn thought. "Let me see…uh…the old guy who hosts that radio show. Howard Stern?" They both burst into laughter.

As they slowly approached the light, and as Quinn ran out of curly-haired celebrities to name, the car grew quiet. Then, Maeve turned to her older sister.  "Alright. I told you my type. Now you have to tell me yours." "Huh?" "Come on. This is an equal partnership. Your type, please."

Quinn shot her a glance. "You know, I wouldn’t be so demanding of the only person in the world who can get you home safely right now." "What happens in the car, stays in the car. Alright? Plus, it doesn’t really matter anyway. It’s not like I’ve seen you even… hold anyone else’s hand, ever." "Maeve–" "I’m just messing around. But really. Of the three guys we saw tonight. Who’s your f–"

"Do you want to sleep in the auditorium tonight?" "Answer the question! Which Pinky Meteor member is it gonna be?" Little sisters, thought Quinn. They always knew what buttons to push, but never when to stop pushing.  "Uh– no. Not my type. Any of them."

Maeve frowned. "Well, what’s your type, then?" Exasperation leaked out of Quinn’s voice.  "Can we please drop this?" At last, the sisters reached the stoplight, and turned onto an on-ramp. Quinn’s eyes were locked on the road, so she couldn’t see Maeve respond to her, but she heard an unmistakable change in her tone.

"No. I want to hear your answer." Quinn sped up the car. The highway was congested with traffic, so she looked closely for an open spot to merge.  "Ok…umm…" An opening! There it was, right in front of her. She’d have to move quickly to get to it, though.

"Ahhh…I–" She pressed the gas pedal down to the floor, ready to pass an oncoming car. The sudden jolt of speed proved completely unnecessary, however, when she watched the approaching car tap its brakes gently to let her in. She waved shakily to the other car’s driver, and shifted lanes onto the highway. She turned to her younger sister and spoke evenly.  "Maeve, I’m gay."

Maeve looked at her, thought for a moment, and replied softly.  "Okay. That’s not a type, though." Quinn laughed through sobs that she really wished she could control. It took every ounce of focus for her to keep the two of them on the road. Eventually, she took a few deep breaths and smiled, her face flushed and wet with tears. "I don’t know. Brunettes?"

"Brunettes. How about Emma Watson? I always thought she was pretty." Quinn nodded. "Yeah. I think so, too." "Jennifer Lawrence? Scarlett Johanssen?" "Both, sure. But I think I like Scarlett better blonde."

The two made their way home. Maeve was much better at listing brunette celebrities than Quinn was at listing curly-haired ones. They laughed and debated until they had pulled back into their own driveway. Quinn shut the car off. As she reached for the door handle to let herself out, Maeve interjected. "Hey, Quinn? Thanks, for being honest. And, you know, for going to the concert with me." Quinn looked at her sister. Someone was sitting there next to her, someone who had heard the words she’d always meant to say, someone who had only existed in her mind for years. She almost couldn’t believe that someone was real.
"I love you, Maeve." "I love you too, Quinn." *        *        * The car’s subtle jostling on the gravel parking lot was just enough to wake Ty.

He opened his eyes slowly, and glanced at Quinn. She was quietly listening to a song playing over the stereo. She noticed his movement, and turned the music down. "Welcome back." Ty reached into his pocket and pulled out his phone. The harsh light made him squint. It was already almost 10 o’clock. "Shit, I’m sorry. I didn’t mean to be out that long," he said, groggily.

"Don’t worry about it. We’re here." Quinn brought the car to a stop. In front of them was a towering building, with the words "Residence Inn" plastered in neon lights at the top. Although it was getting late, a family spoke outside the hotel’s entrance, and busboys wheeled large dollies filled with luggage in and out of the lobby.  Quinn opened her door, and slowly stood up. Two consecutive days of driving had not treated her body well.  Leaning against the car, she stretched her legs as best as she could.  Ty emerged from the passenger’s side. He took in the mild night for a melancholy moment, and walked over to Quinn.

"Are you ready?" She felt for her phone in her pocket, and looked up at the night sky. They weren’t far from downtown Denver, so most of the stars were hidden despite the fact that it was a clear night. Light pollution, her father had told her long ago. Near cities, it was almost impossible to get a good look at the constellations. How she wished, tonight of all nights, she could have found some comfort from the heavens.  She responded to the text she had gotten this time last night in the same way as last night. And, just as before, she and Ty did not have to wait long for a response.

Ask for VIP access at the front desk. We’ll be expecting you at 5:30 tomorrow morning.    A silent moment passed between the two travelers. They were less than eight hours from the end of their journey.

Quinn opened the trunk and grabbed her bag, and Ty did the same. Quinn couldn’t help but notice that her bag seemed to weigh much more on her shoulder than it had on Friday.  They made their way across the parking lot and entered the hotel lobby. It could not have been more different than the reception area at the motel. The floor and walls were made of marble, an ornate fountain gently bubbled in the center of the room, and three well-dressed employees manned the front desk. Soft jazz played quietly from overhead speakers, and men in expensive suits walked past them, talking and laughing amongst themselves.  Suddenly, Quinn, in her plaid button-down shirt and old denim jeans, felt a bit out of place. She hurried her way up to the front desk.  "Room for two, please. And, um…we’ll have the VIP package–"

"Certainly, ma’am. One moment, please." The young woman typed on her keyboard for a moment. Quinn’s eyes wandered. Was anyone watching them? Listening to them? A handful of people lingered in the lobby, but as far as she could tell, no one was giving them a second glance.  "You’re all set! It will be room eleven-sixteen, and the elevator is just past this desk and to your right. If you need anything, you can call the desk at any point. Although…" She looked at her computer screen. "It seems as though you two have indicated that you’ll be checking out early tomorrow morning. Is that correct?" Quinn nodded. Were they even going to have to pay? Or give their names?

"Alright! Here’s the key. Enjoy your stay!"  Quinn grabbed the key and turned toward Ty. He stood behind her, shoulders slumped, eyes blankly forward, examining the hotel’s logo printed on the desk. She grabbed his hand and led him toward the elevator.  That seemed to wake him up a bit. He jogged behind her, squeezing his hand in hers. As they stepped into the elevator, Quinn pulled her hand back and spoke to him.  "Are you okay? You’ve basically been asleep all day."

He shook his head. "I’m fine. I told you already–" "Yeah, and your hand was about a million degrees." She reached for his forehead. He recoiled at first, but ultimately relented.  "Oh my God, Ty, you’re burning up! When were you gonna tell me?" "Q, we–you– have more important things to worry about."

"They had Tylenol right next to the desk! I can go back and get some. Jesus, you should have said something earlier." He nodded. "Thanks, Q." "It’s fine…just…don’t go all superhero on me, ok? If something is wrong, you can’t keep it to yourself." He sighed. "I’m an open book if you’re an open book. Okay?"

At that moment, the elevator reached the eleventh floor, and the doors glided open. Moving silently, the two walked to their room.  Quinn went to open the door, but stopped herself. Her hands were shaking, and her pulse sounded in her ears. With fragmented breath, she put her bag down on the floor, unzipped it, and reached for the steak knife inside. She stored it inside of her jeans on her left hip, and pulled her shirt down to conceal it.  Ty looked at her frantically. She put her finger to her lips.  Quinn removed the key card from her other pocket and unlocked the door with a small click. She opened the door slowly, and reached directly for the light switch.

Nothing. It was a normal hotel room. The bathroom door, halfway open, was directly to their left, and two king-sized beds sat perfectly made in front of them.  The blood began to come back to Quinn’s extremities. Ty closed the door behind them, and addressed her. "Um. What was that?" "What was what?"

"The knife! Did you think someone was gonna be in here?" "I don’t know! Did you know for sure that no one was gonna be in here?" "Well– no– but didn’t you just tell me not to be a superhero? That was, like, right out of an action movie." "Ty, I’m just trying to keep us safe–"

"Quinn. Have you ever used a knife before? A weapon? And don’t you think that if this…person…organization…whoever, wanted to kill us, they would have done it in that shitty motel?" Quinn sat down on her bed. "Um– You’re right. I wasn’t thinking straight. We’re just…so close now, and if…" She didn’t finish the thought. Ty walked over and sat down on his bed.  "Oh, sorry," muttered Quinn. She reached into her bag and found the medication she packed. She handed Ty the pills. He nodded his thanks, and made his way to the bathroom.

Quinn lied down and put her head down on the pillow. She did not feel tired. In fact, she wasn’t sure how she would fall asleep after such an unsettling day, which itself lurked in the ominous shadow of tomorrow.  She turned to face Ty’s bed. She hoped he was alright. It must have been burdensome enough for him, traveling for two days to protect her. But to do it now with a fever?  As she thought, her eyes wandered around the room, as they often did. She looked from the overpriced water bottle on the desk next to the large, mounted television to the hypnotizing wallpaper and landed on the travel brochure folded on the nightstand in between the two beds.  It certainly advertised Denver well. Enthusiastic young people hiked, rode bicycles, and stared in amazement at various aquatic animals on the front cover. But Quinn wasn’t staring at that. Past the brochure, and tucked neatly away behind the alarm clock, was an old camcorder, with a memory card stacked on top.

"Ty?" she called out. This couldn’t be a coincidence. This camera had to be for them.  He opened the bathroom, toothbrush in mouth and face dripping cold water. "Mmhmm?" She showed him the camera. His eyes widened, and he ran back to the sink to spit. Quinn opened the device, and put in the memory card. The pit in her stomach returned as she navigated to the only video saved on the card.  Ty came back into the room, and sat next to her. He leaned in to see the screen, which could not have been more than four or five inches long.

Quinn played the video. It depicted the same room from the VHS video, with dazzling white walls and a two-way mirror. This time, however, someone was recording the room from the inside with the camcorder.  The unsteady shot panned to the mirrored wall, and the identity of the cameraman was revealed. She was short and fair-skinned, with medium-length blond hair. She wore a lab coat over a suit and dress pants, and could not have been older than thirty.  The door opened. The ginger-haired girl from last night’s tape strode into the room. The camera followed her every calculated movement. There was no mistaking it this time. The girl was Maeve.  She kept her eyes trained forward as she walked in what looked like a conscious effort to ignore the young man. When she reached the wall opposite the mirror, she turned around and sat down with her knees to her chest and her back against the wall.

A voice, over the loudspeaker, rang out. "Location attempt one, 3-25-23."  The camera swung back to the door next to the mirror to capture a thin older woman stepping confidently into the room. She wore long black heels that clicked with every step, and dragged an old television on a cart behind her, much like the one Ty and Quinn found in the motel.  She stopped a few feet in front of Maeve, and pressed the power button on the television. The cameraman stood behind the woman, so it was impossible to tell what was playing, but it was clear that Maeve did not want to watch. She kept staring forward, refusing to acknowledge that anything or anyone else was in the room with her.  The woman turned around to give the camera a scowl. Then, she spoke to Maeve. "I’m giving you thirty seconds to find him," she croaked.

Finally, Maeve looked up at her. It was hard to tell exactly what was going on in her face, but it appeared as though for one moment, she projected every ounce of hatred that she had at the woman. Quinn knew that look well.  Though her sister didn’t give it often, when she did, the recipient always deserved it.  Maeve’s eyes went to the television.  Nothing happened. No one moved. For the next short while, the video was so still that it may have been paused. Something must have been happening, though, because before long, another man could be heard running into the room.

"She’s got him! Please, Dorothy, will you shut that off?" The camera turned to him. It was Quinn’s father, tall, well dressed, and clean-shaven. She nodded, and hit the power button. Maeve still wasn’t moving. Her father crouched down to say something to her, but it was too quiet to hear on the video. As he pulled her up and into an unreciprocated embrace, the voice rang out over the loudspeaker. "Results pending for attempt one." The video cut.

./. Quinn held the camera shakily. She had been mostly sure before, but now it was undeniable. This was her family on these tapes. And whoever was texting her had to be  connected to her poor sister in some way. Ty reached around Quinn and put his hand on her shoulder. She tensed up. He pulled his hand back, pretending as though he spotted a piece of lint on her shirt.  Suddenly, the weight of the last two days overwhelmed her. The fog that clouded her mind when they had entered the room re-concentrated, much thicker this time. She snapped the camera closed, and pulled it in close to her chest. Through uncertain breaths, and with eyes straight ahead, she spoke to him.

"Ty, I think I’m losing it." "Wha–Q, no. I know this weekend has been…" "Been what? Batshit crazy? Yeah. I know they’re hurting her. Physically, mentally, I don’t know, I’ve just never seen her like that. But, this tape, it makes no fucking sense. Nothing makes sense anymore. Nothing’s made sense for six months. And I…" She shook her head. "just… sat around, the whole time, and didn’t do anything to find her." She turned to him, eyes vacant. "Ty, my mom is gone! I haven’t heard from her in days! And I think she might have known what was happening, I just couldn’t get her to tell me! And..now…I got you into this mess, too. I’m sorry." She buried her head in her hands. "I’m so sorry."

He took a moment to respond. "Q. Don’t be sorry. If– When– we help your sister, I mean…people go their whole lives without doing something that important. And, more than that, I mean, I–I give a shit about you! Okay? So, let’s figure this thing out. Everything, including finding your mom. Just– let me see the video again." Quinn handed the camera to Ty silently, and laid down on her bed. He spent the next minute or so rewatching the clip. After it had finished, he sighed, and started it again. This time, he stopped it after the voice over the loudspeaker rang out for the first time.  "Hey–Q–the numbers that they say before the woman walks out. Three, twenty-five, twenty-three? That was yesterday’s date, right?"

She nodded. "I guess that would make the VHS tape video…a month old, or so?" Ty smiled, hugely relieved that they had figured something out. "Yes!" He resumed the video, looking everywhere for clues. Quinn was turned away from him, facing the large window that looked out on Denver. Although the heart of the city must have been a few miles away from where they were staying, it was still possible to make out some brightly lit, impossibly tall buildings in the distance. Quinn thought it odd that some people lived forever in a place which always shielded itself from darkness. The glow was almost enough to make her eyes burn, even from her bed, some distance away.  She listened to the video two, then three, then four more times as Ty replayed it in search of more clues. Finally, the noise stopped for a moment. Quinn turned over in her bed. Ty was sound asleep, clutching the camera in his right hand.

She slowly stood up and took it from him. He did not move a muscle.  As she went to get ready for bed, she took a turn at rewatching the video again. Quinn could not push Maeve’s look of utter disdain toward the older woman out of her mind. Sure, she got annoyed sometimes; she was fifteen, after all. Quinn could never hope to count the number of times her younger sister had rolled her eyes at her over the past few years. But Maeve’s look on the camera was much different. Quinn would have never guessed that she was capable of sending so much vitriol to another person just through a gaze. If there was any doubt before, this look confirmed it– something was very wrong at the facility she’d be arriving at tomorrow morning.  She eventually crawled under her covers, and played the video over and over again until her mind grew fuzzy with fatigue. Who was Maeve getting, and how? The attempt was… pending? Was this some psychic test, or something? The questions spun in Quinn’s head until she, too, fell asleep, clutching the camera in her hand.  ./.

It was almost 2:55, and she could not be late. Quinn gave a quick wave of thanks to Mr. Jones, her English teacher, and stuffed her college essay draft into her backpack. As soon as she exited his room, she began to jog. It was a long way– across the whole school and down three flights of stairs, in fact– to the girls’ locker room.  As she ran, students and teachers roaming the halls looked quizzically at her, but she didn’t care. It wasn’t every day that Coach DiAngelo offered one of her players a private lesson, and Quinn wasn’t about to let the opportunity go to waste.  With legs and lungs beginning to burn, she finally reached the locker room’s landing, and pushed open the doors.  Damn it. There was the basketball team, getting ready for practice. The group of eight or nine, already changed into their uniforms, played music from a speaker and talked loudly among themselves. Quinn would have to walk through them to get to her locker.

Most of them pretended not to notice as she contorted her body to sneak past them, but just as she was about to kneel down to open her combination lock, she heard a voice call out over the music.  "Everyone watch out, I think she’s gonna kill someone with that bow for real this time!" Her heart leapt in her throat. It was Sadie. Of course it was Sadie. As the basketball team laughed, she cringed, thinking only about how badly she probably looked–and smelled, from all of that running.  As she swapped her backpack for her bow, she turned around and began to walk back through the team.

"Sorry guys, I would love to, I’m just running a little late today." As she made her way back out of the locker room, she couldn’t help but believe that she heard a few chuckles from the team. Maybe her crappy, spur-of-the-moment joke had landed! It wasn’t really a joke, though. More like an explanation. But maybe Sadie liked it. She hoped Sadie liked it. She really hoped Sadie thought she was funny.  She exited the building and made her way quickly across the soccer field, where her coach had already set up a row of targets at varying distances and a bucket of arrows. As Quinn approached her, she put her hands on her head and spoke through heavy breaths. "I’m sorry…Coach…if I’m late."

Coach DiAngelo checked her watch. "Oh, you’re not late. And Mr. Jones told me you were planning on revising a college application essay with him after school today. So just catch your breath and relax, alright?" Quinn nodded. Her coach had taught her about controlled breathing at their first lesson together, and she knew it to be one of the most important techniques in archery. Very little was controlled about her breathing at the moment. Her coach continued. "You already know that we lost all of last year’s varsity team to graduation, which means you’ll probably have a chance to play in most of our matches this year. So, before the season really starts, I want to get a sense of where you are not only technically, but also mentally. It’s not easy going from shooting with teammates in practice every day to competing against students from other schools, and that’s something I remember learning the hard way when I was your age." "Yes, Coach," responded Quinn.

"So today, I want to see you shoot, but I also want to know what your approach to shooting is like. I want to know what you’re thinking about, to try to help you build a routine that works for you." Quinn frowned, and nodded. She hadn’t done anything like this in her previous two years on the archery team.  "So go ahead and grab an arrow. I want you to take a few shots at the closest target, and let me know when you’re warmed up." She took an arrow, and stood behind the shooting line. She loaded it, took a breath in, squinted her right eye partially shut, and pulled back on the bow with her left hand. The air was completely still.

She fired. The arrow stuck into the target with a dull thud. Seven. She exhaled, and shook her head. She could do better, especially when the wind was as quiet as it was just then.  "Quinn," said her coach. "Watch your elbow angle. Don’t get lazy." "Alright, Coach," she responded.

She pulled another arrow out of the bucket and loaded it. She took a breath in, squinted her right eye, pulled back on the bow, raised her left elbow, and… Five. She was way too high, and had forgotten to account for the slight breeze that had just begun.  "Now don’t think about your elbow. Just make sure it’s right." Quinn was confused. "What?"

"You heard me, Quinn! Don’t think about it." She tried not to think about it, and fired. Eight.  Coach DiAngelo spent the next ninety minutes or so giving Quinn seemingly nonsensical advice, and Quinn spent the time trying to apply it. She shot while thinking about other things, she shot while doing math problems, she shot while talking about her college essay. She shot at targets that were different distances away, she shot under time pressure, and she even took a few shots with her coach’s right-handed bow.  By the end, Quinn had done a bit of laughing and a lot of thinking about archery.

"When you step into your first match this year, you might feel like you’ve never held a bow before," said her coach. "Hopefully I made you feel that way today, and hopefully you figured out that you can work your way through that feeling." Quinn nodded. "For sure! Thank you, Coach. And, um, would you mind if I stayed out here for a while? I can pack all of this up." Her coach thought for a moment, and finally handed her a key. "Sure. The storage room will probably be locked when you’re done, so use this to open it. Make sure you lock back up when you’re done, and you can drop the key off at my office tomorrow morning. Just don’t forget." "I won’t. Thanks, again."

Coach DiAngelo grabbed her bag and began the long walk across the field. Quinn loaded another arrow and pulled back on the bowstring.  Time passed. The sky changed. Even more than the process of firing arrow after arrow, Quinn loved the temporary mental silence that seemed so unobtainable in her daily life. It was just her out there, breathing through shot after shot, with no day behind her and no night ahead of her. It was the same feeling she’d been able to enjoy years ago when she was on stage. She found herself, completely lost in the moment.  It had been a few hours before a light swishing of footsteps through the grass snapped Quinn back to reality. She rolled her shoulders and turned her head to look at who was approaching.  No. It couldn’t be.

Sadie, in her dark red Fillmore High basketball sweatshirt, was walking across the soccer field, right toward her. The Sadie Vazquez, star point guard, was walking toward her. Quinn felt like she’d been waiting all her life for a moment like this. And she still wasn’t ready for it.  With hands trembling, she loaded another bow, pretending that she hadn’t noticed Sadie. Out of the corner of her eye, Quinn saw her stop a few feet behind the shooting line.  She fired at the target, and nearly missed it altogether.

Sadie spoke first. "Hey, aren’t you supposed to aim for the middle?" Quinn turned around to look at her, and immediately felt her face flush.  "Um–well, I’m not exactly Katniss Everdeen, or anything…" A reference! She was already referencing something that Sadie might not have ever heard of. Quinn couldn’t believe herself. Why was she so weird?

Fortunately, Sadie laughed. Quinn chuckled, too. She was having an out-of-body experience.  Quinn continued to speak. "So, uh, how was practice?" Sadie took a second to answer. In their three years at Fillmore together, Quinn hadn’t ever had a conversation with her, but in passing, Saide always seemed to be so confident, so sarcastic, so in control. Was something else going to emerge from under that front?  "Oh, it was fine. You know, I was just wondering, Quinn, since you’re out here all the time…if maybe…you could, try to teach me. How to shoot. Unless, you have to get going, which is fine…"

Quinn felt ready to pass out. Somehow, she formulated a coherent response. "Yeah! Sure, I can do that. I just—I’m a lefty, so it might feel a little off, if you’re not–" "Well, lucky for you, I can shoot from either side." She winked. Quinn nearly choked on her own saliva.  She did her best to remember what her coach had taught her when she was just starting out. She lined Sadie up, told her where to aim and how to hold the bow, and finally gave her an arrow.  "Alright, go ahead," she said, standing behind Sadie.

She released the arrow. It stuck into the ground halfway between the shooting line and the target.  "Well," said Quinn, "I can tell you for sure that you didn’t pull back hard enough." "Yeah, I noticed." Sadie grabbed another arrow and shot again. The bow might have gone two feet further than last time.
"Stay there!" said Quinn. She walked up to Sadie, who still held the grip in her right hand.  "I want you to pull the string back like you were doing before." She pulled it back.

"Now I’m going to show you how far you should be pulling it back." Quinn stood directly behind her and wrapped her left hand around Sadie’s. Together, they pulled the string a few inches further back.  Sadie turned around and looked into Quinn’s eyes. Quinn had seen a lot of people her age that day, that month, that year, at school. Nearly uniformly, their eyes were languid, morose, heavy, fatigued. Behind Sadie’s eyes were toughness, tenderness, honey, spice, wonder, a world parallel to and much more vivid than her own. She could have spent years exploring those eyes.  But Sadie nodded her head, Quinn let go of her hand, and the instant became a memory.

The next arrow that Sadie fired hit the target, but didn’t score any points. She turned around to Quinn, and bowed majestically. Quinn applauded.  Sadie shot a few more times, with varying degrees of success. Finally, when she had recorded her best score yet, a four, she handed the bow back to Quinn.  "I’m tapping out. I want to see you hit some bullseyes." Quinn stepped forward. "Okay. Grab me an arrow, I’ll see what I can do."

Sadie reached for an arrow from the bucket, and ran her finger over the tip.  "Do you think these could do any real damage to someone?" Quinn examined the arrow, and thought. "These crappy school arrows? I don’t know if they’re sharp enough to do anything serious. I’ve cut my fingers just touching my competition arrows, though. Either way, I wouldn’t want to be in front of one to find out." "So, like, if you shot that squirrel over there. You’re saying it probably wouldn’t explode?"

The squirrel in question, which Quinn hadn’t even noticed, sat facing away from them, eating something. It was just past the target they had been shooting at.  Quinn chuckled. "I don’t think it would explode, no. And it would be a minor miracle if I was even able to hit it from here." "Okay," replied Sadie, clearly scheming. "Well, then, I think you should shoot at it." "What?"

"Yeah! Don’t try to kill it, or anything. Just spook it, show it who’s boss." "Sadie, wha–" "Quinn! Come on, it’s got to be more fun than shooting at the same target every day. I want to see that little guy crap itself." She sighed. "You are way more messed up than I thought."

Sadie laughed, but stopped when she saw Quinn raise her bow and point it at the squirrel.  She aimed a pretty generous distance over its head. It kept eating, completely oblivious to what was going on behind it. Quinn squinted her right eye, pulled back with her left hand, and breathed in. Maybe she was aiming too high to properly scare it. At the last moment, she lowered her bow a fraction of an inch.  She fired. The snap of the arrow exiting the bow made the squirrel jump to life and bolt directly away from her.

And right into the path of the projectile. Quinn’s eyes shot open. ./. She reached to her forehead to confirm what she already knew. Her whole body, her clothes, and to some extent, the sheets, were covered with sweat. In fact, she lost so much water that she felt as though she was dying of thirst.

As she walked over to the bathroom, she thought about her dream. It was a memory, but not the one she was used to. Mentally, she hadn’t been in that field, on that day, much at all since it happened. Yet the events in that night’s dream seemed even more vivid to her than those at the theater her freshman year.  After she had gulped two glassfuls of water, she checked the time on her phone. 4:10. She hadn’t slept much more than an hour, but her alarm was set to ring in fifteen minutes. There was no use in trying to go back to bed. The room was dark and still. As Quinn stumbled out of the bathroom and toward her bag to grab a fresh pair of clothes, she could not help but feel that the walls were expanding around her. A hotel room, a labyrinth. This morning, the two seemed indistinguishable. The water stung her skin. She tried to empty her mind, and recount the previous night, but she could not seem to ignore the steady prickle of the high-powered faucet. It was not long before it became too much for her, and she had to exit the shower, wisps of dream still imprinted upon her thoughts.

The air was frigid. How she wished she could refrain from shaking, even for a moment. As she dressed, she slid her knife inside the left side of her pants. As she felt the cold steel against her hip, she searched for warmth in memory. All she found was that helpless squirrel. She walked back into the room. Ty’s phone alarm was ringing, but he was still motionless. Quinn turned on the lamp, and approached him. She heard his breaths, slow, quiet, and raspy.          "Hey," she said, nudging him. "We have to get going."

He rolled over, and opened his eyes halfway. "H–huh?" "Ty, come on. It’s a half hour trip. We’ve got ten minutes." "O–o–okay–" He sat up in bed. Quinn could finally see just how pale he was. He swayed and looked around the room, as though he did not recognize his surroundings.

She stepped back. His squinting, bloodshot eyes trained on her for a moment, and he opened his mouth to speak.  Then, he turned over the side of his bed and vomited.  After he was done, his head fell back and hit the pillow. He wiped his mouth and mumbled, all while breathing those long, raspy breaths.  Quinn felt his forehead. It was even warmer than last night. Panic gripped her.

"Okay, Ty, listen to me for one second," she said with a strained smile on her lips and eyes fixed directly to his. "You’re just gonna stay here for now. I’ll call the reception desk, and they’ll send someone to help. Okay?" He looked at her, but he was miles away. The beginnings of words exited his lips.  "Bu–...No–...Quinn, let—...me–..." She shook her head, and grabbed the telephone on the nightstand. As she looked on the keypad for the reception desk’s number, she heard a rattling noise coming from the bathroom.

She hung the phone up and went to investigate. It was her own mobile phone, buzzing on top of the sink. She had a feeling she knew who was calling. She answered the phone in a shaky voice. "Hello?" The answer was curt, and delivered in a low, quiet, female voice.  "Bring him. Don’t be late."

The woman behind the mysterious text messages hung up the phone before Quinn had any chance to respond.  She put her phone in her pocket and tried to calm down. The morning was moving far too quickly for her.  "Okay," she said, striding back into the room. "Ty, I–" He was dead still, asleep again.

Quinn grabbed his shoes from the edge of the room and wrestled them onto his feet. He winced slightly throughout the process, but didn’t open his eyes.  "Ty, I need you to sit up and come with me. I’m sorry." He groaned. Slowly, and with great effort, he swung his legs over the side of the bed and sat up, shoulders hunched and arms folded. He shook, and his breaths were strained. Quinn, trying to ignore the fact that Ty had just stepped into his own vomit, wrestled one of his arms free and wrapped it around her shoulder. She stood up with him.

Quinn was not a large person. Ty, who worked out regularly and had been a football player in high school, was just as big as he was currently unsteady on his feet. So, as he shuffled out of the hotel room and into the elevator, leaning most of his weight on Quinn, she had to struggle mightily to keep the two of them upright.  Once they had begun their descent, Ty leaned against the wall of the elevator as Quinn massaged her neck muscles.  "Hey–Q–" he began. "Don’t waste your energy, Ty." she said, beginning to feel frantic. "All we have to do is get to the car, okay? Just keep focusing on that."

Ty stared out into the space in front of him.  Once the elevator reached the ground floor, Quinn swung Ty’s arm around her shoulder again and began to guide him through the lobby. An old couple sitting on velvet chairs turned and watched them slowly and awkwardly make their way across the marble floor. One of the employees at the reception desk picked up a phone and yelled to Quinn. "Miss, is everything alright? Should I call an ambulance?" Through heavy breaths, she turned to him and shook her head. She didn’t stop moving.

Finally, they made their way past the ornately carved fountain, out of the building, and across the parking lot, where a few more onlookers gave the pair concerned glances. The sun had not yet peeked over the horizon– it was just as, if not more, dark than when they had arrived the previous night.  Quinn opened the passenger’s side door and dumped Ty into the seat. She then raced around the car, jumped inside, and started it. 5:02. They were running late. She’d have to make up time on the road. She punched in 827 Fairview Road on her phone, and backed out of the parking space, nearly colliding with an oncoming vehicle. Undeterred, she sped out of the lot and toward her destination.  ./.

Quinn’s heart raced as she drove. Anxiously, she glanced down at her GPS’s expected arrival time while speeding down the mostly open highway. It had been 5:34 when she left the hotel. She got it down to 5:32, and then 5:31. As she grew closer, she began to believe that she would make it on time.  She could not even begin to think about what may happen when she got there. She was too concerned with both her driving and the condition of Ty, who had fallen asleep again in the car. She was sure she hadn’t ever seen anyone of such otherwise good health get so sick, so quickly.  Suddenly, just as the GPS’s expected arrival time flashed 5:30, Ty took a heaving breath and opened his eyes, as though caught by a sudden burst of energy.  He turned to her with eyes panicked and lips dry. His mouth quivered for a second before he spoke.
"Quinn–I think—we need to turn around." Her eyes darted to him and then back onto the road. "What?" "I’m s–so cold. I think–I think I need– help." Quinn felt a chill run down her spine.

"Ty, we’re so close! Less than ten minutes away! Just hold on—" He slumped back in his chair, asleep again. Quinn slammed her foot on the gas pedal.  As she finished the drive, she listened closely for Ty’s breathing. It was increasingly quiet and shallow.  In the last few days Quinn had pictured, in a best case scenario, that she and Ty would arrive at the building quietly; Maeve and her father would walk out and hop right into the car; and they would be driving off instantly, just as quickly as they had arrived. She had always thought they would need to enter and exit quietly, perhaps parking in an obscured space, and leaving without contacting anyone suspicious.

In reality, when she finally arrived through the miles of dense forest, she skidded into the suspiciously empty parking lot, slammed on the brakes directly in front of the entrance of the building, and pulled on the front door’s handle. It was locked. She banged on the glass door, and shouted. "HELLO? WE NEED HELP! HELLO?" No one answered. She turned back to look at Ty. His face was turning blue. She had to do something.

She frantically scoured the ground for a loose brick or a rock to throw. Nothing seemed heavy enough to break the glass.  Instinctively, she tapped her pockets. All she had was her phone, her wallet, her car keys, and… Her knife.  She pulled it out and held it pointing downward in her left hand. She stepped up to the door, brought the knife back, and swung with all of her might.

She felt the tip of the knife skid across the glass and snap. A huge chunk of steel ricocheted directly backward and missed lodging itself into her skull by a matter of inches. All she had managed to do was give the glass a healthy scratch.  She looked at the knife. Maybe half of the blade had broken off. It was more like a dagger now.  She came up with an idea.  She flipped the dagger around and grabbed it so that its handle was pointing downward. Her bottom two fingers dug into the serrated blade and dripped scarlet. Ignoring this, she swung the handle at the door, directly where she had made the scratch.
The glass shattered with a magnificent crash.    PART 2

Mr. Lin raised his baton. The violins, shrill and out-of-tune, came in first. As they played, a percussionist’s phone chimed in a key wholly irreconcilable with that of the piece. The atonal interruption and the inventive time signatures the strings were managing to perform in combined to create a musical experience that would have made Frank Zappa proud.

The only issue was that they were trying to play Stravinsky.  Mr. Lin waved for the band to stop playing, and all of the ensemble’s eyes rose to him. "Okay, that was closer! Violins, let’s take another minute or two to really get this section down." He bent forward and began talking to the five violin players seated directly in front of him.

Maeve’s eyes scanned the rest of the ensemble. Most looked down at their phones, while a few stared off into space. As usual, orchestra rehearsal was turning into a violin sectional.  Alexa sat next to her, eyes trained on the paper in front of her. It was wrinkled and folded, even though they had only been using it a few weeks.  "Hey– Maeve–" she whispered. Maeve turned. She knew what type of question was coming next.

Alexa pointed at a spot on the page. "Is this a– um– F flat?" Maeve’s suspicions were confirmed.  "No, that’s a D flat. Remember, all cows eat grass." Alexa counted the spaces on the bass clef. "All…cows…oh. Okay. Thanks."

"And just so you know, F flat is enharmonically the same as an E, so you probably wouldn’t see it written out that way much. Except, of course, when–" "Not interested." She smiled, and shrugged. "Just trying to help." "You know how you can help me, you dork? By writing the names of these stupid D flats or whatever on my music."

"Like, in words?" "No, in hieroglyphs." With a glance at Mr. Lin, Maeve stole the crumpled sheet from Alexa’s stand. She clicked her pen and wrote the names of every D flat on the page, an act which seemed to her both demeaning and sacreligious.  She could not help but giggle to herself as she put the tattooed sheet back on her friend’s stand.

Seeming not to notice, Alexa spoke without removing her gaze from the front of the room.  "Hey, do you think we're going to have to play again before we go?" Maeve looked up at the clock. "There's no way he ignores us for the next ten minutes. We’ve already been sitting around forever." "Do you want to bet?"

Maeve sighed. "You and your bets, Alexa." "Come on! Ten minutes. If we pick up our bows to play before then, you win. If we don't, then I win. Loser has to volunteer to go first at the talent show." Maeve nodded resolutely. "Alright, you're on."  Alexa confidently sat back in her chair and pulled out her phone. Maeve tried to listen in to what Mr. Lin was saying to the violins.

"Oh! Um-- yes, Gary, that's the right string, good. And you're going to want to hold your instrument against your chin, like this--" It looked like most of the section hadn't ever touched a violin before today. And Mr. Lin, ever patient, was going to give them every ounce of attention they needed. Three minutes passed. Then three more. Maeve's eyes wandered around the band room as she began to come to terms with the inevitable outcome of her bet. Cheesy motivational posters hung from the walls, instruments lay scattered and damaged on the floor, and one of the lights on the ceiling flickered every so often. It wasn't exactly what she had been hoping for from a high school-level orchestra. Finally, time was up, and Mr. Lin was just as engaged with the violins as ever. Alexa shot a smug look at Maeve and raised her hand.

Mr. Lin, upon seeing it, seemed to emerge from a deep reverie. He looked down at his wristwatch and nearly jumped out of his own skin.  "Oh! Alexa! I'm sorry, I lost track of time. Everyone performing in the talent show today can pack up and proceed to the auditorium." A few students, including Maeve and Alexa, stood up from their seats and headed toward their lockers. As Maeve carefully lowered her cello into its case, Alexa approached her.
"Better get going if you want to be first." "I hate you." Alexa smiled and waved as she triumphantly walked away.  -------------------------------------------

Maeve made her way to the auditorium through empty hallways. Stupid Alexa, she thought. Why did she make that bet? And why did I even take it? She opened a backstage door and saw a man typing away on a laptop. "Hey, Mr. Abrams." He turned around. "Oh, hey, Maeve! You're here for the talent show, I presume?"

She nodded.  "That's great! You know, I've actually been meaning to talk to you. How's your first month of high school been?" She shrugged. "Alright. It's...not really what I expected." He frowned thoughtfully. "Yeah, I remember starting high school. It was-- well, it was a long time ago, but it wasn't how I expected it to be either."

She nodded again, and he continued. "Anyway, I know that theater was what really got me out of my shell when I was your age. Lots of like-minded people, all working together to do something great. And the costumes, too. Those were cool." A shameless plug. Maeve knew what was coming.  "I just think that you would fit in really well as a part of the theater program. I know you haven't signed up to audition for the musical, but you've still got two weeks, and we'd love to see you come in."

Maeve decided to answer diplomatically. "I'll think about it." "Will you? Great! Just sleep on it this weekend, and if you decide to audition, I can get you the script on Monday. Alright?" "Okay. Thanks, Mr. Abrams. And, um--" she spoke through a wince-- "could you ask Principal Mills if I could go first this afternoon?" He thought for a second. "Sure, I can ask. Just-- say hello to Quinn for me, alright?"

"I will."  Mr. Abrams exited the backstage area. It was dark in the room, and props from previous years' musicals littered the hardwood floor. She stepped around them carefully and navigated to the spot where she had dropped off her guitar that morning.  She opened the latches on the case and pulled it out. It was an old guitar, the one she bought years ago when she first decided to learn how to play. She had the strings replaced yesterday, though, and played a few chords to warm her fingers up to the new steel. The instrument sung crisply. After Maeve had sat and strummed for a moment, she put her guitar back in the case. As she was closing the last latch, she heard the door open again.

She turned and opened her mouth to ask Mr. Abrams whether Principal Mills had approved her request, but her expression changed when she saw who stood in the doorway. It was a man she had never seen before, wearing a sharp suit and a purple badge dangling on a lanyard around his neck.  He swept the room with his eyes and found Maeve in front of her guitar case. He spoke without emotion.  "Come with me." Maeve instinctively turned her head to see if there was anyone else in the room that he could possibly be addressing. When she discovered what she knew to be true-- that she was all alone in the room-- her eyes widened.
"Um-- who are you?" The man raised his eyebrows, and attempted to speak more pleasantly.  "Please, come with me." Maeve shuffled backward and hit the wall. "I need to know who you are."

He reached for something inside his coat pocket. Maeve's blood ran cold. "A friend. You should come with me now. It won't be far." Ignoring all of her natural instincts, she stood up and shuffled toward the man.  He must have been fifty or so. He was tall, much taller than anyone on her high school's basketball team, and sturdily built. His short hair was black, with streaks of gray on the sides. And there was not a wrinkle or a stain to be found on his clothing.

He reached down to put his hand on Maeve's back as they walked together. Maeve shuddered at his touch. She could not remember the last time she felt this uncomfortable.  As they moved through the lowest floor of the school, the man was very careful about remaining undetected. There were another fifteen minutes or so before the school day ended, but a few bored students roamed the halls aimlessly. Once, as Maeve was about to round a corner, the man shot his arm out and brought her to a brief, but tense, stop. After a long glare around the corner, he motioned for her to keep going. "Almost there," he said through clenched teeth. As they walked down the hallway that led to the band room, Maeve noticed something odd. Someone stood in the room's doorway with their back to her– someone who seemed to be having a lively conversation with Mr. Lin. Maeve knew that there was only one person at the school who talked to teachers like that. And yet the man seemed completely unbothered by Principal Mills' presence.

They had taken a few more steps toward the principal when she suddenly turned around. Maeve's heart leapt. This was her chance to call for help!  But as she was deciding whether to call out or to attempt something more subtle, Principal Mills sighed, shook her head and acknowledged the man. "Hello, Bill." He nodded back wordlessly. Maeve was beyond confused. Was that sadness coming from her principal's voice?  What was going on?

They passed her and turned into a janitorial closet before Maeve could gather herself to say anything. ./. The first thing Maeve noticed when Bill closed the door was the oppressive heat and humidity. It was almost enough to make her gag. Then, the man turned on the lights in the small, dingy closet. And the second thing Maeve noticed was another person in the room.

He sat against the rack of cleaning supplies, hands gripping his knees. He had seemed to be muttering to himself before Maeve and Bill entered. When he looked up to Maeve, his eyes were bloodshot. Maeve recognized him. He was a high school student, a senior, that she had seen in passing a few times. He didn't play any sports or have too many friends. She thought his name was James, or Jake, or something to that effect.   When the student looked up to Maeve, a smile grew on his face. When he spoke, he was out of breath, as though he had just run a mile.  "You- you're Maeve, right?"

She nodded. She didn't know what else to do. Adrenaline pumped through her veins.  The student's eyes changed from desperation to compassion. He spoke slowly.  "Maeve, I don't know you. And you probably don't know me. But you...are so strong. And so brave. Okay? And so..." He grabbed her arm.

"...important." She pulled out of his grasp with all of her might, and reached for the doorknob. Unfortunately, Bill was faster. He wedged his foot against the door so that it was impossible to open.  "What the fuck do you want, both of you?" she shouted, eyes wide in terror. Bill moved his index finger to his lips, and removed the object from his coat pocket. Maeve stared at the shine of the revolver and froze.
