"No, no, no!" whispered the male student, frantic, pleading, once again. "Maeve. Please, stand still. Just trust me, please. Look at me." Maeve's eyes found his. As a result, she did not see Bill pull out another object, this time from a holster previously obscured by his long suit.  "Look at me, Maeve. Look--" A noise, a flash, that was as gentle as it was jarring. When its moment had passed, Maeve no longer looked at a young man, but at a leaking corpse.

Her breath caught in her throat. Tears welled in her eyes but did not fall. The ink nearly bled onto her shoes.  Bill reached his arm down and brushed her backwards before it could soil her. Then, he holstered his silenced pistol and spoke, softly.  "You will leave this closet, alone. You will walk into the band room. You will say, 'Sorry Mr. Lin, I forgot something.' Then, a shot will be fired. Everyone will hear it. You will leave the school, go home, and if you never breathe a word to anyone in this building, you will never be suspected of anything. Okay?" Maeve didn't budge.

"Do you understand?" Bill's voice wobbled. Maeve made a noise, more like a groan than anything else.  He nodded, and opened the door just wide enough for her to exit. No one was in the hallway to see her leave the closet.  She stood there, jaw chattering, skin ghostly pale, for a moment. But somehow, slowly, as through layers of rust, her legs started to move.

She walked the two dozen or so paces that she needed to reach the band room, and pulled open the door. The rushing of blood in her head made her ears ring. She said the words that Bill had told her to say, and walked to her locker, without checking to see whether Mr. Lin had heard or understood them. And, as surely as death itself, the unsilenced shot rang out just as she knelt down over her cello case.  Some students ran for the exit. Others hid in the room. Still others froze, or screamed, or hugged each other. Maeve, hardly in control of her hands, continued to open her cello case, and grabbed some extra rosin she had stored in one of the compartments. She rolled the small cube of the honey-yellow substance around her palms. She'd never noticed how nice it felt to the touch. She played with it a moment longer, squeezed it one last time and then stored it in her pocket.

She turned away from the locker. The noise and the movement around her were beyond her capacity to understand. She sat down against the metal cage, eyes glazed, mind empty.   Eventually, Mr. Lin led every remaining student in the band room outside. Her sister ran over to her. Why was she there? Didn't she have class?  They drove home. It took longer than usual. Quinn may have been talking, or maybe she was quiet. Maeve couldn't be sure if she herself had said anything, either.  Moments from the closet began to come back to her in fits and starts toward the end of the ride. The look that the student gave her. He called her brave, and strong. She still couldn't think of his name. But his face, his twisted, desperate, tired face, would stick with her.

They pulled into the driveway. The suffocating heat of the closet, so thick that it was hard to breathe.  They walked up to the front door. The shine of the revolver.  The door snapped open. The discrete, muffled pop of a life, expiring, under her gaze.   When she walked in, her mother went to hug her. She had not ever so desperately wanted to be alone.

But then, her father approached her, and bent on one knee. He spoke in a low voice, as though he did not want to be overheard. "Maeve, listen. I think I know what happened. Did you see it?" It. She had seen it, alright. In fact, it was all that Maeve was going to think about that night, and for many nights to come.  "Alright. Then we're not going to be safe here. Your mother and your sister aren't going to be safe with us around, either. I need you to trust me. Your bag is in the car and ready to go. I can take us somewhere I know we'll be okay."

Maeve looked at her father blankly. "Wha-- How--" "I can explain everything later. But we have to go, now." Maeve glanced over at her mother and Quinn, who were still hugging. Maeve could have sworn she caught her sister watching her with a puzzled expression. She tried to articulate a thought. It was much more difficult than she could have imagined.

"For how long, Dad?" He looked at her and smiled, but the slightest hint of sadness lingered on his face. "We'll be back before you know it, kiddo." He grabbed her hand and led her toward the door. Her head spun. It felt as though she had entered a completely separate world from her own, the one where she lived. As they made their way to her father's car, parked next to Quinn's, Maeve noticed movement coming from the living room window that overlooked the driveway. Quinn had pulled back the curtain and was watching the two of them depart.

She looked positively frantic. She turned wildly to her mother. Maeve wasn't used to seeing her sister like that.  "Anna..." her father mumbled under his breath, opening the car door.  Quinn slammed the curtain closed as she turned away from the window. Surely she was going to run out to say goodbye to them, or to ask what was happening, or maybe even to explain something that she knew.  Maeve's eyes stayed trained on the front door. Her father put the car in reverse and backed out of the driveway. The door didn't open.

The car began to move down the street. The door didn't open. The car turned onto a neighboring road. The door never opened.   -------------------------------------------------------------------- Reality gradually made its way back into Maeve’s head alongside the gentle, predictable hum of tires on asphalt. Time slowed down to a crawl. Eventually, the silence began to grate her ears. She needed somehow to keep it at bay.
"You...you said you could explain everything," Maeve said, gauging her ability to speak. Her father nodded solemnly.  "So...can you try?" Would it matter?
He spoke slowly and softly.  "It was my fault." More silence.  He took a breath. "Do you know what I do for a living?"

She nodded. He was the assistant research coordinator at Sweetwater College. He was practically there all the time.  "Right. Now, have I ever mentioned to you what, exactly, it is that I do for a living?" Maeve paused. She didn't think so. "Well, that's good. But I suppose you need to know now. I'm a member of a department that studies certain kinds of existential threats. There are groups of people out there who would do anything to know what we know. To study what we study. To hold the power that we could, theoretically, hold.

"That's why I can't really talk about my job. It would be a lot like putting instructions to make a nuclear bomb on the front page of the internet.  "Sometimes, though, an email will get sent, or… an employee, will…anyway. Sometimes things get out. And, I think that's why you were targeted, Maeve." His voice broke. "I think that whoever did that horrible thing at the high school today did it because you are my daughter." A pause. A sudden, instinctual wave of hatred. That damned silence. "Why didn't they just kill me, then?"

"Maeve. Don’t talk like that." She glared at him.  Her father relented. "You're going to learn the answer to that question soon. Your life was hard already. Starting high school, everything. But it's about to get much, much harder. And I'm so sorry, Maeve. I'd… understand if you never forgave me. But I would never have accepted my position if it meant I thought there was any more than a million-to-one-- a billion-to-one-- odds that you, or Quinnie, would get hurt because of it. And I wouldn't have even allowed those odds if I didn't believe that what I was doing-- am still doing-- was vitally important to the long-term future of humankind." Maeve turned to look out the window. She wasn't sure what to think. Even if she was, it would be hard to clear her mind of the image of the ever-expanding pool of blood in that hot, dank closet.

"Could you at least tell me where we're going?" she asked, at long last.  "To the airport," he responded. "We're catching a flight to Denver so that you can meet the president of the company that funds my work." "And what should I say to Quinn? And mom? So that nothing happens to them?" "Do not contact them, Maeve. Your phone might be monitored. Nothing will happen to them now, I promise."

"How are you going to ask me not to talk to my fucking… own sister?" She had never spoken to her father like that. She felt as though her words were electrified.  "Honey, I need you to–" "No. I have to."

But as she searched for her sister’s name in her contacts, Steven reached across the seat and effortlessly snatched the phone out of her hands.  "What the fuck–" "You will not continue to speak to me like that. And you will understand how important this is. How important you are." Maeve responded, though the temporary adrenaline rush she had managed was nearly over.

"We can’t– call at a pay phone, or something–" "No contact." Perhaps this was her father, hidden for years by late work nights and piles of paperwork. Future of humankind. She found that she might actually enjoy the silence more than listening to her father. ***

A loud bump jostled Maeve awake.  In a blinding moment of panic, she tried to bolt away from the noise. But as she went to stand, her seat belt tightened across her waist.  Feeling the resistance, she sat back down and tried to slow her heart rate. She was inside of a plane. Turning to look out the window, she discovered that they had just landed.  Everything was going to be alright. People surrounded her, indifferently scrolling away on their phones, or reading magazines, or sleeping, as she had been. Her father sat next to her, perusing documents from one of the numerous files he kept in his black briefcase, unaware that she had awakened.

The last remnants of the Colorado sunset lingered in the sky, casting colorful beams of light into the plane. The cabin seemed to be tinted gold. It was beautiful.  But as the effects of the uneven rest she had taken quickly wore off, the reality of her situation quickly set in. She didn’t know if she was going to be safe at all. For all she knew, she was in a coffin, escorted by some anonymously indifferent chaperone. How important you are. Whatever that meant.  The plane slowly wheeled to its gate. Images of the dead student went off like hidden bombs in the minefield that was her mind. If she let her mind wander for even a moment, something was sure to explode.  She longed to sleep again, to rid her consciousness of the previous day. When she thought back to her nap, the weight of her stress seemed to lift effortlessly.

In fact, she could recall exactly the image she was dreaming about, in vivid detail. She was in a vast, green field, filled with tall grass and yellow flowers. The field sloped upward to a hill, and she was running toward it, as fast as she could, to see the view from the top. She smelled grass and the flowers, and heard birds calling from tall trees at the edge of the field. The air was cool on her skin as she ran, and the evening sun began to tint the edge of the horizon pink.  The image hung in her mind so powerfully that she thought it must have been a deep-set memory. Standing up to depart the plane, she tried to hang onto it as long as she could.  Her father took her hand and led her down the aisle. His grasp felt like sandpaper. A smiling stewardess waved goodbye to the pair as they quickly turned out of the plane and through a hallway that led to the airport.  "Cover up," her father said. Maeve stuffed her long ginger hair into the oversized sweatshirt her father had bought her at the New Jersey airport, pulled the hood over her head, and donned a pair of novelty sunglasses. Steven had been very particular about how he wanted Maeve to look and act once they landed in Denver. "Move fast and blend in," he’d repeated, both to Maeve and to himself.

In fact, she would have felt quite ridiculous in her attire if she wasn’t so scared of what might be coming after her. She imagined that there may be spies, dressed in all black and armed to the teeth, waiting around hidden corners of the airport. Or perhaps the random passersby were enemies, desperate to listen in to a conversation between her and her father.  Perhaps it was the man in the red hoodie who ran past them. Perhaps it was the woman who strolled her baby. There were so many eyes in the airport.  She was in danger. Maeve, suddenly short of breath, staggered over to the nearest gate and leaned on a vacant chair to keep from fainting.

Steven, who had been walking so quickly that he’d failed to notice her detour, performed a pirouette and miraculously found his daughter. He had left her behind by some fifty feet.  "What are you doing?" he asked, refraining from yelling, but straining his voice. "We don’t have time for this." Maeve shook her head. She was still dizzy. "I can’t," she managed.
"You can’t what? Walk? We need to get out of here." All Maeve could think to do was shake her head again.  "I can get you water if you need it–" "I don’t need water. I need to go home."
Steven glanced at his surroundings, and dropped his voice.  "We can’t go home. This is home now." A chill went down Maeve’s spine. "I need you to get up and follow me. Okay?"

"I don’t think I can." "Try." To her credit, Maeve tried. After a few minutes of run-walking to keep up with her father and tensely listening to her surroundings, Maeve could see the exit doors of the airport. They were in a massive room, filled with stores, neon lights, glowing television screens, a line of sharply dressed valets holding names on signs, and hundreds of commuters, moving in and out of the building and chattering over one another. Above all of the commotion was a massive glass ceiling that displayed the serene, starless night sky.  Steven grabbed Maeve's hand and led her through the mass of humanity. They walked quickly with their heads down. Maeve's heart raced. There was a whole world that she apparently had to hide from. Why had they traveled directly to its center?

Maeve glanced up quickly enough to see that she was not heading toward the exit. Instead, they were approaching the wall of sharply-dressed valets. Her father stopped in front of a cheery young woman, who held a sign that read "Joseph and Elizabeth McAllister". She looked at them expectantly.  "Mr. McAllister?" she asked at them. Steven nodded and gestured for Maeve to follow the young woman. Maeve looked through her sunglasses at the other valets around them. No one seemed to be watching with any interest.

The young woman led Maeve and Steven out of the airport and across the lot. They walked in total silence. Maeve tried to concentrate on the small sound of her footsteps moving on the pavement.  Finally, they reached an expensive-looking car with heavily tinted windows. The woman unlocked the car and invited Maeve into the passenger's seat. She looked toward her father, but he already seemed to be stepping into the back seat. What was going on?  Maeve sat down, and the young woman sat behind the wheel. She slammed the door closed, which made Maeve jump, and looked through the darkened windows at the sleepy lot around them. No one was there, and even if they were, there was no way they would be able to see inside the car. Maeve felt the walls of the vehicle close in. But the young woman, also noticing that they had privacy in the car, turned to Maeve, smiled, and extended her hand. "Hello, Maeve. My name is Elyse. And I'm sure you have a lot of questions."

Instinctively, she reached out to shake her hand. But Maeve was unable to formulate a coherent response. "H-- how--" Elyse smiled again, but this time her eyes were sympathetic. "I-- we--" she gestured to Steven in the back seat-- "know how long your day has been. And whether you can believe it or not right now, we're here to help. If there is ever anything that you need, you tell me right away. Okay?" "I just want to know what's going on."

"Well, you're in luck. Because we're ten minutes away from the person who's going to tell you what you need to know. Oh! And you can take the sunglasses off now, if you want." With that, Elyse backed out of the parking space and began to drive through the lot. Maeve pulled her hair out of her hoodie, folded her sunglasses, and leaned against the window. Its tint made it difficult to identify anything outside. She had no idea where they were, or where they could be going.  As they drove, Elyse tried to strike up conversation. "Three favorite movies. Go."
Maeve turned to her, quizzically. Was she really doing this now?  "Um, Elyse, I don't--" "Come on! You have to have three favorite movies." "I just don't want--"

"One movie. That's it." Maeve felt anger brewing inside of her. She reluctantly gave an answer. "Okay–Shutter Island. I thought it was clever." Elyse nodded. "Very nice choice. Are you a Leo fan?" She furrowed her brow. "What-- no, he's weird. Always dating girls half his age."

Elyse shrugged. "I like him. He's very mysterious. Like, does anyone actually know what he's really thinking? Ever? That's so cool." Maeve shook her head and gazed out the dark window again. At least there was still a world out there where celebrities and movies mattered to people. She felt quite disconnected from that world at the moment.  The car slowed and stopped in a densely packed parking lot. Maeve went to grab her sunglasses again, but Elyse stopped her.  "No need," she said. "No one will be watching you here."

Maeve opened the door and instantly found Elyse’s statement hard to believe. They had arrived at a massive, upscale hotel. People entered and exited the front doors, lights turned on and off in windows– energy emanated from its very walls. The very building was alive.  Elyse led Maeve and her quiet father under the oversized Grand Royal Denver sign and into the lobby. It was dazzlingly white– the floor and walls were made of expensive-looking marble. A massive, ornate glass chandelier dangled multiple stories above them, and an odd silver sculpture was positioned next to the row of elevators. Even the people that walked by wore perfect suits and dresses. Everything seemed far too lavish. This was not like any other hotel Maeve had been to before.  Elyse approached the front desk. "Hi, there. We’re the McAllisters." A middle-aged man typed on his computer for a moment. "Ah! Yes. One moment, please."

He opened a cabinet from his desk and pulled out two keycards.  "This," he said, reaching for the first one, "is for Joseph. You’ve been asked to call the assistant, immediately." Steven stepped forward to take the key. Although he wished her good luck, his words bounced off her ears like rain.  The young man continued as Steven headed off to catch an elevator. "This is for you, Elizabeth. You won’t be staying here tonight, but you’ve been requested at the conference room."

He gave Maeve another keycard. Where was she going to stay tonight?  Elyse thanked the receptionist and turned to Maeve.  "The conference room is past the reception desk and through those doors, there. Do you see them?" Maeve nodded. "You’re not coming with me?"

She shook her head. "I’ll be right here in the lobby, waiting for you. There’s nothing to be scared of, okay? President Dorothy is going to help, even if she comes across as a little… intimidating. She’s very smart, like you." Elyse tried to give Maeve a reassuring smile.  She looked blankly back at her. This Elyse was very cheerful. But she didn’t make Maeve feel any less anxious about what might be waiting for her in that room.  Maeve took slow, plodding steps on the polished floor. She went past the reception desk, through a long hallway, and finally stood at the locked door. She tapped her keycard against the reader, and heard the click of the door unlocking. With heart and mind still, she turned the handle. Inside, seated at the end of a long table, was an old woman, wearing oversized pearls around her neck.

./. The old woman stood up. "Hello, Maeve." she said, looking warmly at her. "Have a seat, wherever you’d like." "Is anyone else going to be here?" she asked, looking across the table. It was large enough to seat maybe fifteen or twenty people. But she was alone with this woman, whoever she was.  "No. And I hope to be as brief as possible. In time, you will have much to do, and many people to meet."

Maeve let go of the door handle, and the door locked behind her with another small click. She sat down at a chair near the end of the table opposite the old woman.  "I am President Dorothy," she continued. "I have heard a great deal about you, and it is a pleasure to meet you in person." Maeve nodded and gave a weak smile back. Though her words were cordial, they were delivered with an aura of superiority. She paced around the carpet as she spoke, eyeglasses in hand.  "I understand that today has been rather stressful, and I’d like to apologize for that. No one your age should have to go through what you’ve gone through."

Maeve found it difficult to respond. Her leg bounced underneath the table.  "And I’m sure that you’d like to know why you’ve been whisked across the country at a moment’s notice." "Yes, President, Dorothy." The name seemed to catch in Maeve’s throat as she spoke it. What was she President of, exactly? The old woman stared off at a black television screen at the end of the room across from Maeve. She spoke slowly and carefully. "Your father works for me. What has he told you so far?"

"Um– something about existential threats, and attackers at my school? And that my family wouldn’t be safe if I stayed in New Jersey." With resentment bubbling, she added, "Or, if I tried to contact them." President Dorothy took in the information for a moment. "Well, most of that is true. I would strongly discourage connection, at least at this moment, my employees and I research a certain type of potential existential threat here in Colorado, and your family would most certainly not be safe had you stayed at home, even for tonight. "But Steven mentioned that you had been attacked at school?" Maeve nodded, slowly. "I– think so–"

The president frowned. "That’s not quite right. What I can tell you now is that you shouldn’t consider what happened in that closet to be an attack. More accurately, it was a transfer." Had her father lied to her? Would she be surprised if he did?  "I’m sorry, I don’t understand." The old woman continued. "Jason Bellemare was sick, Maeve. He came to us around a year ago, largely in your position. He had potential, much like you. But he didn’t want to cooperate with us. I’ve spent a lifetime working with people like Jason and yourself. I know that I could have helped him. But he never accepted it."

Maeve’s blood ran cold. "In the end, he truly wanted someone else to have a chance to do what he couldn’t. We tried to convince him to keep trying, to push toward his breakthrough. But it never came, and he was insistent. We then looked for a replacement for him, and you were our primary candidate. "We have every reason to believe that you have the same power as he did– more, even. He gave you so much, Maeve. You should be thankful." Maeve’s heart pounded. She responded softly and distantly.

"You– you killed him." "Killed him?" President Dorothy was taken back. "No. It was completely his decision. And he knew what he was risking when he started to work with us. It was the only way forward." "Well, I don’t know what I’m risking! Capabilities? Potential? Breakthrough? What does that even mean?" The old woman nodded, and thought. "Jason was the leader of a very powerful army. Now you are. All you need to do is locate your soldiers."

Maeve was growing tired of the vague and metaphorical nature with which President Dorothy spoke.  "Locate my soldiers," she said, skeptically.  "Yes. That is where my employees and I come in. We’ve spent years, decades, studying the creatures that you will soon lead. You have much more power than you know. My team and I will do everything we can to help you wield it. And if you listen to us, if you challenge yourself, you will become humanity’s greatest asset." The president was gravely serious.

Maeve finally spoke up. "What is this, some blood cult? I don’t want to be here. I just want to go ho–" "Maeve," interjected the president. "My team and I– your father included– examined a list of hundreds of viable candidates and painstakingly siphoned them down one by one until only you remained. I know beyond a shadow of a doubt you are the young woman for this." She gave Maeve what appeared to be a legitimate reassuring smile.  Taken back by the gesture, she said what she had only meant to think.  "My father?"

"Yes, your father was on the committee. I don’t believe he nominated you, but he didn’t campaign against your Leadership." "I don’t want to see him ever again." "You don’t have to. But this isn’t about him, Maeve! This is about you. For you. There are millions of people across the world who you’ve never met that are counting on you. But all we want to do is help. And if you accept our help, you will get better. All we need is a few months of your time." A few months? Millions of people? When she searched for words, her fifteen-year-old mind found only sarcasm and resentment.

"And they’re counting on me to lead this army of soldiers that no one can find." President Dorothy, noting her continued skepticism, frowned. "Do you usually dream?" she asked. "Vividly, I mean. Everyone dreams. But can you often remember what it is you’ve dreamt about the next morning?" Maeve shook her head. "Not really. Sometimes. I don’t know. Does it matter?" "I wonder, then; have you had a dream, or a feeling, that seemed out of the ordinary today?"

Maeve thought about her dream on the plane, running through that open field. The smells, the sights. It was almost as though she could taste the fresh air, sitting there in the dingy conference room.  "Maybe…" "That could be a coincidence, of course. You’ve had a stressful day, and your mind might be more active than usual. But," she said while raising her eyebrows, "perhaps there are other factors at play." Maeve looked blankly at the president.

"Elyse will take you back to our facility tonight. She can explain logistical matters to you either tonight or tomorrow. I hope you’ll make yourself at home. We have a lot of work to do together." "What? Is that– you’re not going to tell me anything else?" "The details are for later. I hope you will understand that the things that are happening to you are real, and I hope you will avail yourself to help as it is offered to you." The finality with which President Dorothy spoke made Maeve stand up. She shook President Dorothy’s hand and departed the conference room without another word.

As she walked, she stared through the glossy marble floor into her distorted reflection. It seemed to warp and disfigure with each step that she took.  She snapped back to reality when a hustling bellhop carrying a dolley filled with luggage nearly ran her over. She muttered an apology and looked for Elyse in the lobby. Sure enough, she sat on a chair, speaking on the phone to someone. As soon as she noticed Maeve walking over, she hastily hung up the phone and put on another smile. "How’d it go?" Maeve wasn’t sure how to answer. She paused for a moment to collect her thoughts.

"Fine, I guess. President Dorothy said that you would take me–" "To the facility! Are you ready now? Or did you want to say goodbye to your dad first?" Maeve answered curtly. "I’m fine. I’d like to go." "Are you sure? It might be a while before you see him again."

"I’m sure. Let’s go." Elyse led Maeve out of the hotel and to the car.  ./. "You’ll start school on Monday. You can dress however you want– the whole incognito thing was just for the airport. We made extra sure that you’ll be safe at school. Just remember three things– you are Elizabeth McAllister, you can’t invite anyone over to the facility, and–"

"No contact with anyone from home." Elyse nodded. "That’s right." She had been talking to Maeve for a while about the three rules of her new life. It was, apparently, vital that she adhered to them. Maeve had seen and heard too much to even imagine placing a toe out of line.  "Another important thing," said Elyse, "is that you’ll have lessons on Friday evenings. You won’t have one tonight, of course, but starting next week you’ll be busy those days."

Lessons. More cryptic information. "Other than that, though," Elyse continued, in a more cheerful tone, "you can pretty much do whatever you want. If you want to join a school club, or go to the movies, or the mall, or a friend’s house, or whatever! Just ask me, and I’ll make it happen. President Dorothy doesn’t pay me to do her research. She pays me to make sure that you’re as comfortable as possible." "So, you’re going to be, like, my babysitter?" Elyse laughed, glossing over the hints of bitterness with which Maeve’s words were tinged.

"Well, kind of. My official title is "Head Leader/Researcher Liaison". But you can think of me as a very hands-off babysitter that lets you go out or stay up as late as you want. Which reminds me," she said, pulling into a vacant lot in front of an abandoned-looking building, "we need to go shopping tomorrow." "Shopping?" asked Maeve. "Yes! For your room. It’s a little, um, drab, at the moment. And I think all your father packed for you were a few changes of clothes and some other small things. No budget. Free reign of the area. You can design your new room however you want." Elyse popped the trunk of the car open and grabbed Maeve’s bag. Together, they approached the glass doors that led into the building.

Maeve couldn’t help but notice how run-down the exterior of the building looked. Withering vines climbed up old, chipped bricks that made up four stories’ worth of walls, and barred windows looked out upon dense trees that made the area feel even more remote than it was. This clearly wasn’t a place that was going to attract any outside attention.  Elyse unlocked the front door with a key, and invited Maeve to step inside. It appeared as though the building–an old hospital, by the look of it– hadn’t been used in years. They were in a waiting room, and an old, dusty desk kept watch of the scene in front of them. The lights flickered, chairs were overturned, mold grew on the ceiling, and loose straw and rocks littered every corner of the room. The smell of mildew and mothballs nearly made Maeve gag.  "Sorry about this," Elyse muttered, hurrying past the reception desk and through a rusted steel door. "I’ve asked them to clean up a bit, but they say it’s safer this way." "Them. Who’s them?" asked Maeve, as Elyse went to her keys again.

She turned to her. "I’ll show you." Elyse opened this door to reveal a completely different area. They were suddenly in a long hallway made of spotless, polished tile. They strode past open hospital rooms that had been refurbished into office spaces. Water coolers, contemporary paintings, and a few mounted television screens dotted their path. Maeve could not believe what she was seeing. Elyse carefully observed the room numbers as they passed. She came to an abrupt halt at room 137, and knocked gingerly at the door.  "Yes?" called a muffled male voice from inside.

"She’s here," replied Elyse. The door swung open. The man was sharply dressed and wore heavy bags under his eyes. His face lit up as soon as he saw Maeve. "Oh, thank goodness," he said.  He then pulled Maeve into an embrace that she was not ready for nor open to. She tensed up when he grabbed her. When he finally let go, he bent down on one knee and addressed her.

"I know you’re probably confused and scared right now, I know. You’re just– you’re so brave! And so strong. Okay? Don’t forget that." A chill ran down Maeve’s spine. "Come on in, meet everyone else," continued the man, who motioned for her to step inside.  She took a step in. Gathered at a long wooden table were about a dozen people who wore identical suits.

Each of them stared at Maeve with a quiet fascination for a moment. Finally, one middle-aged man stood up and began to applaud. A woman followed him, and then another. Soon, everyone around the table was on their feet, applauding and cheering for Maeve. She noticed a few of them were teary-eyed. The impromptu adoration felt completely foreign to her. It was as though she had won a fixed lottery, or passed a standardized test, and her prize was the plastic yet oddly genuine applause of a long row of suits who had always been in on the joke.  "This is Gary, and Meghan, and Oscar," said the man, frantically showing off his colleagues as they walked over to her with extended hands. "And– ah, never mind. We’ll be out of your way soon enough. We just had to meet you in person."

Maeve stood there, at the edge of room 137, with glass eyes and wooden arms, rejecting the idle words of encouragement that the workers forced upon her ears. Each and every one seemed so eager to meet her– seemed so starstruck, even– so that she began to feel less like a human being and more like a prized lab rat.  Once all of the suits at the table had shaken her hand and once Maeve’s mouth produced one last empty "Hello there" or "Thank you very much" or "I’ve never been so terrified in my life" (she could not have been sure which of the three had come out), Elyse waved goodbye to the room and led her away. For the first time that day, Maeve felt thankful.  "That’s everyone that will be working to help you over the next while, Maeve." said Elyse, turning into a stairwell at the end of the hallway. "They’ve been waiting a long time for someone like you to come through that door."  Maeve nodded without thinking. All she had to do was make it to her room.

Elyse continued to chat idly as they climbed the stairs. "I think we could buy new clothes for you tomorrow, too. I mean, when do you get the chance to go out and buy literally whatever you want? We’ll make a day of it. And maybe we can visit the pet store, too. I think they just got a new batch of puppies." Just make it to the room.  Elyse exited the stairwell on the fourth floor. The hallway was almost identical to the ground floor version. "And… here we are! You’re 408. I’ve got two keys for you, and I’ll always have a backup in case you lock yourself out."

Maeve reached out to grab the brass keys. She fit one into the doorknob and took in her new desolate alcove.  The room, not any bigger than her own at home, featured soft yellow walls and a single fluorescent light that hummed ever so softly on the ceiling. A twin bed with off-white sheets lay underneath a single window, barred from the outside and tinted, like Elyses’ car’s, presumably to give the appearance that the old building was indeed abandoned to any passerby. A completely barren desk sat next to the door that led out to the hallway. The floor was, unlike the hallway, fitted with carpet, and a small door at the corner of the room revealed a spotless bathroom. "Personal bathroom– pretty nice, huh?" said Elyse. "It’s stocked with everything you might need– soap, shampoo, conditioner, toilet paper, other stuff. But if you ever need anything that’s not already here– medicine, food, I don’t know, a friend? Just head downstairs. You’ll find me somewhere. "Other than that–" said Elyse, placing Maeve’s bag down on the floor– "you should be all set for tonight. Breakfast is at 9:30 tomorrow– we’ll wake you up. Alright?"

Maeve still struggled to hold onto the information she was being fed. But just as she sensed Elyse was about to leave, she did something peculiar.  She moved across the room and bent down as though to inspect the bottom of the bed frame, and moved her eyes up to Maeve.  "Don’t wander," she mouthed, soundlessly. "I’ll try to help." Her outward cheerfulness had completely melted. Her eyes, which had been so cloyingly bright that day, darkened considerably. Maeve didn’t react.

Elyse put the veil back on as swiftly as it had come off, and turned to leave. "Good night, Maeve," she said, closing the door. "Good night, Elyse," she mustered.  As she was sealed in, she looked up to the ceiling. Sure enough, a menacing black orb blinked its single red eye at her, directly behind where Elyse had bent over.  Although she was finally alone, she would know no privacy in this room, either.

./. The blood. The unceasing blood, pooling, gathering, tainting her shoes, tainting her mind. Those desperate eyes. The second gunshot.  She turned. Sleep pulled valiantly, but it could not take her. The heat in the closet, the heat under the covers. Melting, disfiguring.  Her mother, shot dead. Her sister, shot dead. Her father, shot dead. That bastard.

A manhunt, boots swishing through the grass, a sniper aiming at her head, threatening to empty the clutter that lay inside.  Waking up in New Jersey, or Colorado, or Singapore. Waking up. Being awake.  ./. Maeve silently pushed her plastic fork through her applesauce. When she picked the fork up and turned it over, the wet food landed with a small plop onto the styrofoam tray.

But she would never hear the food’s collision with the plate thanks to the deafening roar of adolescence that was Allensburg High’s B-lunch wave. Three rows of twenty foldable tables were packed to the brim with adolescents, each one vying to be louder than the next.  Out of the corner of her eye, Maeve saw a group of boys huddling around a makeshift slingshot made of a spoon and a rubber band that threatened to fire applesauce over at another table. At that table, the oblivious soon-to-be victims flipped water bottles onto their fingers. The masochistic act was accompanied with a loud boom every time the mostly full water bottle came down upon someone’s digits. Everyone watching exclaimed with delight when the punishment came to pass.  Laughter. There was so much laughter in that oversized room. Selfish, anarchistic laughter. It was not so different from Fillmore.  Maeve, who had come late to lunch that day and long after seats were unofficially assigned, had managed to find an empty half of a table. She sat opposite a group of a half dozen upperclassmen girls, who whispered and giggled among themselves.

Every so often, she felt a pair of eyes inquisitively linger upon her from across the table. But every time she looked back to check, the eyes were gone.  Maeve looked up at the clock. There were still twenty minutes left of lunch. There were so many faces in the room. Yet not one dared to meet hers today.  She sat alone, playing grimly with the runny applesauce and wishing for the fix of social novocaine that was her cell phone. Her father had hung onto it after he split up with Elyse and her at the hotel, and she hadn’t seen it since. If getting it back means seeing him again, she’d thought that night, so be it. Today, however, she felt much differently. She spotted a few students who buried their faces in their phones, escaping to their over-saturated, heavily-personalized worlds. Maeve sorely missed her own.  It had been another lengthy five minutes of studying the grooves of the wooden table when she heard a pair of clicking footsteps approaching her through the sea of cafeteria noise. She turned around to see Mr. Jones, old-timey dress shoes and all, who offered her a small smile as he reached the table.

"Do you mind if I sit here and talk to you for a second?" he asked. Maeve knew that any and all hope of making friends on her first day would be extinguished if she was seen sitting with her homeroom teacher at lunch. Since she had been feeling quite lonely, though, she shook her head and let Mr. Jones sit across from her.  He was a rather tall, wiry man, who wore a colorful button-down shirt and sported a thick mustache. He taught upper-level history, so Maeve didn’t have him for class, but she got the sense during homeroom that Mr. Jones was not very well-respected by students. "So, how’s your first day at Allensburg?" he asked, cheerfully. Maeve caught the older girls across the table shooting glances at him as he spoke. She tried to ignore them.

"It’s alright," she said, suddenly grateful to be speaking to another human being. "I think it’s just been a little bit difficult to make the transition." Mr. Jones nodded thoughtfully. "Well, Elizabeth–" "Just Bess is fine." "Bess! I apologize, you told me that this morning. Well, Bess, when I was younger, my parents were both in the military. I’ll tell you, I don’t think, from fourth grade to when I graduated high school, that I ever finished a school year where I started it. I know how challenging it is to be the ‘new kid’. Alright? Probably more than anyone else in this cafeteria, I know how you feel."

Of course. Of course he knows.  "So, if I may, let me offer two pieces of advice. The first is that this year’s club fair is after school today. I never found it easy to meet people– really meet people– during classes. So I looked for a way to investigate others’ passions, and to see if I couldn’t develop one myself. Isn’t that what clubs are all about?" Maeve nodded slowly. It wasn’t like she had anything better to do. And she remembered that Elyse did encourage her to join a club a few days ago.  "I’ll give it a look."

Mr. Jones smiled. "Great! I’ll be there at the history club booth. No pressure to join, but don’t be a stranger!" Maeve tried to smile politely. She could think of little that interested her less than a club which prolonged her educational exposure to history.  "The second thing," Mr. Jones continued, undeterred, "is that I know that big moves can tend to put stress on some home environments. I’m not saying that that’s the case for you, necessarily, but it happened to me. The point is that if you ever feel overwhelmed, Ms. Shannon is the best guidance counselor this side of the Mississippi." He smiled again, the corners of his dark mustache turning upward. "You can tell her anything." Anything. It was almost as if the nosy, facial-hair-wearing Mr. Rodgers was teasing her.

"Of course," responded Maeve, impressed that she was able to so convincingly stifle her real thoughts. "Thank you, Mr. Jones." "Any time," he said, standing up to leave. "If you ever need to chat, about school or not about school, you can come to me, too."  She waved politely as he turned to walk out of the cafeteria. There were still ten minutes left of lunch. As loneliness set back in, she once again felt the cold stare of hundreds of nameless students through the ceaseless, pointless ocean of noise.  ./.

"Number twenty-eight. Who thinks they know the answer?" asked Mrs. Kingston.  A girl in the back raised her hand confidently. "Yes, Ryley," said the teacher. "Ionic bond." "Very good! And can anyone tell me why that is the answer?"

Maeve sat at the front of the room at a long black table. The class had been going on like this for quite a while. There was a quiz last Friday, which Maeve had obviously missed. Mrs. Kingston was intent on reviewing every answer in incredible detail, which was rather unfortunate for Maeve, as she was the only student in the class without a completed quiz in front of her.  She wouldn’t have been listening even if she had taken the quiz, though. After lunch, she had developed a splitting headache, which was rather uncommon for her. She had split much of the forty minute period between massaging her temples and staring at the red second hand of the old clock above the blackboard.  Tick, tick. How deliberately it moved. It scorned Maeve’s internal pleas to move faster; laughed at them, even. I am not yours to control, it jeered. Your reality is my domain. Ultimately, impossibly, and yet inevitably, however, it would finally complete its journey. As Ryley was about to expand upon the difference between ionic, covalent, and hydrogen bonds, the shrill bell marked the end of the day. The screaming of metal against metal made Maeve’s head pound. Yet it offered her a beautiful sense of release.

She grabbed her books and made her way to her locker. Walking was dreadful. Each step she took tightened the band around her skull. By the time she had gathered her bookbag, the pain was nearly enough to make her sick. The club fair was the last place she wanted to linger, but since it was on the way to the school’s designated pick-up spot, she struck a deal with herself. I’ll walk into the cafeteria, I’ll turn left, and I’ll sign up with the first booth I see. She wasn’t looking for any particular club, after all. She just wanted something to take her mind off of what was, unimaginably, her real life.  After an arduous journey down the stairs and across the first floor of the school, Maeve found herself standing at the entrance of the cafeteria.  The cavernous room was once again filled with noise, but it was of a different timbre. This noise was of small talk, and logistics, and cleverly disguised sales pitches. The ocean was much more polite than it had been during lunch, but its cleverly veiled inauthenticity made it feel that much more suffocating to Maeve.

She looked across the room to find Mr. Jones in a rapt conversation with a boy from one of her classes. She breathed a small sigh of relief that she would not, per her self-agreement, be forced to join the history club. Maeve hung a quick left and examined the first booth she saw. Allensburg Faux Trading club adorned the oversized sign at the top of the stand. Standing behind stacks of fliers and customized pens atop green velvet cloth, and sporting slicked-back hairstyles and cufflinks, were two of the boys that were hurling applesauce less than two hours prior.  "Hello there," one of the boys said, noticing that Maeve was staring. He spoke with the voice of a salesperson who had a lifetime’s worth of experience.  "Do you want to discover how to make money someday in a fun, stress-free environment? Do you want to learn a thing or two about how the world works? Do you want to meet and interact with like-minded, intelligent people? Then you’re at the right booth! What’s your name, and how can I help you?"

His plastic grin fit his face uncannily well. Beyond the ringing in her head, Maeve felt a mixture of morbid fascination and intimidation. She hadn’t even met this kid yet, and already he was two completely different people.  "Um– I’m just looking around, thanks," she managed to croak back. She turned around without waiting for a response.  She passed the entrance again and looked up at a new booth, which she would have arrived at had she taken an immediate right from the hallway. Two upperclassmen, a boy and a girl, sat at the booth, in idle conversation with one another.

The cloth that adorned this booth was checkerboarded with white and black squares. Maeve painfully lifted her head to see that this was indeed the chess club’s station. It took a moment for either of the students to notice that there was a freshman  willing to talk to them. The young woman could not hide her momentary shock when her eyes caught Maeve’s. "Oh! Hello there. Sorry if we kept you waiting." "Come on, Tess. The only customer we’re going to get all day and you can’t even manage to notice her?"

The male student raised his eyebrows sarcastically at Tess, who rolled her eyes back at him. "Sorry," she continued, taking a composing breath. "If you can’t tell, Keegan is kind of an ass. What’s your name?" Maeve smiled. It was odd. She wouldn’t have expected chess club representatives to act so… improperly. "I’m Bess McAllister. And I was just looking for a club to join."

"Well," Keegan jumped in, "luckily for you, Bess McAllister, we’ve got one. And it’s on its way to becoming one of the great hidden gems of Allensburg High." "Picture this," said Tess. "Tournaments, lessons, exhibitions, simuls, and maybe even… maybe we could play against those losers at Williams! We haven’t fielded a chess team since the eighties, and I really think–" "Tess." said Keegan, removing her from her reverie. "You’re scaring her." Maeve stared at the two of them blankly. "Well, the only thing is that– I’ve never really played chess before. I learned sort of–"

"That makes you exactly as good as me," said Keegan. "I don’t even know how the pieces move." Tess smiled. "Most of our players are beginners. Like, complete beginners. But the game is easy to learn, and I’ve been playing for a while, so I could help to teach." Keegan cast a glance at Tess, and faux-whispered to Maeve. "She’s, like, a chess god." Maeve forgot about the pounding in her head for a moment. In another world, she may have been off-put by these two. But this afternoon, she did not feel that way.

"When does it meet?" she asked.  "Well, we haven’t decided. The other members of the club have said that Wednesdays and Fridays after school both work, so we can let you know when we decide." Maeve tensed up. "I actually wouldn’t be able to do Fridays." Keegan frowned. "Alright then. Wednesdays it is. If you could just, uh, write your name down on this sign-up sheet, then we’ll see you back here in two days."

He slid a clipboard over the checkered cloth to her timidly, as though she may snap it in half. But she was happy to put her name and email address on the paper, which as of now was empty, save for her information. Keegan made an exaggerated fist-pump when he collected the clipboard back in the direction of Tess. She gave him an exhausted smile.  "See you Wednesday!" called Tess.  "See you then!" responded Maeve.

She made for the exit. Her brief interaction with real people was pitifully over. She began the slow walk back to the car with the tinted windows, and felt the throbbing in her head once again.  ./. "How was school?" asked Elyse. "Fine," said Maeve, who did not feel much like talking. "I’m signing up for chess club on Wednesday afternoons, so I’ll need to be picked up late."

"Chess club! Exciting. I’ve always wanted to learn how to play. Do you think you could teach me sometime?" Maeve had hunted for a crack, a slip, anything from Elyse, since Friday night. She had been completely unsuccessful. "I’ll have to learn myself, first," she said, quietly.  Her driver nodded, and paused. She seemed to be growing attuned to Maeve’s emotions, if gradually.

"Hey, are you feeling alright?" she asked.  Maeve’s first instinct was to shrug off the inquiry entirely, but she decided that her pain was too great to hide. Perhaps the veiled truth would do.  "Just a small headache. I get them all the time." And suddenly, there it was. Another slip. Maeve swore that through the continuing agony above her eyes she saw a flash of concern– panicked concern, rather than motherly concern– appear on Elyse’s face.

She snapped instantly back to her cheerful self. "Oh! I’m sorry you’re not feeling well. Do you usually take anything for your headaches?" "No, I just try to sleep them off."  "Alright. Then I’ll get you straight to bed." Straight to bed sounded excellent to Maeve. Yet she could not help but feel that she had given too much away to Elyse. She had reasoned that it may be smart to remain as closed-off as possible until she learned who exactly she could trust. She wasn’t sure what information may condemn her, and what may save her. In reality, she had a feeling that she might end up like Jason no matter what. But her survival instinct dictated that she keep the filter between her feelings and her mouth as stringently closed as possible.

The pair pulled into the dilapidated building’s lot after a few more minutes of silence. Elyse squeezed Maeve’s shoulder as they walked toward her room.          When Maeve was finally under the beige blanket in the mostly-empty room, and when the steps and the throbbing were mercifully behind her, she heard Elyse speak through the rapidly lowering curtain of sleep.  "You’ll feel better when you wake up." She clicked off the light, and just as she was pushing the heavy door closed, Maeve saw her reach for a walkie-talkie on her right hip.

But she didn’t think about that. All she could see through the haze of her pain-induced exhaustion was her shoes, tainted by the blood. All she could hear was the gun. The shoes and the gun.  No, no. I have to be like the clock. Ticking forward, always. Years behind and years ahead. It does not matter. It ticks. I too will tick.  She sunk into a heavy sleep.

./. Through the dark haze; one brilliant, vivid flash. Cold, damp pavement on her feet and hands. A nagging chill in the air, a stale memory of what was just suspended in thin air. Trees, some barren, some green, some brilliantly colorful. She was running again, but not like she had ever run before. She ran desperately. She felt everything. Muscles in her strained body cried out in vain.  A vehicle was approaching; she heard it creep up behind her. She’d have to get out of the way. But she had to run this way, in this direction. It was going to hit her, and she was going to die.  The moment faded as quickly as it had come on.

./. Maeve stared across the table, fleeting thoughts bolting across her mind. Try as she might, they moved too quickly for her to catch hold of one. Distant, contradictory ideas fought for her attention. She had only so many pieces to move, yet the game seemed to be entirely out of her mental grasp.  And then, of course, there was the boy with the damned curly hair sitting across from her. What was he thinking? Was he waiting for her? Did he already have a plan? Somehow, whenever an idea seemed to approach her, she wandered back to him, and everything was lost.

She’d been staring at the board for some time now. She could afford to look up at her opponent. She could, couldn’t she? Maybe that wasn’t what chess players did.  But in spite of her troublesome mind, her eyes lept to reach his for one critical moment, and gleaned all of the information they held.  She slid her queen diagonally, and pressed her side of the clock. She examined her move again, now that it had emerged from her mental alcove onto the cheap wooden board, which sat on the cafeteria table, still dirty from the afternoon’s last lunch wave.  She studied him now, as he thought through the ramifications of her move. Or perhaps he was thinking about something else. Perhaps he was thinking about his opponent’s stupidity, or how her hair was quite frizzy today. Or about her shoes, or about her readily apparent lack of friends. No, no, of course he wasn’t thinking about any of that. He couldn’t be.

As he sat in silent thought, he played with the flap of his ear, which was adorned with a stud earring. He halfheartedly fiddled with it much like an uninterested dog may scratch away a flea.  He started to make a move with a pawn, turned his head, and reached instead for his knight, already in the center of the board. He took Maeve’s knight, studied the move, and pressed his side of the clock.  Maeve pulled herself away from his earring and found that her plan had worked perfectly. She was filled with relief. She wasn’t going to be laughed out of the club. Not yet, at least.  She reached for her queen and moved it once again, this time capturing a pawn adjacent to the white king. Before she had time to speak, he moved his king forward and triumphantly took her queen.

He pointed the discarded piece at her and gave a wry smile. "Got ya," he said, resting it next to an empty Twinkie wrapper that neither player dared touch.  Maeve sighed and reached for her bishop, which stared directly at his king. She slid her piece across the board and picked up his.  His face changed color. For one excruciating moment, neither player knew what to say. But suddenly, Cassius broke out into a fit of laughter. He leaned back and covered his face in his hands, but he could do nothing to stop himself. Before long, he was laughing so hard that the beginnings of a tear fell from his eye.

Something odd happened next. Maeve laughed, too.  For the rest of the hour, the two played chess, trading blunders, glances, and invaluable fits of laughter. ./. She sat on her bed and stared out of her window, past the reflections of the afternoon sunlight on the evergreen trees. An anxiety threatened to hold onto her if she let it. But right now, she fought to keep her mind clear of everything but the ticking clock.

And tick, it did. She was through her first week of school in Colorado, though it had felt like ten. Her half-opened backpack slouched sadly against the barren wall of her glorified dorm room as though it along with its owner had borne the psychological weight of the last five school days.  Whenever an unpleasant thought reached her mind, she tried to replace it with something else. It’s just a lesson, she would remind herself. These people have me here for a reason. But no amount of self-assurance seemed to stop her restless brain from returning to Jason’s end. If I fail them, will they kill me too? Does it even matter?  She spent some time oscillating between admirable bravery and understandable fear. She noticed the shadows from the trees grow steadily longer and longer through the noise. The waiting was sure to drive her insane.  She just wished she had someone to talk with.

But, at last, a timid knock arrived at the door. Maeve, startled, took a composing breath before standing up to answer it.  Elyse, wearing as big a smile as ever, seemed to pay no mind to Maeve’s anxiety. "Lesson time! Are you ready?" Maeve nodded. She strode as confidently as she could out of her room. "Umm… Elyse?" she asked, as they descended the stairs. "Do you happen to know what goes on during these lessons?"

She shook her head. "I’ve never seen one in person. All I know is that you’ll probably be done at some point later this evening." What a wonderfully unspecific answer, thought Maeve ruefully.  The young women exited the stairwell on the first floor and promptly stopped outside of room 137. Elyse reached out to knock on the door but her hand hung in the air for a moment, as though she was scared of what might happen if her knuckles made contact with the wood. Maeve hardly had time to blink, though, before the moment had passed.  "Is she ready?" asked a voice from inside. Maeve recognized it instantly.

"Yes, ma’am," replied Elyse, who tried to give a reassuring look to Maeve. She felt much more uneasy now than she had even five minutes ago.  President Dorothy’s stiletto heels audibly clipped the ground long before she opened the door to greet the two women. When she had done so, she smiled at Elyse.  "Thank you, dear."  With that, Elyse turned away. Maeve was alone with the old woman now.

"Come in, please." Dorothy gestured for her to enter.  It was rather large for a room that was once a part of a hospital, but Maeve remembered this from her first glimpse of it last week. Gone, however, were the large meeting table and the dozen or so sharply-dressed employees. In their place was a chair not unlike the one Maeve sat in when she’d gone to the dentist back in New Jersey. Replacing the adjustable light that commonly hovered above the adjustable seat was a television screen, perhaps two feet by two feet in length, that was connected via metal rods to the ceiling.  Outside of this chair, the room felt concerningly empty. Feet of carpeted floor sprawled in every direction under the dim light. The walls were barren, and any cupboards or desks that may have been in the room at some point were removed. In fact, the only items of interest in the room other than that chair were a small vent on an adjacent wall and a closet door tucked away in the far corner of the room.  President Dorothy led her past the chair and toward this door.

Alarm bells sounded in Maeve’s head. Her heart froze. The images uncontrollably flooded her mind. She had tried to suppress them so valiantly, before now. But the dam was burst.  She felt as though she was watching herself from outside as she fell to her knees. She mumbled and twitched. She could not have been sure whether President Dorothy was concerned, or amused, or if she even cared at all. She wasn’t watching her. The only things that existed were the closet door and the heavy, defiling crimson pool.  After she’d lay there and cried and screamed and seen for hours, she felt a hand touch her shoulder. It was President Dorothy. She was speaking, but it didn’t matter. Words flew from Maeve. "Will you get me out of here– please get me out, I’m sorry, PLEASE I just want to go home," and then her heaving sobs overtook her words, and she was an inconsolable mess once again.

"The floor," she heard, through her cries. "The weight of your body on the floor. Focus on the floor." Though the advice felt ridiculous, her attention turned for an instant to the rough carpet against her left cheek, which she hadn’t even realized was pressed upon the unforgiving ground.  "Good," she said. "Now listen to the hum of the light." Maeve tried to breathe through her cries and listen to the light. It was there. The floor and the light were there, too.
"Now remember, Maeve." said President Dorothy, after a moment. "Stop hiding from it."  Facedown on the open floor, Maeve knew there was nowhere left to hide.  ./. "Go on," she said, expectantly.

"As… as I was walking away, the second shot rang out. I think– I think the man killed himself. I don’t know for sure." "And then your sister came to pick you up?" "Well– everyone was panicking at the school first. I was just sitting in the band room. I don’t know how long I was there for. But… yes, that’s when she came to pick me up." President Dorothy nodded. Maeve must have been twenty feet from the closet door. She sat on the floor and faced the chair in the middle of the room, rubbing moisture from her cheeks with the sleeves of her sweater. She couldn’t have said she was sad, though. At some twisted measure she felt as though a burdensome weight was being lifted from her shoulders.

"And how did you feel during the ride?" "I don’t know. I barely even remember it. I kind of feel like… I woke up again on my way to the airport." "That’s normal, you know. Sometimes, our brains can stop making memories after a traumatic event. It’s called a self-defense mechanism. And even though it seems counter-intuitive, it is harder for young people like you to heal if you keep shoving traumatic thoughts and feelings down. What you did last week was very brave. What you did today was even more brave. Do you understand?" Mave nodded. Even now, she felt a magnetic push from the closet door.

The old woman frowned and put a hand on Maeve’s shoulders. "I’ve said this to you before, but what you’ve been through is extraordinary, especially for someone your age. Although I won’t promise that your hard work is over, I can make you two guarantees regarding these weekly lessons. The first is that no physical harm will ever come to you. My goal– and the goal of my staff, who you’ll work more closely with in the coming weeks– is for you to feel whole again. You were broken– you are broken. It is our job to build you back up again." Head still spinning, Maeve sniffled.  "The second guarantee is that if you are honest with me, then I will be honest with you. If you have burning thoughts, or dreams, or visions; if you don’t feel well, or if you at any point feel unsafe– I need to know, to help you. And If you’re open with me, then I will be open to you. At the end of each lesson, you may ask me whatever it is you wish to know. Anything. And I will answer truthfully, as a symbol of the trust between you and myself." "Okay," said Maeve in a small voice.

"With that being said, our first lesson is concluded. Is there anything you would like to ask me, Maeve?" She gathered her thoughts. She had spent so much of the past week pushing forward from moment to moment that she had not spent much time wondering what she really wanted to know. At last, she decided upon her question.  "When will I see my father again?"  President Dorothy nodded. "I thought it best for you to begin your training without contact with him, at least at first. I know you are angry with him. But you will see in time that he has done as well as he could have done for you, in his situation. You will see him again when both you and I agree that the time is right."

"Alright," she said. She still felt mostly that she could never forgive him. But perhaps President Dorothy was right. Maeve didn’t think that she was intentionally  untruthful in any part of her response.  "Before I let you go," said President Dorothy, sensing that Maeve had accepted her answer, "I want you to have this. It helped Jason immensely while he worked with us." President Dorothy opened the closet door and emerged with an auburn-colored notebook. She handed it to Maeve, who flipped it open. "It’s blank," she said.

"It’s a place for you to store your ideas," responded the old woman. "I won’t ask to read it myself, but journaling helped Jason to understand exactly what he was feeling and how he wanted to communicate it to me. I humbly ask you to give it an attempt over the coming week."  Maeve continued to turn the notebook over in her hands. She could not help but feel a sense of gratitude toward President Dorothy. She had never been through such a visceral experience in her life, and President Dorothy had stopped it.  "I’ll give it a try. Thank you," she responded.  President Dorothy led Maeve out of room 137. "I’ll see you at the same time next week, then."

"Okay." Maeve started back toward her room. Inside, the sun offered its last orange rays to the beige walls, adorned by sparse posters that she and Elyse had found at a thrift store last weekend. She laid flat against her bed, feeling an unnatural weightlessness that she hadn’t felt in what seemed like ages.  ./. Maeve sat upright behind her desk, eyes trained forward on the swirling patterns of its polished wood. The sound of lazily drumming fingers interrupted the silence that otherwise choked the classroom.

Mr. O’Halleran looked (and, in all likelihood, felt) as though he were being roasted alive. Drops of sweat trickled down his scarlet forehead and stained his ill-fitting button down shirt. At regular intervals he would take his water bottle and noisily raise it to his mouth with great fervor. He had recently resorted to using a student file to fan himself in a vain attempt to evade the relentless mid-June New Jersey heat.  Maeve hardly noticed him, however.  She had used her ample time in that stifling classroom to reflect upon the events that had gotten her there in the first place. She wasn’t used to sitting in detention. In fact, this was her first time. But, as she had reasoned, it wasn’t her fault.  She felt Alexa’s presence across the room from her. She couldn’t tell for sure, but she thought by the sound of the drumming that Alexa wasn’t as bothered by the concept of detention as she was. Was it her fault? Well, more than mine, she thought.

"Alright, young ladies," bellowed Mr. O’Halleran with a mighty sniffle and a glance toward the clock. "I’ll let you go a few minutes early since you’ve behaved so well this afternoon. Just please promise me one thing. You’re both going to be high schoolers in a few months, and physical–" he shot a look at Alexa– "or verbal–" he looked back to Maeve– "violence are unacceptable ways to resolve situations for young adults like yourselves. I don’t want this to become a habit, for either of you. Understood?" Maeve nodded, eyes still trained forward on the wooden desk. "Yes, Mr. O’Halleran." "Alexa?" he asked.  Silence. She must have nodded to him, because he stood up and loudly pushed in his chair.

"Okay then. Have a nice summer." As soon as he had made his exit from the room, Maeve went to stand up herself. She felt as though there was a force field preventing her eyes from moving in Alexa’s direction. She began the journey toward her locker as briskly as she could, with her head straight down.  Inevitably, she heard the footsteps of her friend behind her before she had gone one hundred feet out of the classroom. Alexa appeared in the corner of her vision, panting slightly. She must have had to jog to catch up to her.  "Well…that was bullshit," said Alexa.

Maeve, continuing to move swiftly to her locker, responded without looking back at Alexa.  "Yep." "I mean…it’s the last day of school! And I swear…Mr. O’Halleran has the worst timing." Maeve knelt down at her locker and answered flatly. "I guess he does."

"If he had walked over one minute earlier, he would have seen those idiots trying to mess with you. And then…maybe they’d be here instead of us." The small click of the latch opening on Maeve’s locker echoed throughout the cavernous hallway. It seemed that there was not a single soul who wanted to waste even a moment of their incipient summer vacation trapped in that building.  "Maybe you’re right," she responded.  "You know what I think? I think– hey, Maeve, is everything alright?"

At last, Maeve turned to look back at her friend. There she was– Alexa, the one person she could not have made it through middle school without, the one person who had stood up for her today, clearly filled with concern. Yet Maeve’s eyes grew even frostier when they fell upon hers.  "Yes. You know what, I’ll text you later." She grabbed her bookbag and turned to leave, slamming her locker shut.  Alexa hurried to keep up with her. "Hey, are you mad at me?" Maeve stopped mid-stride, and answered without looking back. "No."

Alexa let out the beginnings of an exasperated sigh. "Was it the detention? I’m sorry about that. But it doesn’t really matter, I don’t even know if this will go on our records anyway, and–" "No, it’s not– that." "Okay, well, if it’s not that, then it is something," replied Alexa, expectantly.  Maeve drew a slow breath and labored to look at her friend once more.

"Do you want me to be honest?" "Uh, yeah." A brief pause. "I just don’t know why you had to start something now, of all times." Alexa scoffed. "Start something? Maeve, those girls have been picking on you all year. On us. And the way I see it, if I didn’t step in today, it might have been you at the nurse with a busted lip instead of Jocelyn. Shit, I bet she would have done worse than that. But it doesn’t matter; her whole group of idiots is going to private school next year. So… who cares?"

"Who cares? Alexa– I was fine. All we had to do was put up with them for two more hours, and then they’d have been gone forever. Now we’re just as bad as they are." Alexa shot Maeve a testy look. "You don’t mean that."  Maeve sighed. "No, I guess not. But we just gave Jocelyn exactly what she wanted, on the last day of school, in front of everyone that we have to see next year." "She wanted me to punch the shit out of her on the last day of school? Really?"

"No, no, it’s just…" Maeve was having a hard time articulating just why she was so frustrated with Alexa. Maybe she wasn’t frustrated with her.  "...I don’t need you to protect me like that, okay? I could have handled myself fine. Jocelyn’s been picking on me all year. It’s whatever." Alexa shrugged. "That’s not what I saw. Plus, didn’t it feel good to say…" she looked around to make sure no one was listening. "...what you said to her and her asshole friends? I mean, I couldn’t have said it better myself." Maeve continued toward the front door of the school, even more quickly than before.

"I don’t want to talk about that." Alexa was losing energy to keep up with her. "Look– whatever, Maeve. It’s not a big deal. Just text me once you snap out of this, okay?" Maeve strode out of the door without turning to look back at her.  Just a small handful of cars lingered in a lot that was filled to the brim with joyful students just an hour ago. Maeve remembered that her entire 8th grade class was going to take a picture out in the lot as the final bell rang. So much for that.

She found her sister’s car parked and running not far from the front entrance. As soon as she got in, Maeve realized how flushed her face had become.  "Emotional day?" asked Quinn. Maeve took a shaking breath and leaned her head against her sister’s shoulder.  ./.
Saturday, October 15 Hello.  Sunday, October 16 Today I went shopping with Elyse. It was fine.
Tuesday, October 18 I wish biology would go by faster. Wednesday, October 19 What is today if not yesterday’s tomorrow? Whatttttttttttttttttttttttt

Maeve carefully traced a number of t’s into her notebook in an attempt to make one that she thought was perfect. It was almost 2:30, which meant that she would finally be free from the prison that was eighth period biology. She hadn’t been paying any attention to the class material for much of the period. Instead, she had been flipping through the blank pages of her notebook and staring disappointedly at the few sentences of nothing that she had managed to write over the past few days.  She had really meant it when she told President Dorothy that she would give journaling a try. Then again, she was not exactly thinking clearly when she had made that promise. As far as she could remember, she hadn’t ever felt as overwhelmingly terrified as she had during her lesson last Friday. Or relieved. It was odd.  Ultimately, the old woman was probably right about one thing, though– journaling should have been the escape. Maeve had plenty of thoughts to write down; that much was certain. But she felt as though every time she found it in herself to sit down to write, some barrier blocked the connection between her mind and her hand. So, after four days, she was stuck with a small handful of meaningless letters. She absentmindedly smudged her eraser over some of the "t"’s that she produced. She wasn’t scared that anyone else would read her journal, really. In fact, she could have just as easily written in one of the school notebooks that she kept in her backpack, and no one would be the wiser. There was just something about the documentation process that she was invariably hung up on.

The piercing wail of the metal bell pulled Maeve out of her thoughts. She quickly grabbed her belongings and hurried through cliques of high schoolers toward the auditorium. After what had seemed like months, it was finally time for chess club again.  As she turned into the cafeteria, she squeezed past some rather rowdy members of the school’s volleyball team to see Keegan and Tess, who were already locked in concentration over a board.  Tess, playing as black, wordlessly reached for a piece, hesitated a moment, and then committed to moving it. As she tapped her side of the clock next to the board, Keegan looked up at her with visible confusion. Maeve, who had approached the board, was confused as well. It seemed as though Tess had just given away her knight, as if she forgot that it could be taken. Keegan’s eyes widened as he went to capture it.

The rest of the game was swift. Tess moved instantly, checking Keegan’s king into oblivion. Before Maeve could even blink, the two players were shaking hands and resetting the board.  "I’m glad someone was here to see that," said Tess, triumphantly.  "Yeah, whatever," replied Keegan, curtly. It seemed as though these two had been playing games for quite some time, and Maeve had a feeling she knew which direction they’d gone.  Tess turned to Maeve. "You’re going to be at the same table you were at last week, if that’s alright. I think you and Cassius are pretty well-matched."

"Okay," said Maeve, wringing her hands. As she headed to her seat from last week, she saw that her board was already set up. As she sat down, she picked up one of the cheap plastic pawns and turned it over in her fingers. She was the first one here. What if it was just her today? What if Cassius didn’t show up? She knew she definitely didn’t want to play against Keegan or Tess.  And what exactly, she thought, did Tess mean by well-matched? Was there something behind that? Did she know? Was there anything to know? Did it even matter? And if it did matter, and if there was something to know, then how would she even– "Hey, Bess," said Cassius, pulling up his seat across from Maeve’s. "Oh, hi, Cassius." Bess. I could have picked any name in the world and I went with Bess.

"I don’t think you’re ready for this," he responded. He adjusted all of the pieces on his side of the board as though he were a grandmaster, and flashed Maeve a devilish smile.  "Ready for what?" she said, skeptically. It was as though he had suddenly and effortlessly pulled her out of her own mind. "I," he announced, sliding forward a pawn to begin the game, "have been studying all week for today." Maeve responded with her own move. "I doubt that."

"I guess I’ll just have to show you, then." For the second week in a row, the two players traded banter and laughter, and split their games more or less equally. But again, for an hour on Wednesday, Maeve felt as though she was actually breathing. Her life for the past two weeks had been an incessant stream of noticing, and thinking, and thinking about thinking, so much so that the hour of mental ease could have been a front row seat to every Pinky Meteor show in North America. Most days, after school, she had no reason to emerge from her room. What was there to do? Homework was a diversion more than a nuisance, sleep a pastime rather than a bodily function. Maeve had never known isolation to be so exhausting.  But even when the two chess players were not talking, even when Maeve was staring at the board, terrified of making a horrible mistake, things were different. She was really and truly alright.  The after school bell snapped the pair out of their concentration and prompted Keegan to stand up.

"Alright, everyone!" His naturally loud voice carried effortlessly across the cafeteria. "See you next week!"  Maeve turned around to grab her backpack. The sudden realization that there were seven more days before she could return to chess club hit her all at once.  "I hope we get to play again next week," said Maeve, perhaps more softly than she had intended.  "Oh! Yeah, me too." replied Cassius, looking distracted. He had stood up to leave but his eyes remained trained down at the board, as though studying the position they had ended up in.

"Bye, Cassius."  She headed toward the cafeteria’s exit slowly, but resolutely. She had to find Elyse’s car. That was all that mattered now. It was what she had to do.  But she could not help herself from turning to take one last look at the table at which she had been playing. Funnily enough, Keegan was there, talking to Cassius, who had not moved an inch since she had left.  She turned back around and made her way toward the exit of school with hollow, plodding steps, until they weren’t. The pitter-patter of someone walking up to her from behind made her turn around so quickly that she thought she might fall over.

It was Cassius. He flinched when he saw her turn around, as though he was worried that she might hit him. His face was one shade short of beet red, as though he had run a marathon to catch up with her, instead of a few hundred feet.  "Um… yes?" said Maeve, who was put-off by Cassius’ approach, but still eager to hear what he had to say. "You know what I think is dumb?" he said, struggling to look her in the eye.  "What’s that?" asked Maeve.

"Well, we play all of these chess games– brilliant ones, by the way– and, ah, I don’t even know anything about you." Maeve continued to look at him, expectantly. She tried to stay as cool as possible on the outside, but a surge of energy pulsed through her.  "All of these chess games? We’ve only been playing for two weeks." "Well, um, yeah. But– it feels like longer, right? In a good way, I mean."
