Maeve laughed.  "Anyway," said Cassius, running a hand through his hair, "I was just wondering if, um, maybe, I could have your number? Just, to talk, I mean…" he trailed off. Maeve was one instant away from exploding with happiness when she made a horrifying realization. She didn’t have a phone anymore. Of course she didn’t have a phone, because of her stupid father and the stupid life she was living now. It was too perfect. She tried to suppress her boundless frustration in her answer. "I, um… don’t… have a phone. Super strict parents."

The color instantly drained from Cassius’ face. He took a breath to say something but Maeve interjected.  "I do have my school laptop! You can email my student address. I check it all the time. I guess, I’d… like to know something about you, too." Cassius stood there for a moment, trying to regain his composure. "Alright," he said, frowning. "I guess I’ll be emailing you, Bess." Maeve nodded. What a great moment this could have been. "Alright."

Cassius turned and walked away from her, wringing his hands.  ./. Small strands of hair bounced in and out of Maeve’s field of vision. Her face, bathed in white light, remained as still and expressionless as it had been since she had returned to her room some two hours ago. Her feet, and her anxious heart, both tapped away wildly. As afternoon gave way to dusk, Maeve sat upright on her bed and refreshed her email, hoping against hope for the email that she dreaded more than anything.  A small knock on the door shook Maeve out of her trance.

"Mm-hmm?" she asked, curtly.  "Dinner’s ready in the mess hall," called Elyse from behind the door.  Maeve stretched her back. She had suddenly found that the strain of staying so still for so long had made her quite uncomfortable.  "Could you just grab something for me? Anything’s fine."

Elyse paused for a moment, still outside. "Alright. But promise me you’ll eat." Maeve wasn’t listening. All she could seem to focus on was the look that Cassius had given her in the hallway. How was it possible that he, the one who asked for her number, was the one to give her such a pitiful, confused look? It was as though she’d said yes and then he’d revoked his offer.  Maeve stretched her back. There was no more use in waiting like this– at least, not when it caused her so much discomfort. She grimly placed her school laptop on the floor and set her head down on the pillow. Most nights, to fall asleep, she would try to picture in vivid detail her room back at home in New Jersey. She would see every panel in the windows beside her bed; every fret on the old acoustic guitar she had resting against the wall; even the chips in the paint behind the posters that she hung on her wall. It brought her a sense of calm, this pretense.  Today, as she burrowed under her covers, with heavy school clothes and winter boots still on, she looked at her laptop, and tried as hard as she could to imagine it as a phone. She could text Cassius. She could see what her friends were up to. Heck, she could call them. Or the police. She might be home by tomorrow.

Of course, she could do most of these things anyway if hers was a regular laptop. Unfortunately, nearly every site was blocked except her school’s own, and she could only send emails within the school system. And even if she could somehow bypass these limitations, she was beyond terrified to risk being caught by President Dorothy, or one of her mysterious employees, whose collective absences made the already large facility seem absolutely cavernous. What would they do, if they caught her? After all, no outside communication was one of the few rules they had ever laid out. So she stayed in her bed, eyes open, pretending and considering. She heard the small tap of what she assumed to be Elyse putting her food outside of the room, but she did not feel much like emerging from her mind. So she continued to think. All of her teachers had always raved about her– so quiet, they said, so mature for her age. But when she had been playing chess with Cassius, in spite of everything that had happened in the last two weeks, in spite of the high-brow reputation she thought chess itself had, she could not have felt further from quiet and mature. It was as though his mere presence made words and jokes and laughter spill out, like she was a completely different person.   Only a few people had that kind of effect on her. Of course, Alexa did. Her friend’s name shot through her mind like a bolt of lightning. When Alexa wasn’t being a complete idiot, as she was often, she was so funny, and so thoughtful. And so loyal. Maeve’s chest tightened. How was Alexa doing now? Did she think that Maeve was gone forever? What would they be telling the students at Fillmore about her disappearance?

Maeve gripped her covers more tightly. Fillmore. The gunshots, the blood. The suffocating heat of the closet. She’d seen the carnage brilliantly, relentlessly, subconsciously, for weeks that had felt like years. But, finally, for the first time, Maeve allowed herself to remember the other person who had the power to unleash her other side.  She stood up from her bed and turned the old brass knob that protruded from her white door, marked with small pencil-drawn horizontal lines where the very top of her head reached throughout the years. The upstairs landing was dark and murky, but she knew where she wanted to go. Avoiding the small patch of the floor that always creaked when tread upon, she turned right and walked a few steps forward before slowly opening another white door.  Behind it was her sister, lying in bed. Perhaps she was talking on the phone, or typing away on her laptop, or listening to music and staring out into space, as she often did. Maybe she’d tell Maeve to get lost, maybe she wouldn’t say anything, or maybe they’d converse about nothing for hours, as they often did. But Quinn was there, far more there than some random boy from chess club or some stupidly vague old woman who seemed to get a rise out of playing with Maeve’s emotions.  She closed her eyes and let the memory linger for a moment longer. She found that she could nearly smell the lilac from her sister’s diffuser. Maeve had always complained to her that it was too strong. How she longed to breathe in that foul air again.

Her heart rate slowed. The television was on downstairs, quietly, but just loud enough to be heard from her sister’s room. Perhaps her father had just come home from work, or perhaps she was little and her mother could not sleep that night.  And how beautiful the night sky was. Maeve walked across the room to look at the stars, which glowed magnificently. In between the suspended white dots hung the moon, yellow and majestic, which shone gentle light through the cloudless night onto her face. She sat on the floor next to the window, marveling at the sky, for an instant that may well have been an eternity.  Footsteps outside the room brought her out of her dream. Maeve opened her eyes in her beige-walled room and heard a clatter where the steps had come from, just outside the door.  Her mouth tasted like stale sleep, and her back still ached. She rolled over and turned on her laptop, which was still beside the bed. Two hours had passed, and the laptop’s battery was almost dead.

Sighing, she sat up in bed and pulled the computer up to her lap. She logged in to find that her email was still open.  But something was different. One unread message, highlighted with bold letters, appeared at the top of the screen. It had appeared around fifteen minutes after she’d fallen asleep. Maeve’s stomach turned as she clicked on it. The words, perhaps formal, but undeniably Cassius, stared at her from behind the screen. Dear Bess,

I hope you’re doing well. I’ve never really used email to actually talk to people before, but as the undisputed chess champion of Allensburg, and an overall multi-talented super genius, I’m sure I’ll be able to figure it out. Let me know if you get this. I’ll be around tonight.  From,  Cassius Maeve read the message slowly the first time, soaking in the meaning of each brief sentence. There it was. She could hardly contain her joy. Hours of toil, weeks of rotten school days were all validated. Her eyes, as though magnetized, raced upward to the beginning of the email each time she finished reading it.

But the butterflies which flew so weightlessly in her stomach at first turned quickly to stone. Of course he had to send the message right after she passed out. Now it was nearly 8:30, and he had said he would be around all night, but… And there was that stupid name again. That afternoon, he had said he wanted to get to know her better. What good was that if she couldn’t even tell him her real name? The more she looked at it, the more it looked like a sore on an otherwise immaculate piece of artwork.  Maeve stood up and walked to the other side of her room, still staring at her laptop. She was going to have to respond to him. It was so easy to talk to Cassius over the chessboard. But the keyboard looked more to Maeve like a minefield than anything else. Was she going to apologize to him for falling asleep? Should she ask him questions? Tell him something true about herself? Make something up? Was the school going to have access to these emails? Was President Dorothy going to find out and move her to a different school? Questions and pitfalls saturated her mind more completely with each passing second.  She turned away from the pull of the laptop and approached her window. Night had fallen since she fell asleep. Crickets chirped softly, and the branches of the dense fir trees that surrounded the facility swayed gently in the brisk autumn wind. Maeve lowered her head to get a better look at the sky.

Above the gently waltzing treeline, her eye was met with a vast sea of black. No speck of white light looked back at her. The warm yellow moon which once showered her in pale light was drowned in tar.  She stepped away from the window, emotion suddenly grabbing her chest. She reached for her backpack, which she had haphazardly tossed across her room some five hours ago. She flipped through its contents and pulled out her journal.  She opened it, looked through her first few uninspired entries, and smiled sadly. She scribbled over her entry from science class and wrote, in careful letters, underneath it: Wednesday, October 19

Adrift, beside reality ./. President Dorothy turned her head back to Maeve slowly. The old woman gazed through her with much intent, as though President Dorothy was working out a mental puzzle in her mind. Maeve, frozen behind her, felt a familiar electric current rush through her fingertips.  Some moments later, President Dorothy reached her conclusion. The old woman sighed and deliberately removed her wrinkled hand from the door handle. She properly addressed Maeve and spoke authoritatively.

"I’d like you to open this door." Maeve fixated on the silver handle. It was only a few paces away from her. It was maybe eight inches long, and bent backwards at a steep angle toward its end, presumably to aid with gripping. There was nothing inherently unique about it– Maeve had probably turned thousands of otherwise identical handles throughout her life. But this one seemed to look back at her with the same calculating intent as President Dorothy did.  It was easy, really. Walk forward, turn the handle, sit inside for thirty seconds, and she’d be done. She could see it in her mind clearly. Three year-old children wouldn’t have an issue with what she was doing.  But when she took a decent stride forward, her face was met with a sudden blast of heat. It burrowed underneath her skin and began to boil her from inside. She breathed deeply and wiped a thick layer of sweat from her hands onto the back of her jeans. She held her ground.

One more step, and she’d be able to pull the door open. Her eyes flitted over to President Dorothy. She watched from a few feet back expectantly. But she didn’t matter to Maeve now. The next step was all there was.  *        *        * "How are you feeling now?" "Six… and a half, maybe?"

"That’s good. Keep breathing." She wouldn’t let her gaze meet that of her assailant. In fact, she studied a small patch of the blue carpet across the room from her. The more she looked at it, the more she came to realize it was made up of a number of cool colors, with dark forest green patches bleeding into small swirls of royal purple. She traced the colors in her mind, making note of the effect they had on the carpet, as her heart slowly relaxed its way back into her ribcage. After another minute had passed, President Dorothy knelt down beside Maeve. She moved in close to her and whispered quietly, as though she were revealing some important secret. "I know this may not be how you see things now, but you have already come so far. I know that you might hate these lessons– and I know you might hate me, while they’re happening– but what you’re doing is so important, Maeve. And you are so strong."

Initially, Maeve wanted to laugh. Important. That word had been thrown around so much recently that she had started to forget its meaning. Wasn’t she supposed to be leading some army? That seemed important. But none of these lessons were about battle strategy, or killing, or blood sacrifices, as Maeve had idly predicted upon her first encounter with President Dorothy. They were just walking toward a stupid closet.  And it was somewhat amusing to her that the old woman was self-aware enough to know that she was such a loathsome figure in her life. Although Maeve still resented her father, was President Dorothy not the central figure in the death of Jason? Most of the time, Maeve did hate her. Not just during lessons.  But at that moment, as though it were reflex, she sat up and gave President Dorothy a hug. She only latched on to this wicked, controlling, intelligent, caring woman for a moment. She knew what happened in this room, and on the flight, and in the closet. No one else did.  Maeve sat back down, somewhat shocked at what had happened. It was as though she had lost and then regained all sense of bodily autonomy. For the first time since she had stepped into the janitorial closet, she looked at President Dorothy.

She smiled sympathetically back at Maeve, and stood back up. With a tug on the bottom of her suit coat, she took a breath.  "That will be all for today. You may ask me a question now, if you like."  Although she could not have known for sure, Maeve could feel her face turning just as red as her hair. A mess of thoughts rattled around in her mind. More than once, she took a breath to ask something, but decided against it. Finally, she settled on a question that she already knew the answer to.  "Could I, um… have a phone… at some point?"
President Dorothy chuckled, and began exiting the room. As she walked away, she responded over her shoulder. "Not yet. Be patient." ./. The shrill bell stole her from sleep.

Without opening her eyes, she reached for the clock on the stand across from her bed. Clumsily, she walked her hand up to the spot she knew the unforgiving alarm was, and swiped at it.  In some sense, she was successful– the blaring stopped, replaced by a dull ringing in her ears.  But alas, during her follow-through, she knocked her biology folder directly on the ground. The gentle splat of the papers on the ground told her all that she needed to know.  Maeve mumbled under her breath as she swung her legs over the side of the bed. Loose worksheets and old exams had found their way under her cabinet, under her bed, and into the bathroom.

She stood up, and hunted for an outfit to wear. Though it was still dark, and though she was contending with a mild case of frustration over the spilled schoolwork, she managed to choose something tasteful for the upcoming day.  She made her way into the bathroom and started the shower. As the water warmed up, she hunted for papers across the room. A multiple choice quiz about the classification of mammals was caught against the radiator. She shuddered as she filed that one away. Thank goodness she was many weeks removed from that unit. Cassius had told her that Mrs. Phelps had left the answer key to that quiz on her desk during lunch, so most of her class had been able to cheat on the exam. Not her, though. She had to fight tooth and nail for the eighty-five she got, all because no one could– or would, probably– text her the picture.  For the next few minutes, Maeve contorted her body in every direction to collect every wayward page. The last one, which she had to move her bed aside for, was last night’s homework.

The assignment was a slog. She had to carefully label and describe cellular respiration, a process which was completely uninteresting to Maeve. Fortunately, she spent most of the night emailing Cassius, who had been of some help and of massive distraction.  She braced herself to move her bed back into position. Although she hadn’t moved it far– a few feet, if that– it was much heavier than she’d imagined, and at any rate she still wasn’t fully awake. But before she went to push, a devious plan laid itself out before her, as though laid out by divine revelation. In its current position, the bed was almost up against the door. Just above the door, and definitely reachable if she were to stand on the foot of the bed, was the camera.  She absentmindedly tore off a small scrap of page from the bottom corner of her assignment. She had tape in her backpack. In a second, that red light could be off…

No, she thought. It’s not like I’m doing anything I have to hide from President Dorothy, or whoever’s watching that thing. If there even is anyone watching it. The allure of a moment of privacy. Or perhaps of something else.  Either way, she reached for her tape and carefully balanced at the foot of her bed. Elyse rolled the car to a gentle stop beside the school’s side entrance, and smiled warmly at her front-seat passenger.  "Have a good day!"

The young woman reciprocated Elyse’s smile and opened the car door. She was immediately met with a blast of cold air and the piercing sting of whipping snowflakes cutting across her cheek. As she did often, Bess wondered in amazement how Elyse could be so cheerful on such a cold, dark, early morning.  She navigated past a patch of concrete that always seemed to ice over on snowy days like today, and made her way into the school. There were still fifteen minutes or so before first period officially began, so the hallways were still sparsely populated. Bess walked quickly past walls of ancient trophies displayed proudly behind glass cases and turned into the cafeteria.  Above her head, the school’s giant red homecoming banner hung proudly despite the fact that it had been several weeks since it had been relevant. Although it was early, trash had still managed to find its way onto most of the empty tables. And fortunately enough, Cassius and his group of six or seven other boys were already at their usual table, talking loudly and laughing.  Bess stealthily made her way over to the mess of boys and noticed that Cassius was in the middle of telling a story. She tugged on his coat sleeve from behind. He didn’t react. She tried again. The eyes of most of the boys gathered around the table turned to her, but even then, Cassius kept on talking. Frustrated now, Maeve wrapped both of her arms around him and started unzipping his coat from the front.

"Jesus, woman, what do you want?" he yelled without turning to look at her, previously mid-sentence. Bess and the whole rest of the table erupted into laughter.  He slid over to make room for her, and she sat next to him. After giving her a quick glance to ensure that it was indeed Bess that he had been addressing, he continued his story almost without missing a beat.  "So I’m on the game with Jacob last night, right? And we load into the lobby with two other guys, and we are dead even. I mean, for fifteen minutes I think us and them were within two or three kills of each other. I don’t think I have ever tried so hard at anything before in my life. Definitely not in school, at least. Anyway, with two minutes left, Jacob goes off. I mean off." "Jacob? No," mused Kyle, a stocky, blond football player who was sitting across from Bess.

Cassius nodded enthusiastically. "Eight in a row. There were tears in my eyes. Legitimately. I was starting to think I died and went to Heaven, or Hell. One of the two. "But they’re still killing me, right? So we’re up one with like fifteen seconds left. And Jacob says this into the mic– so deadpan serious– ‘If you sell, C, I will never forgive you.’ And I start dying laughing, but I mean, I don’t want to lose the game for him. So I hide behind a wall, and watch the seconds count down. Five, four, three…" Cassius stuck his pointer and middle finger out to mimic a gun, and pressed them against his head.  "Bang. I’m dead. No idea how. I must have been peeking out from the side. I never heard anyone coming, either. I just got sniped. After my heart attack was over, I slammed the controller on the ground, and may have said a word that I was not supposed to. And downstairs, I hear this huge crash. I guess I must have scared my mom or something, because she yells back up at me, ‘Cassius Minor, you need to control yourself!’ And then my dad yells at me and my mom to stop yelling, and then they’re fighting again. Anyway– long story short– my mom says she’s going to Florida, and she slams the door and leaves. And then my dad yells up to me that he’s going to the place that’s farthest away from Florida. And he slams the door too. Five minutes later, I go downstairs– no cars in the driveway, mug still shattered on the floor."

No one was sure what to say, so Cassius continued quickly.  "Anyway, this morning, they both texted me and apologized. But I guess they’re actually going away for a while. They’re both gonna take next week off from work and go to separate places. My dad said he’d be back on Saturday night and my mom said she’d be back Sunday morning. Which is all to say that I’ll have the house to myself next week. Which is also to say that I recommend that all of you seated at this table haul your respective asses over to my place next Friday night. Jacob and I will provide some refreshments, but you are encouraged to bring your own if you so choose." The rest of the table muttered and nodded, but the mood seemed a bit too solemn for Cassius’ liking.  "Look, guys, I have shitty parents and I’m bad at video games. Whatever. Let’s have fun next Friday."

That woke everyone up. At that moment, the warning bell sounded and the mass of humanity in the cafeteria stood up and gathered their belongings.  Bess felt her chest tighten a bit. A house party? Most of Cassius’ friends were upperclassmen, so maybe they had been to some before. She, however, had not. Beyond that, though, there was the small problem that  "You know I can’t do Fridays!" said Bess, standing up to leave.  "I know, but, can you… see if you can get it moved, or something? She sighed. "I don’t know. My counselor is very adamant that I’m there every Friday. And these meetings…" "I know, Bess," he said, rubbing his arm. "I know they’ve been helping a lot. And I know it’s not easy to come halfway across the country right as you’re starting high school. You know all of those guys; they’re alright. And you wouldn’t be the only girl there, if that’s what you’re worried about. Phil and Ben are gonna bring their girlfriends, and I was gonna invite Becca and all of them too."

Bess took a breath. For as much as she hung out with Cassius during school hours, and for as much as she emailed him, she had never seen him outside of the context of Allensburg High. It might be fun to at least see his house. And she was a bit sick of hanging around with his guy friends all the time. She had quickly become amazed at how little they talked about anything other than their video games and their sports. She rubbed her face. "Okay. I’ll…try to think of something, I guess."  Cassius smiled. "Great. And, if you need a ride, I’d be more than happy to pick you up–" "No!" replied Bess, far too quickly. Cassius recoiled in surprise.

"I— I just mean that– I have a super strict family, you know, like– my phone and everything, and…" "It’s ok, Bess. I get it," he said, standing up. "Look, if you feel uncomfortable going, or anything like that, that’s alright too."  She opened her mouth to respond, but the sound of the late bell loudly interrupted her train of thought.  "Shit!" she said, suddenly feeling the eerie emptiness of the cafeteria. Everyone else had been sitting in their real classes for some time now.

As she clumsily grabbed her backpack and stepped over the row of connected seats, she noticed that Cassius wasn’t moving at all, even though she knew he had first period biology with the notoriously strict Mrs. Phelps.  ./. Friday, December 9 You know, who was I even kidding? "I’ll try to think of something." First of all, there is no way that Her Highness the Queen President Dorothy would even think of moving our stupid Q and A sessions forward or backward one stupid day. And even if that wasn’t a problem, what would I do at a house party? Would I need to look nice? Would Cassius expect me to look nice? Does what he thinks even matter? What does he think we are? You? I wouldn’t listen to you in a million years about anything party-related. I still miss you though.  Maeve tapped her pencil to the end of her thumb a few times and gingerly closed the journal. She reached over the dentist-style chair she was currently seated in and slid it into her backpack, and resumed waiting.  This was actually the first time Maeve had sat in this chair. Each week, she had passed it on her way to the janitorial closet, and it had loomed, isolated, menacing, as though it were some sort of invisible barrier that demarcated the boundary between the comfortable side of the room and the uninhabitable side. The black television stood watch above the room, as grimly as ever. She could only make out her reflection on the screen when she was near the closet. But today, President Dorothy had told her to sit in the chair and wait. She had spent some time studying the small metal table next to the left armrest, and the adjustable headlight that was suspended over her like a dismembered arm. She recalled vividly her painful and uncomfortable trips to the dentist, which always seemed to end ominously, as some twisted bonus. When she was younger, her dentist would mention something about cavities, or flossing more, or wisdom tooth surgery, and she would come home in unconsolable tears. Those small, routine worries, memories of another life, made her smile now.

Finally, President Dorothy opened the wooden door. In her hand was a small black leather briefcase. Behind her, a strong-looking man wheeled a sturdy physician’s scale into the room. President Dorothy pointed to a spot next to the chair Maeve was sitting in, and the man slid the scale off of its small cart and onto the ground next to her with a loud thunk. "How are you feeling today, Maeve?" "Fine." "Great. I hope I haven’t made you anxious, waiting in this chair." Maeve imagined that her face must have been pale.

"No, ma’am. I just– um, school things, that’s all." "You can tell me anything, you know. Especially if it’s bothering you to a significant degree." "No, it’s nothing." After. She’d ask about next Friday after the lesson.

"Alright. I understand that high school comes with its share of difficulties. I was once that age, too." Maeve offered a weak smile.  "Anyway. As you may have come to expect," said the old woman, "today’s lesson is going to be a bit different than those of previous weeks. I have been trying to help you process and accept the terrible tragedy you witnessed at your former high school. "How are you feeling today, Maeve?"  Maeve’s face twitched. That question, again.  "Fine, I think. I had a long day at school so I’m a bit tired. But otherwise fine."  "Is anything in particular bothering you? Physically, mentally?"

"Nothing new since last week." "Have you noticed anything out of the ordinary? Headaches, nagging thoughts, vivid dreams, perhaps?" "No, nothing like that. Not recently, at least."  "But you had reported some dreams some time ago, yes? You said it felt like you were…"

The young woman’s heart leapt in her throat. Although she was not sure what she was going to say, she intuitively felt as though she had to get this answer correct. Home. What gave her the right to say that word? "I haven’t thought much about home," said Maeve, suddenly cool. "I’ve spent too much time in this room playing your games and going to your school and eating your food. Every damn day, in fact. "--Maeve? Was that you?" "Anything else?" asked President Dorothy.  Maeve shook her head, and tried her hardest to look directly through the old woman. "To your room, please."  Maeve took a dizzying step out of her chair and exited the cavernous room without turning back.  ./. The dying embers of the golden sunset lingered just above the thick row of trees that surrounded Maeve’s cell in every direction. She’d been waiting– aching– to hear something from someone. A punishment, an explanation. She wasn’t sure if she should try to find President Dorothy and apologize. She knocked directly under the painted "135" on the wooden door, and turned to make her way back upstairs silently. But that didn’t matter. Now she could see her way to the bathroom. She tried once more to walk without holding onto the walls, but it was nearly impossible. Here she was, physically, mentally exhausted, talking to Cassuis on a school-issued laptop while still full of a God-knows-what drug.

In fact– she chuckled ruefully– she could have said anything before she had fallen asleep. Maybe she told too much of the truth. Maybe she made something up. She could be in new levels of trouble altogether. In fact, she thought, there’s a nonzero chance that someone’s coming to put a bullet in my head right now, just like they did to Jason. Maybe some other kid from across the country is better at communicating while under the influence.  But then why would they have let her wake up at all? Maeve massaged her temples. It hurt to think, and it hurt even more so when it was about what President Dorothy was going to do to her as a result of today.  At any rate, she concluded, she would probably not have woken up alone in her room on the brink of dehydration if she was in the good graces of her captors.  With all of these things in mind, Maeve scanned the email once more. Ordinarily, she did not see President Dorothy throughout the course of the week, so she would not get the chance to ask if she could get a lesson moved before next Friday. It seemed as though Maeve would just have to assume.

She clicked the reply button, and the cursor did not linger on the screen for long.  I’ll see you on Friday ;)   -B ./. Maeve sandwiched her head in between two pillows and pressed them as hard as she could against her ears.

Still, the commotion from below was enough to keep her awake, even though it was hours past her normal bedtime. With heavy eyelids, she checked the solid red digits of the clock on her nightstand.  10:18 PM. She couldn’t quite make out what was being said downstairs, but she was sure that it involved a lot of what must have been either shouting or crying. Under ordinary circumstances, the commotion would have been rather concerning, but Maeve was relatively sure she knew it had something to do with the play she’d just been to.  It was very long and confusing. Maeve knew that her sister was the lead, and she was very impressed by the fact that Quinn had managed to remember so many lines perfectly. But by the time intermission had ended, she had grown quite uncomfortable in her chair, and frankly a bit sick and tired of the way the big kids were always singing about everything all of the time. After she had unsuccessfully asked to leave by tugging on her father’s sleeve, she had decided to try to fall asleep, uncomfortable as she was, in an attempt to make time go by faster.

At first, sleep seemed impossibly far away. She squirmed and wriggled in the oversized auditorium chair in pursuit of the perfect position, but there was always something wrong. Her hand would start to fall asleep, or her neck would be bent at an odd angle. Finally, her father reached over and rubbed her shoulder. "Maeve, honey, sit still. The show’s almost over." Reluctantly, she resumed an upright position and returned her gaze to the stage. There was her sister, lying on the ground, in the grasp of some muscular bearded man who looked just as old as her third-grade teacher.  Maeve knew what was going to happen next. Unfortunately, she didn’t have enough time to look away. The bearded grown-up put his mouth all over Quinn’s mouth, right there in front of the whole audience!

Maeve thought she was going to be sick. It sounded like Quinn was going to be sick, too. She was down on the ground for a while, and then she started calling for help. But when the lights turned back on and some other grown-ups ran onto the stage, she told them not to touch her, but with an extra word that Maeve did not recognize. Eventually, though, she stood up and ran off the stage, so Maeve had thought that everything was alright.  Her parents weren’t acting normal, though. When Quinn ran off of the stage, her mother grabbed her arm and ran out of the auditorium. The Harpers spent the next few minutes asking everyone and anyone if they had seen their daughter. Although she’d mostly grown out of them, Maeve could still remember how she felt during her meltdowns. She would kick and scream and shout because nothing made her more unhappy than when something was unfair, and life seemed to be so unfair all the time. But it seemed as though mommy and daddy were having meltdowns together, at the same time, even though they were grown-ups. She didn’t usually see grown-ups have meltdowns.  Thanks to the help of a thin boy who was dressed entirely in black, the Harpers eventually found Quinn. She had locked herself in a practice room, still in her princess costume, and she was looking out the window. She didn’t want to come out at first, but she eventually unlocked the door when she made them promise that they would take her straight home.  The ride home was very quiet. All Maeve could remember was that the low hum of the car driving on backroads combined with the darkness of the spring night and the cool air from the vent was nearly enough to put her to sleep. Unfortunately, they arrived back home just as she was nodding off. She reluctantly allowed her father to pick her up and carry her into her room.

That was when the shouting started. Now, more awake than ever, she felt curious to know exactly what was happening downstairs.  She turned on the light and took a tenuous step out of bed.  The muffled noise from downstairs made the cold floor vibrate ever so slightly on Maeve’s feet. She felt very grown-up, walking around at this hour. Sometimes, as she was falling asleep, she would hear her father gently making his way around the house. On some school nights, she would be sent to bed before he got home from work, and she’d wake up the next morning after he left. It was a great mystery to her what her father did those nights. At any rate, she knew for sure that no one else from her class was allowed to be up this late, especially on a Sunday night. The excitement made her heart pound. She reached for the doorknob and twisted it open. The commotion turned into words, which Maeve could only just make out.

"...caused it, I mean… anything…" "No! No… Mom, I’m telling you, it just happened!"  Quinn was hysterical. She spoke through uneven breaths, as though she was trying her hardest to stop from crying.  Quinn wasn’t supposed to be having a meltdown; she was practically a grown-up herself. Something must have gone seriously wrong. Maeve made her way silently to the upstairs landing in an attempt to hear the quieter words of her parents.

"And nothing like this has happened before?" "No. I really thought… it was stupid, but I really thought I was going to… suffocate." "Oh, honey," said her mother. There was silence for a moment.  "You know, Quinnie, this type of thing happens to people all the time."

"I wish it could have happened to me at literally any other time," said Quinn, quietly.  "You’re right. I know. But sometimes, when the mind isn’t quite right, the body has a way of…expressing the imbalance." "Dad, what are you talking about?" "I know how talented you are. I know how much this musical meant– still means– to you. But I also know that you’ve been asked to do much more than someone your age should be asked to do. You’re still a freshman in high school! I know I wouldn’t have been able to balance school and homework and social life and three hours of rehearsal every day at age fifteen. Especially not with the added pressure of being the lead."

Another moment of silence. Maeve shifted even closer to the top step. Another six inches forward and she would be in plain sight of the rest of her family. "So when something small happens, because you’re under so much pressure… it can spiral out of control. And it seemed… from my point of view… that–" "That boy. You haven’t mentioned him at all. Is he–" "I don’t want to talk about it."

"Quinn, is he hurting you? Is he making you uncomfortable? I need to know if–" "I said, I don’t want to talk about it." Her voice cracked as she spoke.  Suddenly, Maeve could hear footsteps approaching the stairs. Quinn was coming up! Panicking, Maeve turned around and moved as quickly and as quietly as she could toward her room.  Almost immediately, the socks on her feet betrayed her. As she hopped past the one spot on the old wooden floor that always seemed to creak, she lost her balance for one heart-stopping moment. But with a mighty wobble, she managed to steady herself enough to leap into her room and silently pull the door almost closed in one perfectly executed motion.

With curiosity still piqued, however, Maeve kept her fingers on the single horizontal pencil line that her mother had drawn to mark her height earlier that week to keep the door open by a half inch. Silently, breathlessly, she watched her sister pass by.  She moved quickly, with her head down. She was sniffling as she walked. Her long hair was unusually frizzy, and the elegant princess costume she had been wearing during the play was replaced with one of her father’s old, baggy sweatshirts.  But just as she was about to enter her own room, Quinn stopped and turned around. Maeve jumped away from the door.  Her sister sobbed from the hallway.
"Stop looking at me, Maeve!"  With a loud bang, Quinn’s door was shut.  The light. It had undoubtedly bled under the door and into the hallway. Her heart fragmented into one thousand pieces.  ./.

Bess swung her arm forward. The ball started decidedly right-of-center, but as it approached the pins, it gently spun its way back on course. The satisfyingly solid crunch of the inevitable collision gave way to yield a completely clean lane. She raised both of her hands in the air, triumphant.  "Damn, Bess! You said you’ve never played this before?"

The final scores flashed on the screen. Bess had shot a 201, while Jacob and Amy tied with 183. Ben finished with a whopping total of 94.  The heavily-bearded Ben set his controller down onto the coffee table and took a swig from his bottle.  "There has to be something wrong with this remote. I was turning my wrists and everything, but the ball never–" "Babe," interjected Amy. "You just suck, that’s all."

Ben’s face began to turn pink. Bess had to stop herself from laughing. The fact that he was taking this game so seriously struck her as very amusing.  Jacob took a look at the clock on his microwave, and stood up from his spot on the couch.  "It’s almost nine. Are you guys ready to head over?" Ben mumbled something, and Amy scolded him privately. Bess stretched her legs and stood up. She could hardly believe that they had been bowling for so long.

"I guess I’ll take that as a yes," said Jacob, walking over to his fridge.  Bess stepped past the quarreling lovers to find her shoes. As she moved toward the door, Jacob stopped her. "Are you sure you don’t want one, Bess? For the walk over?" He was bent over, loading some number of drinks into his navy blue drawstring bag. He held out a lite beer and shook it ever so lightly, as though to tempt her with his offer.

"I’m fine, thanks," she said, nervously playing with her hair. "I don’t think I’d be able to pay you back for it… anytime soon, anyway." Jacob chuckled. "Who do you think paid for those iced teas you’ve been drinking all afternoon?" Bess could feel her face heating up. Jacob shook his head.  "Don’t worry about it. If you don’t want to drink, that’s fine. Just let me know if you change your mind. First one’s free."

For as nice as they were, all of Cassius’ friends seemed to get a kick out of messing with Bess. She would just have to get them back someday.  Eventually, they were all ready to go. Amy and Jacob both brought their own small backpacks full of refreshments, while Ben took his stash in something resembling a full-size duffel bag. Bess could not decide whether to feel left out, amused, or horrified. At any rate, she hoped that there were no police officers stationed on the three blocks in between Jacob’s house and Cassius’.  As they walked, they battled the cutting wind of the cold, cloudy night.  "I think," said Ben, shielding himself from a particularly strong gust, "if I could have chosen to not live in one place in the world, it would be right here."

Amy shook her head. "You don’t mean that." "I do!" replied Ben, who had to shout over the howling of the wind. "Well…actually, I might choose New Jersey first." Bess replied quickly. "It’s not that bad." "It’s the sweaty armpit of America. Everyone knows that."

Even Amy laughed.  "At least I can walk up the stairs in New Jersey without feeling like I need to hurl." "I think I’d rather go up another mile and breathe that air than take one whiff of New Jersey." It seemed as though ever since Ben had figured out Bess was from New Jersey, he had not stopped teasing her about it.

"There are real houses where I’m from. With normal people in them. It’s a regular  place. And I think you’re just scared." "Scared? Bess, you’re absolutely right I’m scared. People from New Jersey can’t be normal. They’ve got to be up to something." "Bess," interrupted Amy, "I’m glad you were able to come with us. Even though you are from New Jersey." "How did you manage to convince your parents?" added Jake. "I thought they were, like, super strict."

"I… told them I’d be out tonight." "Really? They were alright with that?" "...Yeah. They want me to branch out, and have experiences, and make connections, and other… things like that." How she wished to forget the summary of the many lectures her mother had given to her all those years ago.

"Ah. So they must have wanted you to convince all of us to run to my car after school and spend six hours at my house just like you did, then." "Yes, exactly." Jacob frowned and nodded. Bess laughed, but she ran a hand through her hair and quickened her pace.  It was not much longer before the four students had reached Cassius’ house. Even standing outside, it was readily apparent that there were a great deal more guests than Bess had anticipated. Cars lined the street up and down, and a mix of bass-boosted music and loud chatter spilled from beyond the walls of the gigantic house.

And gigantic, it was. Stuck in a neighborhood of homes that seemed to be on par with Bess’ own across the country, Cassius’ house, complete with a sprawling lawn, three stories’ worth of massive, ornate windows, and a sprawling, slanting roof, was a mini-mansion.  As much as she wanted to stop and marvel at the house, Bess was eager  enough to be inside that she hurried quickly to the front door along with Ben, Amy, and Jacob. Jacob pulled a glove off of his right hand and banged on the oversized polished wooden door.  Almost immediately, a random man opened the door and let them inside. Bess, the last of the four to enter, could hardly believe the scene she witnessed.  Humanity piled more closely and more intensely than she had ever thought possible. The room she was standing in, less of a living room and more of a foyer, felt as cramped as though she were standing in an outhouse bathroom. It didn’t smell much better, either. People, some she recognized as fellow high school students, and some she didn’t, were dancing either with, on, or completely separate from each other. The music was so loud that Bess’ skull seemed to be vibrating. It took her serious effort to put thoughts together over the assaulting noise. The floor was covered with a thick white carpet which Bess could already see was stained in multiple places, and every so often Bess thought that she could hear a loud crash or a shout over everything.

She turned to see a massive pile of coats next to the door. Inwardly saying goodbye to hers, she threw her purple jacket atop the pile in fear that she would melt otherwise.  She looked back to the sea of people. Everyone she had come with was instantly gone, like pool balls broken by an expert player. She stood on her tiptoes to look for her friends, and began to feel a dreadful panic. There was no way she would be able to spot anyone in this crowd. Bess resolved to at least make her way upstairs. Perhaps if she could find a room which was less than packed to the brim with people, she could think about what to do next. The wide stairway was just on the other side of the foyer.  She awkwardly made her way forward. She tried not to concentrate on how many people she had to touch to move through the crowd. Instead, she tried to mentally  describe the quality of the air as though she was writing in her journal.

Sickly sweet, fermented, with hints of body odor and desperation. Still, if you ask Ben, much cleaner than New Jersey’s– Suddenly, a large man backed up directly into her path. Bess’ shoulder knocked into his elbow, and she could only watch as some of his drink spilled onto his shirt.  "Oh my gosh, I am so sorry–"  The man turned to her slowly. He was well beyond high school age.

"Hmmm?" he said. Bess spoke again, though in reality she couldn’t even hear herself over the music.  The man waited for some time, as though seriously contemplating her words. Finally, he responded very loudly and sloppily.  "You don’t even have a drink? Here, take mine–"

He thrust out his arm with the red cup. Not knowing what else to do, she took it. The man raised both his arms and shouted excitedly. Bess moved much more quickly than she had before, being careful not to spill her newfound drink on anyone else.  At long last, she reached the top of the stairs. As she had hoped, the second floor, though still packed with partygoers, was significantly less congested than the lower floor.  She was in a long hallway which overlooked the downstairs to one side and the house’s backyard to another. There were tasteful paintings on the walls, and toward the end of the hallway, there was a map of the country with pins in various locations. She thought that despite its size, this house must feel very quaint when there were less people in it.

In search of a place to discard her drink, Maeve made her way to the map. She was looking for a bathroom, but every door seemed to be closed tightly, and she didn’t want to find out what was going on behind any of them, especially if they were not bathrooms.  By the time she reached the map, she had become certain that her lot in life was to be stuck there, in the midst of all of these hundreds of people, holding this random red solo cup, for the rest of time. She looked at it sadly. Pins stuck out of New York, Dallas, Phoenix, Minneapolis, Orlando, Memphis, and Denver. None in New Jersey, though.  As she studied it, she heard to her right a very faint flushing noise, followed soon after by the click of an opening door. An opportunity! But as she began to hurry to the bathroom, she stopped in her tracks. Across the hall, near the stairs, was Cassius, walking directly toward her.  "Cassius!" she screamed, forgetting about the drink in her hand. "Cassius!"

Although he did not look up at her, he motioned for her to follow him. A bit confused, she looked to see whether anyone else had noticed and retraced her steps.  He retreated down the other side of the hallway and slipped into one of the countless rooms. Bess squeezed past two groups of girls and followed him inside, turning her head both ways to make sure no one was watching. She didn’t know why, but Cassius had done it, so she figured she might as well.  Sensing no eavesdroppers, she gingerly closed the door until she felt a click. The unbearable volume of the music was softened by an appreciable amount. For that alone, Bess was grateful. She turned around and found Cassius sitting on a cheap-looking chair, in front of a desk topped with a television. He had paused some sort of video game, and held the controller in his hands, but did not resume playing.

"Um… what’s up?" asked Bess. Cassius’ room was quite messy. Clothes littered his bed, and garbage overflowed from small bins next to the wall. There were schoolbooks and papers strewn about on the floor. And eight or nine empty beer cans sat crushed next to Cassius’ chair.  He turned around. "I’m sorry, Bess." "Sorry? What do you have to be sorry for?"

He sighed. When he spoke it was clear that he was drunk, but not yet incoherently so.  "All these people. I didn’t want everything to be this big. I just kept inviting people and I couldn’t stop myself." Bess shook her head. "It’s alright. I think it’s pretty cool that you got this many people to come. I’ve never really been to a house party like this before."  "Did you… want to go back out, then? I don’t mean to keep you in here if–"

"No. I was really just looking for someone I knew, anyway." Cassius gave a halfhearted chuckle. Bess traced the lines of her palm with her pointer finger, which was starting to absorb the chill of the drink.  "Well," said Cassius, slowly, "if you’re going to be in here, then… I got you something. It’s dumb, I don’t know if you’ll like it, it didn’t cost–" "I want to see it. Even though my birthday isn’t until July."

"No, it’s not a birthday present, um…" He fumbled through a row of cabinets below his television, ostensibly looking for the present. As thirty seconds became a minute and then two, Bess began to take notice of an ache in her legs.  "Ah," he said at last, elbow-deep in a cabinet filled with wires and old toys and other pieces of junk.  "Found it."

He pulled out a small black box and handed it to Bess. She held it in her drink-free hand and admired it. It was heavy, and made of felt– the kind of box which might hold a wedding ring. "This isn’t–" "No. Just open it," he said, holding on to her drink. She did. Inside was a shiny silver necklace with a fairly large orange gemstone attached. She held it up. Light fleetingly angled off of the chain and the stone, winking flashes of muted brilliance as it spun in the air.

"Orange sapphire," said Cassius. "It reminded me of your hair." "Wow," she said, breathlessly. She fastened the clasp around her neck. It felt far more expensive than anything she’d worn before.  "I don’t know what to say. Thank you." Cassius gave her the cup back and eyed the door. His gaze seemed to go in and out of focus.

"So… did you want to see the game that I play all the time? It’s called Ultimate Warfare, and I think–" "Um. I’m fine, thanks. I don’t really like violent video games." Cassius nodded quickly. Bess chewed on her lip. Eager to shift directions, she scanned the room. Her eyes came to rest on something familiar.  "Is that a guitar? Do you play?"

Cassius, regaining some composure along with the subject change, blinked twice before answering.  "Yeah, I, uh… my dad was going to teach me, but he never really got around to it." Cassius took a wobbly step up from his chair and reached into the small space in between the base of his bed and the corner of his wall. Sticking his arm out, he could only just fish out the acoustic guitar by its neck. As he pulled it out of its makeshift cubby, some old clothes came spilling out onto the floor. Bess did not want to think about how long those might have been there.  He sat down loudly on his bed, and threw the instrument over his lap. As he ran his fingers over the strings, Bess could not help but notice the way he stared at the fretboard as though it were a python rather than a piece of wood.

"I think… I remember how to play an E," he said, and began pretzeling the fingers of his left hand.  "Cassius," said Bess. "When was the last time you played this thing?" He stared blankly ahead. "I, uh…don’t remember." "You’re going to need to tune it."

Somehow, Cassius looked even more confused than before. "Do you need me to help?" With a smirk, he turned the guitar over to her. She carefully set her drink on the desk next to the television. She then stepped over to his bed and took a seat in between a rogue pair of shorts and a handful of socks which looked upon initial inspection to be possibly clean.  The guitar was warm. It wasn’t warm to the touch, but it seemed to warm her in a way that nothing had in some time. The familiar weight of the body, the way her fingers curled around the neck, the cold nickel-plated steel of the strings. Instantly she was back home.

"I don’t think I’ll be able to get this exactly right," she said absentmindedly, fiddling with each of the tuning pegs and listening closely to the sound of the instrument against the raving, pounding techno-style music that seemed to shout at her from an inch outside the door. "I can get it pretty close, though. My sister has perfect pitch, so she could–" Bess stopped mid-sentence and hoped that Cassius was either too drunk or too distracted to hear her. Fortunately, it seemed at least one of the two was the case. He was staring at a spot on the wall across his room and tapping his foot quickly on the floor.  "All set," said Bess. She strummed a simple chord progression to ensure that everything was in order.  Cassius came instantly back to life. He turned to look at her as though she had just told him he’d won the lottery. His mouth hung open in a stupefied smile for a moment before he spoke.

"You actually know how to play guitar?" Bess smiled sheepishly. "It’s not… my main instrument. I’m much more comfortable with the cello. But… yeah, I’ve been playing guitar for a few years now." Cassius made no effort to conceal his amazement.  "When were you going to tell me that? That’s awesome! Could you play something right now?"

She paused, and grabbed at her necklace. "I guess. But only because I didn’t get you anything."  Bess hadn’t had any practice for the past three months or so, and the callouses on her left hand had tragically faded to a significant degree. Beyond that, all of the strings were old and muddled, and she had to play much louder than she otherwise would have because of the relentless music outside.  But in spite of everything, Bess found that she had not forgotten the piece she had been preparing for her talent show in lifetimes past. In fact, it sounded to her even more bitterly affecting than it had when she’d first discovered it at that concert, on that night, hundreds and hundreds of miles ago. By the time it was over, magic melancholy saturated the loose threads and empty cans of Cassius’ room. "Holy shit," he said, quietly.

Bess set the guitar down gingerly, and found the spot Cassius had been staring into just a few minutes earlier.  "Will you teach me how to play like that sometime?" Bess smiled sadly. A rueful resignation was beginning to overtake her.  "If…I’m ever allowed to see you again after tonight…then yes."

"If–?" Cassius’ face fell. "No. You know what? This is all my fault." "Cassius, stop."         "What the hell are your parents gonna think when they see where you’ve been?" Bess was a bit taken aback. "I decided to come here. Not you."

"That’s not the point," mumbled Cassius. "I could have just told you and maybe those idiots at the lunch table to be here, and everything would have been fine." "What are you talking about? I thought you wanted to have a real house party." "No, no. I was scared. I needed someone to be here tonight, and I couldn’t stop thinking these… stupid thoughts. I just wanted to…do stuff together. With my friends. But also you, Bess. You’re so fucking cool but…you don’t…I don’t…we…"  He lost his train of thought. The music outside seemed to grow so loud that it was pounding on the door. Bess was about to interject when Cassius resumed speaking.

"But fuck that. Fuck it, right? That’s how things have to be. And usually they work out. Like, God or someone decided that I should get to see you tonight even though I decided to shut myself in and let my house get trashed by randos." Cassius let out a big sigh. Bess thought for a moment.  "You’re right." "Hmm?"

"Fuck it." "What?" She knelt in front of him and looked him dead in the eyes. She grabbed the cup from the desk, raised it to her lips and finished it in two big gulps. It was bitter and strong and much heavier than she could have imagined, and it made her want to throw up at first. But she didn’t. And without missing a beat, she reached for his head and pulled him into a kiss.  Maeve had wondered what her first kiss would be like. She had always imagined it in a nice moonlit park, or at a school dance. She imagined the boy would be well-dressed, and she thought it would feel like fireworks exploding in her heart.

In reality, hers took place in Cassius’ hot, cramped room, tasted like cheap alcohol, and smelled like dirty laundry. Fireworks exploded, but they did not feel like they were born of some romantic love.  After she pulled away, Cassius sat frozen still on his bed. The air crackled with electricity. The door pounded, pounded.  "Are… was that alright?" asked Bess, timidly.  Cassius tried to express ideas. "Was that…I…I think…I lo–…ah…"

She kissed him again. Even though he was more ready for it this time, it was not much better than before.  As Bess pulled away for the second time, she knew instantly that something was wrong. The music had jumped in volume to the point where Bess could feel the vibration of the bass in her skull. Cassius’ face, which had just been quite flushed with color, turned a ghostly shade of white, and his eyes looked miles past her. With a sinking feeling, Bess turned around. In the doorway, dressed to the nines and unquestionably more angry than she had ever seen him before, stood her father.  ——————————————————————————————————————-

"I don’t even know what to say to you," said Steven, the words emerging from his throat like sandpaper.  Maeve was fixed on the uniform motion of the road beside her. She breathed as quietly as she could.  "It would be one thing if you had gone to a party without telling anyone. It’s another that I found you at that party in a boy’s room with… how many beer cans on the ground? Eight? Ten? How many were yours?" "None." She barely moved her mouth when she spoke.

"Look at me and tell me you weren’t drinking." "I wasn’t." Her gaze did not move.  Her father paused for a moment to take a particularly sharp turn over a patch of ice.  "You know something, Maeve?" he said, fighting back hysterics. "I could handle everything. I could handle it if you got in this car stinking drunk or pregnant, even. We would figure it out. But to just… go missing? During your lesson? To disrespect not only me, but President Dorothy, and everyone who’s worked so hard just for you—"

"And what exactly have they done for me?" She turned and sneered at him for the first time. Steven was not one to get mad often in the past– not at her, at least. She’d seen– heard, mostly– the visceral anger he could conjure up for arguments with Anna. But something felt odd to her regarding his emotion. There was no fire behind his eyes, no veins ready to burst in his neck.  "They’ve helped you. And how dare you disrespect my work. How dare you put yourself at risk for no good reason at all." "Putting me at risk? You should know something about that."

"Now is not the time–" "Shut up! How can you dump me across the country, lock me up, bail for three months, and then preach to me?" A long, excruciating silence followed. Maeve waited and waited for the threat of a punishment to be levied against her.  "You have food in the back seat," said Steven, in that sandpaper-y voice again.
"I– what?" "It’s behind you. Ham and cheese. I know you liked it when Mom made it." She turned around. Sure enough, perched on the back seat, was a small square wrapped in tinfoil.  "I’m not hungry."
"You’ve eaten, then?" "It doesn’t matter." "Answer the question." "...Yes. At someone’s house."

"With that boy?" "No. A different one." Her father sighed in resignation. As they pulled into the empty lot of the old, overgrown building that had become home, Maeve suddenly felt that she had miscalculated something.

Steven pulled the key out of the ignition and the car came to a stifling halt. With sad, tired eyes, he looked at Maeve. Her hair was frizzy, her sweater was about a half size too big for her, and she smelled of some type of alcohol.  Her eyes betrayed even more fatigue than her father’s. "You’re so beautiful, Maeve." With that, he stepped out of the car, opened her door, and led her ploddingly to her reckoning, guarded by thick glass doors and acres of undisturbed forest.
./. Maeve blearily gazed forward, and extended her hand again.  "Congratulations," said the man in the glasses.  "Good work," said a tall lady.

"Best of luck," said a man with a purple tie.  Handshake, after handshake. They lined the walls, these faceless people. She had seen a few of them on her first day here, but there were so many more today. They all wanted to grab her hand, to see her, to say some empty thing to her.  Her father’s puppet wore its most brightly painted smile, and accepted much of the congratulations as though they were its own. It ushered Maeve forward through the carefully organized crowd, but not before she had met with every last one of them.  Maeve’s mind was just as out-of-focus as the crowd she dealt with. She could not possibly have known what she’d done or what she’d have to do. She confidently could conclude that she’d done nothing worthy of praise, at any rate. She was around five hours late for her lesson. All there was left to do was to wait and see.

Suit, after suit. They passed room after room, shaking and talking and swooning over her. 127, 129, 131. If nothing else, she thought she knew where the line would stop.  And of course, she did. She met with the last man, balding, hoarse, elderly, next to room 137. Through the unceasing round of applause, and through whatever stare her father may have been giving to her, she stepped inside.  President Dorothy, and five doctors in suits, were all gathered around the chair in the center of the main room. Protruding from the corner of the room was an old widescreen television across the room that was perched on top of a small table with wheels. Redundant, perhaps, she thought. The screen that had been on top of the chair ever since she’d arrived at the facility was still keeping vigil over the storage closet in the corner of the room. Perhaps it was never meant to be used at all.  The chair was surrounded by a host of other machines, some large and some small, that Maeve could not recognize. Some flashed, some made noise, all of them tracked, moved, breathed. In unnerving contrast with the rows of people outside, the doctors looked at her blankly, with strained, anxious eyes.

President Dorothy gestured for her to take a seat, but Maeve was already walking over to do so. Her skin glowed bright white, enough even to be seen outside the room.  She sat down, and the doctors sprung instantly into action. One taped a small monitor to her temple, and another clipped a heartbeat sensor to her finger. A third intently read an output of one of the machines, and the remaining two wrote furiously on legal notepads.  President Dorothy monitored the chaos for a brief moment, and then stepped to tower over Maeve, much like she had done the previous week.  "This is an important night, Maeve. I trust you have been properly welcomed by the crowd outside."

Maeve nodded.  "Every one of those people– some from around here, others from across the country, many from across the world– have sacrificed endless amounts of time, money, and sanity to make what will happen here a reality. I wouldn’t want you to take their work for granted. Just as they thank you, you should thank them." Maeve was inescapably numb.  "Of course, you have played your part flawlessly as well. I haven’t told you much of anything about why you’ve been sent here, to Denver, or why you’ve been subject to these lessons. Regardless, you have grieved, and hurt, and healed. You’ve hated and loved. You’ve been bored and you’ve found passion. We now know your true strength."

"What?" said Maeve, genuinely confused.  "You’ve been wronged. You’ve been made to see something hideously unimaginable, and you’ve been made to relive it each week. Weaker minds would have succumbed to the challenge. Not you. You healed. You showed all of us that you can overcome tragedy.  "You also have been open to those around you, albeit partially through the magic of midazolam. You admitted to hating me, and you admitted to loving me. Beyond that, I know you have warmed up to one of your peers at school. It takes some measure of authenticity to love and to be loved. I know that if nothing else, deep down, you are honest with yourself about your feelings.  "Finally, and most crucially, this week you showed me that you relish agency. Why did you go to that party, Maeve? Was it because you thought I would forgive you? Was it because you thought it wouldn’t be a big deal to miss one lesson? I know you’re not stupid. You made a choice, one that you believed in, at any personal cost.

"You are a leader, Maeve. Whether that was always true or whether the past few months have made it so is irrelevant. You’ve passed every test I have administered. It would be foolish, then, to deny you your rightful position any longer."  President Dorothy motioned over to the doctor who had been positioned behind the machines. He wheeled the television slowly in front of the chair. In another existence she watched old documentaries on these types of sets in elementary school.  Wordlessly, he powered on the television, spurring an intense flurry of static that washed over the screen. The noise was relentless and monotone, whooshing to nowhere in particular.  He reached behind the television to manufacture a syringe, and delicately grabbed it with a gloved hand. He set it to rest in President Dorothy’s wrinkled palm.

"Please don’t drug me again," said Maeve, suddenly feeling desperation win out over everything else.  President Dorothy shook her head. "This time, you will feel much different. We must make the mind vulnerable to complete the process. You may recall having some rather vivid dreams directly after the attack, yes?" The old woman took Maeve’s right arm and expertly inserted the needle into one of her veins. Before she could even feel a pinch, it was over. There would be no struggling. There would be no time for further explanation.  "Sit still and watch the screen, my Lady."

Heart thumping, her eyes darted between President Dorothy and the doctors. Everyone here was doing a job. She was in a horror movie. As was the case last Friday, it was not long before Maeve began to feel odd. This time, however, she felt very light, particularly in her head. She settled on watching the television screen. The static seemed to warp and twist into strange patterns, the noise blending together with her very own thoughts and feelings. The room dove and turned away from her, and she felt as though she was going to fall directly out of her chair.  Something impossible happened. She became so light that she floated, gently, gracefully, out of the room, and into her cavernous mind. Everywhere she looked, she saw flashes of white and black, designing intricate patterns, only to please her. She heard grass swishing, bells chiming, rain pattering. She smelled a campfire, she felt the sun on her skin, she was full, hungry, dry, tired, alert, content, agitated.  She swam through the static and found herself, as clearly as though she was watching a movie in a theater. She was chasing after something on hard, dry ground. She wanted to catch it so badly. In fact, it was all she ever wanted. She ran faster and faster. She would catch it, she knew that.

She swam further, and found herself again. This time, she was tired, and she was looking for shelter from the cold. She needed to find it. She’d never been so cold in her life. She’d find shelter or she’d die trying.  Another version. She was angry. She was so angry. There was lots of motion around her, and everything was bigger than she was. She was so confused. Why were these things trying to hurt her?  She couldn’t go down without a fight. She bared her teeth and showed her claws, and prepared to jump to the top of one of those people. "NO!" she screamed, resisting the current of the static.

As though by force, she was jerked from the overwhelming unity of the daydream she’d been caught in. She was still swimming in the static, but something was different. She wasn’t angry anymore. In fact, she wasn’t full or hungry or cold or tired at all.  But she could still see what she’d just been about to do. She was in a city, and a flood of people were crossing a street. She was much smaller than all of them, and she had been just about to try to kill one of them.  But– that wasn’t her anymore. Instead, she watched what was formerly herself stop dead in its tracks mid-jump. In fact, she could see all of the past versions of herself stop dead. Alternate versions, too. It was as though she was watching hundreds, if not thousands, of live first-person body cameras, all at once.

She turned her attention to the one in the city. "Don’t kill those people," she told it.  To her surprise, it listened. She watched it abandon its leaping stance, and to some degree she even felt its rage subside.  She scanned through the different camera-style views, marveling at the way she could understand each of their perspectives. Every one was someplace different, doing something. The things controlling the views seemed to behave like animals, but they weren’t exactly like any Maeve had known about before. She examined one that was trotting around in a forest. She could tell it was rather hot, but otherwise it was content.

She watched it for a moment, ignoring the others. Then she had an idea.  "Pick up a leaf," she thought.  Sure enough, the creature walked over to the nearest leaf on the ground and held it up with a small, pink, fleshy hand.  Maeve disconnected from that creature and sank back into the static. Was she controlling these things? This had to just be a dream. An intensely vivid dream. There was no other way to explain what was happening.

But she had one final idea. She sank back into the static, without focusing on any of the creatures in particular. "Are any of you close to me right now?" she thought.  Suddenly, she was pulled out of the static and flooded with a vision.  She saw, and felt, as though she was around one foot tall. She was perched atop a high place.

To her side were a number of busy people, all tinkering away on pieces of machinery. But in front of her was a young woman with bright ginger hair sitting in a dentist’s chair, who looked like she was asleep, or perhaps in some sort of fitful trance. Maeve pulled out of the vision, gripped with panic. She tried to scream. She was a sickly mixture of confused and disturbed.  Suddenly, air returned to her lungs. She heaved deep, dry breaths, and felt the pounding of her heartbeat in her face, which was (though the room was too dark for anyone to see for sure) undoubtedly bright red. She was back in room 137– and, most importantly, she was back in her own body.  She frantically scanned the room, in an attempt to ensure that she was, in fact, back in real life. Words emerged from her mouth freely and rapidly.

"What happened? What was that? Is it over? Am I safe?" President Dorothy knelt by her side, and all five of the other employees had abandoned their work to get a look at the young woman. Maeve could not stop trembling.  With eyes wide in both curiosity and fascination, President Dorothy ran a hand over Maeve’s and spoke quietly to her. "Did you see them?"

"Did I see what? I saw…"  The expectant looks on everyone’s faces were almost enough to make Maeve cry. She did not want to recount the memory– the visions– she had just seen, for fear of entering back into them. "I saw… I tried… to kill someone. But then it wasn’t me. I told it– me– to stop, and it listened. I saw so much, so many of them. I think there was something watching me–" here she extended an unsteady finger toward the top of the monitor– "from right there." Of course, there was nothing on top of the old television except for a thin layer of dust. Even still, President Dorothy and the others gazed atop the set as though it were a completely alien piece of machinery.

Slowly, the old woman reached into the pocket of her suitcoat and brought out a silver flashlight which was not more than six inches long. She fixed the instrument directly at the spot atop the television, and with a small click purple light beamed across the room.  The pain was instant and overwhelming. Maeve felt it everywhere, but most so in her lungs, which felt as though they contained molten lava instead of air. She convulsed directly out of her chair, and did not scream so much as whimper, as screaming would have taken far too much breath.  It ended just as suddenly as it had begun. Maeve’s left cheek was on the floor, and every muscle in her body was tense, but there was no more pain. Instead, President Dorothy crouched beside her, and ran a gentle hand through her hair.  "I see they have taken to you quickly."

Stunned and shaking, Maeve remained on the ground. President Dorothy continued. "I’m sorry, my Lady. I just had to confirm what I heard to be true." "What happened to me?" asked Maeve, in a small voice.  "Those things you saw. Those things you likely felt as though you were. They’re out there. They’re real. Not many know they exist, but they do, and they always have. Interfectorum animi, they are called. When they do not have a leader, they exist just beyond the scope of observation, independently, recklessly, hedonistically, even. But now they’ve got you."

Maeve shut her eyes. "They are fiercely loyal things. To a fault, even. Now that you have connected with them, they will listen to you; they will share with you. You can unite them in ways that will accomplish great good in our world."  Maeve shook her head, eyes still closed. "None of this makes any sense." President Dorothy sighed. "Do you believe in ghosts, Maeve? Perhaps that isn’t relevant. Many people believe in ghosts or spirits. Many people claim to have had interactions with recently deceased loved ones, or centuries-old murder victims. I cannot speak to the veracity of all of those claims. But I can assure you that interfectorum animi– dreamers, as some informally call them– are naturally drawn to tragedy. And they have a penchant for attempting, in their own way, to speak to those who endure it."

Maeve sat up, still on the floor. "Does that make me some sort of… ghost whisperer?" President Dorothy gave a sympathetic smile. "In a sense. But as far as we know, ghosts are fictitious. Dreamers are not." Maeve asked one final question– one she had been wondering for a long time.  "Why me?"

President Dorothy stiffened. "We like to look for young people to take over when another Leader abdicates. We believe through the course of their lives, young leaders can make more worthwhile connections to dreamers. However, this introduces risk. Many young Leaders throughout history have revealed themselves to be woefully unfit to perform their duty. War, disease, hysteria– left unchecked, or under the control of a vulnerable Leader, dreamers have the power to infiltrate and corrupt the bodies and minds of the public, while remaining completely undetected in doing so. These dreamers are always going to want to inspire tragedy– it is what they are. Under the right Leader, however, this can be managed, and even used as a force for good. A good Leader has sharp emotional acuity. A good Leader thinks for themself, but is always willing to listen and collaborate. A good Leader is intelligent and charismatic. A good Leader is not afraid to do what must be done." President Dorothy sighed. "Your father nominated you, personally, when we decided that the previous Leader was to be replaced. In all of my experience, I could never recall one of my employees nominating a family member for Leader. But he was insistent that you had all of the qualities we were looking for. So my colleagues and myself spent several months observing you and a handful of other candidates, and you won out. Now, after teaching you personally for the last three months, I am confident we made the correct decision." Maeve shook her head. "I still don’t understand." "Come, now," said President Dorothy, helping Maeve to her feet. "You don’t have to understand everything right away. There are more lessons to be completed."

Maeve followed President Dorothy out of the room. In the hallway, which was impossibly bright, not a single soul had moved. The well-dressed people stood shoulder-to-shoulder, lining the walls of the first floor of the building in an eerie silence. All eyes were fixed upon the two women. Maeve looked and felt as though she was going to be sick. Regardless, President Dorothy gave Maeve a look of great pride and addressed the crowd confidently from her place just outside room 137.  "It is with great pride that I tell you: they are ours. I introduce to you today, and forever more, Lady Harper." A wave of deafening applause echoed throughout the human-adorned walls.

PART 3 How silly it was, she thought, that she’d been made to dress up like this. The day was cloudless, breezy, gentle, still free from the heft and humidity that was summer in New Jersey. As she followed her father into her school, she tugged at her dress and took one last longing look at the abundance of color she was being denied.

"Where is it?" he asked, arching his neck to gaze at the amateurish art displayed underneath large painted letters which read Welcome to Fillmore High! "At the end of the hallway, to the right." She spoke in a smaller voice than she’d intended. He sighed and set out to his right in large, clicking steps. Quinn did all she could to keep up with him, twice nearly falling over her own feet. Damn these heels, she thought, and damn women’s fashion.

When they reached the end of the hallway, Quinn’s father held open the door to the main office. Although it wasn’t a school day, the incessant hum of fingers on keyboards and phone calls transferring from line to line polluted the small space, which smelled pungently of new carpet.
