One of the women behind the desk met Quinn’s eyes. She wore large pearls and tapped away at her computer without looking. For an infinitesimal second, Quinn thought she saw something– fear? awe? pity?-- but the glance they shared was brief, and she began conversation with her father.  "Good afternoon. How can I help you?" "This is Steven Harper, with my daughter Quinn. We have a meeting with Officer O’Connell."

"He’s ready for you now. Follow me." Quinn wanted to crawl out of her skin and run back to the car.  The woman, who turned to make sure they were following but never looked at Quinn directly, led the pair behind the desk and around a corner. She stopped at a door and knocked slowly, bringing her hand to her mouth when she was done.  "Yes?" came a deep voice from inside.

"The Harpers are here." "Tell them I’m ready." The woman with the pearls smiled and extended a hand to the door handle. Steven turned it and stepped inside.  "Good to meet you two in person," said Officer O’Connell, standing up from behind his desk to greet them.

Quinn closed the door and shook Officer O’Connell’s hand. Though his grip was firm, his hand was dry and weathered, as though he had worn leather gloves that day.  "Please, sit down." Quinn and her father sat at two chairs which faced the desk. Officer O’Connell unbuttoned his jacket and assumed his position across from them. Though he folded his hands and leaned back as he spoke, understated urgency stained his words. "I don’t want to keep you folks any longer than I have to. To be honest, I think the time for beating around the bush is over, anyway. We have a problem that needs to be solved. As I mentioned in my phone call with you, Mr. Harper, Quinn has eighteen unexcused absences in the past twenty-two school days, which–"

"And as I mentioned to you in our phone call, Officer, she acquired and submitted a doctor’s note, which should have provided an excuse for those absences." "She did," he said, sitting up straight. "The doctor’s note allowed for two weeks of missed classes. It’s been a month since that ended. She would need a new note." Steven sighed. "Please refer to me as Dr. Harper, Officer." "Of course. My mistake. But as I was saying, Quinn has eighteen absences in the past twenty-two school days. New Jersey state law is clear that everyone under the age of seventeen has to come to school on a regular basis. For any other student with this absence rate, I’d have been in contact with the juvenile court system weeks ago. But I do understand there are some… extenuating circumstances, in this case."

Steven twitched as he spoke. "Extenuating circumstances. You’re right about that, officer." Quinn was busy looking at the photograph of Officer O’Connell and what appeared to be his family on his desk. He must have been ten years younger in that picture, with no patches of gray in his tightly kept hair. If they were indeed his immediate family, he had a beautiful wife, and two sons, neither of which could have been more than ten.  "Yes. What happened was very unfortunate. But the reality of the situation is that Quinn needs to be at school. When we talked before it sounded as though transferring was not an option you wanted to look into." "No. Quinn and I both feel strongly about that."

Their smiles were so authentic. Every one of the four in the picture had bright eyes and perfect teeth. It was no wonder Officer O’Connell displayed the photograph so proudly.  "Is that right, Quinn?" She sucked in a breath and met the officer’s gaze. Now that she really looked at him, she figured the picture must have been even more than ten years old.  "Yes, sir."

"Great. Then the way I see it, there are three ways we can solve this problem. The first is that I get into contact with an attorney at the courthouse and the two of you argue against each other. If a judge rules that you don’t take proper care of your daughter, Dr. Harper, you’ll be fined, and Child Protective Services will be notified. If a judge rules that you are uncontrollable, Miss Harper, you could be sent to juvenile hall. That’s the option we’re trying to avoid." They both nodded. Somehow, in that sparsely air conditioned building, trapped in that stuffy outfit, Quinn was cold. Officer O’Connell looked at her as he resumed speaking. "The second option– and there’s nothing wrong with this one– is that you get another doctor’s note. Find a professional, explain the situation, including the absences, and I’m sure they’ll work with you. If you have to miss the rest of the year, you have to miss the rest of the year. Big deal. There’s summer school, you could repeat classes, take this high school thing at your own pace. Plenty of people do. "The third option–" he shifted his gaze to Quinn’s father– "is my personal favorite. You’ve told me that Quinn wants to work through her incident with yourself and her mother. Is that right?"

"Yes. We’d need more time." "Well, we don’t have much left, but if you really believe that is the case, then I’ll give you the rest of this weekend. Whatever it takes to get her to school, do it. I’d want her here and accounted for every day this week. Not showing up late, not leaving early, nothing. Otherwise, I’ll go straight to option one." "I see." "Great. You’ve got my number. If both of you don’t have any more questions, call me by five today and let me know–"
"Option three," said Quinn, abruptly.  A silence followed. Officer O’Connell adjusted his sleeves.  "Dr. Harper?" Steven took a slow breath and studied his daughter.

"Option three," he agreed. "Alright then. Option three it is. Let me know if anything changes." He cleared his throat and shuffled to the door. As the Harpers stood up to leave, Officer O’Connell furrowed his brow. "Uh, Dr. Harper? Would you mind if I spoke to your daughter alone for a moment?"

Steven paused. "Of course. I’ll be outside, Quinnie." Officer O’Connell closed the door behind him. Quinn, who had taken one step forward to leave, retreated and sat in her spot. The room had grown many feet in every direction.  "You’re not stupid," he said, once he was sure that her father was out of earshot. "I tell that to every kid that comes in here, but I mean it with you. I gave your grades a look this morning, and they’re all still A’s and B’s. God knows how you’re pulling that off." He stood behind his desk with his arms folded. Quinn had to look up to address him.

"I come in on test days." "And it looks like you’re getting your homework done on time, too." "My friend brings it in." "Right. I’ve been talking with some of your teachers, and they all say the same thing. Some of the kids that come in here– and I’m not calling them stupid– high school is not for them. Some others have problems at home. Usually truancy comes down to one of those two factors. From what I can see, and from what your teachers can see, that isn’t the case for you."

Quinn felt an overpowering urge to leave that room. She struggled to maintain eye contact with Officer O’Connell. "You’ve got a real chance to be something. And I don’t tell that to every kid that comes in here. After opening night, when the word got out about you… well, you should have seen the lines for those shows on Saturday. And the bootlegs. People were filming the show and charging money to share the videos. I don’t know if you’re aware of this, but one got posted online and now it’s got millions of views." She was aware. "Anyway. What happened, happened. But it doesn’t change anything. I’d be embarrassed, anxious, all of that, if I were you. Honestly, I don’t think I could imagine how you’re feeling right now. But once you realize that was just a… step, on your journey, well, shoot. Just come to class. If anyone gives you a hard time, kid, adult, whatever, just let anyone in this office know about it. They’ll help you. You got that?"

She nodded. She wasn’t looking at him anymore. "You’ve got a lot to give to the world. You’re smart enough to know that gets a lot easier if you do what you have to do now." "May I be excused?" she asked, voice beginning to waver. "Of course," he said, moving toward the door. "I’ll be seeing you on Monday."

She pushed past him and tore out of the office, heels and all. Her father, who had been seated in a chair, scrambled to his feet and followed her at a distance.  ./. She’d been in the car by herself for a long moment before she heard the door swing open.  He sat down but did not start the car. The front lot– heavily congested during school hours– was practically empty. The barren asphalt seemed to suck the color from the day.
"Can we talk?" he asked, quietly.  "I don’t want to," she said, looking away. "I’d like it if we did." She took a breath, but didn’t answer.

"What did he say that made you so upset?" "Nothing. Can we go home, please?" "We can. I just want to talk first." A middle-aged couple approached their vehicle. The man, dressed in rather unflattering shorts, pointed at a row of trees adjacent to the school while the woman laughed.
Quinn waited for them to pass by. "Okay." Steven spoke his question as if it were a statement.  "How did the officer upset you."
"He gave me the same bullshit that everyone else has been giving me lately." "Quinn May, this is not the time for language." "You said you wanted me to talk!" He started the car. "I did. Continue."

"I’m… sorry, Dad. That wasn’t right." "It’s how you felt. I want to know how you’re feeling." "No… I know Officer O’Connell just wanted to help. It’s just, that…" Quinn ran her fingers through her hair. Her father, waiting to turn onto the main road, glanced at her.

"Just that what?" "I don’t know what I need help for," she said, picking up steam at last. "I don’t need help to get better grades. I don’t go to parties and do drugs. I don’t sit around all day either. I don’t have that many friends, but I have Jenny, at least. I put on nice clothes when we go to church and I look after Maeve when I need to. I don’t get it. One bad thing happens, and you and Mom and everyone at school and everyone online tells me it doesn’t matter, but really they look at me like I’m some kind of problem that needs to be fixed. I don’t want that anymore. I just want to be left alone." Quinn found herself breathing heavily. Her father took agonizing seconds to respond. The couple was probably still laughing together.  "Where do you go?" he asked, corners of his mouth turned into a slight frown.

A light heat began to flush her face. She took one deep breath to maintain her composure.  "I go to the park. Different spots every day, different benches." "That’s what you tell me. Where do you really go?" The heat; the unbearable heat. "I’m not lying, Dad."

"I don’t care about that. I want to know where you really go during school." An instant of deliberation between two impossible options was all it took. He had won. She had to give him his prize.  "I– I, go–" "You’re not in trouble, Quinnie."
The words caught in her throat. She knew she had to say them, but the act was nearly impossible. "I, go, tothelibrary." "Do you walk there?" asked Steven, without missing a beat. She nodded.

"You’ve walked four miles through the city every day to the library, by yourself." She nodded again, smaller this time.  "Okay. What do you do in the library?" "My homework," she said, looking away. She was two feet tall.

"It doesn’t take you all day, does it?" She shook her head. He already knew. He must have.  "Is there anything else you do in the library, Quinn?" Perhaps she had expected to break down in this moment, overjoyed or overwhelmed that some other human being would finally be let in on her secret. But her eyes were dry and her spirit was empty. As she spoke, she felt brittle.
"I go downstairs and lock myself into an empty room, and I scream and cry and cut myself with a pair of scissors." A pause.  "Why?" "I don’t know. It’s not– ah–"

It was as though she’d been dumped into another person’s body. Nothing felt right when she spoke.  "Sometimes. When I have my nightmares, the only way… to get rid of them…" "Is by replacing psychological pain with physical pain," said her father, turning onto their street. "I guess," she croaked.

It really was a lovely day outside. They drove past Mrs. Anderson, who at seventy-seven maintained one of the most vibrant gardens in the neighborhood. She grew vegetables– peppers, tomatoes, zucchini, squash, and beans. Every Sunday morning she gave what she didn’t need to her neighbors, and every Sunday night she gave what wasn’t taken to the local farmer’s market. Across from her, a group of boys a few years younger than Quinn played basketball on a makeshift driveway court, just as they did almost every weekend, shoving and shouting and laughing too loud like every middle school boy seemed to do. When Steven parked the car and the hum of the engine and the whirring of the air conditioner surrendered to silence, Quinn felt each dribble of the ball and each drip of the watering can and each clack of administrative finger on key pull on her grasp of reality; question how she thought she knew the world worked.  Why was that couple laughing? "How much?" asked her father, trained on what was left of his daughter.  She shrugged.

"Where?" Quinn unlatched her seatbelt and picked a smudge on the windshield to stare at. Gingerly, she ran her left hand across her right side, starting just below her underarm, navigating over fresh wounds, hastily-applied bandages, and emerging scars which sent dull pain even from under her dress, and ending two-thirds of the way down the outside of her thigh.  "I love you, Quinnie May," he said, when she was finished, "and I think you’re one of the smartest people I’ve ever known. But you’re wrong about something." She looked at him. He’d found the same windshield spot she had.

"You’re not the problem that needs fixing. I don’t feel that way, and your mother doesn’t, either. You have a problem that needs fixing." He stopped, and picked a different spot. When he spoke again, his words were unusually slow. "I don’t know what that problem is yet, but we’re going to work together to solve it. Not so you can get back to drama, not so you can be the most popular kid in school. Because… you are suffering." She was quiet.

"There’s something I want to show you," he said, gradually reacquiring his regular cadence. "It helps me, when I’m out of sorts. I think it’ll help you, too." "Okay," she said, softly. ./. Quinn ran across the sea of shards, nearly losing her balance in the process.

"HELLO!" she shouted, desperation stealing her voice. "I NEED FUCKING HELP!" She frantically surveyed the room she had broken into. It looked as though a tornado had hit an old waiting room for a hospital. Chairs were askew, the electricity was faulty, and it stunk like moth balls.  "What the–" she muttered, in disbelief that she had traveled so far just to see a room like this.  Behind the receptionist’s desk, Quinn noticed a rusted steel door that looked like it hadn’t been touched in ages. Without seeing anything else, she hopped over the desk and banged on it once.

Agony. Quinn nearly blacked out as soon as her fist hit the door. Glass shards, some an inch thick, were stuck into her left arm. She turned and noticed that she had left a trail of blood across the already-stained blue carpet.  Between slow breaths, Quinn continued to bang on the door with her right hand.  "You told me to be here at 5:30! I’m fucking here!" Although she still yelled, her voice had dropped a register. The panic and the pain were beginning to overwhelm her.

With trembling hands, she pulled out as much of the glass as she could. Each piece was a new wall of pain and a new geyser of blood. In between pieces, she pounded her fist on the old door, more and more sure that no one was behind it at all.  When she had plucked the last piece free, she ripped off the coat she’d been wearing and wrapped it as tightly as she could around her injured arm. A new wave of pain told her that she’d probably missed a shard or two.  Quinn leaned against the door and gave it one final slam. With a choked sob, she slid down until she was sitting with her back facing the wall. How stupid she had been.  She let her head hit the door, and closed her eyes. It was over. She had wasted this whole weekend, Maeve was just as gone as ever, and now Ty…

Was going to die. Adrenaline pumped through Quinn’s veins. She was going to have to save him. She willed herself back to her feet, and moved as quickly as she could back to the car. She had taken a class back in seventh grade on CPR. Although she didn’t remember the specifics, she would have to figure something out.  She stopped dead about ten feet from the car. The front seat was empty.  "TY!" she called out, the combination of pain and fear and exertion making her lightheaded. "HEY! ANYONE!" Quinn spun around in desperate search of movement. Although the sun had barely begun to paint the sky with color, there was enough light for her to see that she was alone, save for a great number of evergreens.

With hands shaking, she threw herself into her car. Blood soaked through her heavy coat and stained the seat.  She laid on the horn of her car. The noise was enough to disturb some birds who had taken an early nest in some of the neighboring trees. She had no breath left to yell; this would have to do.  But as she sat there and honked and bled and cried, her thoughts became much louder than anything else. All this way, she thought, all this way for a fucking prank. How did Ty manage to make those videos? I was sure- sure!- it was them. He must have been texting me the whole time, too. And now I’m fucking alone in the middle of nowhere with this guy. I’m so stupid. So stupid. I deserve whatever’s about to happen to me. The horn was not going to elicit a response. Quinn eventually turned her attention from signaling to Ty to her mangled left arm. Gingerly, though through stifled cries of betrayal, loss, and self-admonishment, she removed her coat. It had once been a dark-green, but it was now covered in sweeping, brown splotches. With her right hand, she swept through the glove compartment. She put one in her own car when she’d purchased it years ago. She hoped by some miracle Ty thought the same way as she did.

After an aggravating moment of digging through paperwork, tissues, and perhaps more fast food wrappers from the last two days than she’d have liked to admit, she miraculously felt a plastic box, and pulled it out with such vigor that she spilled much of the contents of the glove box onto the passenger side floor.  She unwound the small roll of medical tape and spun it clumsily around her left arm. Although it was tight and piercingly hot, it stemmed the vast majority of the bleeding.  As she looked over her work, Quinn unmistakably heard a tapping on her window.  She turned to see a short woman who could not have been much older than she was. Even though that early March morning was cold, her face looked much paler than it should have been. Quinn’s initial surprise at seeing her was quickly washed away by strange notes of sympathy.

The woman motioned for Quinn to step out of the car, and she did. With nerves racing once again, Quinn followed this stranger back inside the building. She really had nothing left to lose, anyway.  "Are you seriously hurt?" the woman asked in a small voice once they had reached the large door which Quinn had failed to open. There was a significant amount of blood pooled at its base.  "No," she responded, the word catching in her throat. If this was what she thought it could be– if this mystery person was the key to everything–  She pulled a key out from the pocket of her oversized winter pants and opened the door.

Quinn was amazed by what she saw. It was as if she had stepped into a completely new building. Gone were the dust bunnies and the smell of mold and the overturned chairs. In place of those things, there were clean hallways, sturdy electricity, and paintings on the walls.  The woman walked so quickly, however, that Quinn had almost no time to admire the interior of the building. They rushed past door after door, all of which looked like they may ostensibly contain lively groups of people, but they did not cross anyone’s path.  They were approaching a staircase at the end of the hallway when the pale woman stopped short. She stuck a hand out to Quinn as though to tell her to be quiet, and knocked on the door of room 137 twice.  The door looked just the same as the dozens they had already passed. A blissfully fleeting moment passed in which Quinn could not have possibly imagined why they would stop at this one in particular.

The loudest, most foul noise Quinn had even heard cracked its way into her eardrums from beyond the door. Although it was over as suddenly as it had started, she staggered back, feeling it echo in her lungs.  "What the hell was that?" she croaked. The pale woman swung open the door and spoke numbly, without looking at her. "She’s in the closet."

Horrible connections rooted in Quinn’s mind. Every instinct that told her to run away from the noise was eradicated. She bolted into the large, mostly empty room, and found the closet door, tucked away behind a chair that sat all by itself, on a dead sprint. She threw it open. The room was hot and thick. It could not have been more than a few feet long or deep, and it was lined with cleaning supplies that looked like they had not been touched in ages. An unmistakable smell dominated the room. Iron. Life expiring. Her sister’s.

Maeve was huddled on the ground, shaking and whimpering. A pool of blood, still expanding outward, protruded from her torso.  Quinn fell to her knees.  "No. No, no, no, no–" she muttered, completely unaware of what she was saying.  She slid her hands into the pool and retrieved her sister, who let out an inhuman wail as she was moved.

Their eyes locked. Maeve’s, even more brightly blue than her own, were frantic, pained, open wide. A shout escaped from Quinn before she tried desperately to keep some sense.  "Maeve, I’m gonna help you, okay? I’m gonna find something in here. You’re going to be alright." Maeve groaned as Quinn gingerly placed her back down. She stood up to scan the shelves. Words on the bottles bled into one another, and translated themselves into different languages. There had to be something– medical supplies, a roll of paper towels, even. Quinn shoved aside rows upon rows of chemicals. Curses flowed from her mouth like water. ‘ "Quinn," said Maeve through choked breaths. "It hurts… so much."

"I know, I know," said Quinn. "I’m gonna make it stop." Rows upon rows of bleach, and wood polish, and liquid soap. She scanned a second time and a third.  "Fuck it," she said, finally. She began to rip the bandages from her own arm. They were thickly coated in her own blood, heavy, dripping, ripping apart. She grit her teeth. Tugging the adhesive off was more painful than the initial injury.  When she was done, Quinn knelt down to pick Maeve up again. She wailed again, but less dreadfully.

Quinn rolled up her sister’s shirt and saw a bullet wound through her torso. Flesh cratered on her left side, just below her ribcage. She wrapped the soiled bandages around her as tightly as she could.  "Okay…" mumbled Quinn shakily. The bleeding, her arm, her stomach, constant, impossible to stem. "Quinn…I don’t…" Maeve’s face was lined with cold sweat and coated with crimson. Her eyes drooped. "Hey. Hey. Maeve, no. ANYONE!" she yelled, to no one in particular, and without letting go of her sister. "WE NEED HELP! WE NEED FUCKING HELP RIGHT NOW!"

A breath caught in Maeve’s throat, and she coughed deeply, sending small flecks of blood onto Quinn’s face.  "Don’t…" she mustered. "No one’s… coming." Quinn’s mouth hung open. As she spoke, tears ran from her eyes and fell from the bridge of her nose.  "What do you want me to do?"

"Talk… to me." Maeve’s eyes closed, and she shuddered. "Hold… me. I’m…so…cold." Resisting the urge to wail again, Quinn brought her sister’s head into her chest and began to speak quickly, through cascading waves of emotion.  "I love you, Maeve. I don’t know what happened to you over the past six months, I don’t know if our parents give a shit about us, but I love you so much. Every day after you left I called you; I wanted to go find you. The police weren’t any help. I just– wish I could have done something."  Quinn trailed off. Maeve was wearing a necklace. One of the silver chains caught the light.

An unsteady smile found its way onto Quinn’s lips.  "But– you would have been surprised. People from the high school came to our house and asked about you all the time. Teachers, students. They loved you too, more than you could have known." Maeve’s breathing became a rattle. "Do you remember that flight back from Grandpa’s house, two years ago? When it was just us two on the plane? I must have made you run three miles that day to catch that thing. I didn’t know what I was doing. And then we sat in our seats and watched every Shrek movie because the flight got delayed. The…the whole thing was dumb. I mean, we must have spent the last hour of the flight analyzing every character, at 2am, or whenever it was. But with you it was fun.

"It’s easy for me to say I love you. And I do. But you’re my sister, I kind of have to. It’s just…I like you, too. Some people really…dislike their sisters, or live kind of independently of them, especially if they’re as far apart in age as we are. But I never feel like that. I like doing things with you, I like doing nothing with you…you’re my best friend. And I don’t know… how I would have turned out…" Maeve was gone.  Quinn’s facade of bravery shattered, and she brought her sister into a final embrace through hulking, bitter sobs.  ./.

"I just don’t understand." "You will. You still have time. President Dorothy likes Leaders to progress a bit more quickly, but I’m sure– "Progress? Killing that dog? Is that what you call progress?" "It’s a difficult thing to wrap your head around, I know. I can’t say I would have an easy time in your position either. But this is what we’re all about. We can’t trust you to hunt the people we’re after unless you know…what to do when you catch them. And as for the dog… we picked one that was old and ill. It doesn’t have more than a few months to live anyway. This is all about the greater good here, do you see?"

"I don’t." "You have to. This is what you’ve been training for. And you know they’re just going to get harder and harder to control if you won’t let them get what they’re after." "Find someone else." "You don’t mean that."

"I guess we’ll see." ./. As Quinn knelt down and smelled Maeve’s hair mixed with that unforgiving metal, she stared through bleary eyes in futile hope that she might see the rise and fall of her sister’s chest once again. Seconds gave way to minutes. Blood leaked from untreated wounds. The two sisters, reunited at last, were pale and motionless.  Quinn did not notice the first round of knocking at the closet’s door. She did not notice the second, either. It was only when she heard the rattle of a handle and a pair of gentle footsteps enter the room that she realized she was no longer alone in the room.

Slowly, deliberately, she turned toward the source of the noise. There, just outside of the outer reaches of the crimson pool, were a pair of high heels worn by wrinkled feet. Looking upward, she saw before her a well-dressed old woman.  It clicked before she even had time to understand what clicked. Quinn brought herself to her feet, and before either of them had time to say a word, she threw the old woman to the ground. She looked even older in person than she did on the VHS recordings. With a loud crash, she landed on her back just in front of the solitary chair, and one of the items she’d been holding– a box that looked more than anything like an empty cage that may have been for holding cats– skittered halfway across the room. A small groan escaped the woman’s dry lips as she hit the carpeted ground.  Quinn was so hysterical that she couldn’t see straight.

"I DID EVERYTHING THAT YOU FUCKING WANTED! I’LL FUCKING KILL Y-"   Just as she was about to rain hell upon this old woman, Quinn collapsed into a mess of convulsions. Every muscle in her body burned. The temperature of the room tripled. The world was as bright as the surface of the Sun. As she writhed, she left blackened bloodstains on the rug.  After hours of this agony, it ended just as instantly as it had begun. Though she was free of her physical pain, Quinn shook violently, still in a fetal position just outside the boundary of the closet.  "Don’t…make me do that…ever again," said the old woman through heavy breaths.

Quinn gathered enough of her strength to look back at her. The old woman had steadied herself against the chair, and was aiming a pen-sized flashlight at the box. Though she had just hit the ground with considerable force, it seemed as though her suit coat had been completely undisturbed.  She shuffled across the room to retrieve the box, and spoke in a growl.  "You will call me President Dorothy, and you will do exactly as I say." Quinn kept quiet, watching the old woman move across the room with sulfuric anger.

"Stand up." "Fuck you." President Dorothy, who had been reaching to pick up the box, stopped in place. She frowned, took it into her arms, and tossed it with surprising force against the wall closest to her.  Quinn cried out in agony. This pain was different. She felt as though she’d taken a blow from a world champion boxer directly to the ribs. She rolled over and clutched the side which had been hurt.

But just as before, the pain subsided in a matter of moments. Quinn filled her lungs with air to confirm that her ribs were not broken. Amazingly, all she could feel was the dullest of aches. "Stand up." Quinn swallowed. She forced herself first to her knees and then to unsteady feet. She stared directly at the carpet in front of her, unwilling to meet the eyes of President Dorothy. There was no way she could endure another round of blinding pain brought about by that odd, completely empty box.  "Follow me."

The sound of President Dorothy’s footsteps exited the large room and went out into the hallway. Quinn hesitated only for a brief moment before she followed, moving by what was left of her survival instinct rather than by conscious choice.  As she exited room 137 and saw carpet turn into tile, a single sob escaped from her lips. Grief and apathy and hatred all fought for dominance in her mind, but all were conquered by the relentless visual of those last moments in the janitorial closet.  They climbed three flights of stairs and turned into a large room that was stunningly white. President Dorothy ordered her to sit down on the floor in front of a large horizontally-oriented pipe that was perhaps a foot off of the ground, and painted white just the same as everything else in the room. When Quinn had done so, the old woman procured a pair of handcuffs from the inside of her coat pocket and chained her wrists to the pipe.  Quinn did not resist. She did not say a word. Tears leaked indiscriminately through her eyes.

Once she was restrained, President Dorothy patted Quinn’s left shoulder.  "I apologize, my Lady." Though Quinn still failed to meet the old woman’s gaze, she saw out of her peripheral vision that President Dorothy grabbed a handkerchief from one of her blazer’s pockets. She gingerly tied it around Quinn’s eyes, and the whole world went dark.  The sound of President Dorothy’s heels clicking against the tile grew more and more faint, and soon all Quinn was left with was the soft hum of the fluorescent lights that hung far above her head.

Thoughts and feelings echoed throughout her mind at a dizzying pace. They were so vivid that although she was blindfolded, she could have sworn she was seeing– vast fields, the interior of homes, scenes from memories that oddly may not even have been hers. Smells, sounds, even tastes hung on the outer edge of her perception, as though misplaced in reality.  Beyond the dreadful buzzing, she was stoic. She did not rattle her cuffs; she did not cry for help; she did not fight to remove the handkerchief. Her grief had, for the moment, stolen her resolve to do any of these things. The only thing she wanted was to wake up.  Minutes passed. Maeve is gone. The words looped through her conscious mind without end, but they still seemed to lack concrete meaning. There was no way they could be true– but they always had been, until just a few days ago. She was gone then, just as she was now. Accepting that fact felt akin to letting the devil himself into her already mangled thoughts.  The physical sensations did not fade. If anything, she began to feel as though she was being watched. If she tried, she thought she could almost imagine the room she was in in perfect detail, despite the fact that she hadn’t paid attention to it at all when she’d walked in.

Finally, Quinn heard a door open. It sounded as though something heavy was being dragged by someone who was exerting a lot of effort. She thought about speaking up, but simply collecting the air into her lungs felt a monumental task.  The dragging stopped in a corner of the room across from her. The lump was propped up and facing her, and had its back against the large mirror that encompassed the entire wall, just like it had been on the VHS tape (how did she know this? Instinct, maybe? She couldn’t see a thing.). She heard a sigh, a jingle and click, and then the crescendo of quick footsteps.  As cold hands removed her blindfold, a booming voice rang out over the same PA system she had listened to in the hotel two nights ago.  "This is attempt number one, subject Charlotte, 3-18-24."

The harsh white light of the room was unkind to Quinn’s eyes at first. She instinctively went to cover her face with her hand, but was stopped short by the rattle of the handcuffs’ chain against the pipe.  But after she had blinked a few times, her breath caught in her throat. The lump was Ty, dressed in a baggy gray sweatshirt and even paler than he was when he had vanished earlier. He lay unconscious on his side, and his chained left arm hung grotesquely from a door handle just next to the edge of the mirror.  Quinn pulled with all of her might against her own restraints, and saw that the young woman was the one who had removed her blindfold. As she shouted her voice cracked from stress. "WHAT DID YOU DO TO HIM? FUCKING HELP HIM!"

The young woman watched Quinn with wide eyes, but did not move a muscle.  She sputtered, and felt another wave of grief beginning to crest.  "Please," she begged, yanking her chains against the unyielding pipe once again.  The young woman did not take her sorrowful eyes off of Quinn.

"Wha– What do you want me to do? What did I do? Help me fucking wake up from this–" The mute woman finally responded.  "He’s really dying." Quinn’s face shifted, as though she had some great epiphany. Her heart seemed to stop in its place, and her mind seemed finally to come to rest in exactly one spot. She turned her attention to Ty.
"No," she said, quietly.  Ever so slightly, Ty jerked.  A bead of sweat ran through Quinn’s hair and dripped onto the cold tile.  "No. Stop."

His eyes fluttered, and he heaved a great breath. The young woman, watching him intently, began to make for the room’s exit.  "Don’t. Not…not him." As soon as the words were out of Quinn’s mouth, Ty coughed and slowly moved his unchained arm in an attempt to sit up.  The voice boomed out throughout the building.

"Attempt number one is successful." Ty gulped air and muttered to himself for a blissful moment. But as soon as he tried to pull his left arm down, he was jolted awake. "What the–"  He pulled against the door handle, rattling the chain with violent force.

"HEY!" he shouted, standing up and pounding on the door to which he was locked.  "WHERE THE FUCK AM I?" He frantically turned behind him, and froze when he saw his friend.  "Quinn– holy shit– are you–"

Her eyes had turned to glass. She saw him, but she could not respond.  "Is that your blood? What the fuck did they do to you?" He looked at her with a mix of horror and fascination. She had almost forgotten how thickly she was covered– her arm, her clothes, her skin. She must have been a real sight to behold.  The room spun as she shook her head. Her mouth hung open a fraction of an inch as reality continued to sink in more and more deeply.

"Well…what happened? Whose is it?" She blinked, and started to answer. The name caught in her throat.  "Don’t…don’t tell me. Q, no. No, no. It’s not–" Quinn made a noise as though she’d been punched in the stomach.

Ty slid down until he was sitting against the door once again. His face contorted as though he was about to be sick.  "Quinn, I– I can’t–" Tears and blood and mucus mixed first on her skin and then on the once brilliantly white tile. Ty muttered quietly, more to himself than to her.  "It’s all my fault. If I had been able to drive yesterday– If we could have gotten here early today– I could have helped, I could have– saved her– I could have prevented this, and I asked to come with you, and now we’re stuck here, holy shit, no, no, no…"

For several minutes, the room was crowded with admissions of guilt and wails of mourning.  When Ty was eventually done, he rolled over onto his back, arm still dangling from the handle three feet or so from the ground.  As soon as he did so, he jolted, as though he had just awoken from a terrible nightmare.  Quinn could see from the edge of her vision that Ty was contorting his body awkwardly, like he was trying to scratch an itch with his only free hand. At last, there was a soft ripping sound, and the plop of a weight hitting the floor.

"Quinn," he said, tentatively.  She didn’t respond. She was looking off into a place just beside her reflection in the mirror.  There was silence for a moment. Ty spoke again, more confidently this time.  "Quinn… you need to see this."

"...why?" Her voice was a croak. "I think it’s from Maeve." Quinn turned to him and took a look at his sweatshirt. He hadn’t been wearing that this morning. In fact, for all the time she had known him, she hadn’t seen him wear anything like that sweatshirt.  Out of this mystery piece of clothing he procured a composition notebook which was opened to the first page. From across the room, she could see that it was completely filled, but she could not make out any specific words.

"Her name is on the cover, and… it looks like it’s for you." "For…me…" A great wave of exhaustion washed over her. She briefly felt in spite of everything that she could have fallen asleep right there on the cold floor.  "...Yeah. I’d pass it over so you could read, but…"
He rattled the cuff that tied his left hand to the door.  Quinn, reminded of her own current limitations, heaved a deep sigh. "Read it." "Right now? You want me to–"

"Just read it." But as he drew breath to begin, Quinn stopped him. "Ah– is the, um, date written out, on top? Or maybe, a, a– title? "Yes," he said, flipping through a few of the pages. "They’re all dated entries. And she–"
"Wrote the month out, in cursive letters?" Ty nodded softly.  "And her i’s, do they hook at the bottom?" Ever so slightly, his hand started to quiver.
"They do." Quinn nodded. "Go ahead." Ty scanned the first few lines, and began shuffling pages.  "I guess she wanted you to read the back first."
Quinn closed her eyes.  "Just read, please." Finally, he stopped shuffling, cleared his throat, and mustered just enough courage to read Maeve’s message aloud.  "Hey Quinn,

I guess this is goodbye. The way things have been going, I think they’re going to kill me. I have no idea whether or not you’re in on the whole secret organization/psychic superpower thing like Dad is (has been for years, as it turns out), but something about the look on your face as we drove away on the day of the shooting tells me you aren’t. If that’s the case, and if what I’ve been hearing is true, then I imagine that you’re probably scared and maybe a little bit sad that I’m gone (depending on how you really felt about me, behind all those layers of callous indifference that the years have bestowed so kindly upon your demeanor). But, assuming I can find some way to get this to you, right now I need you. Before I say anything sappy, and I’ll get to all that, I need you to know that something else is going on. I’m almost positive they’ll find some way to give you whatever it is that they gave me. And I’m so sorry it has to be that way. If you feel, underneath everything else, more perceptive, or more imaginative (?), or more out of tune with how you think you should be feeling– then you know you have it." Ty stopped.  "Q, does– does this make any sense to you?" She kept staring blankly ahead into nothing.

"Keep reading." "I’d rather you didn’t," said a voice, stepping into the room.  It was President Dorothy. She wore a scowl, and eyeballed the journal as though it was an unsightly piece of clutter on the otherwise brilliant floor.  She moved quickly across the room, and crouched rather athletically in front of Ty.

"May I ask, how did this book–" here she grabbed it and turned it over, as though it were the day’s local paper– "come into your possession?" The young man, transfixed by her authority at first, lunged to retrieve the book in an effort that amused President Dorothy.  "If you don’t answer me, I’ll have that other arm chained up too. You wouldn’t like that, would you?" It seemed to hit Ty just how dire his situation was at that moment. His eyes flickered between the sneer of the old woman and the pipe that Quinn was tied against.

He slowly returned his left palm to the floor and answered quietly.  "I don’t know, ma’am, it was– sort of, attached to my back, inside my sweatshirt–" "Great. Thank you." She smiled sweetly at him.  "Elyse, you may come in."

The young woman entered the room, lugging an old, heavy-looking television set. Two items sat on a shelf below the old, round screen. The first was a VHS tape. The second was a small black pistol. She stopped the set a few feet in front of where Quinn sat, perched on her knees.  Elyse plugged the set into an electrical outlet that was just out of Quinn’s reach, and the screen buzzed to life. Static flooded the screen and assaulted the once-silent air. Quinn, awake, flicked bloodied hair out of her face and locked eyes with President Dorothy, who was studying her intently.  "What were you doing to her?" Quinn asked through clenched teeth.

The old woman reached for the tape, and examined it nonchalantly.  "She already told you," she said, inserting it into the flap underneath the television screen. "The same thing I’ll be doing to you." The static stopped. The screen showed an elevated, security camera-style view of the small closet Quinn had just been in.  "I’m not sure how much you know about guns, dear. But your father tells me you were quite the archer, back in the day. So you should be able to ascertain that a projectile coming from a weapon like this has the potential to do a lot of damage."

Elyse handed President Dorothy the weapon, and she switched the safety off. Lazily, the old woman showed Quinn the inside of the gun. Her pupils constricted, and she pulled as hard as she could against the pipe.  "Do it." she hissed, eyes locked on the old woman’s. "Kill me."

President Dorothy laughed, and brought the gun down. "Kill you? Don’t be ridiculous. I need you, Quinn. Your friend, though," she said, turning to Ty, "not so much." Ty went white as a sheet. The old woman aimed the gun at him from some five feet from his reach. He let out a cry that seemed to be somewhere between a scream and a groan.  President Dorothy turned her attention back to Quinn.

"If you want to avoid an unfortunate scenario, I need you to do two easy things for me. First, I want you to agree to watch the television for as long as you can after I press play. I do not want your eyes to close or wander. I simply need you to watch until you can no longer do so. Do you understand?" Of course she did not understand. But she nodded her head.  "Great. The second thing is that I want you to swallow this pill." President Dorothy reached into a pocket inside her blazer and produced some plastic packaging. She quickly opened it, and held a small white pill between her thumb and forefinger.

"I want you to show me your tongue. I want you to swallow the pill. I will check that you’ve been honest. And then I will start the recording." A tear fell from Quinn’s eye, but she did not look away from the old woman. She opened her mouth and stuck out her tongue.  "Quinn, no!" interjected Ty, from across the room. "Will you shut the hell up?" asked President Dorothy, shooting him an icy gaze.

Ty backed himself into his corner of the room, even more colorless than he had been before.  President Dorothy placed the pill on Quinn’s tongue. It began dissolving the moment she brought it into her mouth, and she swallowed it without any effort. It tasted just like an Alka-Seltzer.  President Dorothy waited a moment, smiled, and stood up.  "Very good, my Lady."

She pressed play on the television. Quinn’s eyes finally lost their link with President Dorothy’s. They fixed just as solidly on the screen.  Ty watched with shallow breaths as light danced across Quinn’s face. He watched her mouth hang open. He watched her scream. He watched the air betray her efforts to scream. He watched her body go limp. He watched her breaths even out.  He watched her for thirty seconds or so. He did not see her blink.  ./.

Maeve rubbed her eyes and ran her hands through her still-drying hair. Her feet, locked in painful, noisy dress shoes, dragged on the tile floor. Although the sun shone through the second floor windows, a luxury she did not have during the colder winter months, she had still struggled to wake herself up.  She opened the door at the far end of the hallway, and took off her heavy backpack. It hit the ground with a dull thud. Massaging her shoulders, she found a seat in the middle of the large wooden table that ran lengthwise across the room.  "Eggs again?" she asked, having removed the silver dish in front of her. The same meal as yesterday sat before her: two scrambled eggs, two pieces of bacon, some lightly burned toast, and a cup of orange juice. It had seemed to her months ago a rather high-end breakfast– usually on school mornings at home, she would pour a bowl of cereal for herself, if anything at all. Now she was almost repulsed by what she saw.  Elyse frowned from across the table. "President Dorothy told the kitchen that you should have some protein before this afternoon. Sorry."

Maeve sighed and picked up some egg with her fork. It wiggled unappetizingly. "Honestly, I don’t even care at this point. I just want coffee." Elyse smiled and took a sip of her own. "Caffeine and Leadership…" "...are a dangerous mix. I know. The way she told it to me, I think she might rather find me coked out on the floor than in line at a Starbucks."

Elyse had to keep a hand over her mouth to keep her sip of coffee in her mouth. When she had recovered, she tilted her head. "Jesus, Maeve…how do you get these shirts so wrinkly?" Elyse reached across the table and pulled on Maeve’s sleeves in some attempt to smooth the button-down dress shirt she wore. Maeve closed her eyes.  "I don’t know. The wrinkles don’t bother me. The stupid clothes do."

"What happened to your sweater? The nice navy blue one that the school gave you?" Maeve shook her head. "In my room, somewhere, maybe? But it’s fine. It’s warm out today. And there are kids that come to school looking like they walked through a hurricane." "Probably the boys," said Elyse, under her breath. The two ate their breakfasts and continued to chat idly. Although she was sick of them, Maeve could not deny the fact that the eggs were well prepared.

But the orange juice did not agree with the aftertaste of the mouthwash she’d just used. As she grimaced and put her cup down, she noticed that Elyse was staring upward, at some spot behind her.  Maeve turned around and saw that she was looking at an analog clock positioned just above the wooden door that led into the hallway. The red second hand ticked at such a low volume that it was almost inaudible.  As the two studied the clock, which Maeve had never really noticed before, Elyse spoke pensively.  "Do you…want to miss school today?"
Maeve turned back to her, puzzled.  "Huh?" "Do you?" She began to think. She saw that Elyse was still staring at that clock.

"Well…I have two tests…" "That doesn’t matter. I can call and tell the school that you’re sick. They let you make those up, right?" Maeve shrugged. "I think so." Elyse brought her gaze back to Maeve. "Good. Unless, of course, you did really want to take them today."

Maeve shook her head, and tried to answer as nonchalantly as she could. "Um, no. I could have prepared more for both." With bright blue eyes wide open, Maeve studied Elyse’s face.  "Alright. I’ll call in."  She flashed a big, phony smile before continuing.
"What do you want to do today, then?" "I don’t know; I wasn’t planning on being free." "What would you have done back home?" Maeve thought for a moment.

"Mini golf, probably. My old friends and I would practically live at this crappy course during the summer." Elyse smiled. "Sounds fun. I’ll find a place." With that, she stood up and left the room. Maeve lingered on the wooden table, breakfast half-eaten and growing colder by the minute. Muted yet steadily rising panic made her active mind churn. What was going on? Elyse had to know something that she didn’t. For all of her months in this lab (prison), she had never once been offered a skip day.  Did it have to do with the upcoming lesson? She knew President Dorothy wasn’t exactly thrilled with the way she was progressing as Leader– actually, she was probably even more upset than that– was something drastic about to happen? No matter how Maeve thought about it, she could not come up with any other theory.

Elyse came back into the room, triumphant. She sat back down at her place and spoke breezily.  "You’re all set– the lady on the phone told me she hopes you feel better soon. And it turns out there are a few indoor places close to here, so you can pick between monster, pirate, or jungle themed–" "Elyse, can you tell me what’s really going on?" Her eyes shifted for a split second. That was all Maeve needed.

"I just– I know we go shopping, and you have your cello, and you were doing great at your last school and everything, but– I don’t know, this way of life–" she gestured wildly with her hands– "it’s restricting. I can feel it restricting you. We’re not asking you to put a ball into a hoop, or play your instrument all the time, or get straight A’s. We’re asking you to…" She trailed off for a moment.  "What we’re asking you to do is way harder than anything anyone your age is being asked to do. And I just think there should be… some fun moments. That you have to look back on down the road. I think going mini golfing today would be a fun outlet. That’s all." Elyse sipped from her coffee.

Maeve judged her answer briefly, nodded, and turned to go back to her room. "My brother," said Elyse, watching Maeve stand up. She must have held judgment one moment too long. "When I was nine, he went missing for a whole year. I remember calling and calling his cell phone. I lived with my cousin and my aunt and uncle. They were a wreck. The police wouldn’t help, news channels wouldn’t cover it. For a year– thirteen and a half months– we were all so helpless. And then one random day, this old black car pulls into the driveway, and it’s him. He says he went to go find our father. But he doesn’t say very much else. And we cried, and hugged him, and he hugged us too. "But he wasn’t really himself anymore. He was erratic, manic; he kept weird hours and did weird things. He would spend days alone in his room, talking to himself, and then go for jogs around the neighborhood that lasted for hours. Sometimes he would scream at me, or my cousin, or the dog we had. He even flipped a table once during dinner. It was like– he was there, but not really. I mean, he was seven years older than me, and he was annoying sometimes, but I never hated him. From the day he got back, I found myself wishing he hadn’t.

"A few years later, he went away to college. For three months, everyone in my house took a collective deep breath. But when he got back for winter break, he… looked rough. His eyes were sunken into his skull. He barely spoke or ate. I was worried, but– I was eleven. I was just a kid, I didn’t know what to say to him.  "That first night, I couldn’t sleep. It must have been 2:30 or so, and I heard the front door open downstairs. I just knew it was him. So, against my better judgment, I got out of bed and went outside. I was calling his name so loud I must have woken up everyone else in the neighborhood. And I didn’t even know if I wanted to find him.  "As it turned out, he didn’t get far. There was a light on in the tiny shed behind our house. It was made of this really old, flimsy wood, so I could hear him mumbling before I even went in. I was so scared to open the door. But I did. And… he was in there, on the ground, taking these big, deep breaths, and talking nonsense. And next to him was our dog. It was just frozen there, not breathing, nothing. There was no evidence of any struggle, no blood. It was just dead. And before I had time to scream, or run away, Ryan shot up, put a hand over my mouth, and dragged me into that black car. We drove east for ten straight hours. And when we finally stopped, it was in this parking lot, here.  "Ryan explained to President Dorothy what had happened. She brought some other kid into the building, and I never saw Ryan again. But she kept me around. She told me I owed my life to her, and if I ever disobeyed her or told another soul what had happened, she’d go after my family too. That was…fourteen years ago."

Elyse’s mouth hung slightly open. Maeve was glued numbly to her seat.  "I don’t know what it’s like to be a Leader," she continued. "But I’ve seen seven of them, before you, come through these doors. She only lets them leave once they’ve killed someone close to them. She thinks that’s a special trauma that will link the dreamers to their Leader forever. She’s going to ask you to do that today. If you can’t, she’ll probably ask you to do something to bring the next Leader here. "Three of the seven have done it, and four have refused. None of the three made it past two years. They were all young and healthy, but it’s like… their minds just couldn’t take it. They were always back here, begging to be free.  "Now I really don’t know if President Dorothy is just trying to go after evil people in the world through dreamers, like she says she is. All I know is that she's getting crazy government funding and she was in constant contact with the Leaders who did manage to make it out of the lab. But those things… the dreamers… the way they are, once they get a taste, it’s like they always want to kill, traumatize, something. And there aren’t that many people out there who deserve to die. So, naturally, these poor kids… they become like drug addicts, but instead of destroying their own bodies, they can’t help but destroy others’. That’s what happened to Ryan."

Maeve’s heart pounded in her ears.  "I’ve known you for six months now. I know you haven’t wanted to hurt a fly in the experiments they’ve run on you. But you’re smart. And resilient as hell. I think that of any of the seven kids I’ve been around, you would have the best chance at a life as a Leader. If I’m right, about today, it’ll be your choice to make." Pieces fell into place in Maeve’s mind. "Jason…" "He did. He held out a while, but eventually he asked President Dorothy for a replacement. So, you were nominated, and a random researcher went to New Jersey and gave Jason’s power to you. He was a good kid. They all were."

Maeve took a shaky breath, and stepped away from the table.  "Why… tell me this now?" Elyse stayed seated, and stared sadly at her empty coffee cup.  "Because I’m done too. Either I’ll find some way out of here, or…"
She trailed off.  "This is a dumb question, but… do you still want to go mini golfing?" Maeve stopped, and thought, tears welling in her eyes. "Okay. Let me just change out of these clothes first."

As she left the room, she unzipped her backpack and dug for her maroon journal.  ./. "So this is her, yes?" "Indeed. She’d be the oldest we’ve ever had, but that may actually work to our advantage. The kids have proven to be too malleable to last. And if she has visual connection, as we hypothesize, she may be able to control motor function of dreamers both in and out of visual range with a higher degree of precision than any Leader in years."

"You didn’t say visual connection, did you?" "I did. I know only a handful of Leaders have ever achieved non-drug induced visual connection, but initial scans and observation showed that this phenomenon is overwhelmingly likely in this Lady." "Very impressive. I do think I could go without… facial jewelry on our Leader, though. Quite unprofessional, don’t you think?" "I’ll do my best to talk her out of it, Doctor Hunt."

Quinn was awake, but the rest of her body seemed to have failed to receive that information. Her head swam, her back ached, and her arms, still bound against the pipe, were frozen stiff. She was angled awkwardly on the ground. She lay prone on her left side, facing the interior of the room, with her legs tangled with one other and fully asleep. To take her mind off of her physical condition, she decided to listen in to some of the faint conversations around her before opening her eyes.  "Did you hear what happened?" "Yes, but it’s hard to deny the capabilities…" "Poor girl. But what I would do to be in her position–"

"Or study her brain!" "She looks a lot like your daughter, Miles." There must have been at least a dozen people in the room. Voices mingled and interrupted one another, but they all seemed to discuss the same thing. Some called her sturdy, others weak; they talked about how tall, short, old, young she was; they talked about how they would have rathered a young man for the job; they complimented the old hag for her brilliant idea of staying in-family. But everyone was talking about her. Quinn, disregarding her pain, buried her cheek into the cold tile and listened for twenty, thirty agonizing minutes in desperate hope for some helpful information from these voices.  Finally, she caught what she was after.

"And who is this?" asked a deep male voice. "A friend. He will play a very important role for us– perhaps even later today." Quinn’s heart picked up. She could practically hear President Dorothy’s smirk through her words.  She waited a minute longer, and began to squint her eyes and stretch, as though she were just waking up.

The idle chatter came to a complete halt. Even before she had completely opened her eyes, Quinn could tell that every soul in that room was transfixed by the very sight of her. Her head continued to swim.  She took in her surroundings. There were even more people in the relatively small room than she thought– perhaps as many as thirty or forty. They were grouped in packs of four or five, and wore expensive suits and dresses and held glasses of champagne. The room had grown humid and hot, and the vibrant colors of the clothes against the white walls and ceiling made Quinn dizzy.  Ty was still in his corner of the room. Like her, both of his arms were chained, but he was now gagged by a piece of black masking tape. He stared through one black eye and one good eye at the Quinn, clearly relieved to see her awake.  She slowly brought herself back up to her knees. The silence in the room was agonizing. It seemed as though there was expectation for Quinn to speak, but she had nothing to say to these people.

President Dorothy stepped in from Quinn’s right.  "Good evening, everyone. First and foremost, I would like to thank all present for their incredible individual contributions to our ongoing project. Without you all, we would not have such a promising future regarding the responsible containment and utilization of the most dangerous species on our planet." A warm round of applause.  "I would also like to bring attention to the regrettable fact that these convocations of staff seem to be happening all too often. The past decades– the past few years, especially– have been marked by great bravery and sacrifice from our Leaders. Far too often, however, our efforts have been tainted by failure. Much of the blame falls on my shoulders. For that, I apologize.

"But today marks a new era in our history. We believe we have finally found a permanent Leader. We have trained her physically and mentally for this moment through the strength and bravery of our previous Leader. Not an ounce of effort was wasted, from anyone. From our research team to our chemical analysis team to our capture team, know that all of your work has made this moment possible." More applause. Waves of vitriol flowed through Quinn’s veins.  "Now, I will politely ask those interested to make their way to the observation room for the next phase."  The people straggled out of the room, muttering and glancing at Quinn. She kept her head down as they left. The tile patterns seemed to swim on the floor. Every emotion was on the edge of her consciousness. She tried not to let them show.

President Dorothy crouched in front of her and frowned.  "I know you hate me. I know you hate me more than almost anyone. But if there’s one thing you should know, it is that I do not tell lies to my Leaders. Maeve understood this, and so should you." "Get her name out of your fucking mouth." The old woman scoffed.

"I would treat your supervisor with more respect if I were in your position," she said, quietly enough so that no sound would leak out of the room.  "But, as I was saying, all you need to do to leave this building forever are two demonstrations. And, seeing as how you have my word, it shall be so." President Dorothy turned to exit, and spoke without looking at Quinn.  "The first will begin shortly. You are ready, even if you may feel unprepared."

She slammed the door shut, and Quinn and Ty were alone in the room.  He rattled his chains and attempted to make a sound that she could hear, but it was no use. The gag was too tight on his lips. Judging from the red in his eyes and the pools of sweat visible through his clothes, it had been there for quite some time.  "I’m sorry, Ty," she said. "I should have never trusted those fucking texts. And I shouldn’t have let you come with me." He shook his head and cried out in some sort of response, and she tucked her head into her chest. As she did so, she noticed for the first time that she was wearing completely new, blood-free clothes, in the form of gray sweats. A chill of indignity ran down her spine.

But what was she to do about it? The sight of Ty, struggling against his chains– had he fought for her? He was strong, much stronger than she was, and he looked as though he’d stepped into the ring against a world-champion boxer. The white floors were stained with drops of his now-dried blood. He was absolutely pitiful.  She sighed, and rested her back on the wall, an uncomfortable task given the placement of the pipe to which she was still chained.  "We were asking for this. I was asking for this. I’m so god- damn- stupid–" At that moment, the door opened a crack. Quinn could not believe what she saw.

A small animal, perhaps only the size of a housecat, galloped into the room. Beside the fact that it moved on four legs, however, it looked unlike any cat she’d seen before. Its skin was a shade of purplish blue, and knotted flakes of it protruded off of its fleshy body, so that it looked to Quinn as though it would feel sharp to the touch. Its face was something like an owl’s, with a long, extended beak, but its eyes were completely white, so that it was impossible to tell exactly where it was looking. Its feet, which were more like talons than anything else, seemed almost to hover above the ground where it stood.  Quinn, frozen, watched the thing gracefully navigate the room. It was like nothing she had seen before, except perhaps in a nightmare. It seemed impossible that an animal like this could be real.  It stopped in the center of the room, equidistant from herself and Ty. It turned its long neck to Quinn and shone its milky white eyes at her.  She pressed herself against the wall and opened her mouth. It backed up a step and opened its beaked mouth as well, revealing row upon row of tiny, jagged teeth.

Her heart started to race. This thing seemed to be locked on to her. Was it going to attack? She was a sitting duck.  But seconds passed, and the thing simply continued to blankly stare forward. She shot a quick look at Ty, who seemed to be more interested in watching her than the mysterious animal in front of them.  She looked back at it. It looked into her. She closed her eyes.  And somewhere, through the haze of color that was the inside of her eyelids and the racing thoughts of her mind, she found it. She could see herself, chained, concentrating, from across the room. She could make out every detail of the room, of her face, of the baggy gray sweatshirt she was now wearing. She was exactly where this thing was perched.

Quinn tried to picture more of the room. What is to the left? Like she was swiveling her own head, she could now see Ty, in perfect clarity.  Can you move? she asked. She saw herself again– and then jogged over to her. She felt the paws hitting the ground, the air rushing past every flake of skin, the slight effort it took to move itself to her.

It timidly looked down and placed a talon on Quinn’s leg. She felt the action both as it was done and as it was done to her– an incredible, contradictory feeling that must have been impossible. But Quinn opened her eyes to find that the thing had actually climbed up into her lap, just as she felt it did.  "Holy shit," she said, looking at it closely.  From across the room, Ty made a noise. Quinn had an idea.  She closed her eyes and found the view of the creature relatively easily. Go to him.

Sure enough, she was running over to Ty. He seemed to have no idea it was even there.  Take the tape off. The thing stood up on its hind legs and drew itself up effortlessly. With surprising dexterity, it extended one of its talons and peeled off the tape from Ty’s mouth.  "Bwa– what the fuck, Quinn?"
She opened her eyes. The piece of tape fluttered to the ground.  "I– I know, I think it’s listening to me–" "What? What is listening to you? How did this tape come off?" Quinn furrowed her brow.
"You don’t see it?" "See what? You’re really scaring me." Quinn leaned her head back and sighed. "This is it, then. This is what she was talking about."

"What?" "The videos that we watched, where it didn’t look like Maeve was doing anything? I… I know what was happening." "You have been under a lot of duress. And I don’t know what was in that pill they gave you, but please, try to say something that I can understand." "I don’t know if you would believe me," she said, closing her eyes again.

Peeling off the tape seemed to have sparked a change in the thing’s demeanor. It seemed to be fascinated by Ty. She felt a temptation to jump on him. Go away. Not now. With some effort, she persuaded the creature to stand still, back in the middle of the room.  "At this point," said Ty, rattling his chains for effect, "I would believe anything." "Okay," she said skeptically. "There are these– you can’t see them, I don’t think, but I can– cat-owl things that I can control with my mind." Despite everything, Ty started to laugh.

He threw his head back against the wall and coughed and laughed.  She found herself smiling, too. It was weak and out of place. But of all of the things he could have done, it was perhaps the most surprising, to her. "You know what the worst part is, Q?" he said, tears beginning to well up in his eyes. She shook her head.

"I completely believe you." She looked directly forward at the thing, and studied its every square inch. Ty met her eyes and looked at the empty tile in front of him. "Do you really?" she said, after a time. He responded in a voice which she was confident he only used with her.

"Sure I do. What does it look like? Just, so I can, you know, have some sort of frame of reference." Beginning to suspect that he was making fun of her, and feeling ridiculous saying what she had to say, her voice lacked authority when she spoke.  "Well, it’s…purple. Maybe eighteen inches long? Two feet? It stands on four legs like a cat, but its face is like an owl’s. And it’s got these weird…knots all over its skin…" "Okay. Alright. And there’s one in the room right now with us."
"Yes." "And that’s what just tore the tape off of my mouth." "...Yes." Ty’s eyes darted around the room, and he spoke as though he was telling the loudest secret of all time.

"While you were out, and all of those people were in here with us, I was trying to listen in to what they were saying. They were talking about you like you were the damn Chosen One. Like, sizing you up, saying these things about your "potential"-- it was really weird. So maybe there’s something… going on. But I– I think they’re just trying to fuck with your head. Clearly the old hag, whoever she is, hates you. I think whatever they gave you is making you hallucinate. And if we’re gonna get out of here– if we’re gonna make things right for your sister– we need to stay tethered to reality, together. Alright?" Quinn felt as though she had absorbed a gut punch.  "So you don’t believe me." "I believe what you’re seeing, I just– it doesn’t make any sense. You have to listen to yourself."

Humiliation began to seep in. She pleaded with him.  "I know, I know, just– I’ve had crazy dreams, but this is real." An idea. "Let me show you!" she said, breathlessly. She stuck her leg out in front of her.

"Watch my laces, okay? They’re gonna untie." "Okay," he said, as patiently as he could. Quinn closed her eyes and connected with the creature again. It was angry now. It stared directly into Ty, unmoving, unyielding. It made her angry. She knew what she had to do. "Come here," she said. But it did not want to listen. It wanted something else.

"Come here," she tried again. But it had made up its mind. She had to pull just to make sure it did not inch any closer to him.  She opened her eyes, seething, still feeling the creature just as she was seeing it.  "Wow, I’m impressed," said Ty. "Always with that stupid sarcasm. Can you just open your mouth and tell me how you really feel for once? Or is that too hard for you?"

She breathed heavily. She could not contain herself.  "Okay," he said, frowning. "I think you are still drugged up from whatever they gave you. And I think, right now, you need to get out of your own head."                 "Well, then, what was happening in those videos? And how do you explain how sick you got? You were fine during our drive Saturday and you were on death’s door earlier today. They’re real, I– I pulled one of these things off of you. I just didn’t know what I was doing when I did it." He spoke slowly and calmly.

"The videos were weird, I’ll give you that much. But nothing really happened in either one. And we stayed in their hotels both nights we drove. They probably managed to poison me, or something. Or, maybe I just… had a migraine. I think my mom got really bad ones." "And how would you know that?" asked Quinn, before she could stop herself.  Ty took measured breaths, eyes still forward, aimed at but completely missing the creature.  "I guess I wouldn’t."

The words were hardly out of his mouth when a booming voice rang out in the room.  "If you wanted some proof of your friend’s abilities, Mr. Morrisey, you should have just asked. Step on in, Elyse." The door swung open. Elyse, arms folded and shivering, took small steps toward the middle of the room.  "This is demonstration one," said President Dorothy’s voice matter-of-factly over the intercom.

Elyse stopped, took a shaky breath, and knelt down in between Ty and Quinn. Her eyes were locked directly on to the corner of the room in between the two. Quinn watched the creature contort its long neck to watch the new human enter the room. It shone its blank eyes at the frightened young woman, regarding her with a mixture of intrigue and suspicion. Quinn felt the creature’s mind (or her own mind, or whatever it used to think) work as it clipped the tile with its sharp talons, circling slowly while never moving its icy gaze.  Quinn tried to conjure up some anger, some hatred, toward this woman who had led her directly to what she’d seen in that closet. But it seemed as though the foreign emotions of the creature were overpowering her own, even more so than before. It was as though this thing were trying to tell her something– but she couldn’t quite decipher the message.  "Hey, lady!" yelled Ty, eager to break the silence that had grown in the room. "Do you want to tell us what you want? Or what the fuck’s really happening here? Are you just gonna leave us chained up here forever?"

Elyse took a breath, turned to him, and smiled sadly.  "You won’t be here forever. But all I can tell you is that you shouldn’t talk to the others the way you’ve been talking to me. For your other eye’s sake." Ty was taken aback briefly. She spoke in a very warm, controlled voice despite her outward appearance.  "It’s not your fault, though;" she continued, "I know what people go through in this building. I’ve been here for a long time. Too long, really."

She turned to Quinn. She felt the hairs on the back of her neck stand up just as much as she felt the tips of her talons flex.  "She talked about you," said Elyse, regaining some of her color. "She didn’t talk about much– not when she didn’t have to. But she did talk about you." "What?" asked Quinn, confused.  "She was smart, and funny, and… so resilient. I would have loved it if we got to work together in some other world, on some other fucking project…"

Suddenly, this young woman was turning red. "It’s not fair. It’s never been fair. These people, they… I know what they’re trying to do, but it’s like trying to let air out of a tire with a chainsaw. It’s just problem after problem, and life after wasted life. And I– I’ve never stopped them. I’ve never even tried." Quinn tried to piece together Elyse’s scattered thoughts. .  "You killed her."

"I wish it was that simple, Quinn. I could tell you they made me. I could tell you I loved her. But that’s not what they want me to tell you right now.  "I’m here to tell you that you need to kill me." Ty slid back against the wall. "Hey!" he yelled, eyes bulging out of his skull. "What the hell is this?"

Elyse shook her head, and kept her eyes locked on Quinn’s. She spoke slowly and deliberately, as though she was a novice actor delivering memorized lines. "It won’t be hard. The things that you’re controlling– that’s what they want. The hard part is going to be telling them ‘no’ afterwards. But your sister said you were even stronger than she was. And she fought like hell to make it as long as she did." Quinn looked forward blankly, mind racing. She watched as the creature pawed its way up Elyse’s back, stopping its legs perched on each of her shoulders. It moved with surprising grace and balanced with flawless dexterity. It knew what it wanted.  "I can feel it," Elyse said, closing her eyes. "Do it. Do it for Maeve, do it so you can get out of here. Just do it."

Quinn closed her eyes.  "QUINN!" yelled Ty, increasingly frantic. "TELL ME WHAT’S HAPPENING!" She wrapped two of her talons around Elyse’s neck. They fit so naturally.  And ripped a deep tear in the flesh underneath her chin.

Quinn opened her eyes and lurched forward. Her mind was ravaged by a dizzying hit of euphoria. She howled, but heard nothing. She felt so strong. Her chains were made of wet paper. Her body was made of iron. There was no one– nothing– that could tell her no. She was strong. She was so fucking strong.  Her heart pounded in her ears. The creature stood triumphantly upon its victim, who lay on the floor without a drop of blood spilled. Indeed, it may have been thought to be sleeping had its eyes been closed and its chest been rising and falling.  But they were not, and because of it, Quinn had finally found her divine purpose. Her schooling, her friendships, her problems, her journey– all of it had been but an overture for this one, perfect, beautiful moment. The action was effortless and instinctual. The result was nothing less than world-altering.

This realization led to another. The moment would have to happen again.  The creature, finished celebrating its triumph, scanned the room. Quinn, breathing heavily, felt every ounce of pleasure drain away.  It wanted Ty next.

He was sitting in stunned silence. An easy target– chained up, even. She would never have anything this effortless in her sights again. "No," she said, out loud. It didn’t like that answer. It made its way to Ty.  "No, no, no."

It hated her. She hated herself. She felt its longing at the very core of her being.  "Stop, no." She was convictionless. Powerless to oppose it. The feeling needed to come back. It walked its way up his legs and onto his shoulders.  "Demonstration one has concluded."

The lights cut. Although Quinn’s vision went black, the creature did not lose sight of the outline of Ty’s neck.  Then, the room was flooded by blacklight.  The pain flooded in, worlds worse than the victory she had just enjoyed. Ubiquitous agony, overwhelming walls of heat, glass bones shattering from dog whistle frequencies played over loudspeakers. She felt it all. Second after second after eternal second, she felt it. She wailed, she cried, she begged for mercy.  The last embers of her consciousness dulled slowly.
What have I done to deserve this?  Relief did not come until over a minute had passed. Her heart stood still. ./. "God damn it, what do I pay you all for?"
"President, we are working as hard as we can–" "Are you? Then why isn’t she breathing?" "President, please, I need you to relax–" "Relax? Are you fucking kidding me? Relax?"

Dr. Ramos panted as she spoke. Her hands furiously pressed down on Quinn’s sternum. Every few seconds, she would listen to her chest in search of life. Every few seconds, she would repeat the same word to the group of doctors who swarmed her like vultures over roadkill.  President Dorothy, completely beside herself, picked up Quinn’s discarded chains and threw them against the mirror with all of her might. With a tinselly crash, the heavy chains hit the floor underneath a fresh crack in the glass.  Ty, who was mere feet from the site of the impact, hardly even flinched. His eyes were locked onto the corpse which lay completely untouched. He kept waiting for her to get up. He waited for her to say that this was just an elaborate prank that his friend pulled on him, and that nobody was dead, and that all of the horrible blood on Quinn’s clothes from the morning was just red food coloring.  But he had seen the way they drugged her. He had seen the look in her eyes. He knew he had to reconcile reality with Hell. And yet, he found it nearly impossible.

"Hold on," said Dr. Ramos, both hands in the air, ear to Quinn’s chest.  An eternity of opaque silence.  "She’s breathing. But faintly. We need to get her across the hall now."
