Her body, limp, unresponsive, was thrown onto a makeshift gurney, which was really just a wooden table with wheels from the conference room on the second floor. Four of the paramedics hurried her out of the room.

The commotion began to attract the attention of the guests who had been waiting outside. Curious, frightened eyes ogled into the room and onto the gurney. President Dorothy felt a flash of heat that nearly overcame her.  "Won’t one of you unchain him?" she asked wildly, to the pack of onlookers outside. "Does my work mean anything to anyone?" She followed the paramedics out of the room and found herself battling through a packed hallway. She spoke, eyes darting, voice cracking, to the masses rather than to anyone in particular.  "Won’t someone… move out my way! Move… Would you stop staring and do something to help me!"

Soon the halls ignited with sound, in the form of anxious chatter. President Dorothy had been proven quite clairvoyant in stocking a room close to the experiment room with medical supplies, but it seemed as though the hysteria-produced sonic barrier alone might prevent her from ever reaching it.  "Get back! Now! Back to the observation room!" Some of the well-dressed bodies within earshot of President Dorothy’s cry attempted to give her room, but their efforts were not of much use. She fell behind the paramedics. The hallway was so cramped, so hot.  She absolutely could not lose her. Not now.

Gritting her teeth, the old woman reached past a large man and slipped into the room with the medical supplies. She must not have traveled more than twenty-five feet, but she felt as though she’d run miles.  She closed the door and locked it. In front of her was a room that had looked as though it had not been touched since the facility was still a proper hospital. Cabinets full of medical supplies lined the walls, monitors of all sizes were perched next to a small window, and an old bed sat in the center. A dresser next to the bed displayed a vase of flowers which appeared to have wilted twenty years ago.  Two of the doctors lifted Quinn’s limp body onto the bed and connected her to some of the monitors. The room, the relic, so much more still than the prevailing chaos outside, was filled with the tepid beeping of the young woman’s heartbeat.  Dr. Ramos rifled through cabinets and barked orders at the others. Her words did not make much sense to President Dorothy– she had spent her youth studying how people worked, but not which compounds may fix them when they stopped working.

Even if she had, though, she would have still endured this great surge of panic, which seemed to course through her veins as freely as her own blood. It shook her, this feeling. She was not often one to lose control of her feelings in this way. The cause of her overwhelming concern was not necessarily the prospect that a Leader may pass on without a proper plan in place for succession– she had dealt with precarious situations of that manner before, and always she’d managed to procure some improvised plan– but it was something else entirely. In all of her years, she hadn’t felt such responsibility for another human being. All of her work with Maeve had transitioned, seamlessly, perhaps even more powerfully than before, over to an older, stronger, version of herself.  The eye of the storm of panic she felt was a poisonously alluring thought that won over everything else in the old woman’s mind. Perhaps the years of pain and failure could come to an end. Perhaps this is the one. Perhaps our plan will work as it was once intended to after all.  Regardless of the risk, the opportunity simply could not be wasted.

"Is she stabilizing?" asked President Dorothy, involuntarily wringing her hands. "Her heart’s beating on its own, for now. Can you open that for me?" Without ever looking up, Dr. Ramos pointed to the cabinet closest to President Dorothy, and asked for a certain bottle of pills. The old woman’s hands shook as she handed them over. A machine showed that her blood pressure was dangerously low. "Are these going to help with that?" she asked, gesturing to the machine.

"Maybe. This could be a long process, though. Just be prepared to…" At once, the feet and mouths outside the room which had become background static to President Dorothy stopped. Suddenly aware of their absence, she emerged from her own mind and tried to read the doctors’ faces. But the silence lasted only an instant.  The first scream was a woman’s. Immediately afterward was a stampede of elephants that drowned out any other cries that came from the other side of the locked door.

Though nearly knocked off balance by the shaking floor, President Dorothy did not take her attention from the bed. She had to shout to be heard over the noise. "What’s happening?" she asked Dr. Ramos. Dr. Ramos, with wild, unsettled eyes, responded breathlessly.  "I don’t know how, but… she’s waking up."

Sure enough, President Dorothy, from her post near the door, could see that Quinn was twitching, ever so slightly, at irregular intervals.  Her blood ran cold. Her fears were confirmed.  "Ramos, you have to put her back to sleep." "What? Why?"

"She’s killing." Her words, at last, betrayed the panic she felt.  The stampede had largely passed, but the cries were still audible. There were perhaps two hundred or so who had come to see the demonstration; maybe half were on the fourth floor, and another half were elsewhere in the building, meeting about a new drug they were trying to push into testing. Some of them were government representatives, some were financial contributors, some were personal friends.  Now, undoubtedly, some were dead.

She slumped to the ground, back against the door. President Dorothy felt her world fragment into pieces around her.  One of the doctors grabbed a vial of liquid out of a cabinet, and spoke to Dr. Ramos. He produced a syringe from a pull-out cabinet underneath the bed and injected her with it.  Seconds passed. I must be able to fix her, she thought. She’s only killing because she’s vulnerable now. I can teach her still. I don’t need these scientists anyway. She can still learn. Quinn kept twitching. Ramos yelled something to the doctor, who gathered another syringe-full of liquid, and injected it into Quinn’s arm.

Everyone knew what the risks were when they signed on. We’re herding animals– demons, really– it’s not anyone’s fault, just, Lord, let me connect with her– Ramos grabbed the syringe, dipped it back into the liquid, and gave Quinn another dose.  We can go to another place– get away from all of this– I can handle it, I don’t need them, I just need one– "President!" shouted Ramos from the bedside.
"What?" she responded, still seated against the door.  "She’s not falling asleep." "What?" "She– she’s still waking up."
"How? Are the tranquilizers bad?" "No, ma’am." "Then give her more." "President, there’s enough in her right now to kill two horses."

The old woman stood up and approached the bed. Sure enough, Quinn’s eyes were fluttering open. The sound of her heartbeat on the monitor was stable and strong.  An inhuman pounding came from the door so violently that President Dorothy could not believe the hinges did not fly off. All of the doctors jolted away from the noise. "It’s here," she said, blankly. "President, what do we do?" asked Doctor Ramos, fear threatening to keep the words in her throat.

The old woman shook her head. The pounding at the door continued.  "We have to kill her," said the man holding the vial.  A small sound escaped from Quinn’s mouth, barely audible above the pounding.  "No!" snapped President Dorothy, vitriol tainting her gaze.

The pounding stopped for a moment.  "She’s sending one of those things after us, President," said Ramos, hardly even daring to look at her. "We have to consider–" "Consider what?" The doctor lost her nerve. "It can– it has–"

"You will do exactly as I say." The doctor on Quinn’s opposite side shook his head and reached into a cabinet. In one gloved hand, he held a scalpel.  "Jeremy, stop that." Another pound from the door. Splinters flew halfway across the room.

Jeremy raised the inch-long blade over Quinn’s neck. Her eyes lazily met his. "You know what happens if you do it, right?" President Dorothy, in a small but authoritative voice, spoke without taking her own eyes off of Quinn. Jeremy looked around at everyone in the room.

Shakily, he turned his hand over, offering the knife to someone else.  There were four other doctors in the room. Every one of them took a longing look at the weapon.  But before anyone had moved, a hole the size of a beach ball had appeared in the door, sending shrapnel flying into every part of the room.  Jeremy had no time even to cry out.

Three gashes emerged from thin air– two on his neck, and one just above his chin. Blood poured out onto the bed sheets and pooled under his feet. He gave one garbled cough before collapsing and fading away.  All of the other doctors sprinted from the carnage to the shattered door. As if by magic, Ramos’ hair caught in thin air. In an instant, she had suffered the same fate as Jeremy.  President Dorothy watched the others push the door open and begin their frantic exit from the building. She listened as their footsteps grew more and more distant, until finally, she was sure they had descended the staircase. The old woman walked to the side of the bed and knelt down, covering her pant leg in blood. It was so fascinating. These things were usually so discrete in their work.

She reached a shaky hand out and ran it through Quinn’s orange hair. It was longer and finer than her sister’s. President Dorothy spoke softly and deliberately.  "I know this is hard, Quinn. And I know you’re angry. But we… can be so much together. I just need you to trust me." President Dorothy felt goosebumps go up her leg, as though an invisible spider were crawling on her.

"Come on, honey. I know what you’re dealing with. I know what to do." The goosebumps reached her upper back. She pressed her face into Quinn’s shoulder and spoke through welling tears. "I can help you find her again." A blinding pain in Dorothy’s throat cut her off. The air in the room ran out. The instant of surprise immediately yielded to panic and then to lightness.
The last thing she felt was the gentle touch of her head hitting the floor.  ./. The first thing that Quinn smelled was metal.  That’s odd, she thought. My room doesn’t usually smell like metal.

Grimacing, she reached for her blanket but was surprised to find that she did not have one. She opened her eyes and was met with a ceiling that was not her own. Suddenly panicked, Quinn bolted upright.  The first thing she saw were the bodies. Two women and one man were strewn about on the floor around her bedside, pale and covered in blood.  But before she could scream or run or even gag, she met the gaze of a small animal perched atop her shin. It had the body of a small cat, although it was not covered in fur. Its pinkish-blue flesh, matted in awful knobs, came to an end at its talon-like feet. And perhaps most surprisingly of all, it had the face of an owl, except for those eyes.
Those ghost white eyes.  The haze of the past few days lifted.  The color drained from Quinn’s face.  "Did you do this?" she whispered to the creature.

It craned its neck at her and jumped to the floor, as though in response. It did not make a noise, however.  Fighting through tremors, Quinn swung her legs over the bed. She tried to keep her eye level such that she could not see the wreckage that had been wrought. Even still, she knew that one of the victims was that awful woman who had chained her up.  As she walked through the room, she decided that she must still be dreaming. There was simply no way that these people were dead. This could not have happened to her.  She felt horror and shock, sure. But as she opened the door to see the mess of a dozen or so other bodies heading out toward the stairwell, she felt an unmistakable sense of fulfillment, as though she’d just solved a difficult puzzle or had a meaningful conversation with an old friend.

I just have to wake up, and these feelings will go away. Still, she knew that Ty was in the building somewhere. She hoped that he wasn’t one of the ones that the creature had decided to kill.  "Ty?" she called. "Ty, where are you?" She followed the trail of ballistics gel and strawberry syrup down the stairs. She checked quickly that none of them were her friend, but she didn’t look for too long, as her mind was particularly acute at holding on to disturbing images.

"Ty, please," she called out meekly, opening the door to the first floor landing.  Down here, the bodies were less densely distributed. There were only two in the long visible stretch of the hallway. Next to her, a door was slightly open. Although it was completely dark in there, Quinn was almost certain she could hear breathing. She cracked the door open further and took a timid step inside.  "Ty?"

A small amount of light from the hallway entered the room. Uninjured but curled up next to the closet entrance was her father. Quinn breathed a sigh of relief as she stepped inside. It happened very often in her dreams that people would appear in front of her at the most crucial of times.  Steven seemed hardly to notice her at first, but as she took slow steps toward him, his eyes met hers. He stood up, empty. "Quinnie–" he breathed, stumbling over to bring her into an embrace.

His face was twisted, coated in sweat and tears. He stank, too– nothing like her real father. As soon as he touched her, she tasted bile. She shoved him away, retreating behind the lonely chair in the center of the room. "I hate you," she said, softly. "Whatever you are. I should kill you." "Take this," he croaked.  He grabbed for something at his side and slid it on the rough carpet to Quinn. As it was still dark in the room, she couldn’t make out exactly what it was, but she had an idea.

It was cold. And heavier than she would have expected. But, even in the dark, aiming it was a bit like aiming her bow in that big grass field.  "Why?" she managed breathily. "Your mother. And you. If I didn’t– it would have been all three of you." "No. No. Why?"

Quinn’s father was silent for a moment. "When I– when we started, we thought we could contain these things. We thought a human connection could mellow them out. We were trying to make the world better. Safer. We were going to be heroes. Can you imagine that? Heroes. These things, no one knows they exist, they– they’ll kill two million people a year, and we found a way to stop them! To cut that number to one thousand, or less? We just didn’t– we didn’t count on it to take so much from these kids. But I never– I never– meant for her to get involved." By the end of his speech, Stephen seemed to beg, not for his life, but rather for the veracity of his words.  Quinn cocked her head to the side and switched the safety off of the pistol.
"For who?" Stephen’s mouth closed, as though he were attempting to make a sound. None came out.  "Who, Dad, who?" His eyes, barely visible, searched for hers.

The noise was awful. It was so loud that she dropped the weapon as soon as she fired it. A high-pitched buzzing obfuscated anything else she may have been able to hear.  But she had done exactly what she had intended to do. She dropped to her knees. One of his arms was under his back, turning his body awkwardly toward the closet.  I am waking up now, I am waking up now. She may have thought the words, or she may have said them out loud. It didn’t matter. They were all that mattered.  But she stayed right there, in the dark, on her knees, with what remained of her father and her sister.

Her breathing sped up, and her whole body leaked sweat. Time froze.  The closet will open. My real dad will stand up. I will wake up in bed.  I will wake up in bed.  Dull footsteps approached from the hallway. Quinn grabbed the gun and pointed it at the hallway door in a flash of movement.

"Quinn?" called a familiar voice. She made a noise. Light flooded into the room. Instinctively, he put his hands up. She watched his eyes go from her to the body in the corner of the room.  "Quinn, it’s me," Ty said, gulping for air.
She stayed locked in place.  "I’m dreaming." "No. It’s really me." Neither of the two blinked as Quinn tried to process his statement.

"Tell me I’m dreaming." "I’m here, Quinn. Talk to me. Tell me what they did to you." Quinn relaxed her shoulders and realized for the first time that she had been aiming her gun at Ty. Her mouth hung open. "They– I’m–"
Words failed her. Ty swallowed visibly. "It’s okay. We’re going to be okay. We need to get out of here." Quinn slowly turned her head to the closet door.  "No. Don’t look that way. We have to go."

She turned back to Ty. A silent tear had dribbled to the bottom of her cheek. "I’m not waking up." Ty took a step toward her, but stopped dead in his tracks when she lifted the gun to her own temple.  "Put it down," said Ty, slowly.
Her face twitched.  She slammed her eyes closed.  "I LOVE YOU!" Ty blurted out.  One second, another. Stillness.

"I love you, and I’ve loved you ever since I laid eyes on you in that stupid Calc class." The moments pushed past one another. "I love the way you think, and I love the way you laugh, and I love the way you see the world. You give me a reason to get up in the morning. And you are the reason I can’t fall asleep at night. If no one else loves you, I love you." For the first time, Quinn took a breath. The corners of Ty’s mouth tilted upward.

"I want to figure life out with you. I’ve been wasting time for twenty-two years because I didn’t care about anything. Now I do." She opened her eyes and let her arm hang limp. Ty quickly and quietly grabbed the gun from her hand and tucked it into the waist of his pants.  "Come here," he said, pulling her into a tight embrace. She did not hug back. But oh, how she shook.

"We’re going to talk to some people, and figure everything out. I’ll be there the whole time. All I want to do is help. Every day." She sniffled. He pulled away, and took a step back, cocking his head to the side like a critic judging a work of art. "God, are you beautiful," he said, flashing a knowing smile.  Quinn leaned against that lonely chair in the center of the room, and studied Ty’s face. It was funny. She felt like smiling, too. In fact, she just had to laugh. Before long, she was doubled over, struggling to draw breath, crying tears of hysterics.
EPILOGUE Unconscionable, she thought. It is unconscionably hot outside today.

Although it was just before six and the sun had long since reached its apex, the air seemed to sizzle outside of her small window. She could hardly think over the whirring of the dated air conditioning machine in the room. She looked over her work. She was nearly halfway through an essay in which she’d been forced to analyze the actions of one Mr. Robinson, or Mr. Richardson, or something to that effect. She could never remember the man’s name. The book was just too dense. As she was not allowed a computer, she had spent the past two and a half hours writing and erasing on pages of loose leaf paper. She had just thought of the word unconscionable and that seemed to signal to her that she needed a break.  Outside of her room, footsteps came and went. On some evenings, the chatter she could overhear was quite alarming (perhaps in subject matter, or volume, or both), but today it was three older women recalling a canceled television show here, two men debating about sports there. The heat from outside seemed to have a mellowing effect on her peers. It was mellowing her out, too. On a hot day like this, the air conditioner seemed just enough to drown out the noise in her head. Fatigue, which had threatened to overtake her for some time now, finally got the better of Quinn. She took care in setting her materials down and rested her head against the cool pillow.

"...Quinn?" said Ty, timidly standing at the corner of the room.  She squinted and checked the clock. She had been out for half an hour. It felt instantaneous. "Mmhmm," she mumbled, rolling over. "Big day tomorrow."

She drew herself up against the head of the bed and gave a nod. She saw that Ty was still wearing his suit and tie. "How was it?" she asked. "Did anyone pass out?" He looked down at his outfit.  "Oh. No, nothing like that. Ryan did a backflip, though. I thought the dean was going to piss himself."

"Was he really that mad?" "Mad? My God, he was furious. He told us yesterday that if anyone tried something like that, they weren’t going to get their diploma. And I really thought Ryan was going to walk empty-handed off the stage. But he didn’t. I guess the lesson to be learned is that the Dean of Students is actually powerless to control the students." Quinn shrugged. "I wish I’d have known that. I would have cheated more." Ty sighed and looked over at Quinn’s work.

"You’re still going with that?" She nodded. "I can’t keep getting extensions forever."         "I just don’t know why you’re working on this final when you’ll still be short six credits." She shrugged again.

"Something to do, I guess." "And I can’t talk you into taking two summer classes here and graduating in the fall." "No. I can’t stay here. Not now, at least." Ty frowned. "Alright. But there’s always a spot for you in my humble abode. Just say the word when you’re ready."
Quinn nodded, but spoke without looking at him.  "Thank you, Ty." His eyes darted outside to ensure no one was eavesdropping. Even still, he lowered his voice. "How have the urges been?"

"Fine," she responded, echoing his quietness. "I think the new meds they put me on last week are helping more than the old ones. I haven’t in…four days now." "Really? None at all?" "No. I might have to tonight, but I’m not sure yet. It’s progress, anyway." "Yeah. Progress." He looked longingly at the waves of heat outside. "I just wish there was a way you could convince them you needed something even stronger."

"Well," she responded, "I could always pretend to go off the deep end and live the rest of my life here. Maybe a few years of asking would change their minds." "Or, you could try the demonstration theory."  Ty had proposed weeks earlier that Quinn move a glass or a sheet of paper across the room with one of the creatures in front of a doctor.  "As soon as one of those things messes with something physical–"

"I know, I know. But for that brief instant, wouldn’t they be so surprised that everything you were rambling on about was actually true?" "Trust me, I’ve thought about that." A moment of silence passed. "You haven’t heard anything about my mother, have you?"

Ty shook his head. "No. I call every day, just like you’re telling me. I talked to your grandparents, though. Their flight is leaving in an hour or so, and they’ll be here tomorrow at noon, provided everything goes well." "They didn’t seem worried?" "Well, they’re worried about you." "Of course," she said, studying the patterns on her socks. Faintly, intermittently, she held out hope that a text would be waiting for her when she got her phone back tomorrow. Most of the time, however, she was not so optimistic.

"Alright," Ty said, opening a pullout drawer beside her bed. "Last time." "Hopefully," she said. "Hopefully," he said, mockingly. "Come on, last time and you know it." He pulled out the solitary college-ruled sheet of paper that was tucked away in the drawer and clicked a pen.

"Okay. Something old, something new. A Dylan song you may not have heard before, and a screamo song you definitely have heard before." In small letters, he carefully wrote the names of two songs on the sheet. Both the front and the back were covered with song titles and artists, some in ink and some in pencil.  "Are you ever going to listen to me when I tell you I hate that stuff?" "Screamo? Just listen once, Q. That’s all I ask. And rate it with an open heart and an honest mind."
"Alright, whatever."  He put the sheet back and slid the door closed. With a rousing sigh, he stood up.  "So this is it, I guess." She nodded.

"Good luck in Arizona. Take care of your old folks. Get a tan. Drink water. Visit the Grand Canyon. Do other things, I don’t know. Just don’t forget to call and text. I know what you’re going through…sort of. Just keep in touch." "I will." "And…oh. I almost forgot." He unbuttoned his jacket and reached inside. From an inner pocket, he procured a maroon notebook.

"They unchained me, after your heart…stopped. I think they were going to keep me in a room somewhere, but everything started happening before they got the chance. So I figured I should look for this on that…first…woman. And I found it, threw it in the trunk of the car, and I figured I would give it to you when you were better." He held out the notebook.  Quinn grabbed it and leafed through quickly. Surely enough, her sister’s handwriting filled the pages.  "I’ll, um… leave you alone, now."
She stood up from the bed and hugged him.  "Thank you," she said, bleary-eyed. He squeezed her tightly.  "I love you, Quinn."

In any other universe, under these circumstances, she should have been able to say that line back to him as though she had memorized and rehearsed it for months. But not hers.  She smiled, and thanked him again.  His footsteps echoed across the room, down the hall, and into nothingness.  Quinn took a deep breath. She felt for the first time in nearly two months that she was in motion. She flipped to the back with a racing heart and sweating palms and began to read.

Hey Quinn, I guess this is goodbye. The way things have been going, I think they’re going to kill me. I have no idea whether or not you’re in on the whole secret organization/psychic superpower thing like Dad is (has been for years, as it turns out), but something about the look on your face as we drove away on the day of the shooting tells me you aren’t. If that’s the case, and if what I’ve been hearing is true, then I imagine that you’re probably scared and maybe a little bit sad that I’m gone (depending on how you really felt about me, behind all those layers of callous indifference that the years have bestowed so kindly upon your demeanor). But, assuming I can find some way to get this to you, right now I need you. Before I say anything sappy, and I’ll get to all that, I need you to know that something else is going on. I’m almost positive they’ll find some way to give you whatever it is that they gave me. And I’m so sorry it has to be that way. If you feel, underneath everything else, more perceptive, or more imaginative (?), or more out of tune with how you think you should be feeling– then you know you have it. President Dorothy told me an old professor of hers discovered these things– dreamers, they call them– that exist in some metaphysical realm parallel to ours. I can’t explain it; there was a lot of math involved, and you know I’m hopeless with that kind of thing. They seem to be fascinated with killing and traumatizing humans, though, and I guess that as they were unchecked for the entire course of human history, they have been responsible for probably thousands or millions of deaths. They don’t feed, they don’t really reproduce, but they just– kill. It drives them, or something. And they’re smart about it, too. If they don’t have to, they won’t leave any evidence behind. Other people will just think it was a heart attack or a stroke or something. They’re untraceable. Scary shit.  President Dorothy has been working with psychologists and doctors and theoretical physicists (and fifteen-year-olds, I guess) to try and link a human to the hive mind that the dreamers seem to share. Miraculously, they figured it out. It’s unbelievable– but, if you have it now, you already know that. The dreamers have been begging me to kill for weeks. Constantly. I’ve been telling them no, and they listen to me, but it takes every ounce of my energy to resist. The doctors here gave me a dose of something crazy once, and that helped. But I really would rather not go down that road. I mean, sometimes I wake up in the middle of the night and I want that feeling just as bad as I want to give into the dreamers. And I only had one dose.  None of that matters anymore to me, I suppose. I don’t know what they’re going to do to you. The six months or so I’ve spent here have been scary and shitty and above anything else lonely, but they kept telling me I was going to be able to leave at some point. And I do believe them. Had I killed some poor soul in front of the scientists, or even a dog, or something, I think they would have let me go. I don’t think they were convinced I had enough control over the dreamers to do something like that. God knows I did. I just didn’t want to kill the first time, because I know I wouldn’t have ever been able to stop.

But if anyone can manage to stop, I think it’s you. I need you to beat these fucking people. I need you to live. You’re probably going to feel terrible, all the time, but there’s no one on the planet that is capable of saving more lives than you. That’s what President Dorothy told me, at least, every time I failed one of her dumb tests. Ironic, I guess.  No matter what, you’re my superhero. The earliest I can remember, you were eleven and I was probably four. You came back from the dentist with these metal wires on your teeth, and I immediately started crying because I thought they were scary and probably painful. But you explained what they were, and how they worked, and ten minutes later I was laughing. I don’t know how much I told you this, really, but I’ve never stopped thinking of you like that. You do the hard things, and then I come home seven years later with braces, and I’m okay because I know you got through it. And you drive me to concerts. And you sneak me and my friends onto mini golf courses.  So I guess it’s alright that things worked out this way, because maybe for once I can help you out with something. The only thing that pisses me off is that I never got to meet your as-of-now future brunette girlfriend. When you find her, tell her I said hello. -Maeve

The girl in the dark black dress with the dark black hair stood at the front of the line, absorbing their words and shaking their cold, clammy hands. She was quite tall and gaunt, with high cheekbones and narrow shoulders and beady brown eyes that looked through, rather than at. Some of the people in attendance that day thought (to themselves, of course, no one would dare to say it out loud) that she was an even more harrowing sight than that of her poor father, embalmed and puffed up in his polished burgundy casket, still bearing signs of the relentless cancer that had taken him so suddenly, at the age of forty-one. Even still, perhaps in different lighting, or with a bit of make-up, his daughter may have been beautiful.  Next in line was her great-uncle, a loud man who drank and swore too much. Though she rarely saw him, he had taken a liking to sitting her down and giving her long one-on-one lectures about her impending life and career as a woman, as though she were his own child. He would announce to all present at Easter brunches or family barbecues that he was "gettin’ my dear-old grandniece to say somethin’, for a change!" before talking over her in a cramped attic or washroom for twenty minutes that felt like hours. He always stank such that she could not pay attention to him.  She hated him. But more crucially, she found him to be unimpressive.  He hugged her mother and lamented into her ear, lines of spittle lingering on his lips as he spoke. They both cried, their faces red, splotchy, moist. For as ungraceful as they looked, it fit their faces well. Perhaps if it fit her face well, they all would not stiffen their backs and avert their eyes when they spoke to her. Perhaps then she could listen to them.

But she liked it better, this way.  Eventually, after making some show of rubbing his mother’s arm and feeding her more emptiness,"stay strong"s and "he’ll always be with you"s, he made his way to the girl in the dark black dress with the dark black hair. Initially unsure whether to give her a hug, he lurched forward awkwardly, but decided on extending his hand, a gesture for which she felt much appreciation.  "I’m really sorry, Dot," he said, in a low, raspy voice.  "Thank you. And please, call me Dorothy."

The words cut through the air just as her paper-thin lips sliced across her face.  "Right. I know. You’re growing the hell up." An instant of silence. It was rare that her great-uncle was lost for words. She did not mind.  "Hey, speaking of that, how’s Kenimore? You doing okay up there?"

"Fine. I’m learning a lot. And it’s nice to be on my own." "Well, if, uh… you need anyone to talk to…" "Of course." "Especially now. I mean, these things hit you… in waves, sometimes. One day, you might be fine, but then the next, it’s completely different. When I lost my dad, I was shell-shocked for weeks. Walking around, talking, working, everything. And then, one day, I was with old Bear, out for a walk, and I just couldn’t take it anymore. I tied him to a telephone pole so I could just lay down on the side of the road and bawl. I don’t know what caused it, I don’t know why then. It just… happened."

Dorothy glanced over at the line of mourners, which had been moving quite well up to that point.  "I see," she said. "I’m sorry." As though remembering that she was there, her great-uncle drew his shoulders back. "Anyway. Just remember what I’ve been telling you, alright? You’ll be fine. You’re a tough kid."

She nodded. He moved to her left, and brought her aunt into a mammoth hug, punctuated with more tears and more spit. She was one conversation closer to the end of the day.  ./. The afternoon they put him in the ground was irritatingly beautiful. Streaks of wispy clouds drifted slowly across the sky, dulling the sun’s glare. A gentle breeze made fresh oak and aspen leaves stretch and sway, as though they had just been awoken by the recent passing of winter. Flowers of every color sprung out of the rolling hills of the cemetery. There was so much life on this day, and it all moved, and breathed, and stifled coughs, and offered her its best, most meaningless sentiment.

But after the final prayer was said, and the final anecdote shared; after the acquaintances and distant relatives had made their hasty getaways; after a final, longing look was offered to the marble grave, which, at nearly seven feet tall, stood like a beacon in that lovely field– she was thankful, at least, that as she pulled away in her black Thunderbird, she was neither sweating nor shivering.  "Aunt Bertha, Uncle James, and the kids will be over when we get home," said Dorothy’s mother, from the passenger’s seat.         She was in her late thirties, though at this moment she looked older. She had always been around money, and never intended to work. But as Dorothy was going off to college, her husband had suggested taking a secretary position at the college he taught at, outwardly as a means of filling her days with meaning, but truthfully as means to alleviate the inevitable marital strain that would have come alongside boredom. The stress of the new job, combined with that of her husband’s illness, had over the course of only a few months borne deep lines in her forehead that were quite unbecoming of someone her age.  "What? Really?"

"Yes. They’re making dinner for us, which is very thoughtful. Meatloaf, I think, the way that you like it. I hope that’s alright." Dorothy kept her eyes forward and spoke evenly. "They couldn’t have given us an hour alone." "I know. I know it’s been hard. For you, especially. But they mean well, and it’s only one night, okay?"

"Okay? What could they possibly have to say to us that hasn’t been said ad nauseam already?" "Dot-" "I mean it. And why do they feel the need to come over? And you, to host them? Is there something you can’t accept? He’s dead. I’d like to move forward." That seemed to quiet the old woman.

Dorothy pulled into their driveway some minutes later, behind Uncle James’ old Mayflower, which became uglier every time she looked at it. She kept the engine running, and gripped the steering wheel with both hands.  "All of my things are still in the trunk. I’d like to go back to school now." Her mother took one uneven sigh and nodded. She tried to look at her daughter, but it was as though Dorothy were as bright as the sun in that black dress of hers. "Okay. I’ll host the Mahoneys by myself, then."

Dorothy could feel the air enter her lungs for the first time since she’d received the call last week. She could hear the children running and yelping in their backyard already. The adults would cry and drink and rave about "togetherness" and "family", the kids would run and eat until they were sick, and both parties would retire that night with a pounding headache and resentment of the other. Death constantly and oppressively outlines the scarcity of time, thought Dorothy, as she backed her car out and began to brace for the long journey north. Why does everyone seem so intent on wasting it, with good intentions and suppressed feelings? How does its message continue to get mired in– "Dot?" called her mother, running onto the front lawn, waving a piece of paper above her head. Dorothy heaved a long sigh, and stopped the car. She had been two yards from freedom, maybe less. "What is it?"

"A letter," she said, thrusting her arm through the open passenger side window. "It’s from someone at your school. He worked with your father, I think." "Thank you," Dorothy said, giving it a quick glance, and refraining from making a comment about the drop of perspiration that landed on the seat next to her.  "I love you, honey. Good luck. Call me if you need anything." "I love you too, mother. But please stop calling me Dot. It’s infantilizing."

Dorothy rolled up the windows and did not look back before speeding down the road. She did, however, give another brief glance to the letter. She was unsure if she’d read the name of the sender correctly at first, but it seemed now that she had.  Ordinarily, Dorothy would have taken a right onto Sinead Street, another right onto Juniper, and then a left onto Main. From there, she would have merged onto the highway, and driven one hundred and eighty-one miles north to Kenimore College, a trip that should have totaled three hours and twenty-six minutes, give or take. Today, however, she bore left onto Sinead, and pulled into the first driveway she saw. She took a breath and carefully ran her finger under the glue which held the envelope together. Willing her hands to be still, she began to read.  Dorothy, Although I assume you may be tired of hearing this by now, I’m sorry about the untimely passing of your father. I had the chance to mentor him for three years at Kenimore, and then work with him as a colleague while he was a young man. I must say he was brilliant, resourceful, respectful, all of those things that a scientist should be.

But it is not any of that which I will remember most about Nicholas. He was, put simply, more dedicated to his craft than anyone else I have ever met. Holidays, weekends, nights, in his sleep, I tell you, he was always thinking, pushing forward. Any and all advancements made in the field of biology at this college in the past twenty years are a direct result of the frankly unbelievable quantity (and quality!) of man-hours logged by your father. I have been in contact with some of your professors and it appears that the metaphorical apple does not fall far from the tree, in this case at least. Though I am not certain how you may feel about undertaking a project with an old biology professor like myself, given that you are at the top of your class in psychology at present, I am confident you will find much overlap between the two fields. A bit of diligent studying and learning is all that is necessary to fill in any remaining gaps.  To the point. Your father requested his body be donated to science in the event of his untimely demise. I was granted the ability to give him a postmortem examination by the institution, and I found some results that are very inconsistent with the manner of his death. I am not suggesting foul play or negligence by the hospital; independent autopsies have ruled those avenues out, and I agree with their findings. I am suggesting, however, that something else could be at play. What, exactly? And how would I prove it? That’s where you would come in. I would like someone to develop tools, conduct experiments, run ideas by, regarding the inconsistencies I have found with your father. I have already run the same tests on a dozen other human cadavers, and three have shown similar inconsistencies.  I think there is something big out there that no one has discovered yet. I’d like your help getting to the bottom of it.
And yes, you will be paid generously.  Wishing you health in body, mind, and soul. Dr. Carl T. Eugene, Professor Emeritus ./.

She’d always been a cold sleeper. When she was younger, she had gotten into the habit of wearing thick wool socks and sweatshirts to bed, even in the summer. Her own parents hadn’t thought anything of it until Mrs. Pierceson, her friend’s mom, recalled seeing her under two heavy blankets and tangled up in a scarf at a sleepover when she was twelve. She went to a professional, and though they said it was unusual, they couldn’t find anything wrong with her. So, even if it meant waking up in pools of sweat, even if it meant extra laundry, it didn’t matter.  It was the way she had to do things.  Though this sleeping habit was not the entirety of the reason why the 10:15 alarm seemed to come so quickly, it was likely the cause of the blistering succession of shrill blaring that inevitably came at 10:30, and again at 10:45. Quinn Harper, plenty old enough now to understand the cycles of sleeping and waking, was always surprised that it was already time to get out of bed.

She finally committed to keeping her eyes open some fleeting minutes later, and voyaged her feet to the floor more minutes after that. Then she laboriously threw her two weighted blankets across the bed and pulled off the sweatshirt she was wearing– her grandfather’s, and much too big for her, just the way she liked it.  Of course, there was the accompanying chill. It started at her fingertips and slid effortlessly up her arms and into her chest, between her ribs. Her teeth chattered, and her joints ached, and her nose ran. Saturday and Sunday were opportunities to lay in bed for hours, delaying this chill. There was no such luxury today. Quinn tried to stand, and ended up feeling grateful that she didn’t fall face first onto the floor. Sat back on the bed, she became fully aware of just how angrily her head pounded. It was as though her very consciousness was ready to split into thousands upon millions of independent pieces.  If she had felt this way some fourteen months ago, she may have called for an ambulance. Today, however, she sighed and reached to her nightstand for a small orange bottle.

When she picked it up, two measly pills rattled. She twisted the cap open and threw them back. With a shudder, she tossed the empty cartridge into a nearly-overflowing trash can. Quinn ran her hands through her hair and reached for her phone.  To her surprise, someone had texted her- Ty. Of course it was Ty. She opened the message and read it as quickly as she could. Hey Q, got a couple of things I need to talk to you about. Please call me.

She swiped away from the conversation and closed her eyes. She fought off a wave of guilt as she navigated toward another familiar name and hovered her thumbs above the keyboard.  She knew him as Nicholas, and he was an odd fellow. He was probably near sixty, with a great white beard, large glasses, and a tye-dyed bandana which never seemed to leave his balding head. He drove a vintage sports car with the mufflers removed and the speakers blasting, in spite of the fact that he had been arrested (by his own claim) six separate times. He smelled like a boys’ middle school locker room (some days, an overpowering mix of body spray and body odor; others, just the latter), he sent her conspiracy theory videos that she thought were confusing and odd, and his mannerisms and speech were stolen straight from the grassy fields of Woodstock 1969, despite the fact that she knew for certain that was before his time.  Nicholas was as enigmatic as he was odd. He was ex-military and ex-government, both of which he spoke proudly of. In fact, as a former member of the top-secret Delta Project committee in Washington, D.C., he had access to very vital information regarding government-funded projects which may have been viewed as less-than-ethical had the public been aware of their existence. Though Quinn did not know anything about other projects Nicholas was involved in, or even what Nicholas’ last name was, she knew that he was one of the few people– in the government, in the country, in the world– that was informed of what happened last spring in Colorado, and what had been happening for years prior.  She was grateful to have him. Really, she was grateful to Ty for putting her into contact with him. She was grateful to Ty for rounding up all of the scientists she didn’t kill at that ivy-covered building, and the Delta committee members, and coming up with a cover story, swearing them to secrecy, checking in with them regularly, becoming a de facto government official in addition to leading his own life, wherever that had taken him.

She was grateful to Ty for protecting her. She should text him back. Shouldn’t she? The most crucial fact about Nicholas was that he sold her drugs that she did not have a prescription for. The empty bottle in the trash formerly contained nolazopam, a medication that millions across the world took every day to stem anxiety. Though the pills did tend to make her feel better, they served a very different purpose for Quinn. She’d made an accidental discovery in the wake of last year’s incident that drugs that she took affected dreamers- the invisible killing machines that she had a mental connection with- in often counterintuitive ways.

Ordinarily these dreamers would beg their host, their Leader, for freedom to kill so often that it drove them insane. With nolazopam, Quinn had been able to limit their habits to one time per week. Still, the dreamers made themselves felt. Once Quinn had made her refill request to Nicholas, she attempted to stand again, steadying herself with a timid hand against her bed. Thousands of poking and prodding voices ran themselves across her skull, drying her mouth, reddening her eyes. Today marked six days since she had let them loose. Today, just as was the case last Thursday, and the Thursday before that, they begged her with particularly malicious levels of ferocity, knowing perhaps on some base animal level that they were about to receive exactly what they wanted.  But the pills she had taken were beginning to do their work, and Quinn was able to shuffle her way across her small bedroom, across the hallway, and into the bathroom. She turned the shower knob as far to the right as it could go, and slowly peeled off her clothes as steam began to flood the bathroom.  There was a small window at eye level in that shower, a feature which Quinn initially found unsettling, but eventually had come to appreciate. There were more trees in Arizona than she’d thought, at least near her grandparents’ house. Though they were numerous, they weren’t very dense, standing more like individual watchmen than moshing concert-goers. On clear nights such as this one, she loved wiping steam off the window and taking in blurry views of the trees in the moonlight. She could be anywhere, save for the giveaway of the dry, dead ground.

She felt alone, looking out that window. It was peaceful. By the time she stepped out of the shower and ran a toothbrush across her teeth and had thrown on the clothes she’d haphazardly laid out for herself the previous morning, she was beginning to feel better. It was the getting going that was the real problem for Quinn. Once she was in rhythm, once the pills had taken their effect, once that deathly chill had left her body, she went through long stretches of feeling as though life made sense.  She took one last glance at herself in the mirror. Her shirt was a bit wrinkled, and her hair wouldn’t be dry for some time still. The bags under her eyes which started to form when she’d taken the night shift had only grown deeper. She hadn’t said this to anybody, or even really allowed herself to think it, but she felt as though she looked much older than twenty-three.  But that didn’t really bother her. At any rate, she concluded, it was a good thing she wasn’t working in modeling.

She strode past her grandparents’ room, where a ray of changing light and soft dialogue from some sitcom spilled out of a small crack between the door and the wall. They had stayed up for her during her first week, but since then, she had been departing from and arriving to a still household. She grabbed the keys from the rack and felt the dry spring air on her face. For three seasons of the year, she would have loved to work outside, right there on the front lawn, doing anything at all. Winters in Flagstaff could still be miserable. That she knew all too well. Instead, though, she dragged herself into her grandmother’s car and set off for the motel, just as she had done every weeknight for ten months prior. If her car back home was old, this thing was prehistoric; it featured windows that had to be cranked to open and a safety rating that must have been below zero on any credible website. Beyond that, it was an ugly olive green color, and it had a certain old smell that was hard to describe but impossible to ignore.  She didn’t hate it, though. As long as it got her from starting point to destination, and no one was around to heckle her for it, she figured there was no problem.

She pulled into her spot at the motel one minute before her shift was due to start. She had her commute down to a science, and she was proud of it. Since nearly every ride was uneventful and traffic-free, she did her best to hit the same speeds on every road for maximum replicability. She’d leave at nine minutes to midnight, arrive eight minutes later, go in, nod to Jeff, who was on before her, then he would punch out (as it was, by now, exactly midnight), and she’d take over, all without a word.  It was exactly what work should be.  But tonight, as she stepped into the reception area of the Up and Away Motel, she saw Dan, her boss, manning the desk. Though Dan wasn’t necessarily a striking figure– mid-forties, maybe five and a half feet tall, with a receding hairline, and a tie that somehow was always too short for his already smallish body– Quinn nearly lept upon seeing the physical manifestation of a minor break in her routine.  She steadied herself and glanced at the clock over his head. "Good morning, Dan."

He smiled without moving his eyes. "Morning, Quinn. I was, ah, hoping to speak with you in the break room." Her heart sank, and Dan must have noticed, because he practically fell over himself assuring her that "Oh, you’re not in trouble, I didn’t mean to give you that impression, don’t worry." Quinn’s momentary dread was supplanted by confusion. Dan reached underneath the desk and rested a sign which read A desk clerk will be available to assist momentarily next to a polished silver bell that did not work.  Fat chance of anyone reading that sign, she thought.

She followed him across the reception area and into a small room which smelled of old, cheap coffee and cigarettes, despite the fact that smoking indoors had been prohibited for motel employees for probably the last twenty years. He took a seat at the table in the center of the room and extended his arm out, inviting her to sit with him. It was a bit of an awkward fit– both the table and chairs may have been recycled from the local elementary school– but Quinn found herself seated across from her boss. "I’d offer you one of these, but it seems they’re all expired," he said, reaching around to examine the small collection of snacks on the countertop. "I should probably do a restock at some point." Quinn offered a polite smile, and hoped she did not betray in her eyes how she really felt about being in this room. "Anyway," he said, addressing her, "Um– how are you?"

"Fine," she said, noticing that there was a thin layer of perspiration beginning to form on Dan’s forehead. "Ready for my shift." "That’s great," he said, heaving a deep sigh. "You’ve been doing a phenomenal job with nights, you know. It’s not easy, to, ah, reacclimatize to a new way of living, but you’ve been able to do it flawlessly. The rest of the staff really appreciates it, too." "Thanks." This was, officially, more than anyone had ever talked to her over the course of a night. Dan stood up and poured himself a cup of water from a cooler that was nearly empty. He offered Quinn a cup, but she shook her head.

"If, ah," he said, eyes studying the curve of the cooler and voice quivering, "if you, need, anything at all. Days off, accommodations, anything. Let me know, alright?" "Excuse me?" she said, pushing her chair away from the kiddie-size table.  "I know, it– it wasn’t appropriate to watch the special. The media– sensationalizes things, probably. But it’s terrible, and if I had known–" "The special?" she said, standing up. She could feel the color flush from her face.

"Yes. I watched it with my wife, she wanted me to say somethin. I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to upset you. I shouldn’t have listened to her." With that, her boss pushed past her and out of the room. Quinn’s mouth hung open as she tried to make sense of what had happened.  After a moment of stillness, she re-entered the reception area. Though many of the rooms themselves were in need of deep cleaning, she and the rest of the desk clerks did a decent job of making their shared space as homely as possible. A few monthly magazines rested on coffee tables next to cushy chairs resting on fashionable throw rugs. Management had even splurged on a television for the area, a crucial fixture for late nights and early mornings behind the desk.  For now, though, Quinn hustled to the computer behind her desk and, not knowing what else to look for, typed her own name into the search bar. She scrolled past result after result, mostly in regards to an overseas company which bore her name. That wasn’t it. She cleared the search bar, took a breath, and winced as her fingers touched the keys that spelled out her sister’s name.

The first result was a week-old article from a website she’d never heard of, entitled ASN Shows Promise with Hour-Long Special Sunk. She let out an audible groan as she clicked the link to read it.  ASN Shows Promise with Hour-Long Special Sunk By Jeremy Mountcastle You’d be forgiven, in our world of ever-accelerating consumption and disposal of content, if you had forgotten about the Pacific submarine tragedy that claimed the lives of thirty-seven, even if it was only a year ago. Similarly, you might have missed last week’s launch of ASN, the action storytelling network, which promises to be as captivating as it is informative, with a Southwestern flavor. Though the new network is still in its infancy, and I remain skeptical in regards to its long-term outlook in the aforementioned world of today, I must admit that it has produced a winner with its maiden foray into the world of television specials, Sunk.

Deftly paced and emotionally charged, Sunk retells the events leading up to the Pacific’s demise through the lens of Maeve Harper (Greta Wersching), the only child aboard, with her own tragic backstory to boot. The special’s focus on the exploration of her relationship with her father Steven (Johnathan Rudd) and his boss Dorothy (Mia Green) rather than the jargon-laden reasons why the ship sank gives ample room for viewers to empathize with sufferers of disaster of this scale, a concept in short supply now, given the rate at which disasters seem to be happening nationwide.  Wersching, far from a household name in the United States, is as funny and convincing as she is heartbreaking. The rest of the cast is nearly flawless as well, and the appearance by real-life Steven’s childhood friend caps the program off quite powerfully. Though the so-called expert cameos were a bit of a misstep, often breaking immersion rather than enhancing it, they did not detract from what otherwise was an unexpected triumph of a television show. ASN has shown for the first time that it’s not all talk. With a small budget, its ability to field a cast, build a convincingly claustrophobic submarine from scratch, and tell a cohesive story is impressive, and hopefully indicative of things to come.  "Excuse me, miss?"
Quinn looked up from the screen. A young man was at the desk. "Yes. How can I help?" "Can I, um… get a towel?" "A towel. Sure."

The laundry room was just down the hall. She’d made the trip hundreds of times, sometimes just when she needed to walk at three or four o’clock in the morning. Tonight, it was particularly hot and humid in that room. Both washing machines and dryers were running, probably because Dan had started them before he left. He’d run off awfully quickly, hadn’t he? At least the dirty laundry was all in one big basket, and the clean laundry was folded and ready to go, so she wouldn’t have to worry about that tonight. The dryer against the wall was making some kind of noise, though. She could have sworn it was getting worse over the course of the past few weeks. Maybe they’d have to pay to get that fixed, and she knew the motel wasn’t making a lot of money. But if management had the money for a television, they should certainly have enough for a lousy dryer, right? What good was a motel with wet bedsheets and pillowcases? Why was she here again? She took a handful of slow steps out of the laundry room and saw the face of the young man, still waiting at the desk. She felt her heart hammer against her chest. Towel. That’s what he wanted. Towel. Repeating the word to herself (and pulling back after reaching into the dirty pile first, for some reason), she retrieved a towel and brought it back to the man. She gave him a smile as though she’d never seen a human face before.

"There you are. Sorry for the wait." He sighed and turned to leave. As he walked out, an idea leapt to the front of her short-circuiting brain before she could stop it.  "Sir?" she said, as the young man pushed his way back outside.

He didn’t seem to hear.  Quinn hurried to follow him. When she opened the door, a loud clang of brass bells positioned at the top of the doorframe announced her arrival to the outside world. "Sir?" she called again, louder this time. The young man turned around but continued to walk toward his room, in a kind of shuffle. It would have surprised her if he was twenty.

"Have you ever heard of ASN?" He laughed. "ASN? No. But if you want to talk shop… or something else… you know where to find me." When he said this, he stuck his pinkie and his thumb out and held his hand to his ear in imitation of a phone.  Quinn rolled her eyes and went back inside. She’d dealt with plenty of horny teenagers and drug dealers in the past, but this man could just be the full package.

Still, his proclaimed ignorance of the new network calmed her down just enough to get her thinking again. Upon resuming her station behind the reception desk, she pulled out her phone and stared at Ty’s message.  Hey Q, got a couple of things I need to talk to you about. Please call me. This show had to be what he was mentioning. A couple of things, though! What did that mean? And they were apparently so important they warranted a full-on phone conversation. If she’d just learned about the special, which aired on some random network at some unholy hour, probably, then did that demote the importance of their impending communication to a text? Should she lead with that, that she knew what had happened? She still hadn’t seen a second of it, though. And he had asked her specifically to please call.

She sat down in her chair and rocked back and forth, warring with herself over the contents of her hypothetical response. The damage had already been done, hadn’t it? The details of the submarine sinking were already out there, fabricated by the right people, appearing on the right websites. She’d done one supplemental interview, a short, pathetic thing in front of leech people who were only out to make her cry. Fortunately, she hadn’t, and public interest in the case of the drowned science expedition had expired before it ever had a chance to stir up.  But even if someone had seen the special and wanted more about what happened, they could find details online, or wherever, and it would all add up. As far as she could remember, the review article didn’t mention anything about a conspiracy, or new clues that threatened to uncover the real truth of the Pacific. Even if some whackjob went to the site of the wreckage, they would find a submarine. That’s what Ty told her, at least, the first week she was in the hospital. She was not well then, not by a long shot. But she was sure he had said it.  As the clock moved to one, Quinn began to feel herself breathe once more. She’d overreacted. She wished she hadn’t had to find out about the show through her boss a week after it had already aired, sure, but what harm could it possibly do? Their bases had been covered a year ago, and if there was a real problem, Ty would call himself. It was fine, she wasn’t even in the show herself, the actress probably looked nothing like her sister anyway; she’d live her life, in just the same way she had been. She didn’t have to text Ty.

She spent the next hour or so scouring for more information online. The only thing she learned was that the websites which mentioned the special tended to look more like viruses than reputable news sources. If the motel’s computer wasn’t well over a decade old and clearly nearing the end of its functionality, she may have been a bit more careful with her browsing habits.  By the time Quinn had reached the bottom of the fifth page of results, she’d had enough. She rubbed her eyes, closed every tab on the computer, and opened up solitaire. It was her favorite game to pass the time during work. It required just enough thinking to make the minutes slip past, but not enough to where it was ever taxing. Sometimes she made little doodles on a company-provided notepad for the same reason. She must have filled a dozen of them with pictures of the interior of houses, human figures, animals, mountains, anything she could think of to draw. She was not an artist, by any stretch of the imagination, but she figured she must be improving, given the sheer quantity of free time she had to practice.  For the rest of the night, only one person approached the desk– an older man with a thick accent who was something of a mythical figure among the motel employees. At an hour when most were drooling, he paraded up to the desk, drew himself up to his full height, and spoke so loud that the ground seemed to shake. "Ah, so it is Miss Quinn tonight!" he said, laying- but really more like slamming-  both of his hands on the desk.

"It is," she said, instantly smiling. "How can I help you, Mr. Shesterkin?" "You will call me Vasiliy, and I tell you this every time," he said, recoiling as though her words had physically hurt him. "But that is no matter. I want to tell you this. The machine that you put in the room, waaaa–"  He waggled his hands out, as though to demonstrate. "Air conditioner?" she guessed.

"This is its name, yes. Air conditioner. But how do I stop this noise." "Let me show you," she said, heading over to the corner of the room. "This button, here," she said, pressing the power button, "will shut it off completely. The room will get pretty hot, though." "Yes, yes, I know how this machine works," said Vasiliy, studying the button. "I will go back and try it. Thank you, Miss Quinn." "Hey," she said, restarting the air conditioner. "Your English is getting much better. I’m impressed."

"Yes," he said, swelling with pride. "I work very hard at my classes, for my family. I also watch much American television." When he said this, he laughed, a giant, booming outburst that could have rattled leaves free from trees.  Though it was an exercise of atrophied muscles for Quinn, she laughed, too.  She made the commute home at eight o’clock opposite children who had managed to drag their feet just long enough to be late for school and nine-to-fivers who were especially eager to get to their desks. The road was often a bit perilous at this time, as highly caffeinated business people fought to coexist with sleepy sixteen-year-olds who were still learning to drive, and traffic had not yet mounted such that no one could get anywhere anyway.

Ordinarily, she resented the trek home. But today, remembering her interaction with Mr. Shesterkin and feeling somewhat satisfied with how a drawing of hers had gone, she made a rare decision to throw the radio on. To do this, she had to turn a small dial to adjust a red needle to exactly the station she wanted. She’d struggled to learn to navigate the dial quickly, and without much interference, a skill she’d once thought only necessary for people three times her age. She decided on one of her favorites– 92.7, which played oldies– and spent a few seconds fighting through static to reach it.  She smiled wryly. It was Dylan. God, what a grating voice, she thought, ignoring the blaring horn that resulted from a BMW cutting off a beat-up looking minivan ahead of her. It was Blowin’ in the Wind, overplayed to hell, and too vague to mean much of anything, in her opinion.  Still, she hummed along. ./.

Two cups of coffee sat on the kitchen table. In fifteen minutes or so, the owner of the one on the left would shuffle into the kitchen and rest his weight against a chair. He’d take a sip from his cup, decide how long it needed in the microwave, and give the cup on the right an extra ten seconds. When the right cup’s owner woke up, hers would be the perfect temperature.  Both coffee drinkers were retired and childless, so they spent every morning together at home. The owner of the left cup liked to watch the news, and kept up with local politics. He had been very active in his church community when he was younger, and still went every week, despite his failing hips and sight. Many parishioners came to visit him, and they found great joy in bringing lunch and listening to a rambling story or two. The owner of the right cup was a naturalist, constantly hiking with a group of friends she’d found online or battling the unforgiving climate to grow vegetables in her backyard garden.  The two would sit and chat about the news or the weather or something one of them had remembered. And there was certainly no shortage of memories to relive. In 1971, he’d been an aspiring politician and she was studying to break into the male-dominated field of biology. Back then, she found him obnoxious and deceptive, and he found her standoffish and boring.

Today, they would drink coffee together, through forty-eight years of marriage.  The pair were creatures of habit, as many are at their stage of life, and for this reason they would not thank the person who had made the beverages for them. This person wanted to keep to themself, and do gosh-knows-what, not that husband nor wife was dying to figure out what exactly they did anyway. The coffee drinkers loved them, knew they needed space, and could not have imagined going through what they did at such a young age. So, most of the time, at their previous request, upstairs was theirs, and downstairs belonged to him and her.  Sometimes, after they’d finished their cups and begun their day, one of the drinkers would walk up to the coffee maker’s room and stop at the door. There was rarely any noise coming from inside– no talking, no music, sometimes their television would be on, but that wasn’t often. She would come downstairs and say she was worried about them; he would say they just needed more time, and both would move forward with their own days. The coffee maker was still young, after all; they had their whole life ahead of them. Yet they were older than both he and she were when she jumped into his arms walking down the aisle. By their age, he’d put a down payment on a house, and she was readying herself to have children. Both had achieved degrees and paved the way for future careers. Though the coffee drinkers never communicated it to one another, they wondered just what it was the coffee maker needed.

Still, it could not be denied that they made great coffee.  ./. Quinn took a slow breath as she tucked herself under the covers. She hadn’t bothered to change, or even kick off her shoes, but that didn’t matter. Her medication was wearing off, and she’d kept them waiting long enough.  She closed her eyes. It was not at all like falling asleep. The transition was much more like when she’d had her appendectomy during her first year of college. One moment, she was in pain, full of thought, anxiety, claustrophobia, in a room with beeping and lights and faceless people.

The next, it was over.  Instead of the lumpiness of the hospital bed and the nausea that came with the aftereffects of the anesthesia, however, today Quinn found herself awake in the collective consciousness of some vast amount of dreamers. She may have found it a difficult feeling to describe, had she ever needed to do so, but it was more or less like sitting in a director’s chair and watching one million different television shows at the same time. They weren’t very hard to keep track of, though, because she was also the one acting in all of the shows.  Directing and acting. That was all it was.  One of the shows was set in the crowded center of a city. Though it was impossible for her to know which city exactly, it was at least midday there, so it had to be east of the director’s chair.

The leading actor of this show had already picked a mark. He was middle-aged, bald, talking on the phone. He wore glasses that concealed deep wrinkles below his eyes and walked with a limp that was only just noticeable. Though his face was pale, when he laughed or shouted, he turned red. A good actor uses their intuition. Even if the outcome is predetermined, even if the lines are scripted, it is important for an actor to engage with their own feelings and attitudes toward a scene. This particular actor knew it was never in the script for them to drive a gash through their mark’s neck and watch them bleed out on the sidewalk, because that would have been reckless and irresponsible. But they could have achieved the outcome they were after by stopping his heart. The man would go down, doctors would perform an autopsy, and they’d probably reason that he had an undiagnosed cardiac disease.  Intuitively, however, this actor knew they did not want to stop his heart. Maybe someone next to him knew CPR and would spring into action, maybe doctors wouldn’t find anything anomalous about his heart and launch some sort of an investigation, maybe the whole event just wasn’t big enough. No, this actor was not interested in that.  This one jumped up on the man’s shoulders as it realized what it wanted to do. It would start in the thyroid, innocently enough, but it would metastasize quickly. The whole process would be slow, on the scale of many years, with family members involved, and lots of money spent, but this actor would get what it wanted in the end.

It wrapped its awful talons around the man’s neck and sunk its claws into an area just above his ribcage. The man kept talking and laughing as he made his way down the crowded street. He wouldn’t feel anything for some time.  Just as it and its ancestors had done for millenia, it inserted itself into the man, feeling his lifeforce change, feeling— BANG, BANG, BANG.  "Quinn? There’s someone here to see you."

Her eyes shot open and instantly she felt it coming. She tore off her blanket and rolled off of her bed, hitting the ground with a heavy thud.  With the ground spinning sideways, she baby-crawled to the trash can. It took every bit of determination and will she had, but she made it. And without a second to spare.  She heaved into the can so violently that she thought her insides might fall out. A putrid mixture of vomit and spit hung from the sides of her mouth and her hair as she checked to ensure she was still in one piece.

"Hey, are you okay? Can I come in?" That voice from outside. Her grandmother’s. Shit. She spit, and answered unevenly. "I’m fine. Just– give me a second." The last word was hardly out of her mouth when she erupted into another coughing fit. She retched again, loudly, pathetically.
"I’ll tell him to come back another time, okay?" Him? "No, no. I’ll be fine," she said, fighting for air.  "Okay then," said the cursed voice.

Quinn sat next to the trash can for several minutes, attempting to discern whether she would throw up again. Though she was not feeling any better, and the smell of the room was beyond foul, and she likely looked a mess, too, she decided that it was time to move. As the room was still spinning, she continued to crawl back to her dresser and reached clumsily for the handle that opened the drawer. Once she grabbed it, she fought through discarded hair ties and crumpled-up pieces of paper to find her emergency stash of pills.  There were five of them, all together, and when her shaking hand finally stumbled upon the little white capsules, she was so excited that she dropped them all on the floor. Fighting the urge to cry out, she began to scavenge the area. One landed right in front of her. Two had nearly rolled its way under the dresser. Three and Four were together at an arm’s length underneath the bed.  She swallowed them all. She was almost certain she’d eaten some carpet as well, as she could feel strands of hair scratch their way down her throat.  She fought back the renewed urge to vomit again.

Her eyes scanned the floor for the final pill. She looked under the furniture, in the gaps left by placement of previous furniture, among crumbs she’d been meaning to vacuum. She had no luck until she turned to the corner of the room she’d just wobbled from.  There was Five, leaning upright against the trash can, as though it was proud of itself.  Quinn closed her eyes and let the strengthening of the smell guide her. This strategy was not bulletproof, however. Her hand made contact with the can before she realized she’d made it that far. Had Quinn failed to display some impressive reflexes, considering the circumstances, the nearly-overflowing trash can would have dumped its contents onto her carpet. She took a slow breath, rolled over into a seated position, and took the last pill while holding her nose. Gradually, the world began to stop spinning. She pulled herself to her feet and began to think more clearly.

She took cautious steps to the bathroom and turned on the tap. As the sink filled with water, she brushed her teeth in a desperate attempt to purge the taste of bile from her mouth. She spat in the toilet once, twice, three times.  She still felt sick. When she was done, she set her toothbrush down and submerged her head completely in the water. God, was it cold. She turned her neck in every direction to ensure her hair was clean. As she resurfaced and grabbed a towel, she took a look in the mirror. Today, she didn’t feel old. In fact, that face and those eyes staring back at her were strikingly childlike.

She dried herself as she galloped down the stairs, suddenly conscious of how much time had passed since her grandmother had called for her. She’d already begun her apology by the time she reached the front door.  "I’m so sorry, Ty, I just can’t–" The figure sitting on the steps in front of her was facing away from her, but it was not hard to tell that it wasn’t Ty. He was large, solid and muscular, and well over six feet tall. Even before the figure stood up she could tell he was much more diminutive.  "Hello?" she said, mind blanking.

The figure– the kid– turned around and studied Quinn. He had dark hair and piercing eyes, and wore a single stud earring which sparkled in the morning sunlight. Everything about him was angular– his face, his shoulders, his limbs. In a very real way, his body resembled a broken plate, or a shattered window.  At last, he smiled, distantly. He spoke in a soft, gravelly voice, not what she might have expected from someone built like him.  "You look just like her." She was intensely confused for a moment. But the dots soon connected, one after the other. His eyes gave it away.

"Are you… Cassius?" He nodded. He looked at her desperately, completely, as though if he blinked, she would disappear. It was an odd feeling for her, certainly, but she knew she’d been on the other end of that look in years gone by.  "Do you want to come in?" she asked.  "Sure. Thanks," he said, that gruff chill gripping his voice even tighter than before.

She swung the door open and let him inside. A shiver made its way up her spine as she took a fleeting glance up and down her street.  He wasn’t with anyone else, it seemed. But this Cassius she’d let in was more ghost than man.  She turned inside to see both of her grandparents waiting in the living room, wearing wide smiles. Cursing the fact that neither was at a doctor’s appointment or out in the garden or still in bed, for God’s sake, she donned a grin herself and shoved a hand out in introduction.  "Grandma, grandpa, this is Cassius. He’s a, uh, friend."

Both of her grandparents shook his hand. They were positively radiant.  "Cassius! Nice to meet you," said her grandfather, suppressing a cough that was less a throat-clearing mechanism and more an indicator that he was about to embark upon a tangent. "You‘ve got a great taste in… friends, of course. When I was younger, I was always with the older crowd. My brother, you see, he was five— no, six— grades above me, and he’d get together to play cards with his friends— some of them girls, of course, not that that’s an important thing— and I’d tell my mother I was going to my room to finish homework, but I’d really sneak out to a tent, where they were all playing. At first they told me to scram, and I did, being eight or nine, but eventually when I worked up the courage to play they taught me, and I got pretty good. Of course, I can’t remember what game we played, but maybe it was—" "How do you know Quinn?" asked her grandmother, adeptly steering the conversation back to reality.  Cassius’ empty bewilderment was getting the better of him. He waited a moment, opened his mouth, closed it, and before he could come up with anything to say, Quinn jumped in.

"The archery team. And we’re gonna head upstairs, if that’s—" She stopped. The trash bin.  "—alright. Just— one second." Quinn speed-walked up the stairs and into her room. Sure enough, it smelled just as foul as she had felt. With a grimace, she picked up the offending trash bin.

She went through her options. She couldn’t dump it in the toilet, as it was full of other garbage underneath the layer of vomit. She really didn’t have time to do anything except to hide it. So, reluctantly, she carried the bin out of her room and stuffed it in the bottom of the storage closet which was next to the bathroom.  As she closed the door, she heard the floor creak behind her.
