Of course, she had been too slow, and he’d seen the whole thing.  "Rough night?" he said, that look still refusing to leave his eye.  "More like rough morning," she said, pushing open the door to her room.

As she followed him inside, she realized that everything was more cluttered than she’d have liked it to be. There was a pile of clothes in a corner she’d been meaning to put away, a small collection of wrappers under the large mirror across from her bed, and three balled-up pieces of notebook paper on her windowsill.  "I’m sorry," she said, reaching for the air freshener in the dresser she’d nearly knocked over ten minutes ago. "This was just kind of a funny time for Ty to send you." For the first time, Cassius’ face changed. He sat on a bean bag in the corner of the room and nodded slowly.  "What is it?" she continued, more guarded. "What did you want to tell me?"

Cassius took a calculating breath and wrung his hands. "I don’t know who Ty is," he said, deliberately, "but your sister is the love of my life. I want to know if she’s still alive." The words hit Quinn like a sucker punch. Lacking the words to respond, and feeling her face turn bright red, she shook her head.  "She’s not," he said, continuing to speak so evenly it was menacing. "Okay. Then I want you to tell me what the fuck really happened to her." Quinn struggled to breathe. She’d never felt like she’d been so wrong in her life. She felt her weight shift to the side, her feet beg to leap off of the tightrope she’d balanced on for so long.

"How did you find me," she said at last, more confession than question.  He paused, as though deciding whether or not to answer. He sat up straight on that stupid purple bean bag her friend had bought for her on her fifteenth birthday and inhaled slowly. "I don’t know how, exactly, you know me, but I’m guessing you’ve heard about the party I threw, two winters ago." Quinn nodded. She’d read about it in her sister’s journal.

"Her dad– your dad– found her, took her home, and I never saw her again. Not in school, not at my place, not an email, nothing. She didn’t have a phone, she didn’t tell me where she lived. Said she had strict parents. I’m guessing that was mostly the truth." Though Cassius didn’t change his cadence, some other emotion began to crack through his surface as he continued. "Do you know how guilty I felt? How… lost I was? I hated that school, I hated my friends, I hated…" He stopped. Quinn could feel her heart in her temples.

"Anyway," said Cassius, closing his eyes, "After she left, I went on these long walks. My parents didn’t care where I was, and the walking helped me. One day, last summer, I decided to go to the old hospital. I only knew it existed because of ghost stories. Supposedly there was a crazy guy that lived there and made knives, or something. I don’t know. No one my age cared enough to retell them, I guess. "I walked all day to this building, through trees and roots and roads no one’s driven on in forever. I was so lost, I mean, Google Maps didn’t even have this place listed. It was just kind of an opening in the brush. But it turned out it wasn’t a hospital at all. Just rubble.  "When I got there, the sun was maybe ten minutes away from disappearing below the trees. And that’s how I know this was meant to be. Had I been there ten minutes later, or earlier, the sun wouldn’t have shown me this," he said, reaching into a pocket.  He pulled out a large orange gemstone. Though it was heavily scratched and possibly discolored, it looked as though it may have been expensive at some point. It was connected to a small gold chain, intended to be worn around one’s neck.

Quinn did not have a difficult time recognizing it, but she didn’t say anything.  "It was caught in between two bricks, almost too deep to see," he said, studying the artifact. "I went to pull it out, but it was so stuck in there it took me an hour to wiggle it loose. When I got it, it was completely dark out. Didn’t matter, though. I knew it was hers," he said, looking back up at Quinn. "See, if you pull it apart–" He pulled on either end of the gold chain and the necklace opened instantly.  "The clasp is shitty. I was so worried about that when I bought it for her. This is the one."

He methodically reattached the two split ends of the necklace before continuing. "I sifted through those ruins, looking for anything else I could find. I was lifting chunks of brick and metal, digging in the ground, twisting ankles, pulling muscles. But it was too dark, even with my phone’s flashlight. So I left, walked all night back home. "Then I started driving there. I brought shovels, crowbars, any tools I could get my hands on to move stuff, or at least break it up. I went every day for two weeks, and nothing. But you’d be surprised, I think, at how much rubble there was. I hadn’t even been through half of it, at that point. "The third week I was able to cut this huge piece of the wall up. There was a scrap of paper caught underneath," he said, reaching into his other pocket, "and it was ripped, and wet, but I dried it off and made a copy."

He gave the little piece of folded-up paper to Quinn, and she read, hardly believing her eyes.  3/13/2023 (Make sure this date is right) than the studies of Lille and Eugene suggest. The physical attributes of– —matter, as was once hypothesized. The first female Leader, RT, demonstrated fine—

—into today. The findings of preliminary investigations into the familial bypassing of the age— —current Leader, MH, is fifteen years old, female, white, five feet, three inches tall, with red— —being so similar genetically, it stands to reason that they will accept their new host, possibly without ever being aware of the transition. It has long been wondered— The paper was smaller than Quinn’s palm, and torn off at both sides.

"Her name was Bess McAllister. That’s what she told me, that’s who I was looking for. And now there’s this MH business, and she’s a ‘Leader’, or a host, or something. I must have looked up every word on that page, online, in libraries, everywhere. I dug through the rest of the building, too. But that’s where it stopped. I found nothing. Not a trace, not a lead, no information on MH, or leader, or transition, or the studies of Lille and Eugene. It was all I thought about, all I did, fall, winter, spring, but it didn’t matter. "Last week, March 13, I had an idea. I don’t know why I didn’t think of it sooner, but I figured I might try looking up the date. What happened on March 13, 2023, I typed it into Google." "And you found the submarine story," said Quinn, failing to meet his eyes. "Thirty-seven dead on the Pacific, off the west coast of Australia. Halfway around the goddamn world. The only kid on board was Maeve Harper, from New Jersey. She was younger in the pictures they had, but I knew it was her."

"Then?" "Whitepages. There were only two Maeve Harpers in the state. I got lucky, drove to the right one first, had a nice chat with your old neighbors, and looked you up in Arizona. It’s kind of funny, I could have made the trip in less than a day if I knew where you were. Took me a lot longer than that." "Aren’t you supposed to be in school?" she asked meekly. "I dropped out," he said, suddenly bristling, "but that’s besides the point. I want to know why Bess, Maeve, your sister, was in that ghost story building, what the paper means. Oh, and who Ty is. Because it seems to me like the most reasonable explanation is that she got dragged… into some… sacrificial cult, or something, and whatever it is, I think you’re a part of it, too."

Quinn looked for something. An oversight, a hint of doubt, an insecurity, anything she might use to dissuade him, protect him. But Cassius, jagged, weathered, had trekked across the country, sat in her room, and given her every ounce of conviction he had.  She sighed. It was as though his resounding victory over her fantasy had calmed her. There was no need to prevent damage any longer. She’d only have to mitigate.  "I can’t tell you," she said, softly.  The young man drew himself up, his bones, knives, protruding from his shoulders, glinting in the sun.
"You can’t tell me?" he responded, collecting energy, storing it somewhere.  She shook her head. Her heart rate continued to slow.  "Why not?" he breathed.  "You won’t like the reason."

"Tell me, you whore," he growled, more animal than man.  Her internal clock did not hasten. She was cool, free, even. But she could not afford to lose him.  "If I told you what happened, you wouldn’t believe it. If you did, though," she said, saying words which she still did not really comprehend, "millions of people could die." "Bullshit," he responded immediately.

"That’s what I would have said, too." There was a moment of stillness. Then, suddenly, a smile emerged on Cassius’ face. "And how the hell do you expect me to respond to that?" "I expect you to be angry, and confused, and probably ready to kill me," she said, looking as deeply into his eyes as she could, "but I also expect you to understand that what Maeve did— what she died for— it was for everyone. For you, too."

The young man could not stop grinning. Though it was a rueful, malevolent grin, his eyes twinkled, as if he had just been pranked by an old friend. He stood up from his chair, and for the first time, took in his surroundings. He sauntered across the room and gazed out the window, and on his way back, he ran his fingers over her dresser. He said nothing, and moved methodically, stopping every time something caught his eye. When he had completed his voyage, he angled his body so that he could see underneath her bed, a move that finally broke Quinn out of her ataraxis. "What are you looking for?" she said, standing, drawing herself up to her full height. Cassius breathed out slowly and met her. They stood eye-to-eye.  "This is your room, right?" he said, softly.

She nodded. A chill ran down her spine, but she kept her shoulders back. "You’ve been here, what, a year?" Her face twitched. She nodded again. "And Maeve is this hero, right? Died for everyone’s sins?"
"Something like that." "Then where is she?" Quinn looked at him blankly. "Where is she?" he continued. "A picture, a note, a bracelet. I didn’t see her downstairs, either. Where is she?"

Quinn scowled, and with trembling hands, reached into her nightstand drawer for a third time that morning. This time, she had to go all the way to the back to find what she was after. Underneath old grocery lists, coffee-stained napkins, and birthday cards from distant relatives, her hand pushed past a paper trail of the last months of her life.  In fact, it had been so long since she’d seen this item she was worried it may have faded, or ripped, or disappeared somehow. But it hadn’t.  It was a developed photo of Quinn and Maeve at Maeve’s kindergarten graduation. They were in the elementary school gymnasium, which was a furnace. It was always humid in that old building, and the gym was not air conditioned, making recess and phys ed almost unbearable. The day of her sister’s graduation, which Quinn only vaguely remembered, as she was twelve at the time, was during the then-hottest June in the state’s history. To make things worse, all of the parents and siblings were packed like sardines during the ceremony, which lasted at least ninety minutes more than it should have. Both sisters were sweaty and tired, as was apparent in the photo. But someone– maybe a teacher, maybe a friend, maybe a parent– had made a joke just before the camera flashed, and so despite the abject misery of the day, Quinn and Maeve were caught in bouts of uncontrollable laughter. Quinn handed the picture over to Cassius, who studied it for a long moment.

"Bottom of the drawer, ten years old, at least," he said, in a manner such that Quinn couldn’t determine whether he was talking to her or to himself.  He went to stuff the picture in his pocket. "Wait!" she said, far too loudly, instinctually. Cassius obliged, and that grin returned to his face.

"Right answer," he said, returning the photograph to Quinn. She took it from him. She felt dizzy.  "I trust you, alright?" he said, voice barely above a whisper, face inches from her. "But I want in. I’ve come a long way. What do I have to do?" Footsteps, coming up the stairs, across the creaky hall. Thank God this house was old.
"Just be quiet, for now," she said, with no time to think before– BANG, BANG, BANG. "Quinn? Can I come in?" She looked at him, and he took a healthy step backward.  "Go ahead."

Her grandmother, positively beaming, opened the door. Quinn forced a smile on to her face, as well. "What is it, grandma?" "I was just wondering if either of you wanted me to make something. I’m not sure how long you’ll be staying, Cassius, but I was thinking–" "Actually, I’m sorry, ma’am, but I have to get going. Busy morning."

"Oh," said her grandmother, eyes darting between Quinn and Cassius, both of whom were still standing. "I hope everything’s alright." "It is," said the young man, scratching the side of his neck, "just work stuff. People calling out day of. Annoying, but, I need the money, I guess." "That’s too bad! I hope you’ll come back, I feel like I haven’t even met you yet." Cassius chuckled politely. "I will. I’ll be around."
With that, he nodded to Quinn. She gave a halfhearted nod back.  She didn’t know what else to do.  ./. He was still so vivid.

Talking on the phone, the red face, his shoes. She did something to him she hadn’t done to anyone before. No, it had. She’d just watched. She’d approved, though.  Maybe if she was just stronger, maybe if she figured something out, she wouldn’t have to do what she did.  Every seven days. 12:00, on a Friday. She was never awake at this point of the week– not for the past nine or ten months, at least. She wasn’t necessarily unconscious, either. After she’d done what they asked her to do, or rather, allowed them to do what they wanted to do, what was natural, after all, she would open her eyes. Every time, an ordeal that seemed to her to take five or ten minutes had removed the formerly cresting sun from the sky entirely.

She realized something, that particular morning. The memories, seared into her brain one by one, the memories which cut like knives into her flesh and sat like a weight upon her chest every time she returned from the infinitesimal respite of sleep, seemed somehow to be dulled by whatever trance she found herself in on those Fridays. She could push those memories aside for stretches, after all, if she really tried. In fact, over time, she had become quite proficient at doing so. Today’s memory, like a demon, lived within her, alongside her; it pulsed in her temples, overriding her own heartbeat, it had its own motives and feelings, it developed and matured. The thing that she had done– it had done– of course, she had done– to that man was a who, more than it was a what. And this who made its introduction to Quinn as soon as Cassius left her house.  She lay on her bed for hours, wishing for an end, begging to transcend her feelings, to strike a deal with this who. But the morning she’d had was too much even for the two-and-a-half doses of medication she’d taken.  There was calm out there somewhere. It had found her unexpectedly when Cassius was speaking to her. It was gone now.

She muttered and tossed and turned and held onto her pillow in feeble hope that sleep would arrive. Time stretched and warped. She thought she should call Ty at first, but she didn’t think she could fit the words together. Not in that room, at least. Not in that prison of a room.  Just after noon, she put two feet on the carpet. There wasn’t a thought that snapped her out of her anguish. No one called for her or checked in on her. It wasn’t that it was the top of the hour, and it wasn’t that she was going to be late for an event. She moved because she was used to moving. If somehow she wasn’t used to it, then she might have stayed there forever. But most days, she tended to get out of bed. She did again today.  She picked up her phone, which she hadn’t touched since she had arrived home that morning. She scrolled through her contacts, and against what the who memory wanted, she called Nicholas.  He answered almost immediately. "Hey! What’s up?"
"I’m out," she said, in a voice that was as raspy as she felt.  "Yeah. Yeah, I know. I got your text. Did you still want to pick up tonight?" "Can we do now?" "...Now?"

"Yeah." "Alright. I can’t linger, though." "Great." She hung up the phone. Breathing in heavy air, she slid a backpack onto her shoulders and angled the brim of a baseball cap downward to conceal as much of her face as she reasonably could. Ten minutes, she thought, pleadingly, ten minutes there and back.

Ten minutes, and then she’d find out if an extra half dozen pills could do what five couldn’t.  She made her way downstairs and was more than halfway out the door before she heard her grandfather shout to her, from two rooms away. "Heading out?" he asked, undoubtedly with eyes still fixed on the television screen. "Yep," she responded. "Meeting a friend at the park. She’s got a photography project. I shouldn’t be long."

"You should invite her over here, after you’re done." "I’ll ask, but I think she’s pretty busy."  "You have some very busy friends, huh?" Quinn laughed, as faux-politely as she could, and escaped the house. Every refill was a different lie. Ordinarily they were easy, plausible, unchecked; this one seemed to catch in her throat as she told it.

The park was less than a quarter-mile from her house, if she cut through her backyard, and she set out at a decent pace. Though no clouds saved Quinn’s eyes from the relentless glare of the sun, it was a mild day out, cool enough to make her feel grateful she’d been wearing long sleeves. She stepped over sticks and rocks and roots and listened to the crunch of her footsteps on the ground. The ground was dry and brittle, and it seemed audibly to object to any weight that shifted upon it. She’d been this way dozens of times, and she’d go this way dozens more, for as long as— She stopped. She was being watched.  A shadow had darted across the corner of her eye, or maybe it was a noise she’d heard. She wasn’t completely sure why she felt it, but she trusted her instinct.  She spun around and craned her neck in an attempt to find her stalker. She was just deep enough into the woods that she could no longer see her house. Her heart began to thump against her ribcage as she scanned disinterested tree after disinterested tree. Nothing, nothing, nothing.

Quinn rubbed her neck as she performed a final 360-degree scope of her surroundings. A false alarm. I’m stressed out, she thought. I’m being irrational. Still, when she resumed her journey toward the park, she moved quietly and methodically, on the edge of a knife.  Every time she passed a tree, she retreated behind it, to ensure no one was hiding there. It slowed her progress, certainly, but she had to do it, just to prove to herself how irrational she was being.  She performed dozens of these checks over the span of several minutes. Though she was largely unaware of it, she shook, having tensed most of the muscles in her body. Still, despite her vigilance, despite her thoroughness, she found nothing.  Until, of course, she heard it, directly behind her.

She was less than fifty yards from the end of the path when something– a misplaced footstep, probably, or the rustle of fallen brush– made itself heard, in an instant she would have missed on any other day. She lurched forward, nearly falling over in the process, and looked wildly to the source of the noise.  "CASSIUS!" But still, there was nothing.  Quinn had had enough. She bolted forward as fast as she could. Forest blurred by. Breath quickly failed her. She hit the entrance to the park and kept going. Past ducks, past dogs, past children. She made it all the way through the playscape and into the parking lot before she turned back.

Nothing. She dropped her hands to her knees, coughed, and spat. She was not in great shape. Still, an electricity buzzed through her. She kept her gaze trained in the direction of the forest, ready to go again, ready to fight, if she had to.  "Hey!" called a voice from somewhere in the lot. "Crazy lady!" Nicholas. He must have seen the whole thing.

She offered one last look to her invisible assailant and walked over to her acquaintance. She could feel heat radiating from her face.  God, that car. Nicholas had more clients than just Quinn, and sold drugs that were much more potent than the ones he sold to her to people who had much more money than she had. Quinn had always assumed that dealers of Nicholas’ caliber would tend to be cautious, careful, deliberate people. Nicholas, however, loved Purple Rain, the name for his louder-than-life vehicle, and shouting at solitary young women with bright red hair and bright red faces in public settings.  "Take up running?" he asked, when she’d arrived.  "No. Ah, yes. It doesn’t matter," she replied, through heaving breaths.

He sat low to the ground in his car. As he spoke, he revved his engine at various intervals, and to varying degrees.  "How can you say it doesn’t matter? Everything matters." "Okay. I’ve had a long morning. Do you have my stuff?" "Certainly," he said, reaching for a bag in the passengers’ seat.

Quinn took a look around, both for the forest stalker and now for law enforcement. She saw only a family piling out of a minivan from across the lot. Fortunately, they did not seem interested in the spectacle that was Nicholas.   He handed her two orange bottles, identical to the one she had before. She grabbed them through the driver’s side window and stuffed them into a compartment of her backpack as discreetly as she could.  "That will be… free of charge. Say thank you to Uncle Sam." "He’d want me dead, if he knew about me."

Nicholas frowned. "That’s true. But his heart’s in the right place. Or maybe a fingernail is, at least." They were both silent for a moment.  "Okay then. Tough crowd. You know where to find me," he said, rolling up his window.  As Nicholas began to roll out of his parking space, something grabbed onto Quinn. She put her hand on the hood of his car, just before he could speed off into the mystery of the day.
He stopped on a dime and once again rolled down his window.  "What? Watch the finish, lady!" She had surprised herself. She didn’t know what to say. "Uh– how’s work?"

He let out something that sounded like a stab of laughter punctuated by a question mark. His eyes shone as he responded.  "Work is great! I told you, I can’t stay though. If you want to chat, Purple’s got room for one more." Quinn picked up her backpack and stepped into the car.  Quinn stepped into the car?

For as childlike and free-spirited as Nicholas was, he was clearly very particular about his vehicle. There was not a stain nor a speck of dust to be found in the all-black interior. Despite the fact that he’d had the car at least as long as she’d known him, it smelled as though it had come out of the factory yesterday. Quinn could not escape the nagging feeling that she was likely the sweatiest person to ever inhabit Purple Rain. "I was mostly kidding, but this is a nice surprise," said Nicholas, leaving the parking lot at speeds far exceeding those recommended by law. "I’ve been meaning to tell you anyway, I got something at my place that might work better than what you’re on now. If you’re not busy, I could show you around. Just got some work done." "That sounds great," said Quinn, half-seriously remembering that she had an entire army at her disposal, should she need to defend herself. "Anyway, there were a whole bunch of meetings and trials and stuff to approve this new drug– Rolamanin, or Loramanin, or something– they told me all about it, but I didn’t really pay attention. All I know is they gave it to me to give to you."

"Thanks," said Quinn, watching cars and people blur together out of the window.  "Your boy, he’s doing crazy science, man. You should have seen the whiteboards. Totally full of equations."  Quinn nodded, and let the smile ghost off of Nicholas’ face.  "Hey, come on. You’re acting really weird."

"Am I?" "Yeah. I bet you I can guess why, too." He removed both hands from the steering wheel and put his index fingers on either temple.  "I think… you’re upset you weren’t mentioned in that show. Underwater, or whatever it was."

Quinn nearly leapt out of her seat. "You knew about that?" "Yes! I mean, no. Not really. It was on this new channel that I love, by the way, when I got home last week. It was pretty cool, but they never talked about you." "Why didn’t I hear about it?"

Nicholas took a breath. "The golden rule. If Ty doesn’t mention it, it’s not important. And he didn’t. So it wasn’t." "My manager saw the show. He pulled me aside last night, basically crying, and begged me to take a week off." "Ok, so that’s why you’re acting weird?" She sighed, and answered in a smaller voice. "That’s, like, one percent of the reason why I’m acting weird."

"Well, let’s hear about the other ninety-nine." "Awfully presumptuous to think I’d give you that much." "Listen," he said, pressing firmly on the brake to screech to a stop at a red light, "I’ve got to tell the boss something, alright?" "The boss. He’s younger than I am! And what the hell do you even talk about in those meetings?"

"It’s great. We all call in, a few dozen of us, and the smart ones talk about research, and the important ones talk about who knows what, who should know what, who shouldn’t know what. And then Ty calls on me, and I tell the group if I saw you, what I gave you, and how you were. This week, I will tell them that you were frazzled and contentious," he said, giving Quinn a mock leer that almost made her laugh out loud.  "And I’m still not invited," she said, knowing the answer. "No, you are not." God, she should have answered Ty’s text.

"I got woken up," she said, laboring, "in the middle. Usually I kind of sleep, after. But I woke up, right as I was doing it, and it felt awful. Way worse than usual. I was out of pills, too, except for my emergency stash. I still don’t feel right." "That sounds like a complete explanation if I’ve ever heard one," said Nicholas. Quinn elected to let his comment go, and he didn’t chase her. The pair drove in silence for a while.  "So," said Quinn, noticing that they were heading into a nice part of town, "you never really answered me before. How’s work?"

Nicholas took a breath. "You really want to know?" She shrugged. "Sure." "Okay. It pays good. I meet a lot of interesting people. Some real whackos, too, but I think you’d be surprised. The other day, I get a phone call from one of my more dependable clients, says he and a friend need some supplies for a function downtown. I head to our spot, and I’m waiting five, ten minutes, and there’s no sign of this guy. It’s a nice spot, way better than ours, out of sight, all that, so usually I wouldn’t have minded waiting. But I had this weird feeling, like something was off. Couldn’t tell you why. Maybe it was the air pressure, I don’t know. Some people can feel that shit. So I’m starting to freak out, and I’m thinking about bailing, when I hear a tap on the window. I turn around, and it’s the damn CEO of–" He caught himself, just in time.

"--a prominent company. Fortune 500, recognizable, all of that. I almost shit myself, thinking he had started some kind of crime initiative, or something, and he was out here busting people like me himself. But it turns out he was the friend. He gave me the biggest tip I’ve ever gotten, not that I get many, and went off with the stuff." "Really?" asked Quinn skeptically.  "Yeah. I looked up the gentleman afterward. Net worth of three and a half billion. And there was no mistaking this guy, either." "So," she said, watching a man hit a shot on the golf course they were driving past, "Who was it?"

"That I cannot tell you. Dealer-client privilege. Practically in the Constitution." "Can I have a hint?" "Under six feet tall, no facial hair. Company has the letter ‘q’ in its name." "I guess dealer-client privilege isn’t as strong as I thought it was."

Nicholas shook its head. "That’s the thing," he said, pulling into his long driveway, behind another sports car which was much less purple than his own. "It’s up to the dealer to decide how much privilege the client gets." But Quinn had not listened to his response. Instead, she marveled at the aura of the house she was approaching. It was three stories tall, and it jutted out at every corner; gently slanted roofs of differing colors gave the impression that there were multiple houses on that plot of land, as opposed to just one. Part of the front of the house was constructed with flat disc-like rocks, which made the residency look more like an art museum than a place of living. A ten-foot-wide window on the second floor overlooked a patch of golf course that was visible through the tree cover, and on the balcony of the top floor, someone sat in a hot tub, lazily looking down at their car through a pair of sunglasses.  Nicholas parked the car, opened his door, and shouted without bothering to stand up. "HEY! COMPANY’S HERE! GET DECENT!"

Quinn, with ears ringing, watched the hot-tub user wordlessly exit the pool and wrap a beach towel which had been hung over the railing around her waist. She ran her hands through her long, dark hair, and shook her head. As if by magic, or by a lifetime of practice, not a strand fell out of place. Tiny streams of water dripped from the bottom of the towel as she strode inside, leaving a trail to where she sat.  "That’s my daughter, Valerie," said Nicholas, whose words again nearly made Quinn jump. "You caught her at a real busy time, as you can tell." "You know, it’s alright if you don’t want me to come in," said Quinn, speaking quickly. "This wasn’t planned, and I just don’t, uh, want to bother–" "Bother? You’ve already bothered me, and she teaches virtual yoga and makes herbal supplements, or something. It’s bullshit. Bullshit that I’m proud of her for, but bullshit."

"No, really, it’s ok–" "Come on," he said, getting out of his car. "She’s your age. She likes young person things. I wouldn’t be scared of her if I were you. Or is it the whole walking into a drug dealer’s house thing? That I could understand, but I hope you see me as more than that." Quinn sighed, and pulled the baseball cap off of her head. Her dumb orange hair was frizzing, she knew it. And she hadn’t showered since she’d come home from work.  Quinn followed Nicholas into the house. It was every bit as magnificent on the inside as it was on the outside. The front door opened directly into what appeared to be the living room, which was larger than the entirety of her old house’s upstairs floor. The ceiling was made of polished wood, and it let in natural light at angles which seemed to make the white walls glow. A virtual fireplace complimented what was decidedly an earthy decorating style– pinecones filled a crate on the coffee table, three detailed diagrams of leaves were mounted on the back wall, and the art-museum rocks visible from outside lined the edge of an attached kitchen. The whole place was spotless, and open; it was as though Quinn had set foot in the largest and most comfortable camping tent of all time.

"VAL!" said Nicholas, rounding a corner and nearly bumping into his daughter.  She had thrown on a baggy T-shirt and a pair of fuzzy pink socks. She glared at her father, and whether it was for yelling at her from inches away, or nearly knocking her over, or perhaps for years of perceived mistreatment and embarrassment, she silently made it understood to all that he deserved the look he was getting.  "...Alright. I’ll go see if I can find where I put those damn pills. Quinn, Val. Val, Quinn." With that, Nicholas huffed and puffed his way up the stairs and out of sight.

Quinn was frozen atop the welcome mat. Speaking, moving, and standing all felt like terrible options. Valerie surveyed her, up and down, with large, brown eyes that had been hidden to Quinn before. She could feel herself failing the test already, but it wasn’t her fault; she hadn’t had a chance to study. Nicholas’ daughter sighed and crossed the room, her towel’s dripping now slowed to a crawl, her perfect hair swaying on her shoulders, back, forth. "You know, you can sit down," she said, without looking back. Quinn was halfway in between saying "Okay" and "Thank you", so she gave a little cough instead. God, this shouldn’t be so hard, she thought, sitting rod-straight on a sofa in the middle of the room. You had friends. You went to school with people.

You knew how to do this. Quinn thought she might need to initiate a conversation with Valerie, but she struggled to land upon a worthwhile topic. What did she know about this woman? Young person stuff? Yoga and herbal supplements? Or something? Nicholas didn’t exactly give her the complete manual.  Valerie effortlessly navigated the kitchen in silence. She grabbed two bananas from a basket beside the stove, peeled them bare, and threw them into a blender. From the depths of her thoughts, Quinn watched her add blueberries, strawberries, oat milk, a healthy scoop of yogurt, and what looked to be a kiwi.  Valerie turned the blender on. The fruits spun around a few times in futile protest before becoming a homogenous, viscous, red-dyed liquid.

"Do you, uh, want a glass?" asked Valerie, somewhat tepidly. Quinn had been staring at the smoothie. She probably shouldn’t have been.  "Okay," she breathed.  Valerie fetched two glasses and poured the contents of the blender into them both. Flecks of blueberry lined the edges of the machine and slowly dripped back down into what was left of the mixture.

Valerie marched back across the room and handed Quinn her drink. To her surprise, Valerie then placed her own drink on the coffee table next to the pinecones and sat next to her. "So," said Valerie, fishing a remote control out from between two couch cushions and flipping through channels on the massive television which was mounted on the wall, "are you and him a thing, or–" "Jesus, no," said Quinn, nearly spilling the smoothie that she’d reached for. The hints of a smile graced Valerie’s lips for the first time. "Okay. Sorry. It’s just, he doesn’t bring many of his clients back home."

"Right. No, he’s, uh, not my type." "Sure, forty years older than you, immature, balding. But he’s got money. Keep an open mind." Valerie was making it very hard for Quinn to drink her smoothie.  "So why did he bring you here? Are you taking over the family business?"

"No, nothing like that," she said. "I don’t…really even know why he did. I won’t be bothering you much. At all." "Okay," said Valerie, frowning. "It sounds like my dad’s just being creepy. Don’t let him push you around. You’re too pretty for that." Quinn tried her hardest not to melt.  "Do you want to watch anything?" continued Valerie. "News, soap opera, game show? He’ll probably be a while up there."

"It’s all crap," she said, before she could stop herself. Valerie smiled, and looked Quinn up and down once again with those big brown eyes. "Yeah," she said, "it is." She turned off the television. "So, what do you do? Other than drugs, of course."

Quinn brushed that last sentence off. "I’m a desk clerk at a motel. Night shift. Which means I mostly do nothing." "Not that. I mean what do you do for fun." This question caught Quinn off balance. She took a long sip of her drink– which tasted mostly like banana, hardly her favorite flavor– and tried to come up with something.  "I, uh, sleep."

God, that was pathetic. Valerie cackled at her, each sharp intake of breath digging deeper and deeper at something locked inside of Quinn. "You can’t sleep for fun. Really, what do you do?" "I like to draw." "No. Fun."

"I don’t know. What counts as fun?" Valerie gave a big sigh, and made a point of looking up, and appearing to be deep in thought. "Let’s see," she said. "Cutting class to bar hop on St. Patrick’s Day your senior year of high school. That’s fun. Running from the cops in Mexico in the morning, flying down to Brazil later that day, and then running from the cops there in the night. Scary, but fun. Getting your uncle to genetically engineer a wooly mammoth so you can ride it to Coachella." "You’ve done those things?" "Only the first two. But you see the idea! Getting out there, doing stuff that you’ll remember in fifty years, if you’re still alive."
"Okay. I, uh, like to go to concerts." "Alright. Who have you seen?" "...Pinky Meteor. You probably haven’t heard of them." "I have not. How was it? Who’d you go with?"

"It was good, but I mostly just went because my…" Quinn trailed off. The memory was tainted now.  "My friend liked them. But she’s across the country. It was almost two years ago." Valerie nodded skeptically. "Anything more recent?"

Quinn took a measured breath. "I guess, I just… do what I have to do, mostly." This time, Valerie shook her head and grimaced.  "Oh, honey, that’s no way to live," she said. She took both of Quinn’s hands and looked her directly in the eyes. Quinn felt a warmth she hadn’t felt in years, maybe ever. It was a dangerous warmth, one that she knew she’d be addicted to chasing if she had too much. For now, though, she let it wash over her, let it stain her vision, let it quiet her mind.

"I will make it my mission to force you to have fun," said Valerie. "Alright," said Quinn, beginning to smile. "Holding hands already," bellowed Nicholas, turning into the room. "I knew you two would get along." Quinn felt herself begin to blush. Before she could say anything, Valerie jumped in.

"Why did you bring her all the way here? Alone? Are you being creepy again?" "Again?" said Nicholas, tossing another orange container at Quinn without looking. "When was I creepy the first time?" Miraculously, Quinn threw out her hands and caught the bottle. "Nick. Ask any judge in the state, they’ll tell you."

Nicholas held up a finger at his daughter, but looked at Quinn while he defended himself.  "I’ve been arrested for selling drugs, not for being creepy. Big difference." "That still doesn’t answer my question." "I brought her here because I wanted you to meet her in person. Down the line, you’ll be glad you did."

"What?" asked Valerie, microseconds before Quinn could ask the same thing.  "She’s pretty important. Government stuff. Can’t tell you exactly," he said, winking at Quinn. Valerie gave Quinn an incredulous look.  "Really?" she asked.

When Quinn was seven, her grandfather took her fishing for the first and only time of her life. She’d never forgotten the way the fish flopped around and moved their mouths when he put them into his bucket. She’d always imagined it was excruciating, but she’d wondered just how it felt, to be so oblivious to the panic and pain that was to come one moment and in the middle of it all the next.  She didn’t have to wonder anymore.  "Well– No– I–" The more she fragmented her words, the more excited Valerie became.

Nicholas laughed. "I’m just messing around. Val, can you drive her home? I really have to get myself organized for this afternoon." "Yeah. Of course. Let me put some pants on first." "That’s important," said Nicholas, as his daughter retreated upstairs. Quinn waited until she was out of earshot, and whispered with as much force as she could muster.
"What the hell was that?" "What was what?" asked Nicholas, who kept his voice down as well. "That! How much does she know?" "Nothing. I told her nothing."

"And what does down the line mean? What’s happening?" For the first time that day, Quinn thought she saw Nicholas break. "Down the line… well… things change, right? People talk, just… it doesn’t matter. Right now, everything’s quiet. We’re trying to keep it that way." It felt like months ago that she was on her most recent shift, clicking through link after link in certainty that the truth was going to be exposed to the world. In one of her most recent conversations with Ty– nearly three months ago now– he told her what they would do to her, if word escaped to the public. Confinement, tests, drugs, media coverage, debates, activists, attacks, arrests. A mess. One brutal and incomprehensible system fed to the fickle desires of another.

Quinn was not unfamiliar with death. She had learned about it from stories and the news when she was small. It came for her old high school in a very public way two Septembers ago, and she had seen it take her sister from her arms. She had caused it to claim others, indirectly, semi-directly, by her own hand. Still, as she watched Valerie walk back down the stairs, perfect hair, perfect clothes, perfect body, she realized she had somehow failed to understand what it was trying to tell her. Sitting behind her desk at the motel, or lying in her bed, hours and days were expendable, things to be trodden through and hopefully forgotten.  But now, as she held conversation with Valerie in the passenger’s seat, and fought off questions about her secret job, and laughed at the jokes she made; as she squinted against the sunlight which was as fierce as though it had been reflected by a magnifying glass, or by the sharp edges of a boy who wanted to know the truth; as she swallowed the visual of a red-faced man talking on the phone, and fifty others from weeks past, she understood what death meant, what she had long known on some level to be true. She was running out of time. And it scared her.
Valerie parked her car in front of Quinn’s house. "This it?" she asked. Quinn nodded, and reached for the door handle. Her hand was shaking. "If I… text you. Would you respond?"

That smile began to spread over Valerie’s face again. Quinn liked it, a lot. "Phone, and pills," she said, extending her arm. Quinn reached into her pockets and produced both items.  "Here…is…my…number," said Valerie, handing Quinn her phone back. "And… What are these for? Anxiety?"

"Something like that." "Alright. Well, it says to take one every eight hours… three a day… plus some for an emergency…" Valerie dumped about half the bottle into her hand, and counted them out. When she was done, she put a few back in the bottle. "Twenty-five," she said, extending her hand with the loose pills to Quinn. "A week’s worth. When they’re gone, you text me. Not him."

Gingerly, Valerie tipped the pills into Quinn’s grasp. One bounced and nestled itself in between the seat and the arm rest. "Twenty-four," said Quinn. "Looks like you’ll just have to text me sooner," sighed Valerie. "Looks like it."

Quinn opened the front door, left hand curled into a fist. "How was it? Take any good pictures?" Her grandfather had not moved from his spot since she’d left.  "Yeah. We went and grabbed lunch after. Some smoothie place in town."

"This is a nice time of year to be outside, before it gets too hot." "For sure," said Quinn, running upstairs, taking extra caution to ensure her pile of twenty-four did not become twenty-three. ./. Three taps came from the window.

They were quick and authoritative without being too forceful; they did their job just as well as they could have. Dorothy, eyes burning, cranked the glass down and met the gaze of the officer. "Are you a student here, ma’am?" he asked, underneath a thick mustache.  "Yes, sir. Graduate student." "Mm. Can I see some ID?"

With fumbling hands, Dorothy went into her bag, which had fallen from the passenger’s seat onto the floor. She sifted through pages filled to the brim with small, meticulous, hand-written letters to find what she was looking for.  She pulled the small badge out and handed it to the officer. A few of the pages fluttered out of the bag, and she silently cursed to herself. He stared at the ID for a moment, and looked back at her. "Do you have somewhere to be?"

"I’m meeting with Dr. Eugene, in the biology lab." A smile creeped on to the officer’s face as he handed the badge back to its owner. "Dr. Eugene. How’s that old bastard doing, anyway?" Dorothy swallowed.

"He’s fine." The officer rested his forearms on the exposed windowsill and positioned his head halfway inside the vehicle. Dorothy shifted her weight away from him in desperate attempt to maintain some level of personal space.  "I’d tell you to say hi to him for me," said the officer, bringing his voice down, "but we didn’t get along well. Failed his class, twice. He was smart, but… I couldn’t understand a word he was saying." Dorothy nodded along. Mercifully, he stood back up, taking with him the olfactory remnants of some meat he’d had for lunch.

"You’re free to go," he said, idly scanning the rest of the parking lot, mostly empty on that Saturday afternoon, "but listen. There’s a lot of homeless around here, walking around, using our facilities, that kind of thing. I see someone sleeping in their car on campus, I’m gonna have to start kicking them out. So do me a favor and doze off in one of Dr. Eugene’s lectures instead, okay?" Dorothy nodded. "I apologize." As the officer tapped the exterior of her car and walked away, Dorothy grabbed the five or six pages which had settled in random fashion about the car.  She read each one carefully, and flipped through the report fragments which had not been disturbed from their original position. God, it was all a mess. Maybe if she’d had time to proofread her work, she’d know where to sort the loose pages. Maybe if she’d had time to drive to the biology lounge, she’d have been able to staple the whole report together, and nothing would have happened in the first place. Maybe if she’d had time to sleep last night, or the previous, she could actually think.

At last, when she was confident the pages were in their rightful places, she collected herself for a moment before beginning the walk to the lab. It was always eerily quiet on the days they met. Though this was by design, she still found it odd to walk through empty hallways and dark classrooms and barren offices to get to her meetings. Even the stench of tobacco, ingrained so deeply into the essence of the building, seemed to hide from her on these Saturdays. Dorothy reached her destination– an unimpressive wooden door, which guarded a seemingly unimpressive lab space, not any larger than the classrooms– and performed the secret knock, in three distinct groups of three.  The answer was prompt, as though Dr. Eugene had been waiting with bated breath for her arrival.

"Dorothy…dorothy, dorothy. You’re late." Yes, professor," she said, stepping inside and closing the door tightly behind her, "I wanted to have a frank discussion with you on the subject." "Discussion…discussion, discussion. Yes, alright. Make it quick, dear; I’ve got something to discuss with you…with you, with you." Professor Eugene walked– or, rather, hobbled as well as his eighty-five year old frame would allow him– across the lab as he spoke, touching each tabletop or piece of lab equipment he passed exactly three times.

"I have the report you assigned," she said, watching him retrieve a file from his large and cluttered desk, "regarding the air pressure readings around our specimen." "That’s good, good, good," said the professor, burying his nose in the file, which must have been two inches thick, laid flat.  Suddenly, Dorothy felt her words catch in her throat, for just a moment. She usually didn’t have this much trouble telling the truth. She took a breath and thought of the officer leaning into her car.

"It’s not my best work," she said. "I haven’t been feeling myself lately. I have my thesis to complete, two classes to teach, and of course my project with you to honor. Additionally, I have some… familial obligations I am expected to carry out." Seven hours a week, she could save, if her mother could simply move on or find someone else. And that was only the time it took to drive home and back.  "What are you proposing?" asked the old man, glancing up at her. "I am suggesting that it may be time to look for additional help. I know you had wanted to keep our research confined among ourselves for the time being, and I respect that wish, but truthfully, the work we’re doing is too much to do alone."

"That’s all?" asked Professor Eugene. Dorothy found it hard to look back at him. "That’s all." He removed his thick glasses and removed a handkerchief from the breast pocket of his jacket. He made three deliberate passes at each of the lenses and nestled them back onto his wrinkled face.  "Would you be so kind as to bring our specimen over there?" he asked, pointing at one of the long, black tables that stood between Dorothy and himself.

"Of course," said Dorothy. The specimen in question was kept in a closet opposite the entrance to the lab. Upon unlocking the door, Dorothy was met with shelves filled with chemicals of every variety, a modest collection of lab safety equipment, and on the ground, by itself and appearing rather out-of-place, an empty cage, roughly eighteen inches wide and two feet long.  Dorothy picked up the cage and rested it on the table next to Professor Eugene’s desk. The thin iron bars, meshed together at inch-wide intervals, may have been suitable to hold a family of gerbils, or a small cat. Though it opened from the front on a hinge, this particular cage had remained closed for over a year.  "What was your report…report…report…about, Dorothy?"

"My report?" "Yes. Summarize it quickly." "It appears as though the air pressure in the immediate vicinity of our specimen exceeds background levels by as much as two inches of mercury, after multiple measurements over a timeframe of several months. Furthermore, the pressure increase is exacerbated by the shining of ultraviolet light at the specimen. Though it is not certain why this is the case, I outline several hypotheses for the effect." "Yes, yes, yes. We have noted a similar trend with temperature, correct?"

"Correct. The air temperature is approximately one degree Celsius cooler in the cage than it is outside. Just less than a noticeable difference for most humans, ultraviolet light notwithstanding. Professor, may I ask what is going on?" "I took measurements this morning, as I always do. Tell me what you see." Professor Eugene plucked the front page from the file he’d been examining and extended it toward Dorothy.  She instantly lost feeling in her fingers and toes. He’d taken ten measurements over the course of an hour both inside and directly outside of the cage. The first nine readings were the same for both locations, and he’d noted that the final measurement actually read a tenth of a degree warmer inside of the iron box than outside of it.

"We’ve never observed anything like this before," she said, refusing to believe what she was seeing. "Did you try–" "Blacklight. Yes. And I did not apply so much as to harm the specimen, if that concerns you." He handed her another paper, with near-identical results.  "How– what– did it, die?"

Professor Eugene shook his head and closed his eyes, as he often did when he was thinking. "I have studied these creatures for years before I wrote to you, Dorothy. When they disappear, they simply do not leave any trace of themselves behind, as most life tends to do. I’ve never found any evidence that they die, as we die." "Did someone open the cage, then?" "I find that to be highly unlikely…unlikely…unlikely… as well. I can confirm our specimen was present yesterday at this time, and no one save for myself, yourself, and the rest of the biology faculty has access to the closet. What I believe happened is what I believe happens often naturally, for them.  "They don’t always move through space and time as you and I understand it."

Dorothy sat down on one of the chairs.  "What?" she asked. "It’s all theory, of course," he said, picking up the file he’d been glancing over  and handing it to her, "and my work has not been reviewed, and is therefore incomplete. But I hypothesize that our specimen has traveled to a hub, of sorts, where it is truly from, which is not connected to or bounded by the physical world." Dorothy stood up. A wave of rage threatened to engulf her.

"I did not agree to work with you to study pseudoscience. Why is that cage empty? What did you do?" Professor Eugene remained as calm as ever. "I encourage you to examine my findings. If they are incorrect, I would welcome a proper refutation of my idea. Though I am old…old…old…and manic, I still have confidence in the scientific method." Dorothy sat back down, and flipped through the file. Inside were sheets upon sheets filled with physics equations, most of which she did not recognize.

"Not connected to the physical world," Dorothy repeated, marveling at the depth of work Professor Eugene had completed.  "No," he replied, "but profoundly related to it. Just as our specimen had developed its own relationship with us." Dorothy closed the file and took a breath.  "What now?" she asked, in a small voice. "Do we find another? It took us years to capture this one."

"No," he said, rubbing his temples, "we do not. You had mentioned that you thought we needed help…help…help… I concur. I trust you to find someone– a student, a professor, it doesn’t matter, really– someone with a physics or mathematical background, preferably; someone who can help you to verify every letter of my findings, and someone who will know to remain quiet about them. I will not burden you with further experiments or reports. I believe our wealth of study is sufficient, should we eventually need to defend the existence of our specimen. I want you to focus on that file. Spend every ounce of energy you have finding flaws on those pages." Professor Eugene was not especially excitable, but something in his voice conveyed the gravity of the task he had assigned to Dorothy. She could feel her heart begin to beat against her ribcage as she allowed herself to consider the implications of his work. "Professor, I don’t know if I’ll need help with this," she said, flipping through the file once more. "Annotations will be quicker than writing, and as I won’t have to conduct experiments, I’ll have time to–" "Dorothy…dorothy…dorothy…" interrupted Professor Eugene. "I’ve been thinking. I am old. If my body doesn’t give out first, it will be my mind. And if it isn’t my mind, it will be my spirit. When I am gone, I want to know our research is in good hands. Should, God forbid, anything happen to you, I would find it unacceptable for our work to be lost to history, or worse, for it to fall into the wrong hands. I trust you to find adequate help to prevent those outcomes."

"Your spirit?" she asked, puzzled. "You’ve so much more to do." "That’s right," he said, folding his arms. "I believe it is possible– I intend personally– to join our specimen and its kind, wherever it is they go." Dorothy was silent for a long moment. "You what?" she asked, at last.

"If you can verify my work," he said, "I believe you will find that human beings and these– interfecorum animi, as I refer to them– have, for all time, been living much closer than even I had expected. So close, in fact, that it is not inconceivable that the two species, under the correct circumstances, could operate as one mega-symbiote. Under those circumstances, we could access and share their realm, study and adopt their behaviors. "Dorothy, I believe we could conquer death." "Shit," said Dorothy, softly.  "It’s not much more than a guess at this moment," said the professor, "but I believe it is more than possible to bring about the necessary circumstances for the aforementioned scenario. In the meantime…meantime…meantime…"

He pointed to the file. "Yes, sir," said Dorothy, touching it, feeling it hum, listening to it whisper. ./. Quinn dropped her pencil and held the loose leaf sheet at an angle in an attempt to catch the first rays of the morning sun. She studied the way the light tickled the page, the way it made the deeper lines shine, the way it blended her thinner marks with the color of the sheet itself. The fluorescent lamp she’d been working under for the past several hours was serviceable, sure, and it probably held the distinction of being the object most responsible for her enduring sanity at the Up and Away Motel. But it simply could not compare to natural light, she thought, wiping away a stray eraser shaving from the corner of her work.

The sun also seemed more honest than the lamp. The longer Quinn looked, the more she became convinced her mountains were concave.  She placed the sheet back onto the desk and began the editing process. She was a deliberate artist, but not a very ambitious one; her projects almost always moved from idea to finished product within the confines of a shift. Today, however, she would be unable to complete her landscape in the five minutes she had remaining. The thought excited her, especially on the precipice of a weekend. If nothing else, she’d given herself something to look forward to when she came in the following Monday.  When Quinn had reached a suitable stopping point, she carefully slid the page into a drawer underneath the reception desk. Every desk clerk had their own, and it was considered a fireable offense to rummage through someone else’s, except in cases involving unpleasant odor. Though she hadn’t been around long enough to witness the enforcement of this exception, she’d heard unverifiable stories about rotting food and bad weed and an awful prank involving a dead mouse. She certainly hoped there would not be a repeat of the mouse incident, if it had ever happened in the first place.  Just as Quinn closed her drawer, she heard the front door swing open. It was Dan.

That was her cue. She dutifully grabbed her bag and left her station. The two brushed past one another. He smelled of cologne, cheap, pungent.  Just before Quinn reached the exit, she decided to try something.  "Good morning, Dan," she said, turning back to look at him. "Hm? Oh, yes. Morning."

He seemed to be very interested in clacking a stack of paper records together on their side, ostensibly to organize them.  "Been a pretty light week, huh?" she said, a smile creeping onto her face. "Light week. Of course, yes." He continued to clack. The papers could not have been more rod-straight.

"Alright then. I’ll see you on Monday," said Quinn, stepping halfway out the door. "See you then," he said. And there it was! His eyes flitted up to Quinn’s in a moment so brief she’d have missed it if it wasn’t the exact thing she was looking for.  By her own diligent account, it was the first time Dan had made eye contact with her since their conversation last week. Maybe she’d grown a head that was only visible to him, she thought. That must be it.

Quinn had taken two steps toward her car before she was forced to a sudden stop. She was in the shadow of a man, one that she recognized. "Miss Quinn!" he bellowed, evidently startled by her presence as well. "You look cheerful today, yes?" "Heading home for the weekend, Mr. Shesterkin," she responded, tilting her neck upward at a rather extreme angle to address him. "Will you ever listen to me? You will not call me by that name any longer."

"Oh, gosh, I’m sorry, Valerie." "Vas-il-ee. Like that. You will get it right next time, okay?" Quinn covered her mouth with both hands. Of course she knew it was Vasiliy.  "Ah— I’m so sorry, Mr.-- Vasiliy, I know, it’s just–"

The man patted her on the shoulder and laughed as he stepped inside the reception area.  Quinn hurried to her car, face flushing. God, she’d been at that damn motel for eight hours. Why did she have to make an ass out of herself in the last ten seconds? She opened the door and rested her forehead against the steering wheel. She’d taken a few trips to the ocean when she was younger, and vividly remembered the feeling of trapped water in her ear. She must have spent hours of her childhood hopping around on beaches, listening to the muffled sloshing of the liquid, fearing that the unpleasant feeling may never go away. But each time, with enough effort, the warm water would find its way out, and Quinn would be ready to jump back into the ocean. She wished memories worked that way.

Valerie. Why did she say that? She was such an idiot. She did need to text Valerie.  Quinn pulled her phone out from her pocket and went to find her number. As Quinn searched, however, she made an unwelcome discovery. To her horror, during her shift, she’d gotten another message. From Ty.

I need to hear from you. Call me, when you’re ready.  And then another, two minutes after the first.  I’m sorry. Quinn sighed and stared at the screen. It took her several minutes of thought to come to a decision, but once she had, she swiped away from the conversation and resumed her search for Valerie.

The small blue cursor blinked optimistically at Quinn. Another impossible choice, this one completely open-ended. Her first instinct was to simply give up and go home– but she was running low on pills, and they had worked well. They had done their job so well, in fact, that she was hopeful she could stretch the seven-day cycle she was currently dealing with to ten, or perhaps longer. In any case, they weren’t crying out to her as loudly or as urgently as they usually did on Friday mornings, and for that she was grateful. She didn’t want to ruin that momentum.  Her second instinct, then, was to call Nicholas and explain everything. Maybe he had a backup supply, maybe she wouldn’t have to text Valerie and risk whatever it was she thought she was risking. But the more she explored this instinct, the more cowardly she felt. She was an adult, Valerie was an adult, they had agreed to do this last week. She had looked forward to doing this last week. The small blue cursor blinked optimistically at Quinn. She had to ask Valerie to drop off the rest of the pills. Did Valerie remember where she lived? What about the spot that she and Nicholas usually met at? Should she be vague, in case someone else read her text? Or straight to the point? Should she be funny? Sarcastic? What was Valerie like? What text would she want to get, if she was Valerie and Valerie was her? Quinn began typing, deleted her draft, then did it again. The more she thought, the more she decided her worst nightmare would be to actually enter a text conversation with Valerie. She could hardly stand sending one message. She hoped against hope that she would not have to do this all again.

The small blue cursor blinked optimistically at Quinn. Okay, brief, informative, not rude. That was all. Fewer words meant less likelihood of including a wrong one. By the time she had finally typed her whole message out, her shift had been over for some twenty-five minutes. Drop off at St. Anne’s Park later today? Any time’s fine. Quinn had been on the fence about using the word "meet" instead of "drop off", but she eventually decided that her text was as good as it was going to get. Through two big breaths, she hit send and began the journey home. It seemed as though the world was driving just a bit slower than normal. Unfortunately, because the clock next to her dashboard was also moving a bit slower than normal, she could not find reasonable grounds to lose her temper at the mother in the minivan who would not budge from the left lane. She did, however, have a legitimate gripe with the sun, which shone so amicably at her earlier that morning. She could practically feel holes being burned into both of her retinas as she drove due east.

Quinn stopped at a light and sighed. With hands that didn’t seem to listen to her and a gaze that didn’t seem to settle on any one thing, she fumbled with the radio, but eventually decided she didn’t need it. The silence was fine.  When at last she turned onto her street, Quinn audibly groaned. She could hear it before she could see it, but she knew what it was all the same. A sports car idled with windows open on the side of the road in front of her grandparents’ house. The only thing louder than the puttering of the car’s engine was the music that blared from its high-powered speakers. It was not yet 8:45 in the morning. Quinn sped into her driveway and threw her dinosaur of a vehicle into park. She ran-walked across what little front lawn there was, turning her head in every direction to search for onlookers.  "Hey girl!" shouted Valerie, just audible over the synthetic groove of whatever song was playing. "You look cute in that outfit!"

"Are you crazy! This is—" Quinn stopped in her tracks once she reached the curb. A stench met her so violently that she turned around and gagged. "What is that?" she croaked. Valerie shook her head and pointed to her ear. "I can’t hear you!"

Quinn, with tears in her eyes, waved her hand, in a frantic attempt to tell her to lower the volume. Miraculously, Valerie got the message.  "What is that smell?" asked Quinn, now raising her voice to overcome the ringing in her ears.  "Oh. Yeah, in the back seat. Rough night for those two." Quinn held her breath and craned her neck to get a look at the back seat, which contained two men, murmuring, half-asleep, covered in pools of vomit.

"Oh, fuck," said Quinn, fighting back the urge to gag again. "Are they alright?" Valerie laughed. She wore bright red lipstick and the same sunglasses she’d had on last week. Though her brown hair was frazzled and her face was caked in sweat, there was still something so effortlessly flawless about her. "Got ahead of themselves. We’re on our way back to their frat. They’ll be fine. I can’t say their douchebag friends will be as helpful and understanding of their condition as I am, though." "Okay," said Quinn, forcing the image of their vomit-soaked bodies out of her mind’s eye.

Valerie opened the glove compartment and produced an orange bottle. She shook it once, and extended it to Quinn. As she reached for it, Valerie pulled it back. "Before I give this to you, I have an offer. The only rule is… you can’t say no." Quinn should have wanted to kill Valerie, toying with her in that loud car, with those foul drunks, at her house instead of the park. In fact, at that moment, she tried to make herself feel that way. She couldn’t. "I guess I have no choice, then."

"That’s right. I matched with this guy on Tinder the other day. He said he has a friend who needs to get out more. I said I did, too." Quinn felt the color drain from her face. "We were thinking Paulie’s at ten. So, meet up at my place before then?" "Tonight?" asked Quinn, feebly.
"Yes! Tonight." "And, uh… it’s not those two, is it?" Valerie found that question to be awfully funny. It took her some time to collect herself. "No, Quinn. Not them."

Quinn absentmindedly wrung her hands together, and found them coated in a layer of moisture. Valerie watched her eagerly, like a parent waiting for her child’s first steps.  "Okay…okay," said Quinn, swallowing a myriad of concerns, coming up with reasons to believe herself. "Yes! You’re gonna have fun! Call me later, alright?" Valerie handed her the pill bottle through the window.

As Quinn took it, she glanced down at the small writing on the label. "If we do this again, can we just… meet in the park?" "Meet in the…" repeated Valerie, grabbing her phone. She swiped at it for a moment. "Oh! You told me that. Sorry, sometimes I don’t read things too closely."

Quinn closed her eyes and smiled. "I– Look, it’s fine, no one cares, and you basically live in the forest away. But– yeah, we can meet in the park." "You are just like your dad," said Quinn. "What– you take that back! He’s– I’m–"

Evidently, she could see the resemblance, too. "You better call me tonight," said Valerie, "or I’ll come back to this spot and sell you drugs every day for the rest of your life. Ugh, you’re the worst." With that, Valerie sped off. It was very courteous of her, thought Quinn, to reach the end of the street before turning her music back up to full volume.  She stepped inside her house. She was met with the smell of instant coffee.

A voice from the kitchen. "Quinn, is that you?" The pills! Quinn flattened her hand against her side and strode as evenly as she could, to prevent them from rattling.  "Yeah, it’s me. Sorry, I got a little caught up this morning." "That wasn’t you outside making all of that noise, was it?"

She sighed. "No, grandpa. That was my friend. We, uh– I guess we’re going out tonight." Still in the kitchen and out of her sight, her grandfather let out a one-note chuckle that made Quinn’s skin crawl. "How about that? It ought to be good for you." Unwilling to continue the conversation any further, Quinn tiptoed up the stairs as quickly and as quietly as she could, and prepared to face the lonely hours that had the unhappy duty of bridging morning and evening.

./. She had one dress. She’d bought it online the week before her senior prom, a night she looked back on with indifference, more than anything else. She was at a table with some friends from the archery team, and though she enjoyed their company, the experience quickly became tiring. The dancing and the smuggled alcohol and the cheapest expensive food her high school could buy did not sum up to an unforgettable night for her, as so many of her classmates claimed it did for them, whether they truly believed it or they simply felt that it was the right thing to say.  At any rate, the dress and the night seemed to share an identity. The dress was blue, a color she picked because it seemed less conspicuous than red or black, a color that was much deeper in person than it was online, a color she had no direct qualms with but one she did not love. It fit her decently well, certainly well enough for her to wear out, but not well enough to the point where she felt beautiful, if that was even a possibility. In some ways, she thought, examining herself in the mirror, feeling cool air against her exposed back, it was perfect for tonight.

She sat down on her bed and checked the clock. It was nearly 9 o’clock. Either she’d have to call Valerie now, or risk losing the only embers of a friendship she’d been able to stoke in the year or so she’d been in Arizona.  "Hey, Valerie." "Quinn! What’s up?" "I need to tell you that I know– I appreciate– that you’re trying to get me out of my shell. But I think maybe we should do something else, like… getting coffee, or taking a walk… this is all just a little fast."
"You are so lame! What are you afraid of?" "Afraid? I’m not…" "Of course you are! Have you ever been on a date before?" "Yes– not– uh…"

"Don’t you want some action?" "Action? What do you—" "I don’t know, Quinn. That’s awfully suspicious. I think you’re hiding something from me." Quinn went through seemingly all of the ways her phone call with Valerie could go, and none of them were any good. 9:05, 9:15. She was still daydreaming.

"I’m really sorry, I can’t go. I’m in the hospital. Family emergency." "Family emergency? Your mother’s daughter has cold feet, I’m guessing. Or is it that government thing of yours? What do you do again, exactly? My dad was explaining it to me, but I couldn’t believe some of the details…" As the clock approached 9:30, another scenario played in Quinn’s mind. "You couldn’t have even bothered to tell me no? Unbelievable. Don’t you realize I was just trying to help? How many people are trying to help you? Do you push them away, too?"

With shaking hands, she picked up her phone and called Valerie. One ring, two. Maybe she’d forgotten. A third. A twisted hope leapt up and threatened to grab her. "...Quinn! Yes! I knew you were gonna call!"
Instead, it shook hands with resignation on its way down. "Hey…Valerie." "Get over here, woman! I told the boys not to be late or else I’d kill them." "I… okay. Uh, I– what, uh…"

"4656 Piper Lane. I’ll text it to you, in case you forget." Quinn paused and stared at the questions she’d come up with, which twinkled and chipped like broken glass.  "Okay. I’ll be there in fifteen minutes." Digging through them would only hurt her further.

Quinn hung up the phone and threw it into her handbag, a cheap old thing she’d stored under her bed since she got it on her eighteenth birthday.  She walked halfway across the room. There was the mirror, bidding her one last farewell. She tried to ignore it, but it called to her, as it calls to everyone, especially on nights like this. It showed her the old handbag, the too-blue dress, the hair, which she’d taken hours to get right to little avail, and the face, adorned with what little makeup she knew to use, applied by an unsteady and sorely underqualified hand. The mirror seemed to delight in this goodbye, in this condemnation of her effort, but not because she was pathetic, or ugly, although at times, she believed both of those things to be true. The mirror, in its stoic, unflinching way, showed Quinn something starkly unlike herself. It couldn’t explain to her exactly why this thing had joined it in its effort to send her off, but it did show her just how plastic, how stretched around the edges, how alien the thing truly was.  She fought off an urge to crack the mirror and run away. How wonderful it might feel, knocking one of the smug bastard’s teeth out. It had no idea what she was going through. Why should it get to judge her? Yet as the farewell echoed in her mind, she began to understand that the mirror had hidden something beneath its mocking. She took a deep breath. You win. I’ll bite. She looked it in the eye and asked it what it was hiding. To her surprise, it told her, in clear terms.

She pulled off the blue dress, balled it up, and threw it onto her bed. As it landed with a weak whump, she looked at the mirror again. Her eyes shifted downward, and settled on the same spot they always did, when she was like this. She felt a familiar twinge, perhaps weaker than in years past, but enough to convince her that her reflection had re-appeared in the mirror.  Quinn pulled on a t-shirt, a pair of jeans, and a flannel. As she exited the room, she ran her left hand over the top of the mirror, grateful that it had said goodbye.  ./. January 2024

"How long has it been now?" "Eight-and-a-half. You’re ready." Quinn took a deep breath, picked up the small device next to her, and blew into a small tube protruding from its side for as long as she could. It blinked for a moment, and then displayed its result stoically.

"Still zeroes," she said, turning it toward Ty.  The young man chuckled as he wrote something down on a notepad. "What?" she said, a smile beginning to appear on her own lips. "It’s what you said you thought would happen." Ty threw his work onto the countertop beside him and began to speak evenly.

"Close your eyes–" "and hold each arm out. Now, touch your nose with your dominant hand," Quinn recited, performing the act with ease, seeing as how she’d had plenty of practice over the past thirty minutes or so.  Ty relented, his authority diminished, the result all but certain. "Okay, okay. Do the straight line thing and we’re done." Quinn stood up, and positioned her feet on the thin strip of yellow tape plastered over the white tile floor. Steadily, she swung one foot in front of the other, wobbling once, but never losing her balance.

The spectacle seemed to amuse Ty greatly.  "I did say I thought this would happen," he admitted, while Quinn sat back down on the exam table. "It’s just, I mean, I’ve seen 300-pound tackles out after half a bottle. You just did three-quarters, almost." Quinn shuddered. "You don’t have to remind me. I think I’m gonna be tasting that crap for weeks." Ty reached for his coat, which he’d hung up on a chair. It was a particularly frigid week in a run of cold ones, only made worse by the fact that the sun had not yet begun to crest over the horizon.

"So, is this gonna be in a big research paper, or something?" asked Quinn. "Well," said Ty, continuing to collect his things, "the research team is pretty convinced it knows why the dreamers are kind of knocked out by the pills you’ve been taking. They’re not so sure how the medication is affecting you personally, though. The prevailing theory, the one that I believe is true, is that it’s not really affecting you at all. Alcohol and nolazopam do the same thing to the body, more or less. The fact that you’re stone-cold right now is pretty good evidence for my theory." "I guess that’s good," offered Quinn, putting on her own coat.  "The question, then," said Ty, holding the door open for her, "is why you’re not being affected. Of course, the dreamers play into it, but are they removing the substances from your system somehow? Allowing you to store them somewhere where they can’t reach your brain? Is the connection awakening some reflex that changes the way you process them? I mean, it’s incredible you were blowing zeroes. Something biological is happening. It’s kind of weird to say, but I think they can…to some extent… influence the way you operate, just like you can do to them."

"That’s a nice thought," muttered Quinn, bracing for the cold. The pair hustled out of the building. Quinn, having never been west or south before last year, had thought Arizona would be dry and warm, even throughout the depths of winter. This morning, even though it was only ten steps to Ty’s car, the chilling wind and the whipping snow cut deep enough to freeze the soul.  Ty hastily started his car and cranked the temperature dial as high as it would go. "Thank God they kept the heat on for us," he said.

Quinn looked through the defrosting window at the Pediatric Care Center of Flagstaff sign that stood watch over the parking lot. It was an eerie feeling, being there at such an odd hour, with no other soul in sight. She wondered which strings Ty and his group of indeterminate power had to pull to get access to the space, but she knew better than to ask him about it. He’d give her the same answer he always did when she pried too deeply for his liking. It doesn’t matter. The only thing that matters is you. "So, what’s on the docket for today?" asked Quinn, after a time. "Me? Oh, I’ve got to fly to D.C., and meet with some people. Then it’s back home to prepare for a conference in Chicago tomorrow."

This time, it was Quinn’s turn to chuckle. "There’s no way you’re doing all of that." He shook his head. "Right now, I’m trying not to think about it." "Do you remember," said Quinn, as Ty began the journey back to her house, "at my old place. You said you wanted to go anywhere after you graduated. I guess you got your wish."

Ty sighed. "Yeah, I remember. This isn’t really what I meant, though. I’m mostly just ping-ponging from home to D.C. to wherever someone needs me. And, when I can," he said, stealing a glance at her, "to here." "That’s awfully nice of you," she said. "Well, it’s a lot, sometimes. But it’s good to see the subject of my work in person every once in a while." She stiffened, and turned to look at the snow falling sideways out of her window.
"So you flew all the way across the country to run this experiment." "Pretty much," he replied. "Knowing how often you had to travel in the next two days." "I guess so."

Quinn grimaced slightly. "I’m honored, but if you ever need to make me sit in a room and drink again, I think it would save both of us if you could just get one of your lackeys to watch me." Though she’d planned on saying it, it felt much more abrasive than she’d meant it to be. Though Ty didn’t respond immediately, his face changed. Suddenly Quinn noted dark circles under his eyes, undoubtedly borne of long nights and never-ending projects and classified information.
