"You don’t get it," he said, softly, in a tone she didn’t recognize. "I– Hey, I was just messing around." "Okay. Say what you mean, then." "What, I– Ty, it was a joke, of course, I’m glad that–"

"No. Cut that out. Just say it." Something was stirring inside of Quinn, but she could sense that something with far more energy was gaining momentum in him. She thought before she spoke. "Ty, I would be dead without you. If it wasn’t… that day, it would have been the next one, or the next week, or the next month. I owe you everything. But every time I’ve seen you recently, it’s… experimenter Ty, or researcher Ty, or government official Ty, I don’t know. And you’re running tests on me, or making me sign papers, or talking to the press… it’s fine, I know we have to do those things, but I… I miss friend Ty." "Friend Ty," he repeated, vacant.

"Yeah… I know you don’t have time, or energy, just… a text, ask me how I’m doing, tell me how you’re doing, talk about some TV show you watched. Or… tell me if you’re scared. Tell me how you feel. Something. I know there’s shit happening that you don’t want me to know about, and that’s fine. I just… it’s to the point where… I don’t even feel like I know you anymore, really." "That it?" he asked. "Yeah. Your turn. No holds barred." "Okay," he said, running a hand over his shaven head. "You want me to tell you how I feel? I’ve been telling you for ten goddamned months. I’ve done everything I could to show it. I’ve risked jail, injury, death. I’ve put a damn army together to protect you, from nothing. And I still don’t have any idea what I’m up against. I don’t sleep, I can barely even think. That’s how I feel. But– no, the hell with all of that, I’ve told you explicitly. You know exactly how I feel, Quinn Harper. I love you. I don’t do what I do for the good of humanity, or for some greater purpose. I don’t believe in any of that shit. I do it because I’ve loved you ever since I laid eyes on you in McHugh’s class. Friend Ty, he’s gone. He was supposed to just be a step toward more-than-friend Ty. Or get-the-hell-out-of-your-life-forever Ty. Whichever one you wanted. But, this whole time, I’ve never gotten anything back from you. No idea. So…I need you to tell me how you feel."

Quinn drew her head to her chest. The snow outside was moving so violently even looking at it for too long made the tips of her fingers numb.  "Ty, you know I love you–" "But what." "But…I can’t. Not like that. I’m lesbian."
The tires churned over snow.  "How long have you known?" asked Ty, softly.  "Always," she said, matching his tone. Tiny flakes pattered on the windshield.
"Was it fun?" "What?"  "Stringing me along, for a year. It must have been fun." "What the hell are you talking about?"

"You know exactly what I’m talking about." "I don’t!" Ty leaned his head against the headrest and continued to drive, eyes forward. "You don’t understand anything unless it’s spelled out for you like you’re fucking five. Alright. I want you to look at me and tell me you had no idea I was into you. Ever."

She looked at him, mouth open. For as hostile as he had become, she could not escape a feeling of pity.  "You can’t," he continued. "You’re not as stupid as you pretend to be. I mean, look what you squeezed out of me. Saved your life, protected your identity, went through hell and back, all because you knew to keep a secret for yourself." "What did you want me to do?" asked Quinn, feeling blood rush to her head, raising her voice to match his. "Raise my hand in Calc and announce to the world that I’m gay? ‘Yeah, the answer’s twelve, and also I want to sleep with women.’ It’s not that fucking easy! And maybe I was worried you were gonna flip out, like you’re doing right now!" "Is it so unreasonable for me to assume it would have come up at some point over the last twelve months? You just admitted you knew I wanted to be with you. Was it gnawing at your conscience? Were you losing sleep?"

"We had some important things going on! And maybe if you had been more open about actually connecting with me, as a human being, and not a specimen, or a potential sex doll, it would have come up!" Ty shook his head and mumbled something like "You don’t understand shit" under his breath. Quinn pressed her nose against the cold window, closed her eyes, and wondered if she understood Ty better now, or not at all. ./. The footsteps were growing louder.

She could hear them drumming on the wooden floor from outside, unmistakably rising in volume.  She had thought about her drawing on the ride over, and what she would do on Monday to fix those damn mountains. They weren’t misshapen anymore, but they still weren’t right. Maybe they needed more snow, maybe she’d need to blur the base, to simulate fog; she didn’t know how she’d attempt that, but perhaps she’d have to try.  She thought about Dan, who was likely still at the motel, manning that lonely desk. What could he have in his drawer? A few fantastic ideas passed through her mind– what if it was a gun, or stacks of cash, or a secret cell phone?– and though he probably could have managed to hide any one of those things with impunity, she decided the most exciting thing he ever stored probably was whatever cold sandwich he’d brought for lunch. She’d even managed an idle chuckle at the contrast of the two cars nestled together in the driveway. It had all ceased to be real, for a short time, and she found she’d taken for granted how wonderfully abstract the moment she was in had once been.

The door swung open, and there she was. Gorgeous, objectively gorgeous, offensively gorgeous, a beauty beyond dispute or defense. Quinn’s eyes watered and her throat ran dry as she hugged her in greeting. With every ounce of effort she could muster, she tied herself to the present.  "Come in! Oh my God. They’re gonna be here any second." Quinn followed Valerie inside. The living room looked completely different under artificial light– if it was a rustic hub of exploration last week, tonight it felt more apt for homework-doing and dish-washing, those homely Sunday night tasks that come with the admission that another week will come, after all. As Quinn sat down on her drug dealer’s couch once more, she thought that it would not have been so bad to spend the night in, basking in this feeling, remembering when the pinnacle of her worries was a social studies test or a road match against her rival high school.  But the energy with which Valerie moved was a reminder that it was a Friday night, and that they would be spending it at Paulie’s, a bar notorious for its sticky floors and hazardous bathrooms. Her host sped to the counter and poured two glasses of white wine, downing one as she handed the other to Quinn. Before she even had the chance to thank her, Valerie sped up the stairs and out of sight.

Quinn waited for a moment and then grabbed her glass. She spun it in a small circle, something that she had seen other people do, but something she never understood. Performing the action now brought her no closer to understanding.  Valerie tore down the stairs, holding what appeared to be a vial in each hand. "Which one?" she asked, waving them side-by-side. Quinn squinted. They were two tubes of lipstick. One was a dark red, and the other was more purple.

"I’m… probably not the person you should be asking," said Quinn, wine still spinning around in her glass. Valerie shook the tubes again, in demand of an answer.  "Red," she decided. Valerie went back upstairs, and Quinn took a few sips of wine. Each was more sour than the last.

Fortunately, Valerie did not leave Quinn alone with her drink for long. In record time, she was standing at the base of the stairway again, this time with lips dyed red and hands empty.  "Ok. Be honest. How do I look?" She stuck her arms out and spun around. Her satin dress was solid black, and nearly floor-length, so she looked like a shadow as she twirled. The material wrapped around her neck in the front and was tied together so that an oversized bow covered her back. The outfit was equal parts conservative and curve-hugging, subdued and elegant; the contrast of the jewelry on her wrists and ears with the color of the dress was undeniable. All of this was to ignore her hair, just the color and style Quinn had dreamed of since she was eleven years old, and her face, quite possibly the most unrelentingly perfect thing Quinn had ever seen. "Um–"
Quinn swallowed.  "Yeah. You look good." Valerie adjusted the dress, and flicked off a piece of lint from the side. "But, like, would you go out like this?"

Quinn scoffed. "I would… probably do some unspeakable things to go out like that." That seemed to lighten Valerie’s mood. She smiled, poured herself another drink, and sat beside Quinn on the couch.  "Okay. Let me show you…yeah. These are the guys. The one I matched with is Nathan, over here on the left. And his friend is… that shorter one, on the right. His name is Cooper, I think. They play baseball at NAU. I mean– not bad, right?"

Valerie showed Quinn the picture of their dates, and though she looked and said something in response, she was finding it difficult to concentrate. Valerie’s perfume was strong, and her shoulder was nearly touching Quinn’s. "...he wasn’t talking to me about it, and I– oh, shit! That’s him! They’re outside. Come on!" Valerie stood up, took one final swig from her glass, and galloped through the front door. Quinn, who suddenly found herself alone in the house, remained in her seat. She wasn’t sure exactly why she made that decision– she knew they were all waiting for her, and beyond that, she wouldn’t have liked a guest to linger in her living room if she were in Valerie’s position– but as she did so, she felt an alluring sense of heaviness begin to set in. Every second she continued to sit on that couch, every second she stared at the drop of wine that had jumped out of Valerie’s glass as she set it down for the last time, was a second her legs and her lungs more ardently refused to work together to set her in motion. It was a sensation she recognized, but not because she often felt it.

She’d had experience managing plenty over the course of her life. But it was not anything familiar– not grief, nor bitterness, nor apathy, which paralyzed her in that moment. It was something she’d seen, something she hadn’t been able to put her finger on until now, something that she had to swallow instantly, for fear that it would consume her.  Quinn shot up and walked into the cool spring night because she had realized what it was for a quiet rebellion against a self-constructed plan to fail.  ./. Though it was an uncomfortably tight fit, she managed to squeeze herself into the back seat.

"Yeah, sorry about that," said the driver. "Got a lot of equipment in the trunk. I was gonna throw it in our apartment, but I totally forgot." "That’s… alright," said Quinn, arching her back to avoid a baseball bat that stuck out from atop the massive pile of debris behind her, thanking whatever deity was out there that Paulie’s was just three blocks away.  The driver turned around and spoke through several inches of black beard. "Nate," he said, pointing to himself. "And this is Coop." Had Valerie not shown Quinn the pictures of the two of them, she may have thought they were the same person. Both wore pastel collared shirts, with light cargo-style shorts that did not reach their knees. Though Coop was, as advertised, a bit shorter than Nate, and though Nate’s beard was much fuller than Coop’s, physically there was not much difference between the two young men, even down to their reddish complexion and matching boating shoes.

"Quinn," she said, finding it a bit odd that Nate Jr. hadn’t turned around or made a noise. "Can we get going? I’m literally dying back here," said Valerie, who, despite her need to contort herself to fit in her seat like Quinn, could not keep from smiling. "Anything you say, princess," said Nate. He drove with one hand on the wheel, and one hand massaging Valerie’s knee through her dress.

"So Quinn," he said, lazily, "she tells me you’ve never been to Paulie’s before." "Uh, yeah," she said, tensing all of the muscles in her core to keep from falling over as the car began to accelerate. "I’ve only been in the area for a year or so, so I haven’t really…gotten the chance." "You’ll like it!" said Valerie. "My dad and the owner are good friends. It’s not the nicest place, but it’s… homely." Quinn had to fight off a wave of nausea as she looked at Valerie.

Coop, from the front seat, whispered something to Nate. He shrugged and glanced at the rearview mirror. "Are you two alright with music?" Quinn nodded. This Coop still would not look at her. For the next minute or so, the car was cramped further by a particularly grating track that Quinn did not understand.

The bar was at the dividing line between upscale suburbia and the edges of downtown, tucked into a plaza which also contained a Pizza Hut and a Dollar Tree. Richer folk from Valerie’s direction tended to cherish the spot as a harmless, temporary look into how the other half lived, with broken knickknacks, processed food, and the smell of stale beer a reminder that fun was cheap, and of who and what they were ultimately above. People who were not so well off came with their family and friends to share in a culture perpetuated by tough luck and winding stories and inexpensive authenticity, a culture misunderstood by many, including those who took part in it. At any rate, as Quinn put her feet onto gravel, stretched her back, and stared at the neon sign which read "Pale’s", since the "u" and the "i" had burnt out, she could not shake the feeling that she was an atheist standing on hallowed ground. Nate and Valerie led the way, his arm wrapped around her shoulder. A few paces behind them, Quinn and Coop traded furtive glances at one another, exchanging no conversation. Though it was true that Quinn was not an experienced bargoer, her extensive Google review research of this place had proven to be an appropriate expenditure of her time. The floors were, indeed, sticky; she could feel the soles of her shoes latch and begrudgingly unlatch from the dirty tile floor with each step. There was a small wooden stage at the far end of the bar upon which nail heads poked their way up from below. The felt on the pool table had almost completely eroded, the smell of tobacco hung in the air, and every so often, the already dim lights flickered. In this way, she was relieved. She’d pictured a true dive bar, and she’d gotten it.  But, of course, there was the rest of the night to attend to. Nate and Valerie took two seats at the counter, Cooper took the one next to them, and Quinn, who always seemed to walk slower than everyone else in a group, was forced to sit two boys away from the only person she hardly knew in the whole bar.

A middle-aged man approached them, wearing a T-shirt that bore the Paulie’s logo on its chest. Though he moved deliberately, his voice rose easily above the chatter produced by the dozen or so groups that were spread out throughout the bar.  "Good evening, welcome to Paulie’s," he said, addressing Nate first. "What’ll it be?" "I’m gonna open up a tab," he responded. "And, I’ll have, uh… what’s the most expensive shot you got?" He made a show of looking at Valerie as he asked the question.
The bartender turned and grabbed an ornate bottle filled with golden-brown liquid. He set it gingerly down on the table.  "90 dollars." "...For the bottle?" asked Nate. The bartender chuckled.

"For a shot." He looked back to Valerie again, his eyes lacking something they had just a moment ago. Quinn couldn’t see the look she gave him, but she saw him harden in response. "Alright," he said. "One for all four of us." It was Valerie’s turn, now, to make a show of hitting Nate on the arm. This seemed to restore his confidence.

The bartender produced four shot glasses, and filled each one equally, without wasting a single drop. Quinn watched as hers rippled in time with the music playing over the bar’s cheap speakers.  "To new things," said Valerie, raising the glass high above her head. "And new people." The remaining three echoed Valerie’s movement, and brought their glasses to their lips.  Quinn closed her eyes and grimaced. It tasted like winter.

As the bartender took Nate and Valerie’s next order, Quinn decided that she had little choice but to engage in conversation with Coop. He was staring in the direction of a group of people in a booth who, by way of their shouting and dancing, clearly had been there for some time.  "So," she said, addressing her date. His eyes stayed trained on the people in the booth. "So," she said, raising her voice.

This at last captured his attention. Though it was hot in the bar, his face had lost most of its color.  "Um…" said Quinn. "So, what do you do?" Though she was relieved to hear him respond, he spoke so quietly that she had to fight to interpret every word he said.  "Baseball player. At NAU."

"That’s pretty cool," said Quinn, resenting the fact that she would need to be the one to drive the conversation forward. "I don’t watch a lot of baseball. I did play softball when I was little, though." "Oh, that’s cool," he echoed, in his little voice. "What position?" "I was outfield. I think my coach just wanted me to stay away from the ball. I wasn’t very good." "Nate is an outfielder. He’s the best player on our team."

Quinn looked at Nate. Valerie was resting her head on his shoulder, laughing.  "Yeah. I think I would have guessed that." The bartender made his way to the two of them. "What’ll it be for you, young man?" he asked.

"A scotch. Neat, please." "And for you, ma’am?" "A blue moon, in a glass." As the bartender fixed them their drinks, Quinn learned that Coop was a catcher, who, after five years of waiting, would take over the starting role at the start of next season.

For the next fifteen minutes or so, Quinn learned a few more things about Coop– he was studying history at school, he had a brother, his parents were farmers. None of these things particularly interested her, but she attempted to extract them because the effort of doing so was all that separated her from complete silence. She attempted to tell a story or two of her own, at first adhering to the truth, but then steadily incorporating exaggerations and lies in a simple attempt to make their conversation more exciting. Even this tactic was unsuccessful. She had eventually wrapped herself up in telling him that she was aspiring to be the first woman to land on the moon. Judging by Coop’s reaction, she may well have claimed that she was in training to be the manager at the local Target. But, as the minutes passed, Quinn did begin to take notice of a few peculiarities. The first, and the most obvious, was Coop’s ability to put away scotches. He downed his first three as though they were water, and he’d just spent the entirety of a summer day behind home plate. Though he slowed a bit after this, Quinn lost track of what number he was on in relatively short order. Despite all that he was drinking, she did not see a change in him, other than in his face, which began to flush again.  Quinn also kept intermittent tabs on Valerie. She seemed always to be touching Nate– his shoulders, his arms, his hair, his legs. The first drink she ordered was a colorful cocktail, one that stained her tongue blue as she finished it. But the next was a copy of her own– a Blue Moon in a glass. Quinn, in no mood to finish the drink, sipped hers until it was halfway gone. During long breaks in her conversation with Coop, she would look over his shoulder to find that Valerie, too, had seemed to give up on her beer, in the same spot Quinn had.

The final detail she took note of was that an unmistakable energy had grown in the bar. When they had arrived, there were thirty or forty other patrons, a decent number for the smallish venue, but nowhere near its capacity. The general chatter was more or less at the same volume as the music, which alternated between inoffensive pop rock and dance. But the longer she pressed on through her conversation with Coop, the more frequently she heard the front door swing open. It wasn’t long before large groups of people had to resort to standing on that putrid floor, in between the booths that lined the wall and the bar itself. The effect was two-fold: first, that the temperature in the cramped building, already hot, rose further; second, that the background level of noise grew exponentially, making Quinn’s communication with her supposed date an exercise in lip-reading, rather than in listening. Finally, just when she was convinced that one more group of people would make the bar explode, a small woman wearing the same t-shirt as their bartender stood on a chair directly behind them and clanged a wooden spoon on a metal pot.  The bar fell dead silent. Quinn’s ears rang. "Friday night karaoke starts in five minutes! Go find Gary to sign up!"

The floor shook as the bulls charged the counter. Gary must have been the bartender’s name, and he had happened to be refilling Nate’s drink at the time of the announcement. Quinn could not help but laugh as she ducked and covered her head, absorbing bumps and shoves from rabid patrons.  So it was karaoke. She had begun to worry that they were about to sit in on a cult meeting, or a riot organization, given the manner in which the bar had gained momentum. Once things settled down, it would be better listening to happy drunks misremember tunes than talking to Coop.  Eventually, the mad dash settled down, and the makings of a line began to snake from the back of the bar to Gary, who wrote names down on an oversized pad.  When Quinn looked to her left, she did not see Coop.
"I was scared we were gonna lose you," said Valerie.  Quinn swallowed.  "Yeah… this isn’t the night I was planning on having, you know." Valerie grinned from ear to ear.

"Listen," she said, "if we head up there now, I think we’ll push past everyone just in time." "What?" Quinn said, certain she’d misheard her over the chatter of those in line.  Valerie grabbed her hand and pulled her into the crowd. Quinn’s adrenaline spiked. "No–" protested Quinn, yelling to be heard over the noise. "We’re not–"

"Yeah! We are!" she responded. "Nate signed us up!" "You and me?" "Yes! He’s too manly to sing." A large man took a sudden step backward and spilled his drink on the back of Quinn’s jeans. She did not have time to say anything to him before Valerie had led her through a gap and away from him.

"I don’t– Are you crazy? I can’t do this!" Valerie stopped, a risk given the density with which the bargoers were packed. They stood so close to one another they were nearly touching.    "We are gonna go up there, and we are gonna sing Close My Eyes Forever, and I’m gonna be Ozzy, and you’re gonna be Lita. It doesn’t matter if you don’t know the song, just make something up. I know you’re a good singer! I can tell, from your voice. For God’s sake, have fun with this! Make an ass out of yourself! I know I’m going to!" Perhaps it was the words Valerie had said, or perhaps it was the look in her deep brown eyes. Maybe it was their proximity to one another, or the feeling of her warm breath on her face, or a combination of everything that had happened that night. But Quinn, who happened to know the song in question quite well, squeezed Valerie’s hand, and followed her the rest of the way to the stage without complaint.

As it turned out, Valerie’s estimation was correct. The pair had finished their painstaking traversal of the fifty feet or so which separated their seats at the bar and the stage just as the woman banged her wooden spoon on the pot once more.  "Alright!" she said, from the middle of the bar. "If you’re in line, stay in line. Everyone’s gonna get a chance to go. Okay? First up is… Valerie and Quinn, singing Close My Eyes Forever. Valerie? Quinn? Where are you guys at?" The stage was raised three or four feet above the floor, and they were in the process of climbing up. Though Quinn momentarily regretted her choice of jeans for the acrobatic exercise, she soon found herself standing, microphone in hand, before hundreds of expectant eyes.  The lights dimmed. A screen on the back wall projected the opening lyrics. The first notes of the guitar chord echoed with surprising strength over the speakers.

Quinn had been in many musicals, met with a handful of vocal instructors, and taken a few years’ worth of dance classes. She’d been made friends with and learned under countless performers throughout the course of her life, and every one of them seemed to have their own outlook on what performance was. Some said it was like a test, where the song or the routine was akin to a set of questions, and the joy of a great performance came from acing all of them. Others said it was more like a ritual, and that joy came from an innate connection with performers of the past, and the inspiration given to performers of the future. A great many said that performance at its core was communication with one’s own self, and the core joy was unlocked for performer and audience member alike through authentic expression.  Quinn thought all of these interpretations were reasonable, if flawed. The test interpretation left little room for improvisation and embellishment, unless of course those were questions on the test, which would then in turn penalize faithful adaptations of source material. The ritual interpretation seemed to her a bit naive in its belief that all performance had self-imbued value. It didn’t account for the undeniable existence of poor, unskilled, or malicious performance, best lost to time and history, separated from the great acts both passed on and to come. The self-expression idea was perhaps closest, but Quinn still reasoned that the vast majority of performances were regurgitations of someone else’s work, and that any expression reflected the original author or artist at least as much as the performer themself.  What Quinn had come to believe was that performance was debate. Attention is a valuable commodity, something that can be bought, sold, haggled over, stolen, wasted, returned, gifted. Whenever she would stand on a stage, she adopted the viewpoint that whatever work she was interpreting was worth the considerable price of the audience’s attention. She assigned the audience the viewpoint that their attention was too precious to spend on whatever it was she was doing.  Her skill, the one she had so many years ago, and the one she aimed to apply that night, was her knowledge of where, precisely, she was in that debate. There was the all-important opening statement, in which she would outline her abilities, without giving too much away. She can carry a tune, she can hit that note, she can manage a vibrato. Sow an early seed of doubt in their minds. She’d see eyes look up from phones, conversations begin to fragment and die off. They had communicated to her. She knew to listen.

Then, there were the chief arguments. She had to know what she was up against, always– in this case, it was the length of the song, the instrumental sections, the people more interested in snapping pictures of their drinks than taking in their surroundings. She knew she had to rebut these arguments either directly, or through the strength of her own arguments. Once she had opened how she wanted to open, she began to test the waters of persuasion. She embellished, she took a few notes up an octave, she threw in some added harmonies with Valerie, who was not such a bad singer herself.  The audience was breaking down. By the end of the second chorus, they had the head and shoulders of nearly everyone in the bar. Well, what about the long guitar solo? What are you, just gonna stand around and wait for it to be over? No, that wouldn’t work. So, it was only logical for Quinn to lick her lips, go back-to-back with Valerie, and rip one of the meanest air-guitar solos of all time.  Was it cheesy? Sure, but Quinn knew better than to always do the most dignified and responsible thing during performance. The song was dated, the bar was cheap, it was a virtual certainty that air guitar with the hottest girl in the building would play well. And it did. The massive crowd of people hollered, and raised their arms, and turned their phone flashlights on.

Finally, there was the closing argument. She knew that the last thirty seconds or so of any performance were what really stuck with audience members. During occasions when the debate was not going so well for her, she tended to employ a strategy similar to her opening, in an attempt to at least send people home convinced that she was good, if nothing more. But tonight, she got the sense that she had a chance to make the audience see her point of view in an even stronger way than she saw it herself. She drew herself up, and got under the skin of the song and the performer, felt everything as deeply as she could. She cocked her head back, a mane of blonde, now, and strutted across the stage, stepping around each irksome nail with grace and dexterity she seemed to lack in every other context. As sweat dripped down her face, she delivered the last line, bowed, and submitted her performance to the judges, in a sea of darkness. Oh, how she had won. The cheering from the crowd shook the foundation of the bar. Valerie ran up from behind her and gave her a bear hug. It was as natural to her as breathing; as logical as addition or subtraction. But it excited people to a wholly irrational degree.  That was why she used to love it so much. Quinn was vaguely aware of her trek back to the bar. Men and women congratulated her, tousled her hair, rubbed her shoulder, offered to buy her and Valerie a drink. She responded to them, and she knew that Valerie was still hanging on to her, but she did not truly wake up until she sat back down on her stool and heard Coop speak.

"Holy shit!", he yelled over the next group that was on stage, stumbling through his words, eyes bulging from his head. "You…you…you were unbelievable, it was like I was watching TV, and you were on one of those shows, I don’t know what it’s called, but everyone in here was going crazy! I, I mean, what… what was it like? Were you and her, the other one, planning it this whole time? I had no idea it was even gonna be karaoke night, and I don’t know if you did either, and it’s like… what would have happened if we didn’t come? All of these people in here, they never… they never would have heard you sing! Everything happens for a reason, that’s what my dad says, and I didn’t really know what he was talking about, but this kind of has to–" "Hey," said Gary, approaching them deliberately. "Let her breathe." "Did… did you hear her, too?" "Yeah, I did. I actually wanted to ask her a question. Both of you, actually."

Quinn turned over shoulder and nearly jumped out of her seat. Valerie was standing there, just behind the booth. God, she thought. I must have really been sleeping. "We’ve done this karaoke thing a long time, and it’s got a pretty loyal following, as I’m sure you can tell. What you guys did, I haven’t seen that in twenty-two years working here." Quinn glanced at Valerie. Her eyes were just like Coop’s had been– glossed over, aimed idly, in her case, at one of the dozens of framed photographs that hung on the wall next to the racks of drinks. Clearly, she hadn’t come out of the temporary coma that Quinn had just exited. "...Anyway, I wanted to let you know that if you’d like to, we’re looking for some acts. Weekends, weekdays, just give us some notice. It’s a great environment, and you’ll get some exposure, for sure. We’d just need some advance notice."

Quinn looked back up at her. She was beginning to feel a mild level of concern. "Hey, uh… what do you think, Val?" She turned to look at Quinn slowly, as though her muscles had rusted stiff.  "Hey, um…" she said quietly, looking at a spot next to Quinn, as she had turned her neck too far. "I… have to go to the bathroom, and I’d… feel better if you came with me."

"Oh," said Quinn, motioning to stand up. "Okay. Uh, Gary, we’ll be right back." Quinn wrapped her arm around Valerie and led her toward the bathroom, which fortunately was located at the opposite end of the bar from the stage, away from the density of the crowd. As they walked, quicker than Quinn might have expected, given Valerie’s condition, Quinn turned around to see purple-faced Coop gnawing Gary’s ear off about something of certain importance.  There were three stalls and three sinks in the bathroom, and they all looked equally unappealing to use. Valerie raced into a stall missing the top corner of its door. Quinn halted at the entrance.
"Do you need help?" Valerie, completely concealed, took long, slow breaths. "No, I just need… a minute." Quinn approached one of the sinks, cracked and full of gum, and looked in the mirror.

Older or younger? she asked herself, turning her neck around at every angle in judgment. Which direction is it today? She frequently asked this question to herself. Most days, she felt that she looked older than her actual age. Today, she was not so sure.  "Hey… is there anyone else in here?" Quinn turned around. Though she knew the answer already, she bent down and checked the bottom of the other two stalls to be sure. She saw copious amounts of scattered toilet paper, but no other pairs of shoes.
"No," she said. "Just us." "Could you… make sure no one else comes in here?" "Uh…really?" "Yeah."

Quinn scratched her head. The door swung open into the bathroom, so she’d need some way to wedge it closed. Though there was not much to the small bathroom, the trash barrel was nearly overflowing, and when Quinn wiggled it, she was convinced it would hold the weight of the door. First, she tried to slide the barrel the three feet or so it needed to travel to block the door. Unfortunately, whatever gunk had adhered itself to the rest of the bar’s floor had doubled in thickness here, causing the bin to remain firmly in place.  Her next idea was to pick it up completely, and shuffle it over to the door. When she tried this, however, she learned that it must have been in season for guests of this bar to throw away their cinder blocks in the bathroom. She lifted until she was certain straining any harder was going to throw out her back. After a moment of bewilderment, Quinn began to realize what she would have to do.

"Do we need to be alone in here? Can we… go outside, maybe?" Her response was simple and flat. "No." Quinn sighed, tipped the barrel ever-so-gently onto its edge, and began to roll it toward the door. As she had predicted, there was a small landslide of used paper towels and cans and wrappers and other things she could not even bring herself to think about. She extended her arms as far out as they could go in an effort to keep the detritus from ending up on her shirt. Though she was ultimately successful, by the time she stood the barrel up against the door, there was a steady line of garbage marking the exact trail she’d taken in moving the foul barrel.

"No one’s getting in here," said Quinn, testing the handle.  "Are you sure?" "Yeah," she responded, checking each of the three soap dispensers, and finding them all to be empty. "Not unless they’re John Cena, or something." Valerie sniffled.

"I’d be pretty surprised if he tried to get in." Quinn ran her hands under water that was far too hot, and scoffed. "Me, too." She turned the tap off and reached for the paper towel dispenser. Amazingly, in spite of the sheer volume of trash in the garbage barrel, the machine was completely empty. Quinn sighed, rubbed her hands on the sides of her jeans, and turned around.

Valerie had emerged from her stall. Her eyes had changed. They were no longer glossy, but still they seemed to lack something that would have indicated full lucidity.  "Feeling better?" asked Quinn. She shook her head. Her hair bounced on her shoulders. "I want to get out of here," she said.

Quinn’s eyes shifted to the trash can. "Okay," she said. "Okay. I’ll get the door open, we’ll tell the guys you’re not feeling well, and we can walk back to your house, it’s only–" "No," breathed Valerie.  She put her hands on Quinn’s shoulders, and gingerly slid them down the length of her arms, until they were holding hands.

"I want to get out of here with you." Finally, Quinn understood. "The window," she said. Though it was wide enough for them both to fit, and low enough that they could climb through it, a thick-looking layer of opaque glass protected the alluring exit.

"Can you open it?" asked Valerie. Quinn shoved on the frame with all of her might. There was a hinge, but it only allowed the window to move a fraction of an inch. "Shit," she said. Just then, a loud bang came from the door. Quinn’s barrier had held.
"Hello?" came a woman’s voice, in between knocks. Quinn and Valerie looked at each other in a shared moment of horror. "Are we–" whispered Quinn. "Hold on," Valerie replied.

"What?" Without an instant of hesitation, Valerie kicked her right heel off, and felt its weight in her hand. "Oh my God," said Quinn, putting the pieces together. She winded up and threw the shoe at the window with all of her might. It connected with the window with an earthy thunk, but bounced back harmlessly.

The voice from outside. "Wha– hello? What’s going on in there?" "Fuck," said Valerie, racing to pick up the shoe once more. Quinn took a few steps backward and watched her reload, aim, and fire again. Thunk. This time, a massive crack ran diagonally across the pane.

Nothing from outside this time. "Valerie, I don’t know if this is–" "Shut the hell up," she said, bending to collect her shoe, which had rolled under a sink. "I know what I’m doing." Sure enough, when she took aim a third time, the glass became dust.

A light murmur ordinarily leaked into the bathroom. Pieces of conversation, clinking of ice in drinks, the shuffling of footsteps, all reminders that the bar was just as alive as any one of its guests. But after the last bit of shrapnel had hit the ground, the motion outside stopped. "Go, go!" Quinn ran over to the window and swept away the shards on the windowsill with her sleeve. Again cursing her jeans, she awkwardly swung her legs up and over the ledge, and landed on asphalt with a hearty crunch. She turned to look back at Valerie. Damn it, her shoe. Quinn scanned the pavement in front of her and found it, upside down, twenty feet from the window.

She hurried to it and shook glass from its insole. By the time she’d returned to the windowsill, Valerie had pulled herself up, legs dangling over the edge. "We gotta run," she said, tugging the shoe onto her foot. That much was clear to Quinn. The banging on the bathroom door had begun again in earnest, trash can inching forward with each strike. "Which way?" she said, breathless.

Valerie turned and sprinted around the side of the building in answer. Quinn followed as closely as she could. The plaza was separated from the main road by a dirt hill of considerable incline. Valerie, who ran quite well, once again abandoned her shoes to make the climb, this time for good. Quinn, swallowing every thought that threatened to surface, dug both of her hands into soil and trailed her upwards. The odd plant or rock made the already sheer ascent plenty dangerous. But the fact that the obstacles hid in complete darkness left the health of their wrists and ankles to blind fate. On multiple occasions, Quinn felt her foothold give out, and each time, she waited to tumble all the way down the mountain and into the waiting arms of the employees of the bar, if she managed to survive the fall. But each time she steadied herself and kicked away the debris that should have ended her ascent.  Both women were shaking and panting when they reached the guardrail that divided the road from the hill, but importantly, both were alive, and for the moment, undetected.

"Look at that," said Valerie, through gulps of air. Atop the cliff they had summited, they had a bird’s eye view of the plaza. A group of a few dozen stood outside the bar, huddled around the broken glass. "They know it was us," said Quinn. "What do we do?" "We do what I always do," responded Valerie, pulling out her phone. "Get Nick to bail me out."

"What?" "If there’s one guy in the world who owes him a favor, it’s Gary," she said, typing out a message, and reholstering her phone. "Trust me on that." "...Really?" asked Quinn. "Yeah. The golden rule. If you’re gonna do stupid shit, pick your spots wisely."

Quinn had to chuckle. Down below, the scene had begun to lose its novelty, and most of the onlookers had re-entered the bar. A few, however, had fanned out in separate directions in a half-hearted search for the perpetrators. "Oh, shit," said Valerie, smiling, grabbing hold of Quinn. "We gotta keep running." And so the two jogged hand in hand on uneven sidewalk under the glow of flickering street lights. The cool air and the shine of Valerie’s hair and the small thwack that her socks made as they hit the concrete made this leg of their escape feel much less dire than the last. They turned around, shouted, made each other run faster. Quinn knew that she was breathing heavily, and that her lungs should have been burning, but that didn’t apply to her, not now. She knew that Valerie could have lied to her, or misread her father’s situation with Gary, and that the police, or even the boys they had run out on, could be waiting for them around any corner. But what did that matter? Those consequences were for another universe, for a different version of herself.

She was smart enough to know she was being foolish. She was human enough to cast the thought aside.  By the time Valerie’s house was in sight, Quinn was laughing, and soon enough, the two of them were in hysterics. They breezed through the door, galloped through the living room, tore up the stairs, warm, breathing together, touching. Finally, they stopped. Her room was wide open, white, carpet, sheets. Quinn kicked off her shoes, and they were eye-to-eye, mouth-to-mouth. This was it. Valerie undid each button on Quinn’s shirt, slid it off, unzipped her jeans, wrestled them off her hips. Quinn reached around Valerie’s waist, found the zipper, undid her dress; it slid off like snakeskin. "Arms up," and up they went, and off her shirt came, and down she went, pinned to the bed, wearing only– "Uh– oh," said Valerie, eyes frozen.

Quinn lifted her head. From the middle of her ribcage to the top of her thigh, dozens of thin ridges, some an inch long, some two, some even longer than that, all parallel to one another, all healed pale. Every one of them spoke to her, and for the past nine years, they’d spoken to her alone.  Tonight, Valerie rubbed an inquisitive hand over all of them, and they said something to her, too. "I’m sorry, I didn’t mean to be… I just, haven’t–."
Quinn chewed her lip. Valerie’s fingers were cold. The whole room was cold. "We can still–" Quinn shook her head.  "I think…this was too fast, anyway."

Valerie pulled herself up and sat on the edge of the bed. Quinn lay on her back and stared at the ceiling. The only sound in the entire house was their slowing breaths. "I should probably go," said Quinn. "If you want," Valerie responded, in a small voice. Quinn stood up. Her clothes were scattered near the window. The street was still.
Valerie, from behind her, spoke again. "But we could take things slower, if you wanted that." Quinn turned around.  "What do you mean?"
Valerie shrugged. "We could, just…talk." Quinn blinked, twice.  "Okay." She glanced out the window again.

"Would you mind if I… got dressed, first?" "Oh, yeah. Um… hold on." Valerie headed to the other side of the room and stepped into a closet. She returned in pajamas, holding a neatly-folded t-shirt and a pair of gray sweatpants. "I saw that guy spilled on your jeans earlier… I know I’m a little taller, but I think these might be more comfortable."

Quinn pulled them on. She’d never worn a softer pair of pants in her life. "These are perfect," she said. "Thank you." Valerie nodded, and sat back down on the edge of the bed. Quinn joined her. "So," she said. "What do you want to talk about?"
Valerie looked down, and fidgeted with her hands.  "Is it okay… if…" "My scars?" "...Yeah."
Quinn reflexively ran her hand along her side.  "Go ahead." Valerie sighed, and asked her next question without moving her eyes. "Are you still…"

"No. Not for a long time. I was fifteen, and I… guess I didn’t know any better." Valerie was silent. "I was in my school’s musical," continued Quinn. "It was my freshman year, closing night. Everything was… fine, before that. I mean, the rehearsals and the music prep and all of that was tough, but I liked it okay. And I never really felt nervous, like I know some other people did." "But something happened."

"Yeah, right at the end, I just… freaked out. They had to drag me off stage, in front of everyone. I don’t even remember it, really, I just came to in one of the band practice rooms after it was over. And that… kind of started everything that I did."  It felt different, this time, when she said it. "Did you ever figure out why you freaked out?" asked Valerie, after a moment had passed. "You know," said Quinn, through a sigh, "I have a couple of theories. I talked to a lot of doctors, and they had theories, too. But I always thought– and this is stupid, and you’re probably gonna laugh–"

"I’m not gonna laugh," insisted Valerie. "Okay. Well, I was the female lead… and, sort of as a joke, uh, the male lead stood up and kissed me before the show, in front of the rest of the cast, and–" "Wait. What? Were you guys, like–?" Quinn shook her head and smiled weakly.

"Well, no, not really, but he kind of told me it was coming, so–" "What did he say?" "I don’t remember exactly, but it was something like…this is practice, for later, like, when we were supposed to kiss at the end of the show." "Quinn, he assaulted you."

"Val," she said quickly, "I could have stopped him, I could have done something, he was just… being dumb, and I was being dumb, too." "He hurt you." "Well… yeah, he didn’t help me, but he didn’t… make me do what I did." Val slid her hand across the edge of the bed, and Quinn took it. Each attempted to take in the other, completely; Val ran her thumb along Quinn’s knuckles, the rest of the world stopped dead.
"Did you know, back then?" Val asked. "Know what?" "That you were… you know…" "Gay?"

"Yeah." "Well," Quinn said, "it wasn’t something I ever had to… figure out. I’ve kind of always known. Even when I was really little, when I watched Disney movies, or saw straight couples on TV, I mean… I knew what they were doing, and I knew why, more or less, but I knew I didn’t want that for me. Maybe everyone’s like that when they’re young, but… I don’t know. It’s hard to explain." Val nodded. "Why?" asked Quinn. "When did you know?"
"About you? Roughly an eighth of a second after we met." "Really?" "Uh, yeah." Quinn dropped her head and smiled.

"What gave me away?" "I’m usually good at figuring those types of things out. But mostly it was because of the way you were staring at me." "I didn’t– uh–" "You’re fine. To be honest, I think it was the fact that you were forcing yourself not to stare at me that did it."
"You’re pretty smart," admitted Quinn. "I don’t know about that. Observant, maybe." "Whatever it is, I’m not." "What do you mean?"
"I mean…I had no idea about you." "You know what’s funny?" asked Val, staring off into space, just as she had done at the bar. "What?" "I had no idea either, until about an hour ago."
They were both silent for a short time. "You’re sure you’re not just drunk?" asked Quinn. Val chuckled and shook her head.  "You’re awful. If I was drunk, I think everything would make more sense."
More silence. "Welcome to the club, then, I guess," said Quinn, shrugging. "The club?" "Well, I mean… people are a little bit obsessed with labels, I think. But, uh…"

"Quinn, I’m sorry. I didn’t mean for this to get… weird. I was, just, so stupid, tonight, with the window thing, and the dragging you on stage, and the… finding guys to bring out with us. I meant for it to be fun, I wanted us to have fun." Quinn shook her head. "We did! I did, anyway. Look– I should have warned you, about what I had going on. In a lot of ways, I guess. So it’s on me. And I don’t think I said what I wanted to say right, I don’t want you to feel–" "No, that’s… no. I just… can I be honest with you?" "Yeah. Of course."

"Okay. I like to go out a lot. Big surprise, you probably knew that already. But I don’t have that many close friends, not really. What I like doing is meeting new people, getting them into trouble… seeing what they’re made of. I think, if you really get someone going, that’s when you find out who they are. Most people are… douchebags, or cowards, or idiots. Some of them, I’m not convinced there’s a person in there at all." "That’s pretty bleak," said Quinn. "Not everyone," she said, smiling. "I mean, I’ve met people…men… I could have spent the rest of my life with, if things were different. The point is, I guess, I thought I knew how they worked. I thought I knew how I worked. But I look at you, and… fuck. I don’t know anything." Val rested her head on Quinn’s shoulder.

"That might be a good thing," said Quinn, wrapping her arm around Valerie, leaning in. "You think?" "I was pretty sure I knew exactly how the rest of my life was gonna go, before tonight. I mean, I’ve been hiding for so long, I thought… I was just gonna go from place to place, dumb job to dumb job, by myself, one step ahead of whatever was out there." "What are you talking about?"

"I don’t know, I… I’ve seen a lot. Everyone has, really… I’m not special, or anything. But I sort of came to think that the less I did, the easier things would be. And now, I’m at my drug dealer’s house, in the hottest-girl-I’ve-ever-seen’s bedroom–" "You’re full of shit," said Val. Quinn shook her head. "--and I don’t know anything, either," she finished.
"Hey, Quinn?" "Yeah." "Do you maybe want to stay here tonight?" Quinn scratched her scalp, in mock thought.
"Do you have a spare toothbrush?" Val smiled. "You can use mine. The bathroom’s across the hall." "Uh, what?" "The bathroom’s straight ahead when you walk out, you can’t–"
"Not that. Sharing a toothbrush?" "Yeah. Is there a problem with that?" "That’s disgusting." Val sat up.

"You’ve gotta be kidding me." "I just think everyone should have their own toothbrush, that’s all." "We were making out five minutes ago, and I don’t think there was a single inch of my mouth you missed out on." "I– well– it’s different," mustered Quinn.

"I think there’s one in the cabinet, behind the mirror," said Val. "You weirdo." Fortunately for Quinn, there was. As they freshened up together, she studied herself in the mirror. Tonight, she was younger, without question. Her eyes were a bit brighter, her skin tighter; though she’d just run a substantial distance, she looked lively.  "What now?" she asked, stepping back into the room. Valerie sat in her spot on the edge of the bed.

"I don’t know." "We can figure it out later." "Yeah," she said. "Later." The two burrowed under the covers. Val wrapped her arms around Quinn, played with her hair, rubbed her shoulders; Quinn felt Val’s presence and the restlessness of the past twenty-four hours begin to overwhelm her.
"God, I love your hair," Val murmured. "Pretty tough to miss," responded Quinn, already half-asleep. "It’s just like this? You don’t color it?" "No," she yawned. "My sister, too."

Quinn was a cold sleeper. She always had been. If this was any other night, she’d have tossed and turned for hours in the baggy T-shirt Val had given her, teeth chattering, fingers numb. But tonight, blanketed by her hostess, miles away from her coffin of a room, blissfully unaware of the mental lapse she was making, sleep greeted her quickly, soundly, and with all of the poisoned warmth her waking hours never seemed to provide.  ./. She was somewhere familiar.  The earth was soft and damp. The air was cold but still; a steady wind may have been enough to freeze her in place. Though it was too dark to see much of anything, and she wasn’t yet sure exactly where she was, she didn’t feel lost. In fact, something with great power, something that burned white-hot deep below the surface, drove her forward.

Yes, it was very familiar. Perhaps it was a smell she had stored in her subconscious. She stopped and breathed deeply. There was something beyond the dirt and the dew, she was sure of it. She needed to think. Ideas and feelings rolled around, crashed into one another, shattered.  She kept forward through long grass and the low hum of crickets. Her whole body had atrophied. She misstepped and landed on her back. The stars spun above her. How long had it been? Weeks? Months? More? As she reoriented herself, she attempted to shake the wretched hibernation from her muscles. Time stretched and separated her from sleep further. The smell became unmistakable, and then overbearing, a confirmation that she was headed in the right direction.

Still, she could not place it. The scent was deep and almost natural, nearly of a clearing in a forest, where water glided over rocks and low plants grew in patches of sunlight. But there was something peculiar about it, something that made her sure that the place she was headed had not existed for very long. The familiarity, the artificiality, the climate, the stars… She put it together just as she laid eyes upon it. She walked over wood chips, processed to avoid giving splinters to small children, climbed up a slide made from elements that may have once existed deep in the Earth, watched a fountain that spouted water processed miles away.  She was at her elementary school playground. Alongside hundreds like her. The entire area seemed to live. Though it was a timid life, it was a steady one, with more of them approaching the swingset or the rusty monkey bars through the field with each passing moment. Thousands of claws and necks and backs stretched, white eyes blinked, knots of exposed flesh brushed against cold metal and soft skin.

They were all here. They were all her. And they all knew, without a word, exactly what they were to do. They’d move together at first, through the school, into the neighborhoods, branching off into houses and buildings and vehicles as they encountered them. They would take each one they found to the place they needed to go. It was never communicated, never agreed upon; it was simply what they all knew what was to happen. It was as natural as a mother’s love.  Minutes passed. Everyone had arrived. She was clear now. Strong.  It was time for them to go.

They strode together. The ground shook beneath them. They would be even more powerful if they could get themselves in order.  Why does this one keep looking at me? Into the school. It was nighttime. Empty.  Just let me through the door– we should all take turns–

They crowded the halls. The air grew heavy. They were finally free. There was a world out there, if they could just reach it. I am awake. They– she– had come together in spurts, through a haze of medication and lethargy. The plan was weak. She was weak no longer. In fact, she felt better than she ever had. One of them touched her foot as she attempted to step forward, and that was all she needed. She turned to it– herself– and pounced, just as it pounced to her. She swung her claws and bared her teeth. She dealt a blow to its ribcage, it dealt a blow to her face. She didn’t feel anything. The two next to her locked into battle, inspired by her own actions, and before long, the halls of the school were filled with silent cries of warfare.

Quinn bolted upright in bed. She’d forgotten to take her pills. ./. Quinn’s heart rattled her ribcage and her lips began to go numb. She stood up (dizzy steps– is it because I’m nervous, or is something happening to me already?) and grabbed her phone off of the nightstand. 4:15. She’d have to try anyway.  She dialed Ty’s number and stumbled out of Val’s bedroom. It rang once, then twice. She tried to think, but her mind was only capable of producing one word.
Fuck. Fuck. Fuck. It went to voicemail. God damn it, she didn’t have time for this. She dialed again.  Riiiing. Riiiing. Rii- "Quinn?"

Ty, hoarse as she’d ever heard him. He must have been in a dead sleep. "Ty– I forgot– I forgot, to–" "Breathe, Quinn, I can’t understand you." She tried to take a breath, but it only sped her up. Colors danced on the periphery of her vision, her lungs sucked air up and down faster than she could control.
"Totakemypill. Something’s wrong, something happened, I–" "What? What happened?" He sounded much more alert already. "I was barely controlling them, they met up, uh…"

She fought to conjure up the images she’d seen. "The dreamers were at my school, elementary school, they were gonna get the whole town, but they kept waking up, they were so awake they didn’t know what to do with themselves, so they started attacking each other, I couldn’t stop them, even–" It was her right arm, from the crook of her elbow to her shoulder. The pain was like a slash, but hotter, more focused; it convinced her instantly that the dizziness she had felt before was completely psychosomatic. This was it. This was how it would end.

She fell to her knees first and then onto her left side, howling the breathless cry of the cornered and dying. The next wave of agony, an insult, ripped through her middle; open heat consuming her from within. She wrapped her good arm around her ribs to prevent offal from seeping onto the carpeted floor. She lost track of time. She rattled breath after breath through seizing lungs and a punctured diaphragm. A shadow bent over her, examined her, reached for something. It did not feel pity. The floor grew moist, the air grew cold, dense; it threatened to rupture her skull. Her cries became whimpers. There was no peace in this death.

The shadow returned to meet her. There was no air left in her to greet it, so she stared through glass eyes. It knelt next to her and showed her one of its knives– cruel irony– and spun her over.  Without a word, it jabbed its grim tool into her arm. I used to shoot arrows with that arm. Quinn woke up in a pile of drool.

./. "She’s– yeah, she’s breathing again. Her eyes are opening. Holy shit, what— please tell me what that was. No. Hold on–" Quinn pulled herself into a seated position. She rested her back against the wall and stuck out her legs. Oxygen had never felt so refreshing.  "Hey," said Val, squatting next to Quinn. "What happened, babe?"

Val was holding Quinn’s phone by her ear. Quinn shook her head, and in doing so, saw the syringe that protruded from her left shoulder. She reached for it, made a face, and went to pull it out– "WAIT!" screamed Val, nearly falling over Quinn’s legs to stop her. "Can she, uh… take it out now?" Ty said something to her over the phone, and Val shrugged.

"Go ahead. Sorry." Though needles had never made her squeamish, and the short jab of pain was incomparable to what she’d just endured, she found the sensation of pulling the syringe out to be quite unpleasant. "He, uh, wants to talk to you," said Val, extending the phone to Quinn. "Can you just… tell me what he says?" asked Quinn, her voice rumbling to life as though it were a cold engine.

"Can you just tell me?" relayed Valerie, into the phone. "Mmhmm. Yeah. O–okay. He says you don’t need to worry about your old meds anymore. They’re not gonna work. He also says… to keep calm, he’ll figure something out… and get into contact with my dad, ASAP. When you see him, tell him you need to see the doctor. And he’s on his way. Ty." "That it?" asked Quinn.  "Uh… yeah, that’s it. He really wants to talk to you, though." She shook her head, slowly.
"Okay." Val hung up the phone, and dialed her father’s number. "Is he gonna be awake?" asked Quinn. As if in response, Nicholas’ voice rang out of the speaker.

"Quinn! What’s up? Need someone to talk to?" "Uh, no, Dad," said Val, cheeks tinging red. "V? Honey? What’s– what’s going on?" "Um, Quinn crashed here tonight after we went out, and… she had an episode."

"An… episode. Oh. Oh… no. Is she alright?" "Yeah! Yeah, she’s… fine. I talked to… Ty, and he told me what to do. But he said something about… she needs to see the doctor." "Yeah. Yeah, she does. Okay. How long ago was this episode?" Val frowned. His voice was different than usual, and Quinn could see that Val had picked up on it, too.

"Two minutes, maybe? She just came out of it." "Alright. Alright. There’s still time. I’m gonna be home in a few minutes. Grab the other two syringes from upstairs and have her meet me out front. No fucking around, okay? When I get there, we need to go." "Al– alright, Dad. Love you." "Love you too, hon."

He hung up the phone.  For a moment, Valerie’s mouth hung open a fraction. Her dark hair stuck up in every direction, bags hung under her eyes, she gritted her teeth to stifle a yawn– it was clear that she had just emerged from a deep sleep. Yet the pace with which she moved upstairs to grab the two vials and the flushing of her face when she returned betrayed no sign of sleep– she looked more to Quinn like an athlete who had trained all day for an event than someone who had just returned to consciousness a handful of hours after being out on the town.  "You’re not– epileptic, are you?" asked Val. Quinn shook her head.
"It wasn’t a panic attack? I get those sometimes, maybe not to that extent, but…" Quinn shook her head again.  "Or a heart thing?" "No, nothing like that," said Quinn.

Val paused before asking her next question as though deciding whether she wanted to deal with its answer. "When my dad said something before, about… you working with the government… he wasn’t kidding, was he?" Quinn stared off into the wall behind her. "Oh. Okay. What went wrong, then? What can I do to help?"

The low buzz that had been brought on by the attack had finally lifted, and in its place was a realization. Quinn stood up, walked a few paces in the direction of Val’s bedroom, and put her hands on her knees, nauseous. "Quinn. What’s happening?" "It could have been you," she said, barely above a whisper. "What does that mean?" asked Valerie, donning a smile, gently wrapping her arm around Quinn.

"You have to go, now. You have to get as far away from me as possible. Everyone does." Val took a step back. "You’re not… contagious, are you?" "No," said Quinn, turning to face her, guilt radiating from every word she spoke. "Yeah. Kind of. But you’re not sick like me yet. You need to go while you still can."

"I’m scared," admitted Val, face changing. "Tell me what’s wrong." "I can’t," Quinn replied. "I need those syringes. I have to meet your dad." Val spun the two plastic vials in her hand, and came to a decision. She tucked her fingers beneath her thumb and put her hand behind her back. "No," breathed Quinn, as though she’d taken a body blow.

"Not until you tell me how to keep from getting sick." "I already told you, stay away from me. But–" "Well, I just slept in a bed with you, so I haven’t been doing a good job of that. How do I really keep from getting sick?" Quinn sighed and bit her lip. She needed those vials, she needed to solve the puzzle, this cruel puzzle–

"You’re fine now. That’s what matters. We’re both fine. I just– I don’t have time–" "No. Tell me how–" "I would have to die," said Quinn, cringing, "which I almost did. And judging from the way Ty and Nicholas were talking, it seems like there’s a great shot of that happening, pretty soon."  Emptiness began to show itself on Val’s face. She examined the contents of her hand, and began to march past Quinn, downstairs.

"What– where are you going?" she asked, turning to follow. Val moved with such elegance and purpose. Even though the lower floor of the house was completely dark, even though it was only a silhouette which descended the stairs and strode across the kitchen, Quinn could never have mistaken her for someone else.  "I want to go with you," she said, looking out of the window. "That can’t happen," replied Quinn.

"You seem to forget I am the one with the merchandise." A faint wagging of the hand that held the two vials. "Val. This is way bigger than you think it is. Way more fucked up. The more I learn about it, the worse it gets. And something tells me I still haven’t even scratched the surface." "You’re doing a great job selling this," said Val, whose face was momentarily lit up with the glow of approaching headlights.

"My sister is dead," said Quinn, the words still foreign to her. "My father is dead. Sometimes… I wish I was dead." The ghost of a smile departed from Val’s face. She watched her father speed down the road for a moment, and extended her hand to Quinn, palm exposed, revealing the two syringes identical to the one that saved her life.  "If you really don’t want me," she said, eyes trained downward. Quinn took a long breath and collected her prize, which was warm and damp.

"Thank you," she said. Quinn slipped on her shoes and hustled into the warm night. Nicholas hardly slowed his car as she entered it. "Alright," he said, breathing as though he had run instead of driven to pick her up. "You have the meds? Good, good. We kind of planned for this. Kind of. Those stims are like horse tranquilizers, they’ll stop those creatures dead in their tracks. We think they only work for an hour or so at a time, and they’re pretty hard to make, those exact kind, so we only kept an emergency stash in my place. Good news is, there’s more in Scottsdale, on a military base, you know, where the doctor is. No, you don’t know. The doctor– wait, V didn’t want to come?" "No," said Quinn, flatly.

"Really? Okay. Anyway, the drive’s two-and-a-half hours usually, and I got connections at that base, so we should be fine. We just gotta hustle. But you’re fine, you’re strong, as soon as you feel anything, pain, dizziness, as soon as they start waking up again, you hit yourself with those meds. Got it?" "I guess so," she replied. "You guess so?" he asked, incredulous. "No questions? No, ‘what’s gonna happen when the stash at the doctor’s runs out?’ Because the answer to that one, you see, is that we’ll figure it out. We’ve been doing this whole thing on the fly, me and your buddy and those suits we meet up with every once in a while. They’re smart, they’ll think of something. You’re in good hands. I just gotta do my part. That’s all, keep driving. Can’t get pulled over, obviously, they probably wouldn’t be too kind to someone with as many priors as I have. So I won’t go too fast. Traffic is light this early in the morning anyway." Quinn folded her arms and closed her eyes. She found herself fighting for breath again, at times so violently that she could feel Nicholas’ gaze shift. For now, the dreamers were still asleep, congregated in the halls of Dewey Pattinson Elementary School, as dangerous as a brisk wind or a faulty thermostat. But the existence of the catatonic atom bomb was her fault. The drive was her fault. That there would be no coffee on the table for her grandparents was her fault.

And she never had the chance to change out of Val’s pajamas.  ./. "You, keep don’t saying anything. I’ll take care of this." Nicholas glided to a stop at a small checkpoint flanked by a long row of wire fencing. A young man, late twenties or early thirties, hair buzzed, muscles bulging underneath his sleeves, stood at the booth alone and communicated with Nicholas from behind a glass panel.

"Identification, please?" he asked. Nicholas reached into his wallet and handed the man his drivers’ license.  "Sir, this area is off-limits to the public." "I’m aware. Trust me, I used to live on a base like this. Mine was bigger, I think… Uh, Dr. H called for us. We’re picking up supplies for her. I believe we’re expected."

"Dr. H? One second, please." The man began muttering into a walkie-talkie. Quinn rubbed her shoulder. Three puncture wounds stared into the sleeve of her T-shirt, each making her arm feel more like lead than flesh. She’d been in and out of sleep for most of the ride, save for the moments where she felt the pressure begin to weigh upon her head and the embers of pain relight in her stomach. All told, according to the clock underneath Purple Rain’s rearview mirror, these flare-ups were a little more than fifty minutes apart.  She’d done some math during the drive and figured they had around ten minutes to play with once they reached the base. Ten minutes. Shorter than the length of the cartoons she used to watch, which were two episodes per half-hour slot, minus commercial breaks. She might blink during a shift at the motel or during a class and ten minutes would pass. Six hundred seconds, give or take a few, depending on how long the dreamers took to rip each other to shreds.

Yet she could not work herself up to be anxious. During her freezing, uncomfortable fits of sleep, her dreams had been more like hallucinations, mixing and augmenting reality in odd ways. She had discussions with old friends, she went to the dentist, she was given the wheel and forced to drive, each vision a new life grown from the seed of something in her immediate consciousness. Most recently, she had found herself on a daytime talk show, complete with a studio audience and cameras. She saw herself from the outside, but she couldn’t seem to open her eyes. "And we’re back, with Miss Harper!" said the host through a shower of applause. "Say, don’t you know it’s respectful to look at someone who’s talking to you?" Laughter. "I’m sorry– I’m just, feeling tired. That’s all."

Eventually, she would come to and decide what was real and what wasn’t– a tricky proposition, given by the time she thought she was sure, she had dozed off again.  "The hospital is straight ahead, up about a mile. Check in with Amanda when you get there." With that, the thin barrier lifted, and Nicholas motored forward. "When we get there, you stay quiet," he repeated, under his breath. "I’ll handle it. I’ve been here before, but it was a while ago. Ten…fifteen years…how old is V? She was little…I think there are supply rooms on the first floor. Amanda’s gonna know where to get your meds. I never heard of her, before, of course, but if that’s what Dr. H wanted, for me to check in with her, then that’s fine. She’ll know what to do."

"Who’s Dr. H?" asked Quinn, mostly to interrupt the stream of words that were so loosely flowing from Nicholas’ mouth.  Nicholas squinted his eyes for a sign of the hospital as he spoke. "Dr. H? Oh, she’s… uh… kind of the brains behind all of this… no one really knows her, outside of professionally, of course… she keeps a low profile… we can trust her, you don’t worry about that…" Quinn felt the hairs stand up on the back of her neck.

They drove a minute or two longer before they reached a large sign advertising the hospital’s entrance. Nicholas skidded to a stop on the side of the road, threw his hazard lights on, and set out at a moderate jog. Quinn followed. The hospital was a large brick building, three stories high. An American flag stood watch over the set of concrete stairs that led the way inside. It had seen better days, the facility. Lord knows what it’s seen. Quinn and Nicholas entered a waiting room and approached a woman sitting behind a desk. Not a soul was in the room with them.

"Hey… you must be Amanda," said Nicholas, puffing his chest out to hide the fact that he was short of breath.  "Uh, yes," she said, puzzled. "And you are?" "Nicholas Samuels," he said. "Dr. H sent me. It’s urgent." "Urgent," mumbled Amanda, eyes sweeping over to a computer screen. "Who is this Dr. H?

Nicholas laughed a short staccato note. "Ah, what’s funny is, uh… that’s all I know her as. Dr. H." Amanda raised her eyebrows.  "We have a few professionals here who could fit that description," said Amanda. "It seems unreasonable that–"
"Dr. Harper," said Quinn. Amanda paused. "I see. One moment, please." She grabbed a clipboard and walked through a door that led to a long hallway.

"What the hell was that?" whispered Nicholas. "Lucky guess," responded Quinn.  The two of them found seats. Nicholas’ leg bounced. "Hey," he said. "The second you start to feel anything, you let me know. I’ll find it."

Quinn nodded.  One minute, two minutes. Nothing from Amanda. She’d had her last dose at 6:02; the clock on the wall read 6:51.  Her life wasn’t flashing before her eyes in any sense. A blanket of silence had descended upon the room, snuffing out her ability for reflective thought. She didn’t find herself sentimental, or angry, or even afraid. More than anything, Quinn Harper wanted this moment to end.

It was not long before she got her wish.  It began in her head. It was a gentle lightheadedness, not out of the ordinary by any means– it felt as though she’d stood up too fast, or had just had a particularly powerful yawn. Just as she opened her mouth to say something to Nicholas, Amanda returned to her station at the desk. "Thank God," said Nicholas, hustling to Amanda, laying his hands on the polished wood, knuckles white. "Do you have it?"

"I’m sorry, sir," she said, failing to meet his gaze. "You’re under arrest." Nicholas coughed, and recoiled.  "What the hell are you talking about, miss–" Two men in uniforms threw the front door open. One ordered Nicholas to get on his knees while the other brandished a pair of handcuffs.

Nicholas, who was overweight, balding, and in late middle age, broke for the hallway. The scene nearly made Quinn laugh. He took two plodding steps toward the door before reaching for his back and falling to a knee. The security guards, each built like Greek gods, walked over to him, shoved his head to the floor and chained his hands together. "You’re making a big mistake!" he cried, face full of tile. "You have the right to remain silent, anything you say can and will be used against you in the court of law–" "No! She needs help now, she needs–"

But it had already started. Her arm was the first to re-light. She howled and fell from her chair. One of the guards moved to her, took a knee, touched her. He may have said something, but her ears started to ring.  A line of fire ran down her middle. Her head pounded. She coughed blood into her mouth and choked on it. The people around her became shadows. The ground grew damp. The air became cold. The pain stopped.

./. She was facedown on dewy grass. She balled her hands into fists and filled her lungs. Everything still works. She pushed herself up and looked around. It was nighttime, but the stars shone brightly enough that she could see quite well. Surrounding her in every direction were irregular rows of trees with thick trunks made of old, weary bark and dense clumps of leaves that blocked out swaths of sky. Purple fruit, as big as softballs– plums? Huge ones?-- littered the ground beneath each tree.

Quinn walked over to the base of a tree and looked up. Dozens more of these fruits hung from its branches. She plucked one off and felt it. It was as though she was holding a giant water balloon– there seemed to be no solid substance to its center, only some combination of mush and liquid held together by a membrane. She threw it as far as she could. Splat. The fruit hit the edge of another tree trunk and exploded in a way that made Quinn chuckle. But before she picked up another, she stopped.

That sound was the first thing she’d heard. She listened closely. There was no wind rustling the leaves of the trees, no hum of insects feasting on the falling fruit, no brushing of animals walking through the grass. The sky was void of blinking lights from planes or satellites, at least in the patches she could see. All of the motion she’d once taken for granted was gone. Quinn’s chest tightened. She looked in every direction. It was all the same. Trees, fruits, grass. Occasionally a root poked through the ground. Nothing moved, nothing rustled. All she could hear was her own breaths and a faint ringing in her ears.  Okay. What to do. She thought it might be best to set out in the direction she was facing when she woke up. I turned right to get to this tree. No– left. Yeah, definitely left.

She cried out as she moved. "HEY! IS ANYONE ELSE HERE? HELLO?"  All she received in response was the echo of her own words.  Quinn may have been walking on a treadmill. Five, ten, twenty minutes she moved, longer; the grass did not dry, the forest did not clear, the sky did not lighten. She ran for a while, ran until the air felt like fire, and still nothing changed.  "No…" she mumbled, falling to her knees. "No…no…"

This is it, this is the end, this is it, so alone, just like always, twenty-three years plus forever, why, why was I– Something small poked out from underneath a tree. Quinn held her breath. It was a dreamer, walking on all fours, staring directly at her.

Her heart pounded. She closed her eyes, emptied her mind, made the connection– Nothing. Here it was, in the flesh. She couldn’t feel it. She wasn’t on meds, it should have worked. She tried again. Absolutely nothing.

The dreamer had pawed its way up to her. It shone two beacons of unblinking light through her, enough to send a chill down her spine. She backed up a step.  "Hey," she said, gently. It leapt at her throat. She recoiled, lost her balance, and hit the ground.

But it wasn’t the ground she hit.  She’d landed on the bed in her room in New Jersey, just as it had been when she left it.  But no, that wasn’t right either. The window was to her left, not her right. And her desk was different. And there were posters on the wall behind her.  It was her room as it had been many years ago.

"What the hell?" breathed Quinn, standing up. She was wearing pink socks and a set of matching red pajamas with moons printed on at regular intervals. She felt the soft fabric, rubbed the shag rug she stood on. All of these things were gone, donated or thrown out or otherwise lost to history.  Her backpack was half-open against the wall. She pulled out a folder. Written in careful letters was the following: Modern World History

Period 5 Mr. Dennis It was her freshman year of high school. She flipped through it. Assignments, notes, exams, all in full detail. Each stirred up some memory she didn’t know she had. Jenny’s doodles on the corner of one of her homeworks, a study guide in red ink, thrown together in an act of desperation the morning of a quiz, her very first project, which she nearly failed on account of her anxiety as a new high school student.

She rubbed her throat. It just tried to kill me.  It just did kill me. Though she felt no lasting effects from the dreamer’s attack, she did feel something wasn’t right.  She’d had an old desk that used to be a fixture of her room. It was bulky, antiquated, and two of its five drawers didn’t open. Though the creaky wooden thing was sorely out-of-place in her room, she didn’t mind it. She used the functional drawers to store some personal items– a diary she only wrote in when she was particularly upset, and some old toys she didn’t want to get rid of, to name a few– and as a result, the space became quite meaningful to her.

In an attempt to spruce up the corner of the room that contained the Victorian-style hunk of wood, she bought a vanity mirror– the biggest one birthday and allowance money could buy, complete with bordering lights– and mounted it just above where she did her infrequent diary-writing. Later, in a year or two, she’d go into a Polaroid phase, and tape dozens of pictures to the outside of the mirror.
