She always knew that mirror and that old desk were living on borrowed time, and she wasn’t unhappy improving her setup as she transitioned into college, but the day she canned both was a melancholy one. At first, when Quinn looked across the room at that old mirror and that old desk, she felt a warm wave of nostalgia. She was reunited, at the unlikeliest time, with two old friends.  But then she saw what was looking back at her. She was scrawny. Her shoulders were too narrow, her face appeared longer than it actually was. She was pale, too– pale enough that her freckles, long since hidden, peeked out, and her hair was too long, too long and too light, more blonde than it should have been.

She ran over to the mirror and gasped. She really was fifteen again. Quinn studied herself from every angle, touching her face and pulling on her hair to believe what had happened. It was still her inside, she was sure of that, but it was someone else in the mirror.  Another old friend. Quinn slid the diary out of its spot in the topmost drawer, opened to a random page and read an entry.

January 15 Jenny sat with Steve again at lunch today. Why? What does she think I’m gonna do? Sit with them and buddy up with dumb Steve? She talked to me later about it, but I didn’t tell her the truth. I wish I could. I don’t like him, I don’t like how she is around him. I just hope if I do tell her about it she doesn’t shut me out. My life would be O V E R Quinn shut the diary and slid it back into the drawer. She knew how dramatic her friend had felt, tracing those pen lines around the word "over", how important each day felt, each spoken sentence felt, when she was around Jenny. Her friend was crying out to her, begging for help. Her friend depended on her– to find a job, to find a place, to love, to be loved, to grow up.  Her friend, Youth. Herself, Hope.

Had Quinn failed her friend? Well, she thought, retreating to the bed, maybe I haven’t yet. Maybe someone will come along… maybe I’ll find a calling, or a passion, or something everyone talks about– And suddenly she was Youth, and she was appealing to her other friend, Hope. Quinn shook her head and rubbed her eyes. What am I doing?

There was a way out; there had to be. She took one last look at her old room, turned the handle of the door that led to the hallway– And nearly stepped out into a sea of black. It was incredible. It was the night sky, above her, below her, in front of her, starless, without a single blemish. It may have extended a foot in front of her or ad infinitum in every direction. There was no way of knowing.  Quinn shut the door.

But the darkness, having been revealed, came to life. It seeped through the cracks of the door as though it were tar, pooling on the floor, swallowing everything it touched. She shuffled backward, watched it stain her backpack, spread to the legs of her bed.  What have I done? The carpeting beneath her desk, farthest away from the door, was the last island that remained. She hung on as long as she could before scaling the old wooden thing. It groaned under her weight, but held.  Could I have run past those guards while they were apprehending Nicholas?

The room was capsizing. The first row of drawers, the second row of drawers. A few surfaces were all that remained. Maeve, I’m sorry, I let you down, I let the whole world down– The top of the desk turned from brown to black. Does it hurt is it going to hurt to go will I hurt forever
A pang of cold against her hip. She recognized it immediately, pulled it out. Broken, just as it was before.  Something glass. The mirror, of course.

Quinn slammed the butt of the steak knife against the mirror. It shattered, revealed a world beneath its face, and pulled her in. That’s odd. What happened to my pink socks? ./. A fly buzzed to her left.

This was death. Another, to her right. No, that didn’t make any sense. She was thinking about how she was dead. That wouldn’t be possible if she was dead.  She wouldn’t have heard the incessant buzzing, either. Or felt it, below her right wrist and right ankle.

She was alive. Quinn cracked her eyes open and was blasted with brilliant white light. She squinted and waited for her head to stop throbbing.  There was something in her nose. And something in her left wrist.  She took in a deep, slow breath, felt her chest rise, let it hold for a while. She was weak. Something had broken inside of her, but she couldn’t place it physically, not outside of the buzzing.

The buzzing. The flies she heard stopped when they saw her breath, changed into voices. A man and a woman, very excited. They were underwater when they spoke. "--happened before, what is–" "mean? Should I get the nurse, what–" Quinn let go of the breath and coughed gently. They were very excited. She felt stuck in place.

But not paralyzed. She wiggled her toes, and though they creaked and groaned, they obliged. And nothing hurt, save for that damned buzzing. She was fine, if brittle.  Why did it feel as though she’d woken up in some alternate version of her mind? Quinn decided to try to open her eyes again. The shock was less potent this time. She was in a hospital room.

She looked left. The man. Ty. She looked right. The woman. Val. She was in a hospital gown, attached to an IV machine, breathing through a tube. A window across from her bed showed her the night sky. It was just the three of them in the room, as far as she could tell.  Ty spoke to her. She could almost understand it, but he was too deep under the surface.

Something odd happened to Quinn. She wanted to tell Ty to be louder. That was the goal. But as soon as she put the plan into action, her brain began to overheat. Nouns jockeyed for position, sentences of no meaning formed and re-formed, clauses and prepositions bounced around, gaining and losing meaning at random. She opened her mouth, stopped, felt her cheeks flush.  "Loud," she managed, at last.  No, that wasn’t all, there was more. How did she want to say it? What would the first word be? Where would she go from there?

"Speak," she concluded. Ty’s face changed. For a nearly imperceptible instant, he glanced up at Val. "You want me to speak louder?" he garbled.  Quinn nodded. Yes, that was it. He put the question together with ease, each word exactly where it belonged.

"Okay," he said, forcing a smile. "How do you feel?" The whirring started all over again. She was a machine stuck in an infinite loop. She felt herself strain. "Fine," she replied. That was reasonable. "We thought we lost you," interrupted Val. "There were times when… it looked like, uh…"

Quinn turned to face her. Her eyes were damp and bloodshot. Another overheating, this one even more furious than before. "Okay," she offered.  That was too flat. Quinn pulled her hand out from underneath the covers, the buzzing hand, and offered it to Val. She took it, but returned the look that Ty had given to her.

Quinn’s stomach dropped.  She wanted to express a thought, an important one. She knew exactly what the thought was. There were feelings behind it, and nuance; in a past life, it would have gone out freely. "You," she mustered, looking at Val. Ty stood up and jogged out of the room. Val held her gaze and pursed her lips.

"Don’t talk," she said. "You need to rest." Quinn rolled over onto her back and looked at the ceiling. An elephant sat on her chest.  Even elephants could make themselves understood.  Ty returned a short time later with a doctor, whose wide eyes and bouncing gait indicated an excessive use of caffeine. The doctor asked Ty and Val to give her a moment alone with the patient, and they shuffled into the hallway. Quinn could see their shadows stop just outside the door.
Listening. Judging. Worrying. "How are we feeling?" asked the doctor, smiling wide. "Fine," said Quinn. She knew the answer to that one already.  "Can I have your name and date-of-birth, please?"

Name. That should have been easy.  Yet when she tried to say it, it didn’t come out. She knew it well, heard it often, but didn’t say it much. Her mouth wanted to make the k-sound, but that wasn’t it, not quite… "Quinn," she said, relieved. "And last name?"

She had to smile, a little self-pitying smile. That wasn’t going to happen. She shook her head. "Could you try writing it out?" asked the doctor, retrieving a pen and pad from a drawer, as upbeat as ever. She took the pen and signed her name without thinking.

There it was, in all of its glory. The script letters warped and tumbled on the page, but she got them to stop long enough to read them. "Harper," she recited.  "Good," said the doctor, turning away from her to type at a laptop computer perched next to a sink. "And could you give me your date of birth?" "No," she said, mind already white-hot from exertion.
"Okay," the doctor responded, staring at the screen. "Is it… March 5th, 2005?" "No," said Quinn. "How about… January 11th, 1999?" "No."
"January 8th, 2001?" "Yes."  "Ah," said the doctor, taking a seat in a rolling chair, rolling over to the bedside. "Well done." Quinn blinked twice.

"Are you having trouble communicating, Quinn?" That much was clear. She nodded. "It’s not unheard of, especially after what you’ve been through. Are you up for a few more questions?" She wanted to ask a question herself, but she nodded again.

"If I were to tell you that I had a friend, Destiny, who’s worked out every day for the past ten years and eats her fruits and veggies at every meal, how would you describe her?" Quinn shrugged. "Good" was the answer she kept coming back to, but there were better words than that. "Would you describe her as unconscious, self-conscious, or health-conscious?" "Health-conscious."

"That’s right. Now, say I had another friend, Caden, who graduated from Harvard and teaches at Oxford. Would you call him subversive, intelligent, or ardent?" "Intelligent." "Great. One more. Say I were to follow my dreams and save thousands of lives as a doctor over a long career. Would that make me dutiful, heroic, or responsible?" "Heroic?" she offered, less than pleased with her variety of options.

"Alright," laughed the doctor. "All three would have worked. That was a trick question." Quinn took a slow breath. "And how are you feeling physically? Is anything bothering you?" Thinking a demonstration to be easier than a description, Quinn balled the fingers of her right hand into a fist in plain view of the doctor.
"Your hand. Does it hurt?" She shook her head. "Numb?" She nodded.
"Anything else?" Quinn pulled the covers up and wiggled the toes on her right foot. "And it’s the same thing? Numbness?" She nodded again.

"Alright. Do you mind if I bring your friends in? I’d like to get them up to speed on how you’re doing." "Okay." The doctor stepped into the hallway. It was a cloudless night. The stars and the moon peeked from beyond the black sky, watched her, asked something of her. She wished she could walk across the room and shut the blinds.

She wished she could ask someone to shut the blinds.  Ty and Val flanked Quinn as the doctor shut the door, making doubly sure that the latch clicked. "So, Quinn," said the doctor, sitting in her chair, closing her laptop, wheeling closer to them, "you had a cardiac incident yesterday morning. It’s very fortunate that you had it in a hospital, of course, and it’s fortunate you had someone with you who knew exactly what it was you needed." Val rubbed her shoulder. The doctor betrayed a hint of exhaustion as she continued to speak.

"You were brought into this room, and doctors made an extensive effort to get your heart beating again. Nicholas, I suppose, was adamant that you received an experimental drug that we stored elsewhere in the hospital, and once our staff had exhausted every other option, they tried that. And it worked." Quinn looked at Val, who stared straight ahead. "In terms of your heart, Quinn, we’re not sure exactly why you had this episode. Your friend here tells me that this isn’t the first time you’ve had an incident like this, either. We looked for structural abnormalities, but we couldn’t find anything. In the absence of those, you’re much younger and much healthier than most people who have had two heart attacks. I’d recommend you to see a cardiologist for more testing." Quinn nodded.

"Now, in terms of the speech. I’m not a neurologist, and I haven’t conducted formal testing, but most of your symptoms are consistent with what’s called Broca’s aphasia. When your heart stops, blood can’t flow to the brain, so certain areas can be damaged. In your case, it was your Broca’s area, which is responsible for the use of language– forming sentences, vocabulary, things like that. Now, the important thing to remember– for your friends, here– is that your ability to understand language has remained intact. You might have a hard time communicating a thought, but that doesn’t mean you aren’t processing what others are saying. In fact, Broca’s aphasia isn’t thought to impact intelligence at all." "Can she get better?" asked Val. "I mean, uh, can she learn to speak better?" "Absolutely," said the doctor warmly. "I can recommend a speech therapist. Just like learning any new skill, it takes time. And– speaking to her friends here– it can be very frustrating to suddenly face a communication barrier like this. I’d advise you to be patient with her; give her time to say something if she needs it. But there are plenty of people with Broca’s aphasia who have gone from nearly mute to conversationally fluent over the span of a few years. It’s certainly possible." Someone’s foot tapped on the tile floor.

"If no one has any more questions for me, I’ve got to run along," said the doctor, once again breaking into cheerfulness. "Press that button to your left if you need anything, alright, Quinn?" "Okay." The three of them were alone in the room. "Glad to know you’re still in there," said Ty, tapping his temple.

He stood up. He was tired. His eyes were bloodshot and he walked like his muscles were stiff.  "Yes," said Quinn, who still couldn’t seem to look directly at him. "Don’t say anything," he muttered, opening the door a crack and peeking down the hallway to make sure that no one was listening in. "Just relax. I’ve got a lot to throw at you. And I like to hear myself talk." Click.

"Okay. So, uh, where to start. It’s Sunday night. Actually, early Monday morning. You almost made it two whole days. I didn’t get here until late yesterday, but they told me your heart stopped for, uh, six and a half minutes. And if that sounds like a lot, then… it is. Most people couldn’t last that long. It’s kind of a… miracle you survived." Ty found his fingernails to be quite interesting.  "As you might imagine, the last two days have been… pretty interesting. I have good news and bad news. Ordinarily, I’d, ah, give you a choice, what you wanted to hear first, but the good news doesn’t really make any sense without the bad news. And the bad news is… kind of… multifaceted. The first bad news is that Nicholas is in custody." Quinn looked at Val, who found her fingernails just as fascinating as Ty.

"Long story short, the only thing they have on him right now is the drug dealer stuff. But the only reason the cops were after him was because some informant showed up with new evidence in an old case tied to you. I’m sure you know the one. The evidence was, uh… compelling enough to where they were following you, digging through your messages, all that crap. Right now, Nicholas is just collateral damage from that. But once they figure out what it was he was giving you, or who he was working with, I mean…" "Over," said Quinn. "Yeah," Ty responded. "It’s just a matter of time." "He wouldn’t talk," said Val, pleading more than reasoning. "He’s been arrested before, I mean… he’s not going to be intimidated by cops–"

"I know he won’t. But it’s not about him talking. It’s about the cops doing an ounce of investigative work. They’ll figure out what he’s really been doing. They don’t even want him for the drugs, really. They’re after what’s going on with Quinn. Just too many loose ends now. I can’t believe I’m not in jail yet." "But is this whole thing really illegal? I mean, you work with the government, right? Don’t experiments go on all the time that regular people don’t know about?" "Well, yeah, but I only work with a small handful of government people. I’m kind of against most of the government. If all of, say, Congress knew about this? They’d want to regulate the shit out of what we do, string Quinn up, make her a zoo animal for a while, slice her open, and repeat for whichever lucky bastard is next. In the meanwhile, of course, it leaks, goes public, and the whole world goes crazy. We thought– we think– we can get rid of dreamers for good without years of red tape and ethics discussions and preventable deaths. Unfortunately, our line of reasoning is not, uh, lawful." "She?" asked Quinn.
"She? Um… yeah, she’s doing fine. Right, Val?" "Oh. Yeah, I’m okay." "No," said Quinn, thinking.  "No… know. Yeah, she knows. Everything, more or less. We’ve had a lot of time to talk."

"I’m sorry," said Val, taking a deep breath. "I know you wanted to keep me out of this. And it was probably for the best. But… I’m here now. And I still care about you. I kind of think… it’s badass, you know? What you’re going through?" Quinn scoffed. She’d said it so gently. "You’ve got to be messed up in the head," said Ty, echoing Quinn’s thoughts. "No! She’s… piloting thousands of murder-beings with her mind. And she’s been doing it for, what, a whole year? You do not screw with this crazy bitch."

A grin broke out on Ty’s lips.  "Uh, no. I guess you don’t." Quinn sighed. Much of her right side still buzzed. She was weak. "Anyway. The second piece of bad news, is that, um, we’re not out of the woods yet. With your health. You’ve been getting an IV drip of that solution Nicholas had at his place. This stuff is more refined than what was in those syringes, so it works in smaller doses, but that bag you’re attached to now is the last one. They want to just switch you over to something else, but, uh…"

Another death sentence.  "The good news. You should be fine until morning, at least. And I’ve got a plan. Dr. H is gonna request to see you off base, and–" Quinn sat up in bed. The effort made her sweat. "Hey, hey, hey. Relax. It’s gonna be fine. You’re taken care of."

She took a long breath and rested her head back against the pillow, far too flustered to say anything. Quinn noticed Ty exchange another nervous glance with Val. "I just need to know… where you went. If you went anywhere. While you were out." Quinn studied Ty, watched his face change a shade. There was a lot riding on this answer, she was sure of it.

She stuck out her index and middle fingers on her left hand. "Two," deciphered Ty. "Two different places." Quinn nodded. "Forest," she said, proud to have remembered the word. "Okay. Okay. Do you remember any details?"
"Night. And, trees." She got stuck trying to remember what the things that had fallen from the trees were. "Were you alone?" "No."
"Was it… uh…" A quick look at the door. "...dreamers?" She nodded.
"Good. Did it feel real? Was it vivid, or more like a hallucination?" Quinn dragged her thumb across her neck. "Uh… I’m not sure what you mean." She repeated the action. "Dreamer."

"You killed a dreamer?" She shook her head, stuck two fingers out again, and turned her wrist.  "The other way around," said Val.  "Oh," said Ty, rubbing his forehead. "Did it hurt? What did it feel like? Could you stop it?"
Quinn rolled her eyes. "Yeah. Alright. Sorry. Where’d you go next?" "Home. Younger." Ty sighed and took his seat again.

"Well, I don’t know about that one. But what you said about where you went first is good news for tomorrow." "Great," said Quinn, exhaustion and sarcasm finding their way into her voice.  "I know. But, look. We’ve still got a shot to do something unbelievable. After everything, all this crap collapsing around us, right at the buzzer, you wake up. That’s not a coincidence. That’s fate. Not a lot of people get a chance to do something really great, right? And we do." Quinn didn’t say anything. In fact, she decided she probably wouldn’t have said anything if it was still easy for her to speak.

"I’ve gotta make a couple of calls. Get some rest, Quinn, alright? I’ll tell you what the plan is tomorrow morning." ./. "You really don’t like him, do you?" Quinn sighed. For as much as she wanted to say yes, it was the wrong answer.

"He said you guys had a falling out a little while ago. He wasn’t very specific." Quinn nodded. She wasn’t in the mood to divulge details, either.  "I don’t know. He doesn’t seem like a bad guy. It’s just– it wasn’t really adding up, what he was telling me. First, he goes with you on this hostage mission even though he only met you a few weeks beforehand. Then, he goes from barely passing college to the governmental head of whatever the hell operation this is. And, also— well. It just seems like he jumps into things too fast. And too deep." "Guess," said Quinn, shrugging.
"Well. We don’t have to talk about him." "Dad. Scared?" "My dad? No, he won’t be scared. He’s been arrested more times than I can count." "You?"

"I don’t know. I’ve been waiting for him to get busted for something big for most of my adult life. I’ll be fine, he’ll be fine… I just didn’t think it would be for secretly aiding someone with the power to blow up the world, or whatever you can do. Look, you shouldn’t worry about anything other than you right now. What do you need?" "Lots," said Quinn. "More of that drug would be nice. Or, a way to pass off your superpower without dying." "Yeah."

"Anything I can do for you now?" "Water," she said, gesturing over to the sink at the other end of the room. Val strode over. The way she moved. God, the way she moved.  "Beautiful," said Quinn, without thinking.

"The sky?" asked Val, looking out the window next to her. "I agree. The stars are very pretty." "No, you." Val turned around slowly and fired a glance in the direction of the door to ensure that no one was listening. "Did you just ask for water so you could look at my butt, you perv?"

All of the blood rushed to Quinn’s head. Then, she started to laugh. It was odd, the laughter. She was unsure what she was doing as she did it, and it came out more like a wheeze than a proper fit of laughter. But it felt good, and it made Val smile, too. "You’re lucky you’re the best-looking heart attack patient in this whole hospital." "Low bar."

"You’d be surprised. There’s a ninety year old guy next door, doesn’t look a day over eighty-five." Val brought her chair next to the bed and grabbed Quinn’s hand. Quinn squeezed back in an attempt to feel it beyond the buzzing. They breathed together for a while.  "Sorry," said Quinn, studying the fatigue etched on Val’s face. "Sorry for what?" asked Val, arching her back so that her head rested on the corner of Quinn’s pillow.
"All." "Don’t be sorry." "I… brought you." "What did you bring me, Quinn?"

"Everything," she said, waving her left hand around. "You brought me into everything," Val deciphered. "Well. It wasn’t you that asked to meet me in the first place, right? And it wasn’t you who invited me to Paulie’s. Wasn’t you who asked me to sleep together either, and then you didn’t tell me anything before you ran off yesterday morning." "Guess," said Quinn. "But do you know what?" asked Val, running a hand through Quinn’s hair, smile disappearing from her face.
"I wish you had." They were both silent. "Sorry," said Quinn. "Stop apologizing."
"No. I…" Frustration returned. There was something more, something on the precipice. It wouldn’t come out. "Read?" she asked. "What does that mean, Quinn?"
"Read… something?" "I still don’t understand." Quinn touched her hands together and turned her palms outward.  "Read," she repeated.
"Oh. You want to read a book?" "No. You." "Okay. I don’t have one with me, but I could get one on my phone. Is that alright?" "Yeah."

"What do you like? We could start with something easy, if you want–" "No," said Quinn. Val took out her phone. "Alright. I, uh, don’t read a lot… how’s this one? The Plague. A classic, recommended to me. Sounds like a… downer." "That."

"Whatever you say." Val held out her phone so that both of them could see. Quinn angled her neck so that her head rested in the gap between Val’s shoulder and cheek. "Part One," read Val, clearing her throat. "The unusual events described in this chronicle occurred in… one hundred ninety-four dash?" Quinn snorted.

"One hundred… oh. Nineteen forty-something. But it’s written like– I’m stupid. You’re laughing at me because I’m stupid." "No," said Quinn, who could not seem to stop laughing.  Val continued irritably. "...at Oran. Everyone agreed that, considering their extraordinary character, they were out of place there." Val read to Quinn for some time. She frequently stopped to criticize something– Who the hell is talking? How do they know so much? They sound so pretentious.-- or to comment on what she thought was going to happen– Oh, man, they’re all gonna die. It’s so obvious.-- or to wonder about the definition of a word. It was not an ideal way for Quinn to experience the story as its original author had intended it to be experienced. But every time Val stopped, Quinn looked up at her, felt her warmth, her life, and found it impossible not to feel warm as well. And while she read, Quinn didn’t connect with the city of Oran, or with its people, or with the story’s pretentious narrator. She studied the words on the page, how they fit together in a flurry of cohesion, how they went seamlessly from pixels on a screen to Val’s mouth, and she hoped that one day, she would have another chance to use those words to tell Val exactly how she felt.

./. "One-oh-eight over seventy-two. Normal. No dizziness, hot flashes, shortness of breath?" "No," Quinn responded. The blonde-haired doctor flipped through pages of a clipboard that contained information she’d painstakingly gathered regarding Quinn’s vitals. Quinn had been poked and prodded and pricked for what had felt like several hours.

"And you are giving your consent to be transferred to Stowe Memorial Hospital?" "Yes," said Quinn, though she’d given her consent several times already. "We’d be more than happy to provide transportation, if you–" "Fine," Quinn interjected, shaking her head.

"Alright," said the doctor. "We’ve sent over your records, so you’re all set. This is highly unconventional, to say the least. But I wouldn’t have approved any transfer unless you were healthy enough to make the trip. And Stowe is great. They have speech therapists on hand." "Thanks." Quinn stood up, shook the doctor’s hand, and began her journey out of the hospital. Tiny pins stuck themselves into the bottom of her right foot each time she took a step.  She masked a limp as she walked.

The morning was as clear as it was dry. It was too early both in the day and in the year for the heat to assert its oppressive power, but sunlight reflected so brightly off of the concrete walkway that Quinn barely saw the car idling mere feet in front of her. Her home state had its share of unpleasant summer days, but in Arizona, the sun was an adversary, a constant combatant, crafty enough to cause pain in several different ways. Quinn rubbed her eyes and stepped into the car. Ty was behind the wheel, and Val flanked him. "How much time do we have?" asked Ty, who hit the gas pedal before Quinn had time to sit down.

She’d planned for this question. Subtracting minutes from an hour would have been hopeless. She had, however, set a countdown on her phone as soon as she’d been disconnected from the IV.  "Twenty minutes," said Val, watching the seconds tick. "That’s enough time. Right?" "To get there? Sure. I’m just…" Ty cast a glance into the rearview mirror.

"Never mind. Dr. H is there already, she let me know. She’ll–" "She?" asked Quinn. "Yeah," Ty said. "She’s great. Staff at Stowe hospital, works with us. I mean– I’ve only talked to her a couple of times. But we can trust her." Quinn shuffled in her seat. A pile of dirty clothes scattered on the floor gave the car a sour smell. Even the seat cushions seemed saturated with something odorous.

"‘We can trust her?’ If I was Quinn I would definitely believe you. You make a pretty compelling argument–" "I know. I know. She’s just secretive. Doesn’t like to let people see who she is. It makes sense, I think." "We’re entrusting her life with some… mystery doctor?" "No. Dr. H is responsible for that drug that’s been keeping her alive. She’s published papers, suggested research directions… done more than half of the goddamned bureaucrats I’ve had to work with combined. And, she managed to get Quinn out of that hospital which was about to poison her anyway. If we can’t trust her, we can’t trust anybody."

"Okay," said Val. "What exactly does she want us to do, then?" "Shit, if I knew, I would have told you by now. She just told me to get to the address, as fast as I could." "The address. You know where you’re going, right?" "Uh, yeah. This is important enough that I made sure to know where–"
"Mom?" interjected Quinn. Ty froze, as though suddenly remembering there was a third person in the car. "Wh–what?" he asked, trying to hide his stammer. Quinn didn’t feel the need to repeat herself.

"I don’t know. I don’t… She doesn’t like to… I haven’t ever actually seen her. She shuts her screen off for video calls, she doesn’t see people in real life. This would be the first time." "Hear?" asked Quinn. "Yeah, um… She sounds like, uh… I’m sorry, I can’t remember–" "Okay."

The car ground to a halt at the checkpoint. There was a moment of silence so complete that she was sure Ty and Val had stopped breathing.  Fortunately, the retractable barrier lifted, and the landscape continued to slide past her window. Ty drove with urgency, but without the reckless abandon Quinn had expected from him. Traffic was light, as it was a late Tuesday morning, which allowed him to accelerate to appreciable speeds most of the time. But whenever he saw another vehicle– behind, in front, on another road, even– he slowed to the speed limit until he was sure they were alone again. At one point, he even stopped at a yellow light he could have easily made, earning a thwack on the arm from his copilot.  Quinn watched his eyes through the rearview mirror. They were everywhere. Left, right, forward, back. Left, right, forward, back. Occasionally, he would turn his whole body to look behind him, as though he were reversing. His eyes asked a constant question of the environment around him, and it was difficult to guess what answer he was looking for. The only hint Quinn got was a thin veil of perspiration that coated Ty’s forehead.

Whether it was Ty’s restlessness or the smell of the car or the events of the last few days, Quinn developed an anxiety that was unlike any she had felt before. It grabbed at her, toyed with her breathing, lengthened the pins stuck in her foot. Three days, now, on her deathbed. Three days and this was the first moment she felt anything but detachment.  What would she miss? Certainly not much. If the past year was an indication, she’d have worked her deadbeat job for years, perhaps found an apartment somewhere, and lived out the rest of her adult life keeping to herself as much as possible, to limit the pain. She would have had to keep killing and live with increasing, unbounded guilt. She would have had to get old, feel her body break down. And die anyway. Death ends the pain. Death ends the pain forever. Still anxious. Who would she miss? Who did she have? Her father was gone. Her sister was gone. Her mother? Gone for so long, gone for so much? Certainly not her. She loved her grandparents, but they didn’t know her. Ty did, kind of. No, he used her, thought she could be scored or thrown away, or paraded around like an animal, anyway. Val didn’t, either. She was a blip, a stroke of luck, a rounding error. She would have screwed it up with Val sooner or later.

Death ends these sour relationships. Death absolves sins against others.  Still anxious, even more so. What if there’s something after death? That would be hopeful, right? Ad infinitum, in her own mind, as herself. One hundred years, one thousand years, one million, one thousand more millions, one million more of those.  Twenty-three felt like long enough, sometimes.  And what if there was nothing? Unending blackness. Could it not be brilliant white, though? What color is death? No, death wouldn’t have a color. There would be nothing. No sense of time, no memories, no shouting, nothing. Death wouldn’t feel like anything.

Death cures feeling. I feel.  The thoughts moved like building blocks, stacking one atop the other before crashing down, quickening her pulse. She saw pictures, and explored concepts, but failed to latch on to any piece of language other than those two words. I feel.

I feel. I– "We’re here," said Ty.  They stopped on the side of the road in a suburb filled with one-story houses with low, red roofs. Any one residence would have been indistinguishable from another save for the limited variety in vegetation that sprouted through the dry, sandy soil that constituted its front lawn.

Ty and Val hopped out of the car, and Quinn followed suit. This particular house was guarded by a brick wall, around five feet tall. A door, made of metal bars and painted black, guarded the property from the street.  Ty hustled toward it. There was a keypad with buttons corresponding to the numbers one through five next to the handle. "What the hell?" he muttered. He punched in a combination, and a light above the keypad turned red.

He cursed to himself and tried again. His hands shook so violently that he could hardly press the buttons. Again, no dice.  "Fuck this," he announced. Ty reached over the wall, dug his shoe into a small crack between two bricks, and threw himself into the front lawn.
"God damn it!" he cursed. "What? What’s wrong?" "I landed on a stupid rock," he said, drawing himself up, head and shoulders above the wall. He gingerly stepped to the gate, and let the two women in.

"Is it broken? Do you need help?" Val asked. "No. And not now." Ty, hobbling, led the way to the front door. It wasn’t a hospital, it wasn’t a facility. It was someone’s house.  Ty turned the handle and walked in.

Sunlight beamed in through gaps in the blinds, but otherwise, the room was dark. A sofa, a television, books on the coffee table. Someone’s house. "Hey," he announced, voice tinged with coarseness from the pain. "Where are you?" There was a picture frame on a bookshelf beside the television. It was too dark to make out what the picture was, but it almost looked like… "Down here," called a male voice.

Time was wasting. Through the dining room, where a mug sat on the table, past a closet, full of colorful jackets and shoes, down a set of stairs.  The basement was dingy and unfinished. The odor of mildew hung in the air.  A single light was on. Two wooden chairs, one facing the other, sat in its glow. One was empty.
